title: Finance Management System Support
description: Abri are seeking a contractor who can provide a full level of support for the current Finance Management Solution used within Abri (currently Open Accounts), Abri require this supplier to provide a solution that can meet the following key elements.• Full reactive maintenance service for Open Accounts and Ebis, enabling the logging of issues/defects and providing resolutions through an excellent responsive approach.• Carry out a full , thorough systems healthcheck across Open Accounts and Ebis , to review current use of the product and advise on any changes to achieve optimal utilisation of functionality.• Engage in a routine cycle of review of system use advising on new functionality & system development.• Support the business with the implementation of all regular upgrades and patch fixes.• Support the business with the expansion of the software, implementation of new functionality and/or complimentary solutions.• Provide access to a user environment where the business can interact on best practice and system use.• Provide regular updates, fully supported by metrics, on quality of service delivery.

The Tender documents can be accessed when logged into In-Tend by selecting ‘View Details’ on the relevant tender advert and clicking the ‘Express Interest’ tab. Once in the tender there are five tabs, namely ‘Tender’, ‘ITT – documents’, ‘Correspondence’, ‘Clarifications’ and ‘History’. Select the 2nd tab (ITT - documents) where you will find useful information under ‘Tender Details’. Continue to scroll down to the heading ‘Tender Documents Received’ where you will be able to view / download the documents. Please download all the documents and read very carefully. Opting In and Opting Out Please note you are required to ‘Opt In’ before you can access the ‘My tender Return’ to start populating your response. The ‘Opt Out’ functionality will also be available throughout the duration of the tender process. Opting out will give you the option of declaring you no longer want to receive any further communication in relation to this tender along with the opportunity of providing comments and feedback for this decision. You can choose to ‘Opt In’ at any time during the tender process if you initially decided to ‘Opt Out’. Further Guidance In addition, guidance on how to participate in a tender, download and upload documents / returns and if required, register your company (free of charge) can be found on the In-tend site under the ‘Help’ or ‘Information for Suppliers’ buttons. Receiving Notification Emails To ensure you receive email alerts and notifications from our system, please add the email domain `@in-tendorganiser.co.uk`  to your Safe Senders list.

title: Provision of IT Consultancy Services Framework
description: Associated British Ports (ABP) require specialist technical resources and consultancy to provide guidance to, and support the delivery of IT projects. The supplier services shall include, but are not limited to, solution Architecture, Business analyst and Project Management. Resources must be available to attend an ABP site when required.The consultancy firm must possess expertise in a diverse range of IT domains, including but not limited to software development, network infrastructure, cybersecurity, and cloud computing. The consultants provided should have proven experience in analysing clients' business processes and aligning technology solutions to meet strategic objectives. The ability to conduct thorough needs assessments and deliver clear, actionable recommendations is paramount.The consultancy team should demonstrate proficiency in project management methodologies, ensuring efficient resource allocation, timely delivery, and adherence to budget constraints. Furthermore, a robust understanding of emerging technologies and industry trends is essential to provide forward-thinking solutions. Effective communication skills, both written and verbal, are crucial for conveying complex technical concepts to diverse stakeholders. Data security and compliance expertise must be ingrained in their approach, considering the increasing importance of safeguarding sensitive information. The consultancy firm should also commit to continuous learning and adaptation to stay abreast of the rapidly evolving IT landscape

title: Immingham Green Energy Terminal (IGET)
description: Immingham Green Energy Terminal (IGET) will be a multi-user bulk liquid green energy terminal to support the import of green ammonia (NH3) from Neom in Saudi Arabia to be converted to green hydrogen. This will assist with decarbonizing the UK’s transport sector and the import of Carbon Dioxide (CO2) to facilitate carbon capture storage, both of which will assist ABP’s transition towards Net Zero. The proposed terminal is to be operated by ABP as a common user facility, providing port capacity for multiple customers. ABP is responsible for the development and operation of the marine facilities to meet the infrastructure needs. ABP is looking to appoint a lead contractor or consortium to undertake a design and build contract for the development of IGET at the Port of Immingham.

title: Invitation to Tender for Suffolk Countywide Provision for Smoking Cessation support programme
description: This is a joint procurement which is to cover all areas of the Suffolk Districts. The joint venture procurement is being run involving East Suffolk District Council, West Suffolk District Council, Babergh District Council (BDC), Mid-Suffolk District Council (MSDC) & Ipswich Borough Council.(the council listed above’) are based in central Ipswich Suffolk districts  ) All of the above contracting district councils invite suitably qualified organisations to tender for this project. 1.	Purpose1.1 Population NeedsNational Context / Evidence BaseTobacco use is the single most preventable cause of ill health in the UK - and Suffolk - and there is clear evidence that by reducing prevalence of tobacco use that health and healthy life expectancy will improve within the population (ref GBD).   Smoking is a major cause of health inequalities, with smoking rates much higher among low-income groups and among adults with a mental health condition; around 40% of those with a serious mental health condition smoke. In 2019 around 1 in 4 (23.4%) of people in routine and manual occupations smoked, compared to only 9.3% of those in managerial and professional occupations. Smoking accounts for around half the difference in life expectancy between the richest and poorest groups (ref HNA).Smoking behaviour is primarily driven by addiction to nicotine; however, a wide range of personal, social, and environmental factors interplay with this addiction to influence who starts smoking, who continues to smoke and who gives up. Tackling smoking therefore requires a comprehensive approach which incorporates a range of public health interventions at different levels to tackle the individual, social and cultural influences on smoking behaviour. Reducing smoking prevalence and the use of tobacco can help local government to 1) cut costs to local public services, 2) protect children from harm, 3) boost the disposable income of the poorest people, and 4) drive improvement across key measures of population health.1.2 National PolicyIn July 2017, the UK government published ‘Towards a Smokefree Generation – A Tobacco Control Plan for England’. This contained a vision of a smokefree generation (prevalence of 5% or lower) with a plan for action to reduce both overall prevalence and reduce the inequality gap in prevalence. Actions included a focus on prevention, supporting smokers to quit, eliminating variations in smoking rates and ensuring enforcement e.g., high duty rates for tobacco products.Additionally, The NHS Long Term Plan contained the following actions relevant to smoking:•	By 2023/24, all people admitted to hospital who smoke will be offered NHS-funded tobacco treatment services.•	The model will be adapted for pregnant mothers. •	A new universal smoking cessation offer will be available as part of specialist mental health services [2]More recently, The Khan Review: Making Smoking Obsolete acknowledged that England will miss the smokefree 2030 target by at least 7 years, and the poorest areas in society will not meet it until 2044. To have any chance of hitting the smokefree 2030 target, there is a need to accelerate the rate of decline of people who smoke, by 40%.1.3 Suffolk Context•	Smoking related illness kills 3 people every day in Suffolk, more than obesity, alcohol, road accidents and illegal drug use put together. •	Almost 1 in 5 adults in Suffolk smoke (16.0%) and it is estimated that there are currently 107,914 adult smokers in Suffolk.•	In Suffolk smoking is associated with 1,549 hospital admissions and over 1,100 deaths (approximately 15% of all deaths) every year.  •	Smoking prevalence in Suffolk has decreased in recent decades.  However, those living in deprived areas in Suffolk have higher levels of smoking prevalence, estimated to be at 30%. •	Smoking accounts for about half of the difference in life expectancy seen between the lowest and highest income groups.•	Smoking prevalence in Suffolk (16.0%) is similar to the East of England average (15.6%) and national average (15.9%) (ref PHOF).  •	Suffolk Health and Wellbeing Board have agreed to deliver recommendations in the Aspiring to Be a Tobacco Free Suffolk report which set out actions for Prevention, Protection and Cessation. This service specification will be required to support these objectives.•	Smoking is significantly higher among routine and manual worker populations. Although Suffolk is statistically similar (29.1%) to England (24.5%), Ipswich presents a significantly higher proportion of routine and manual workers who smoke (42.5%) compared to England and the East of England (ref PHOF).(All reference provided in reference section below)1.4 Service AimsThe provider must be able to deliver a Suffolk wide, comprehensive, core stop smoking service that allows clients access to behaviour change information, guidance, and support via various communication formats throughout their quit journey, and in turn, reducing the number of people in Suffolk who smoke. •	The provider will deliver stop smoking, behaviour change support for the term of 6 months (October 1st, 2023 – 31st March 2024) with the possibility of extension.•	The provider shall ensure that all practitioners who conduct community-based stop smoking behaviour change support are appropriately trained to deliver the programme as per NICE Guidance NG209 and subsequent Quality Standard QS207 Quality statement 1: Identifying people who use tobacco | Tobacco: treating dependence | Quality standards | NICE where applicable.•	The provider will be responsible for all elements of service delivery seen in the ‘Scope’ section of this specification.  •	The provider must ensure that all aspects of the service it provides to members of the public is fully accessible to all communities and those with protected characteristics.•	The provider must use targeted engagement with clients from high-risk population groups, such as routine and manual workers, and areas of socioeconomic deprivation to a) encourage and enable those individuals to stop smoking b) improve their health and wellbeing by stopping smoking and c) understand levels of engagement from these groups and monitor the barriers to stopping. •	The Provider shall work with the District and Borough Leads to access the Feel-Good Suffolk digital platform for inputting client quit data or create a robust reporting feedback loop to collate necessary data requirements. The provider will need to collect and report accurate data through an agreed method.2.	ScopeService descriptionThe service will provide targeted high-quality provision, offering a behaviour support programme for people who want to stop smoking. The service must be compliant with NICE guidance NG209 and aim to further contribute to the evidence-base in smoking cessation and behaviour change support. A description of the service model is not given here to allow for innovation and flexibility. The aspects of the service that are described are not exhaustive and provide an overview of the broad remit of the service.The service is characterised by: •	Provision of behaviour change support to smokers who want to quit, offering potential quitters a choice in the type of support they receive where appropriate.•	Options of contact outside of standard session(s)/regular appointment(s), ensuring a feedback loop for if the client drops out.•	Ensure the programme addresses health inequalities with stop smoking behaviour change support and pro-active targeting of sub-population groups, including but not limited to, routine and manual workers, and those from lower socio-economic groups.•	Develop culturally appropriate stop smoking behaviour change support to enable more smokers from these groups to successfully quit.•	Monitor and record quit rates at a minimum of 4 and 12 weeks, either self-reported or CO verified, aiming for 50% of clients to have successfully quit smoking at 4-weeks.•	Provide monthly feedback on quit rate figures, along with quarterly reports.•	Flexible provision with options of face to face, virtual and group support to suit different levels of needs within specific localities and population groups, working closely with district and borough leads to ensure this is done successfully. The service will be flexible enough to respond to local community priorities in different localities with the potential for different models of delivery in different areas to take account of the prevailing circumstances at a local level. 2.1 Expected OutcomesThis service specification has been developed to enable the commissioned service to contribute to a range of outcomes, as follows: •	Reduced smoking related mortality and ill health in Suffolk.•	Reduced prevalence of tobacco smoking in Suffolk communities with the highest smoking prevalence.•	Reduced health inequalities associated with smoking. •	Increased inclusion in stop smoking behaviour change support among Suffolk residents who want to quit.Joint Health & Wellbeing Transitional Strategy for Suffolk (2022 -2023):Call to action 4: Residents and communities will become more involved in decisions that affect their lives, health, and wellbeing. Please see the Joint Health and Wellbeing Board Strategy for more information. Suffolk Smoking Needs Assessment•	Targeted engagement with populations at higher risk of smoking-related harm•	Work in collaboration to target geographical and population-based smoking cessation interventions.•	Work in collaboration to develop, monitor and evaluate local pathways for […] smokers as part of the NHS Long Term Plan•	Improve data collection and monitoring of longitudinal data around quits to […] enable future understanding of long-term impacts of […] stop smoking behaviour change support.•	work with district and borough leads to develop and deliver support and training options for Primary Care and wider statutory and voluntary sectors organisations.Public Health Outcomes Framework (PHOF)The PHOF sets the national strategic direction for the delivery of public health interventions and allows progress to be monitored. The framework sets out a range of outcomes and indicators which are significant to adults. These include:Overarching indicators•	Increased healthy life expectancy.•	Reduced differences in life expectancy and healthy life expectancy between communities•	Health Improvement•	Smoking Status at time of delivery•	Smoking prevalence age 15 years - regular smokers•	Smoking prevalence in adults in routine and manual occupations•	Smoking prevalence in adults with a long-term mental health condition •	Self-reported well-being•	Smoking prevalence in adults•	Low birth weight of term babies•	Preventable sight loss•	Healthcare and premature mortality•	Infant mortality•	Smoking attributable mortality•	Smoking attributable deaths from cancer•	Smoking attributable deaths from heart disease•	Smoking attributable deaths from stroke•	Mortality rate from lung cancer•	Mortality rate from COPD•	Mortality rate from oral cancer•	Preventable sight loss - age related macular degeneration.•	Smoking attributable hospital admissionsThe Provider must ensure that the service contributes to the PHOF Indicators, the Joint Health and Wellbeing Strategy for Suffolk and the Health Behaviours in Suffolk Health Needs Assessment: Smoking. The Provider is not solely responsible for achieving all of the outcomes and indicators in these documents.KIPs / outcome measures have not yet been set but will be discussed in collaboration with the successful bidder at implementation.2.2 Target/Priority GroupsThe service will use resources where they are most needed and where they will have the most impact, based on good understanding of the links between a broad range of socio-economic factors, evidence of what works well and outcomes.There are individuals whose personal, social, and economic circumstances result in reduced protective factors, putting them at higher risk of poorer outcomes. Hence, whilst the delivery of this specification does not exclude any tobacco user, there are priority groups that the service will be expected to target, including but not necessarily limited to:•	Disabled people.•	People with long-term health conditions and limiting illness.•	People from ethnic minority backgrounds with high smoking prevalence.•	Those living in deprived areas.•	Unpaid carers•	People exiting from rehabilitation services.•	Routine and manual workers3.	Service Delivery3.1 Acceptance and exclusion thresholdsPopulation covered.•	Any smoker aged 12+ resident or working in Suffolk•	Individuals who are smoking tobacco products •	Individuals who need support to stop smoking tobacco products3.2 Data Requirements/Performance StandardsThe provider is expected to collect, maintain, and monitor data in accordance with the agreed collection and return requirements. This data would then need to be reported back to District & Borough Leads, via the Feel-Good Suffolk case management system or another agreed method, ensuring any new data requirements that arise are met. The following data requirements are an example of identified minimum standards and will be subject to change on award:For smoking cessation:·	Age·	Sex·	Religion or belief·	Ethnicity·	Disability·	Sexual orientation·	Gender reassignment·	Pregnancy status·	Occupation·	Home postcode·	Smoking status ·	Additional information including marital status, medical history, parity, and family make-up.·	Source of set quit date and 4-week quit (e.g., specialist service, general practice, pharmacy, prisons)·	Lost to follow up information.·	Do not attend information by source and client type.·	CO validation (where available)·	Intervention used to support 4-week quit.The service Provider will also be required to undertake ongoing qualitative evaluation to provide further contextual data to explain the successes, challenges, and impact of the programme. The Provider will cooperate with all reasonable requests concerning data and evaluation. Ongoing evaluation will be conducted by the District & Borough Leads.3.3 Accessibility of serviceServices can be available through a range of media e.g., digital, telephone, face to face, and potential for delivery from a variety of different locations. The location and type of media delivery will be determined by level of need and suitability to the group/cohort, and their needs.  Services will be available across Suffolk.  Consideration should be given to accessibility of services for those living in rural areas. The provision of the behavioural support service should be made available at timings relevant to the client group, e.g., daytime, evening, and weekends. Provision should be made to ensure that those with additional needs, such as a language other than English or disabilities are able to access the service.  It is REQUIRED that the contract and service will commence on 04-10-2023.

We would be really pleased to meet with organisations to discuss materials, contract length, fee mechanisms. A list of discussion points will be provided to all companies before the meeting including a summary of the current services provided.Companies who are interested in taking part in this market engagement  exercise, are required to send a message via correspondence in the In-Tend portal by 12 noon on Wednesday 20th December 2023.Meeting slots through MS Teams will then be offered to those companies expressing an interest.  Meetings will be held virtually via MS teams and separate slots will be provided to each interested company and will last approximately one hour. Meetings will be attended by senior staff members representing the service area and a senior member of staff from the Council’s Strategic Commissioning and Procurement team.

title: BC-10754 Bedfordshire Schools Trust ICT
description: The Bedfordshire Schools Trust (BEST) was incorporated in August 2016 following on from a previous organisation called Bedfordshire East Multi-school Trust (BMAT). The Trust now includes three middle deemed secondary schools, six primary schools, one secondary school and three nurseries.Currently ICT support is provided across the Trust through an outsourced provider. It is envisaged that staff members employed by the current provider will be eligible for TUPE.The Successful Bidder will be expected to manage the complete IT lifecycle of the schools from initial advice and installation through to the day-to-day support and management. The services under this contract will comprise of managed ICT support services, ICT equipment and consumables, licenses and broadband. The Trust or the schools may also utilise the new provider for additional sourcing as and when required e.g., for Wi-Fi upgrades.The Contract period will be for 3 years initially with the option to extend for a two year period. Estimated full contract value is expected to be in the region of £5,000,000 including VAT, 30% of this value is the expected spend for the managed ICT support services. The services are to be provided at the following address:  	Samuel Whitbread Academy (Pfi), Shefford Road, Clifton, Shefford, SG17 5QS	Etonbury Academy, Stotfold Road, Arlesey, SG15 6XS	Pix Brook Academy, Arlesey Road, Stotfold, SG5 4HB	Robert Bloomfield Academy, Bloomfield Drive, Shefford, SG17 5BU	St Christophers Academy, Gorham Way, Dunstable, LU5 4NJ	Gothic Mede Academy, High Street, Arlesey, SG15 6SL	Langford Village Academy, Church Street, Langford, Biggleswade, SG18 9QA	Lawnside Academy, Lawnside, Bigglewade, SG18 0LX	Gravenhurst Academy, High Street, Gravenhurst, Bedford, MK45 4HY	Campton Academy, Rectory Road, Campton, Shefford, SG17 5PF	Central team provision – Central office on Samuel Whitbread site        BEST Nursery Arlesey, High St, Arlesey SG15 6SL        BEST Nursery Shefford, Shefford Rd, Clifton, Shefford SG17 5QS        BEST Nursery Langford, Langford Academy, Church Street, Langford SG18 9QA It is anticipated over the course of the contract that additional schools may join the Trust in the future who will roll into this contract.

title: BHCC - RS - Brighton and Hove City Council and Brighton and Hove Seaside Community Homes Insurance Tender
description: Brighton & Hove City Council invites bids for the provision of its property insurance in respect of private dwellings sold on a leasehold basis; the majority of these were under the Right To Buy (RTB) legislation.  The dwellings are flats in blocks and flats in houses (maisonettes) where the Council still retain the freehold ownership and the leases state that the Council, as the Freeholder, will arrange the buildings insurance on behalf of the Leaseholder and recharge the premium as part of the Service Charge. Other flats in some blocks have not been sold (Council tenanted) and are separately insured so insurance cover for these flats is not required.Property insurance is also required  for those properties in the ownership of Brighton & Hove Seaside Community Homes, a charity  with whom the Council has 100% nomination rights.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                Three portfolios of properties make up this Tender all of which are included under the same lot, however three separate policies will be required from the successful bidder.

title: BHCC JB Provision, installation and maintenance of CCTV Traffic Enforcement Cameras and associated enforcement support system
description: The Council is seeking to appoint a Contractor to replace its current digital unattended enforcement system and CCTV Traffic Enforcement Cameras. Including providing full maintenance and support of the whole new system. Additionally, to the replacement of the current solution the Council may require the Contractor to supply, install, support, and maintain additional cameras and systems. The purpose of replacing the system is to take advantage of new technology, increase capacity and functionality to enable efficient enforcement of traffic regulations to support the wider goals of the city’s Carbon Neutral 2030 commitment. The Council anticipates the expansion of the CCTV Traffic Enforcement camera network and the capacity to accommodate this must therefore be shown by the successful tenderer.  The Contractor is to also make provision for (up to) a further 59 cameras and additional capturing and reviewing stations to be purchased and installed during the course of the contract should the Council wish to do so. This additional spend is subject to funding from other sources and by no means guaranteed to the Contractor. The Contractor is to fund all mobilisation, equipment, and installation costs (related to the initial 37 cameras). The Contractor will invoice the Council for these costs once the solution has been signed off by the Council on the go-live date.

buyer_name: BHCC COMMUNITIES EQUALITIES AND THIRD SECTOR
title: BHCC EB Refugee Resettlement Casework Support
description: Brighton and Hove City Council (the Council)  is seeking a Supplier to deliver Casework Support as part of its Refugee Resettlement Scheme. The primary aim of the services being procured is to fulfil the requirements set out by government in the funding instructions for the  following resettlement schemes: The UK Resettlement Scheme (UKRS) , The Afghan Citizens Resettlement Scheme (ACRS) and the Afghan Relocations and Assistance Policy (ARAP).The Council is seeking to procure holistic casework support, including ESOL and employment support, for households arriving on government funded resettlement programmes. The support is to be provided for 24 months following arrival into the city. The casework provision can be extended, exceptionally, to 30 or 36 months for the most complex cases. The successful Supplier will be required to have capacity to scale up or down at pace in response to varying rates of arrivals and unexpected world events and changes to government schemes/funding arrangements, with an anticipated maximum arrival per annum of 70 individuals. The Council is conducting a two-stage procedure under the Light touch regime in order to appoint a suitable Supplier, in accordance with Regulation 76 of the Regulations.An overview of the service required is provided in the attached document ‘Schedule 1 – Service Overview’. To see full documents, please "Express an Interest" below and review the "Stage One" tab.The Council intends to develop further detail regarding the service specification as part of Stage Two of this tender. Further details are given within the guidance document. The value noted in the notice is based on the maximum five year term and based on supporting the anticipated maximum amount of individuals arriving per annum (70). This figure also includes taking on support for existing caseloads at the commencement of the contract and all figures are based on currently understood funding levels and schemes. As noted in the Service Overview, the full scope of the services cannot be confirmed at the time of writing and the Council intends to provide further information as part of Stage Two, including consideration of arrangements in relation to individuals currently being supported through the existing contract

title: SK-ITT-Swanborough - Civil & Structural Engineering Services
description: The Estate Regeneration team are looking to develop a former play area on Swanborough Drive to provide 39 new council-rented one-, two-, and three-bed homes to be let at an affordable rent, plus community space. The site measures 0.26ha and lies at the northern tip of the Whitehawk Estate.  It faces onto Swanborough Drive, a one-way street, backing onto the Brighton Racecourse Community Orchard to the north and surrounded by council medium and high-rise flats of 4-10 storeys to the south and west. The site slopes steeply down to the south by approximately 2 storeys in height. Key to the council is the approach to sustainable design and renewable energy needs that details how the development will minimise embodied, operational, and transport-related carbon emissions, and optimise the use of renewable energy to align with the Council’s ambition to be carbon neutral by 2030.The current design is currently at RIBA 1, which covers evolving proposals for a 39-unit scheme, but which is currently being developed further to reflect feedback from pre-apps and design review panel indicating potential for additional storey height.The current anticipated delivery milestones are as follows, but subject to change as the design development evolves:.RIBA 1 completion: January 2024RIBA 2 completion: March 2024RIBA 3 completion (including planning application submission):  May/June 2024RIBA 4.1 completion: September/October 2024 (RIBA 4.1 commencement expected immediately following planning application submission)Ad Hoc support through build phase may be required[RS1] [SP2] . The Civil & Structural Engineering services are required to commence immediately following the appointment of the preferred consultant, starting at RIBA 2.

title: BHCC - AP - Housing Materials Supply Chain
description: 2.1.1 	This contract is to provide the supporting supply chain of construction related materials that allow the Council to continually maintain and reactively repair its housing stock to ensure a high property standard for its tenants. 2.1.2	The Council is responsible for the repairs and maintenance of approximately 12,500 dwellings in the city of Brighton & Hove. These dwellings comprise of a mixture of housing types from studio flats to 7-bedroom houses, and from Leasehold properties to high rise blocks. 2.1.3 	This portfolio is a mixture of stock types, such as council owned Housing Revenue Account (HRA) dwellings, leasehold property to Temporary Accommodation. Full details of our Housing Stock profile can be found in Appendix D – BHCC Stock Profile. 2.1.4 	The Council’s Repairs & Maintenance service is responsible for around 3000 repairs per month across the Council’s Housing Stock. In addition to this the service carries out around 80 empty property (void) refurbishments per month. 2.1.5 	Repairs and maintenance are carried out by a mixture of council employed repairs staff and contractors. All contractors appointed to this framework will support the Repairs and Maintenance service to deliver the service objectives. 2.1.6	The council also has a wider requirement for construction related materials that may utilise this contract throughout its lifetime.

title: P0915 - Reopening of the Request To Participate (RTP) in a Flexible Contracting Agreement (FCA) for the provision of Refugee Support and Integration Services - Lots 1-5
description: The Council wishes to establish a Flexible Contracting Agreement (FCA) via the Light Touch Regime in accordance with Regulation 34 of the Public Contracts Regulations 2015 (PCR 2015) and the Public Procurement (Amendments, Repeals and Revocations) Regulations 2016as set out in Schedule 3 of the Public Contracts Regulations 2015 (Annex A) (PCR 2015) in relation to Social, Health and Education services.  The Council wishes to establish a Flexible Contracting Agreement for support and integration services for refugees and sanctuary seekers who arrive and are living in Birmingham via Government initiatives and policies and who are entitled to local authority support. The services will be split into 5 lots in total as follows:•	P0915A Lot 1: Tenancy & Family Support (follow on service) - to help refugees and sanctuary seekers with maintaining their tenancies, including personal budgeting and providing support with family welfare issues•	P0915A Lot 2: Refugee Participation and Engagement - to link refugees and sanctuary seekers to local support to prevent social isolation, according to their interests and hobbies, as well as to encourage links with local support and communities•	P0915A Lot 3: Employability Service - to assist refugees and sanctuary seekers in becoming work ready, obtaining employment, creating career pathways, providing training opportunities and supporting with recruitment and selection processes•	P0915A Lot 4: Wellbeing & Mental Health - to raise awareness regarding mental health issues amongst refugees and sanctuary seekers and help them access relevant services•	P0915B Lot 5: Support, Orientation & Accommodation: To facilitate the initial settlement period for new refugees and sanctuary seekers in Birmingham including delivery of information, advice & guidance The Flexible Contracting Agreement (FCA) will last for 4 years (unless terminated under agreement provisions). It will operate in a similar way to a Dynamic Purchasing System and remain open for suppliers to join at any time during the duration of the FCA. The Flexible Contracting Agreement (FCA) will be awarded to unlimited providers in each lot; providers can apply for multiple lots.  Potential Suppliers only need to complete the Selection Questionnaire elements once, even if applying for more than one lot.The FCA is a two-stage process:•	Stage 1 – Selection Stage – all Potential Suppliers must submit a Request To Participate and pass the criteria to be appointed to the FCA.  The selection stage consists of qualification questions to select  Organisations.  The questionnaire will be based on mandatory and discretionary exclusion criteria as well as quality assessment questions. All successful participants will be admitted to the FCA.•	Stage 2 – Invitation To Tender – following consultation, the Council will develop service requirements based on existing and future needs. A Further Competition will take place based on the specific requirements. All FCA Suppliers in the relevant lot will be invited to tender for the requirement. Where the requirement could be delivered by more than one lot the opportunity will be offered to the relevant lots that could deliver. The Council will be using its free to use e-tendering system (in-tend) for the administration of this procurement process and potential suppliers must register with the system to be able to express an interest. If you wish to express an interest in this opportunity please click on the following link to access https://in-tendhost.co.uk/birminghamcc/ and submit your details to register. You will then be sent details on how to log on which will enable you to download all relevant documentation.  If you are unable to register with In-tend or have any questions or problems on how to use this web site please either email us at: etendering@birmingham.gov.ukThe DPS is open to providers until 31st March 2027 to join and are required to complete and return of the selection questionnaire using the Supplier Portal.

title: P1121/ 2 - Flexible Contracting Agreement for NHS Health Check and Smoking Cessation Services - ROUND 2
description: The Council wishes to establish a Flexible Contracting Agreement for NHS Health Check and Smoking Cessation Services. The services will be split into two Lots as follows:•	Lot 1: NHS Health Checks – One of Birmingham City Council's mandatory public health services is the NHS Health Check, which is provided by health professionals.It is a health examination for adults in England between the ages of 40 and 74. It is intended to detect early indications of dementia, type 2 diabetes, kidney illness, heart disease, and stroke. We are more likely to develop one of these conditions as we age. Finding measures to reduce this risk is assisted by an NHS Health Check.The examination includes a series of questions about a patient’s health and lifestyle, including ones concerning physical activity, as well as measurements of height, weight, and blood pressure and a quick blood test to check cholesterol. The health professionals go through the results with the patient and discuss any changes required to enhance the patient’s wellbeing. •	Lot 2: Smoking Cessation Service - The Smoking Cessation Service is to be delivered by Pharmacies, GP Practices and other qualified providers. The model of smoking cessation support being commissioned is a 12 week behavioural programme that utilises a combination of nicotine replacement therapy (NRT) and electronic cigarettes (e-cigs), to reduce withdrawal cravings and advice/support that provides strategies to cope with quitting smoking. For this Lot, Providers can bid to deliver the 12-week programme, the NRT scheme or both.The FCA will be for a period of 4 years in total (unless terminated under agreement provisions); 2 years commencing on 1st October 2023, with an option to extend for a further 2 years. It will operate in a similar way to a Dynamic Purchasing System in that it will reopen after the initial procurement and remain open for suppliers to join at any time during the duration of the FCA.The Flexible Contracting Agreement (FCA) will be awarded to an unlimited number of providers in each lot; providers can apply for either Lot 1 or Lot 2 or both.  Potential Suppliers only need to complete the Potential Supplier Information once, even if applying for more than one Lot.For Lot 1 NHS Health Checks, only qualified GPs will be admitted to the FCA in year 1. BCC will review and potentially widen the selection criteria in year 2 to include Any Qualified Provider (AQP). If the decision to include AQP is progressed, the service specification will be revised to reflect these changes and any additional national NHS guidance or criteriaThe Council will be using its free to use e-tendering system (in-tend) for the administration of this procurement process and potential suppliers must register with the system to be able to express an interest. If you wish to express an interest in this opportunity please click on the following link to access https://in-tendhost.co.uk/birminghamcc/ and submit your details to register. You will then be sent details on how to log on which will enable you to download all relevant documentation.  If you are unable to register with In-tend or have any questions or problems on how to use this web site please either email us at: cps@birmingham.gov.ukYour completed tender submission should be returned by noon on 3rd January 2024 via the ‘in-tend’ system https://in-tendhost.co.uk/birminghamccThe FCA will re-open in May 2024 for the duration of the FCA.

description: The Council is conducting the procurement exercise using the Light Touch Regime in accordance with Regulation 34 of the Public Contracts Regulations 2015 (PCR 2015) and the Public Procurement (Amendments, Repeals and Revocations) Regulations 2016 as set out in Schedule 3 of the Public Contracts Regulations 2015 (Annex A) (PCR 2015) in relation to Social, Health and Education services. title: P1005 - Adult Weight Management App
description: The Council wishes to establish a contract for an Adult Weight Management App.There is a requirement for all adult residents, aged 16 and over, with a Body Mass Index(BMI) of >25kg/m2 (or >23kg/m2 if of Asian or Black origin) to be able to access the App (with no limits on resident numbers able to access the service).  The App should provide a multi component weight management programme incorporating advice and support on diet and exercise which is age appropriate and considers gender and ethnicity.  The App will allow the resident to set their own activity weight or loss goals and keep track of their activity and weight loss. In addition to the criteria above, the App will include a BeActive+ user area for individuals who meet the criteria for the BeActive+ programme.  The App will interface with the 12-week BeActive+ GP referral programme run by BCC as part of City Operations, Neighbourhoods Service.  The programme is delivered at several Wellbeing Centres.  Furthermore, all App users will be able to access support and advice on how and when to exercise which is relevant to them.  Users will be able to identify and locate relevant gyms, leisure centres, walking routes, amateur sports groups, gardening group, cooking groups etc in their area. The App will also provide links to mental health and wellbeing support. For safeguarding purposes, the App will have the functionality to screen for BMI below normal range and risks indicated by user responses to health screening questionnaires on the App i.e., scores that are higher than the ‘normal’ range.  Intervention will include promoting healthy weight, healthy eating and exercise, and/or to advise the user to contact their GP or relevant health professional.The successful provider must meet the NHS Digital Technology Assessment Criteria (DTAC). The DTAC includes criteria covering clinical safety, data protection, technical security, interoperability, plus usability and accessibility. For your digital health product to pass the DTAC, you need to meet all requirements in each of the areas.  You will need to hold an ORCHA certified DTAC badge, certificate and evidence or successfully undertake the assessment via ORCHA https://orchahealth.com/our-products/assessment-frameworks/digital-technology-assessment-criteria-dtac/ prior to the App’s launchThe Contract will be for a period of 2 years with the option to extend for a further 2 years subject 	to funding availability and satisfactory performance.The contract will be awarded to one supplier.	The Council will be using its free to use e-tendering system (in-tend) for the administration of this procurement process and potential suppliers must register with the system to be able to express an interest. If you wish to express an interest in this opportunity please click on the following link to access https://in-tendhost.co.uk/birminghamcc/ and submit your details to register. title: QU480_2024 - Provision of Food Inspections for Regulation and Enforcement
description: The Council requires a supplier for the provision of Food inspections for Regulations and Enforcement. One supplier will be appointed for these services.   Providers should note that there is no guaranteed level of work under this contract. Birmingham City Council (BCC) is the largest Local Authority in England and Wales with a population of over 1 million people.  Approximately 11,100 food outlets are based within the city, ranging from small family run businesses to large national and international enterprises.  This number has drastically increased from a steady 7,500 over the past 3 years. A large number of businesses change hands, set up or close down within the course of a twelve-month period.The city sets what they aim to achieve in the year through the food law enforcement plan. Whilst the ideal would be to meet 100% of its food hygiene inspections, this is not currently the case whilst addressing a back log from the pandemic. This involves between 4,500 and 5,000 primary food hygiene inspections each year, in accordance with the statutory Food Law Code of Practice.Inspections carried out must meet the full range of Food Law Code of Practice categories, although it is expected that most will be Category C/D . Any type or size of food business may be inspected, many of which will be located within the inner-city areas, and some food business operators have difficulty understanding the basics of food safety and food law.  Food hygiene inspections should normally be combined with food standards inspections and Duty of Care inspections to check that businesses have suitable refuse contracts in place. Food safety work is carried out by the Environmental Health Section of Regulation and Enforcement from one office located in the City Centre and the provider will be required to work from this location.The successful provider is required to ensure they can demonstrate that they have the resource base and food inspection officers available as and when needed by the Council at any given time to support primary food hygiene inspections each year. (This may require when requested 7 days a week working, or outside of standard business hours if needed with a working week being 36.5 hours) . Please note that subcontracting will not be approved.This contract will be for a period of 3 years commencing 1st June 2024 until 31st May 2028.  The Council will be using its free to use e-tendering system (in-tend) for the administration of this procurement process and potential suppliers must register with the system to be able to express an interest. If you wish to express an interest in this opportunity, please click on the following link to access https://in-tendhost.co.uk/birminghamcc/ and submit your details to register. You will then be able to log on which will enable you to download all relevant quotation documentation.If you are unable to register with In-tend or have any questions or problems on how to use this web site please either email us at: etendering@birmingham.gov.uk Your completed tender submission should be returned by noon on 2nd February 2024  via the ‘in-tend’ system https://in-tendhost.co.uk/birminghamcc

title: P1258 - Framework Agreement for Right to Buy Valuation and Housing Stock Valuation Service
description: Birmingham City Council wishes to appoint suitably qualified service provider to provide professional valuation services across its corporate property and housing estates for Right to Buy valuations, building insurance valuations and housing stock asset valuations.  Our objective is to deliver ‘right to buy’ valuations on Council owned residential properties as governed by the Housing Act 1985 and subsequent amendments. We are required to provide building insurance valuations and general valuation advice. We have an obligation to determine a valuation of the housing stock assets held by the council as identified in the asset register compiled annually. The Council also requires provision of its housing stock asset valuations for financial reporting purposes for each financial year . This will include a mixture of tenanted residential units of varying ages and character together with various garages.  The supplier is required to determine a valuation of the Housing stock assets held by the Council as identified in the Asset Register compiled annually and valued as of 31 March annually for each year for inclusion in the authority’s balance sheet in accordance with the Chartered Institute of Public Finance and Accounting (CIPFA) Code of Practice.  The supplier will review and give assurance that the values at the end of each financial year (31st March) will be materially correct and if necessary, update any valuations, where the movement is material.Tenderers are to note that this contract will be undertaken on a call off basis with orders placed as and when required.The Framework Agreement will last for 4 years (unless terminated under agreement provisions) commencing 1st April 2024. The Framework Agreement will be awarded to one supplier.The Council will be using its free to use e-tendering system (in-tend) for the administration of this procurement process and potential suppliers must register with the system to be able to express an interest. If you are unable to register with In-tend or have any questions or problems on how to use this web site please either email us at: cps@birmingham.gov.uk. Requests to participate must be by way of completion and return of the tender documentation no later than 12 noon on 23rd February 2024 using the Supplier Portal. Site Visits:It is recommended that potential suppliers undertake a site visit to ascertain the existing conditions that could affect the demolition process and make sure that their tender price is sufficient to carry out the project safely. It is however a recommendation not a condition of the tender, therefore and if a potential supplier wishes to visit the site, then they should read the following information and act on it accordingly. Open morning has been assigned to view the site and buildings which will take place on Wednesday 7th February 2024 between the hours of 9:00am to  11:00am. Please note PPE is recommended to be worn due to the fire damaged areas.Attendance can be any time between 9am and 11am. Any persons arriving after 11am will not be permitted to enter the site. THERE WILL BE NO FURTHER OPPORTUNITY TO INSPECT THE SITE. A maximum of three persons per potential supplier will be allowed to enter the building. The maximum time allocated is 20 minutes inside the building. The potential supplier’s representatives will be required to sign in and provide contact details (mobile numbers) whilst on site. No hand wash facilities are on site and each person must bring their own hand sanitiser.The potential supplier’s representatives will be responsible for providing their own PPE. Parking facilities are not available on site and on the road, however, there is a pay and display car park nearby on Ward Street.Potential supplier’s representatives must also leave the site promptly after their visit and any queries following on from the site visit must be directed via the portal.

title: BPSQ075 - Provision of RICS Assessment of Professional Competence (APC) Counsellor
description: The Council requires a supplier for the provision of an APC Counsellor to support employees on their path to become a RICS qualified Chartered Surveyor within the Investment and Valuation division of the Council.The contract will be for a period of 1 year and is expected to commence on Thursday 18th January 2024.The programme requires a RICS qualified counsellor to ensure APC candidates receive the necessary support required to meet the high standards of professionalism required to become a Chartered Surveyor. All APC candidates must be allocated an APC counsellor before they can enrol for the APC with the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors (RICS). The counsellor will provide guidance on appropriate APC pathways, identify training and competency gaps, formally sign off submission documents whilst working within the RICS best practises.There are currently five employees on the APC training programme. However, it is anticipated during the contract period that there may be more employees undertaking this programme. The Council makes no guarantee of the volume of work that will be placed under this contract.The Council will be using its free to use e-tendering system (in-tend) for the administration of this procurement process and potential suppliers must register with the system to be able to express an interest. title: P2168 - Young Carers and Young Adult Carers Transition Service
description: The Children’s Trust wishes to establish a contract for the provision of a Young Carers service providing a range of services to support carers, including an assessment and intervention service for young carers and their families across the city. The service will deliver a range of intervention responses to meet the diverse needs of young carers. The young carers service will provide interventions to young people and their families that support Birmingham Children’s Trust vision and practice model, as outlined in the service specification. Interventions will be grounded in the relationship-based tradition, and influenced by systemic, strengths based and restorative approaches. The young carers service will work to the Early Help guidelines, as outlined in ‘Working Together to Safeguard Children (2023)’ and ‘Birmingham’s Early Help Strategy’ (2021-2023). The service will work with young carers ensuring needs are addressed at the earliest opportunity, preventing the escalation of need and maximising opportunities for educational and social development. The Contract will last for 3 years (unless terminated under the terms and conditions of contract) with the provision to extend for up to an additional 2 years subject to requirements and satisfactory performance.The contract will be awarded to a single provider.  The Council will be using its free to use e-tendering system (in-tend) for the administration of this procurement process and potential suppliers must register with the system to be able to express an interest. title: PQ0483 - Provision of ordering, receiving, packaging, storing, and distributing Healthy Start Vitamins (HSV)
description: The Healthy Start Scheme is a statutory public health initiative to improve the health of low-income pregnant women and families.  Women who are at least 10 weeks pregnant and families with children under four years old qualify if they are on benefits and tax credits. The scheme offers eligible women and families £4.25 (£8.50 for a baby under 1 year) to spend on milk, fruit, vegetables and first stage infant milk. In addition, families also receive Healthy Start Vitamins. Birmingham City Council (the Council) require a supplier that can, electronically manage vitamin orders from distributing sites, order vitamins in a timely manner, store vitamins  and distribute the vitamins across the city to  active distribution sites such as:•	Children Centres•	community pharmacies•	GP practices•	midwife/health visitor teams•	nurseries•	faith organisations, with active settings currently at 138 sites. The successful provider will:•	Must hold a current  MHRA (Medical & Healthcare Products Regulatory Agency) licence for the collection and distribution of vitamins,(Copy of licence needs to be attached to application form)  •	Be responsible for ordering Healthy Start vitamins through NHS Supply Chain ensuring each distribution site has sufficient stock. •	Have in place and continue to maintain stock control management software which tracks stock levels, orders, and deliveries.•	Maintain data quality and record keeping, utilising the aforementioned  computer software to reflect site activity that can be  gathered into quarterly  reports to the commissioner which can identify trends on vitamins orders, issue, and overall  distribution.•	Facilitate registration of new HSV sites.•	Ensure appropriate storage of vitamins, maintaining a temperature below 25 degrees.•	Take vitamin order requests from distribution sites, collecting relevant data regarding quantity, site code, and ensuring appropriate troubleshooting when relevant. •	Transport vitamins  in response to orders, ensuring  they are kept at an ambient temperature upon delivery and collection.•	Vitamin stock  delivery  should be  completed  in a timely manner  (within 5 working days). •	Take the lead in stock management, working closely with distribution sites and the NHS Supply Distribution Chain  to maintain vitamin stock availability while minimising waste and appropriately disposing  of returned/ expired  stock.•	Produce quarterly performance reports for contract meetings with commissioning team, addressing any troubleshooting issues within a reasonable timeframe, and minimising any 	potential risks.The contract will commence on  February 2024 for a period of 3 years with the option to extend for a further 1 year  subject to funding availability and supplier performance.  The Council will be using its free to use e-tendering system (in-tend) for the administration of this procurement process and potential suppliers must register with the system to be able to express an interest. If you wish to express an interest in this opportunity, please click on the following link to access https://in-tendhost.co.uk/birminghamcc/ and submit your details to register. You will then be sent details on how to log on which will enable you to download all relevant quotation documentation.If you are unable to register with In-tend or have any questions or problems on how to use this web site please either email us at: cps@birmingham.gov.uk Your completed tender submission should be returned by noon on 3rd January 2024  via the ‘in-tend’ system https://in-tendhost.co.uk/birminghamcc

title: Provision of Employee Assistance Programme and Whistleblowing services
description: PQ0476 - Provision of Employee Assistance Programme and Whistleblowing servicesThe Council requires a supplier for the provision of Employee Assistance Programme (LOT 1) service and for a confidential Whistleblowing Service (LOT 2).Under LOT 1, the contractor will develop and provide a workplace Employee Assistance Programme (EAP) which will be made available to all eligible users that is designed to improve employee health and wellbeing by promoting self-awareness and self-care, providing support and intervention, and building resilience.Under LOT 2, the contractor will develop and provide a Whistleblowing Service which will be made available to all eligible users that is designed to allow the reporting of employee concerns in relation to (but not limited to) discrimination, malpractice, bullying, unlawful or unethical conduct in the workplace can be reported.This contract will be for a proposed duration of 2 years commencing 1st March 2024 until 28th February 2026.The Council will be using its free to use e-tendering system (in-tend) for the administration of this procurement process and potential suppliers must register with the system to be able to express an interest. title: PQ0478 - Business Support Programme supporting Inclusive Innovation (funded by Innovate UK via DIATOMIC project)
description: Birmingham City Council (The Council) are looking for a supplier to offer a bespoke business support to 10 businesses led/owned by women and/or Black, Asian and Minority Ethnic entrepreneurs based in East Birmingham and open to collaborating within the WM Inclusive Entrepreneurship Network.  This support will be linked to the work and opportunities emerging from developments driven by the Tyseley Strategic Alliance within the Tyseley Enterprise and Environmental District (TEED), the emerging work on the East Birmingham and North Solihull Growth Zone (part of WM Levelling Up Zones work), the East Birmingham Impact Coalition work bringing strategic partnerships like the National Trust, UHB NHS Trust, and the Birmingham Anchor Institution Network and has to be complementary to a number of business support programmes funded by the UK SPF (currently being launched by the Council.The Council is looking for an organisation to deliver this service during a period of up to 14 months commencing 8th January 2024 and concluding on 31 March 2025.Contract to be awarded to one provider.This is being funded by the Innovate UK DIATOMIC Project and all publicity materials and reporting will be required to reference the funder and use the appropriate WMCA, UKRI and Innovate UK’s logos.It is expected that the business support will cover the following specific objectives:- Supporting businesses in designing their Regenerative Business Strategies by: conducting in-depth assessments of current business models to identify opportunities for regenerative practices; assisting in the development of tailored regenerative strategies that align with future market needs; and, providing guidance on incorporating circular economy principles, resource efficiency, and sustainable business practices.- Create sustainable supply chains by: collaborating with businesses based in East Birmingham to evaluate their supply chain or unlock opportunities to enter a new supply chain and identify areas for improvement; Promoting sustainable sourcing practices, ethical supplier selection, and fair-trade initiatives; and, assisting in the adoption of green logistics, carbon footprint reduction, and waste management strategies.- Open the innovation ecosystem to new more diverse businesses by: Supporting businesses in leveraging emerging technologies to enhance sustainability and future readiness; identifying opportunities for digital transformation, automation, and smart systems integration; and, facilitating partnerships and connections, and encouraging consortia building where relevant.The Council will be using its free to use e-tendering system (in-tend) for the administration of this procurement process and potential suppliers must register with the system to be able to express an interest. If you wish to express an interest in this opportunity, please click on the following link to access https://in-tendhost.co.uk/birminghamcc/ and submit your details to register. You will then be sent details on how to log on which will enable you to download all relevant quotation documentation.If you are unable to register with In-tend or have any questions or problems on how to use this web site please either email us at: cps@birmingham.gov.uk Your completed tender submission should be returned by noon on 13th December 2023  via the ‘in-tend’ system https://in-tendhost.co.uk/birminghamcc

title: PQ470 Infant feeding Strategy
description: As part of the Family Hubs Transformation Programme, it has been agreed that Birmingham and Solihull will work together to co-create and develop an infant feeding strategy to improve breastfeeding outcomes in Birmingham and Solihull.  This will incorporate an insights project on the barriers to breastfeeding in areas of highest deprivation in Birmingham and Solihull, directly addressing disadvantage and entrenched formula-feeding cultures in communities. In partnership with the NHS Birmingham and Solihull Integrated Care Board (BSol ICB) and the Local Maternity and Neonatal System (LMNS), Birmingham and Solihull Council’s are now looking for a provider to develop a comprehensive, co-produced five year, infant feeding strategy with recommendations and action plan to improve breastfeeding outcomes in Birmingham and Solihull. The two areas share maternity service providers and care pathways for families in addition to their geographical proximity and transient movement of the population across the areas for education, employment and leisure.We would expect the successful provider to implement the most appropriate methodologies to ensure broad representation from the diverse communities in Birmingham and Solihull to co-produce the strategy with families and partner agencies

title: P1139  - East Birmingham, North Solihull SME and Social Enterprise Support
description: This project will fund a Tailored Business Support Programme which will explicitly seek to connect local SMEs to public-sector contracting opportunities within the area. This programme will cover mapping of eligible businesses, business diagnostics, business transition (especially around commercial viability for Social Enterprises), referral to existing start-up support, access to finance, and tailored support around consortia formation. To support this project will also fund a small grant programme, and a series of meet-the-buyer events aimed at further removing logistical barriers to accessing contracts.This programme will run in collaboration with market research which will aggregate contracting opportunities from within the Birmingham Anchor Network, Tier 1 contractors, and Solihull MBC. The successful provider must provide ongoing support to this mapping.The contract will be awarded to one supplier, commencing January 2024 for a period of 15 months (ending 31st March 2025).This project is funded by the UK government through the UK Shared Prosperity Fund (UKSPF).Please note that this service will be delivered in conjunction with Solihull MBC with procurement and additional support from the CouncilThe Council will be using its free to use e-tendering system (in-tend) for the administration of this procurement process and potential suppliers must register with the system to be able to express an interest. title: P1138 - Start Up Business Support
description: The Council is seeking for organisations for the provision of start up business support.This project will aim to encourage entrepreneurial activity across the Solihull and Birmingham local authority geographies, supporting early-stage businesses with the skills and support to enable them to establish their companies here, leading to further growth and development through further mainstream and specialist business support programmes. The project will aim to:•	support the registered number of start up businesses within the region,•	support business survival rates within the region.Enabled through the following:•	To enable start ups to access relevant support including finance, premises, and skills,•	To support start ups with a credible business plan and financial forecasting,•	To equip entrepreneurs with the leadership and management skills to support their early-stage business,•	To facilitate local recruitment, business growth and productivity,•	To link to wider mainstream and specialist support across the region to support their continued growth and development.Please note that this service will be delivered in conjunction with Solihull MBC.The contract will be awarded to one supplier, commencing January 2024 for a period of 15 months (ending 31st March 2025).This project is funded by the UK government through the UK Shared Prosperity Fund (UKSPF).Please note that this service will be delivered in conjunction with Solihull MBC with procurement and additional support from the CouncilThe Council will be using its free to use e-tendering system (in-tend) for the administration of this procurement process and potential suppliers must register with the system to be able to express an interest. title: P1137 - Supporting Local Businesses with Production and Service Innovation Support
description: The Council wishes to seek organisations for the provision of Supporting Local Businesses with Production and Service Innovation Support.  The overall goals of the programme are to support SMEs in developing new products and services, to foster innovation, and to enhance their competitiveness in the market in both Birmingham and Solihull. The programme aims to achieve the following outcomes:•	to drive business growth through product diversification and new production development, •	to create an environment that supports SMEs to develop new products and services to meet existing and future customer demand, •	to provide technical support and expertise to help frame market opportunities. to facilitate the development of prototypes as Minimal Viable Products through access to facilities to enable production•	to connect businesses to the wider business support network and facilitate introductions to investors and investor vehicles.The contract will be awarded to one supplier, commencing January 2024 for a period of 15 months (ending 31st March 2025).This project is funded by the UK government through the UK Shared Prosperity Fund (UKSPF).Please note that this service will be delivered in conjunction with Solihull MBC with procurement and additional support from the CouncilThe Council will be using its free to use e-tendering system (in-tend) for the administration of this procurement process and potential suppliers must register with the system to be able to express an interest. description: The Council wishes to seek organisations for the provision of Route to Net Zero Circular Economy.  This will be commissioned across Birmingham and Solihull and will aim to deliver outcomes to support the Council’s Route2Zero strategy and sustainability strategies with a focus on industrial symbiosis. The project will aim to:•	build understanding/insight into the Council’s maturity on net zero/climate change, develop resources and capability/ knowledge specifically in relation to supply chain measurement and reporting practices, market insights and best practice in supply chain and develop a programme of engagement and knowledge sharing to support supply chain net zero readiness, •	ensuring referrals into UKSPF and other business support programmes and grants,•	the programme will identify near, medium- and long-term actions to build relations and support growing maturity of supply chain readiness, •	aim for delivery of near-term programme of engagement activities which may include workshops and knowledge sharing events with other local and regional SME support networksThe contract will be awarded to one supplier, commencing January 2024 for a period of 15 months (ending 31st March 2025).This project is funded by the UK government through the UK Shared Prosperity Fund (UKSPF).Please note that this service will be delivered in conjunction with Solihull MBC with procurement and additional support from the CouncilThe Council will be using its free to use e-tendering system (in-tend) for the administration of this procurement process and potential suppliers must register with the system to be able to express an interest. title: P2161(SMT)  -  Heat Network Metering and Billing - Soft Market Testing
description: Birmingham City Council (the Council) is looking to improve the management of its heat networks to become an area of excellence for the organisation, going beyond compliance to provide excellent customer service. As part of this journey, the Council is looking to source a new heat network metering and billing solution and a metering and billing agent across its heat network portfolio of 31 sites and circa 1500 properties. The new heat network metering solution includes the following equipment:•	Heat Meter•	Payment Meter•	In Home Display•	Pre-payment ValveThe new heat network metering solution must be: •	Transferable i.e. be able to be operated by different and multiple metering and billing agents to manage risk and provide value for money•	Operate initially in Pay-As-You Go (PAYG) mode but have flexible functionality to operate in credit mode.•	Reliable (meter read percentage of 95%), accurate (to all metering directives and regulations) and have a 10-year warranty period (kit and installation).The scope of works of this contract will be as follows:1.	Install and commission the new heat network metering solution, including full project management and resident engagement/communication.2.	Ongoing metering and billing service to customers3.	Account management to the Council4.	Repair and maintain the heat network metering solution; in line with warranty periods and the Council’s Repair Response TimesThe Council is carrying out soft market testing in preparation for the procurement of its heat network metering and billing solution and service provider.  This process will enable the Council to further understand the current market for this service area in more detail and collate valuable feedback for consideration and possible inclusion into the formal contract and tender process. The soft market testing process will consist of two phases:1.	Phase 1: A detailed questionnaire for interested parties to complete. We would encourage participants to respond as openly and honestly as possible as all responses will be treated in the strictest confidence.2.	Phase 2: An informal 45-minute interview to discuss your individual responses in more detail. This interview  will take place remotely via Microsoft Teams during w/c 18th or 25th September 2023 If you are interested in participating in this soft market testing, please register online via the Council’s In-tend e-tendering portal https://in-tendhost.co.uk/birminghamccA questionnaire will be made available to those parties who have expressed an interest in response to the advert (reference: P2161 – Birmingham City Council Heat Network Metering and Billing: Soft Market Testing)Registration and access to the In-tend electronic tendering tool is free and all correspondence for this market consultation must be made via this on-line process. Interested parties must download a market testing questionnaire from the e-portal and submit completed questionnaires by 5pm on 8th September 2023.Report any problems in accessing or using the In-tend e-portal to the Corporate Procurement Team via email at cps@birmingham.gov.uk  PLEASE NOTE: This market consultation exercise and the phases outlined above do not form part of any potential or subsequent procurement process and should not be treated as a formal call for competition. The intention of this market consultation is purely to assess and consider responses to this questionnaire in order to assist the council in developing the most viable and efficient future delivery service for this area. The closing date for the return of all completed questionnaire via the Intend portal is 5pm on 8th September 2023.

title: PQ0467 - Transport Evidence Base for the Birmingham Local Plan –  Transport Assessment
description: The Council requires a supplier for the provision of transport evidence base for the Birmingham 	Local Plan – Transport Assessment.  This contract will be for a period of up to 9 months aiming to commence week of 16th October 2023.  Birmingham City Council is undertaking an update of the Birmingham Development Plan (BDP) which was adopted in January 2017. The Birmingham Local Plan (BLP), as it is now to be known, will be the statutory planning framework for the whole city and will guide planning decisions on all development and regeneration activity up to 2042. It will set out how, where and how many new homes, jobs, services and infrastructure will be delivered and the type of places and environment that will be created. This will be a period of significant change for Birmingham, with the city aiming to achieve net zero carbon emissions by 2030, or as soon as possible thereafter a just transition allows. To help inform and evidence the BLP, the Council is seeking consultancy support to establish the transport evidence base and understand the impact of the new development proposed in the BLP.The Council will be using its free to use e-tendering system (in-tend) for the administration of this procurement process and potential suppliers must register with the system to be able to express an interest. title: PQ0492 - cardiovascular disease (CVD) public health campaign 2024
description: The cardiovascular disease (CVD) campaign is a gold-tier Public Health campaign which will support the cardiovascular health awareness efforts currently being delivered by the Million Hearts Programme pilot operated by BSOL ICS.The Provider will run a campaign to increase public engagement with the ongoing Million Hearts Programme (MHP). It is a community engagement initiative which targets Birmingham residents at risk of hypertension and signposts them to primary care practitioners for support with managing the condition. MHP also hands out free blood pressure monitors to residents who may be at-risk of developing hypertension.The provider will be tasked with planning, negotiating, and executing a comprehensive local marketing campaigns to maximise our reach and engagement within the targeted demographic groups (i.e. BAME residents, with a focus on people of black African and black Caribbean heritage) as well as the wider public as part of an overall effort to raise awareness of the issue of hypertension and the associated dangers.The city council has a maximum budget of £30,000 to undertake this work and a fixed price submission is expected to cover all costs including expenses associated with delivery of the outcomes set out in the quotation document available to download as follows.The Council will be using its free to use e-tendering system (in-tend) for the administration of this procurement process and potential suppliers must register with the system to be able to express an interest. title: PQ0490 - Bolder Healthier Workplace Champions
description: Bolder Healthier Workplace Champions - PQ0490The Council requires a supplier for the provision of the development and delivery of the Bolder Healthier Workplace Champion programme.This contract will be for a period of 2 +1 years, commencing March 2024 until 31 March 2026.  The Bolder Healthier Champions Programme was built on the COVID Community Champions Programme which was successful at engaging communities in action which reduced the transmission of the virus and vaccine uptake. This was achieved by recruiting members of the public and supporting them to share important messages through their existing networks.The programme overcame barriers to health literacy, disseminating information to communities and receiving intelligence which informed ongoing public health actions.The Bolder Healthier Champions Programme has four workstreams: •	Community•	Workplace•	Plus•	YouthTo date, the Workplace workstream has been delivered within the Public Health Division. The limitations of this approach have led to the decision to commission a partner organisation via this procurement to develop and lead the delivery of Bolder Healthier Workplace Champions Workstream going forward.The Council will be using its free to use e-tendering system (in-tend) for the administration of this procurement process and potential suppliers must register with the system to be able to express an interest.
