title: PQ0465 - Evaluation of a behaviour change intervention to increase uptake of MMR
description: The Council Behavioural Science Team sits within the Public Health Division and has a key aim of optimising behavioural science across public health and corporate priorities.The aim of this contract is to provide key external and independent evaluation of the first internal primary research systems and processes. This will also inform future planning for the behavioural science team as well as the division.The Council, therefore, requires a supplier for the provision of the evaluation of behavioural science informed intervention aimed at increasing uptake of MMR through motivational interviewing educational training. This commission will entail the evaluation of the gold project from initiation to completion.The provider is expected to work with the council and system partners involved in the MMR intervention. Quality evaluation of the project will inform the council of whether contributing to primary research through behavioural science intervention is useful and necessary. The provider is expected to evaluate the whole process from initiation phases, research processes, implementation of intervention, data collection and analysis as well as write-up. They are also expected to evaluate the implementation of Health Literacy in the intervention and ensuring that the project is culturally competent. As such, the evaluation will run alongside the actual study.SupportThe council will provide appropriate and proportionate expert public health advice, support and signpost to appropriate information. The Council will work with the provider to enable the contract delivery as much as possible. Example of support are as below. This list is not exhaustive:•	Guidance throughout to ensure the report maps the service specifications•	All documentation of the study will be shared. These include:	Literature review	Behavioural Diagnosis and mapping of intervention type and functions	Full intervention plan and access to intervention content and delivery	Raw data, if relevant	Finding of study  This contract will last until the end of the financial year 2023/2024 at 31st of March 2024.  The Council will be using its free to use e-tendering system (in-tend) for the administration of this procurement process and potential suppliers must register with the system to be able to express an interest. title: P1214/1 - Birmingham Safeguarding Children Partnership (BSCP)
description: Birmingham’s Safeguarding Children’s Partnership (BSCP) is seeking to establish a high quality and cost-effective Dynamic Purchasing System (DPS) under the Light Touch Regime, consisting of qualified Individuals / Organisations to offer learning and development services, providing locally delivered, flexible skills training and Sector specific training.    The DPS will be established for the following categories of training:	-	Attachment Theory and Brain Development  -	Child Sexual Exploitation: Tackling CSE in Birmingham  -	Child Sexual Exploitation: Advanced Level  -	Drugs and Alcohol—Delivering Brief Intervention -	Understanding and Responding to Domestic Abuse and Coercive Control (Module 1) -	Working with those who are, or may be Experiencing Domestic Abuse and Coercive Control (Module 2) -	Understanding and  responding to perpetrators of Domestic Abuse (Module 3) -	Modern Slavery  -	Neglect and the Graded Care Profile  -	Raising Awareness of Female Genital Mutilation  -	Safeguarding Children and Young People with Disabilities 	-	Safeguarding for Senior, Designated and Operational Managers  -	Understanding the Impact of Parents with Mental Health Conditions on Parenting and Children  -	Understanding the Strengthening Families Framework & Working in Core Groups -	Working with Families who have disengaged-	Working with Those Who Are, Or May Be Experiencing Domestic Abuse & Coercive Control  -	Working with Substance Misusing Parents -	Working with people at risk of knife crime -	Trauma Impact on young people-	Learning from serious case reviews -	Professional curiosity -	Keeping children safe online -	Contextual Safeguarding -	Cultural Competence / Awareness Potential Suppliers may apply for admission for one or more of the categories and shall be invited to submit a tender for each specific contract at the time of tendering (call-off).The DPS will be for a period of up to 3 years commencing 1st August 2023 until 31st July 2026, (unless terminated under the terms and conditions of contract) with the option to extend for a further two years in yearly increments. The DPS is a two-stage process:•	Stage 1 – Selection Stage – all Potential Suppliers must pass the criteria to be appointed to the DPS.  •	Stage 2 – Award Stage – There are two ways of making a call off from this arrangement as detailed below:-o	Direct Awardo	Mini CompetitionBCT will be using its e-tendering system (in-tend) for the administration of this procurement process and providers must register with the system to be able to express an interest. The web address is: https://in-tendhost.co.uk/birminghamcc Registration and use of In-tend is free. All correspondence for this procurement process must be via the In-tend correspondence function. If you are unable to register with In-tend please either email us at: cps@birmingham.gov.ukThe DPS is open to providers until 31st July 2026 to join and are required to complete and return of the documentation using the Supplier Portal.

title: P0819A - Application to join the Dynamic Purchasing System (DPS) for the Domestic Homicide Reporting
description: Birmingham City Council on behalf of the West Midlands Community Safety Partnership is seeking applications to apply to join a Dynamic Purchasing System (DPS) for Independent Author/ Chair, combined role to undertake statutory reviews for domestic homicides within the West Midlands region. The service provides a review of the circumstances in which the death of a person aged 16 years and over that has, or appears to have, resulted from violence, abuse or neglect by a person to whom they were related or with whom they were, or had been in, an intimate personal relationship or were a member of the same household as themselves. The purpose of the review is to:•	Identify any lessons to be learnt from the death;•	State the lessons to be learnt, the changes required, actions to achieve those changes and 	associated timescales;  •	Apply those lessons to relevant policies and procedures;•	Prevent future domestic abuse and homicide.The West Midlands Community Safety Partnership is seeking for Independent Author / Chair to conduct Domestic Homicide Reviews based in the 7 Local Authorities in the West Midlands Region; as listed below:•	Birmingham City Council;•	Coventry City Council;•	Dudley Metropolitan Borough Council;•	Sandwell Metropolitan Borough Council;•	Solihull Metropolitan Borough Council;•	Walsall Metropolitan Borough Council;•	City of Wolverhampton Council;The service required is for an Independent Author / Chair to provide Domestic Homicide Reviews.The DPS is a two stage process:-  Stage 1 – Selection Stage – all Potential Suppliers must pass the criteria to be appointed to the DPS. -  Stage 2 – Award Stage – invitation to tender documentation will be invited from all Potential Suppliers on the DPS for Independent Author/Chair contract to be awarded.The DPS will be open to new suppliers to enter throughout the duration.   The DPS will be open to new suppliers to enter throughout the duration. This enables suppliers 	who miss the initial advertising of the opportunity or who may not initially meet the selection 	criteria to apply or reapply at any time. Suppliers have the opportunity to review their 	processes, capability or financial situation and apply or re-apply, as the case may be, for 	acceptance onto the DPS. In addition, to support small and medium enterprises, there is the 	opportunity for suppliers on the DPS to revise their submission as circumstances changeThe Council will be using its free to use e-tendering system (in-tend) for the administration of this procurement process and potential suppliers must register with the system to be able to express an interest. title: P1006  - Adult weight management disability service and children and families weight management service
description: The Council wishes to establish Contracts for the provision of two Public Health Services: Adult Weight Management Disability Service and Children & Families Weight Management Service.The Services have been split into 2 Lots as listed below:Lot 1: Adult Weight Management Disability ServiceA minimum 12-week, Tier 2 NICE evidence-based weight management programme including:•	A thorough assessment of the individual to understand their needs•	Resources and programme design that is accessible for all with a disability; this includes session content, follow on content and any activities engaged in during the programme, particularly physical activity. •	Consideration of other contributing factors such as medication/underlying health conditions and how they affect the individual and their ability to change•	The staff who deliver the intervention must be personable and flexible in their approaches to support people.•	Open to participants who are awaiting surgery but need to lose weight to be able to have the surgery; introductory periods and nutritional support should be provided in the first instance. •	Partnering with local and national charities and organisations in the engagement and coproduction of this serviceThe contract for Adult Weight Management Disability Service will last for a period of 2 years commencing 2nd January 2024 with an option to extend for a further period of 2 years (2+2), subject to satisfactory performance and budgetary 	availability.  Lot 2: Children & Families Weight Management ServiceThe Service will provide safe, effective, age-appropriate, evidence based, Tier 2 behavioural weight management support for children aged 5-12, who have a BMI Z-score over the 91st centile and their families, to move towards and maintain a healthier weight.  The contract for Children & Families Weight Management Service will last for a period of 2 years commencing 2nd January 2024 with an option to extend for a further two 12-month extensions (2+1+1) subject to satisfactory performance and budgetary availability.  Bidders may bid for one or both Lots however, separate contracts will be awarded for each Lot. In the event that one Provider bids for both Lots and is successful for both, the two contracts will be awarded to the Provider. TUPE information will be released to tenderers upon receipt of a signed copy of Appendix 6 - TUPE Confidentiality Agreement. You are advised to fill this in as soon as possible on receipt and return via the correspondence function on In-tend.The Council will be using its free to use e-tendering system (in-tend) for the administration of this procurement process and potential suppliers must register with the system to be able to express an interest. description: Blackpool and The Fylde College (B&FC) is seeking to appoint a single supplier, to deliver its requirement and ensure the service meets the contractual requirements of the agreement and ensure Key Performance indicators are met from the outset and throughout the life of the agreement.The Contracting Authority wishes to appoint an experienced service provider for the provision a Digital Immersive Space.The works and services required are for the install of a New Immersive Space area located at our Bispham campus (Bispham HUB). The space will  provide a digital immersive experience describes the perception of being surrounded by – and being a part of – a different environment than our normal day to day. It will form a:Large-scale digital immersive environment: an open space acting as a ‘digital canvas’ and simulating real-world environments, for large-scale immersive learning via Augmented/Mixed Reality .Development space for collaboration between computer science/wider curriculum colleagues/students (including healthcare students), informing the development of specialist digital content for healthcare needs.The installation will comprise:• Seminar style curved display (Internal) (Sound system to be included in works)• Entrance display board (External)• Reception entrance display (External)• Entrance foyer full wall display (Internal)• HUB Ticker display (Internal)• HUB Curved display screen (Internal)• Wayfinding Display 1 (Internal)• Wayfinding Display 2 (Internal)• Panoramic display “Vertical standing” (Internal)• 3-Sided LED Cube style Display. title: Bolsover Skills to Thrive 19+
description: Bolsover District faces social and economic challenges that include a prevalence of low paid work in low productivity sectors such as retail, warehousing and some parts of the health and social care sector; and high levels of area deprivation with nearly half of all areas (46%) in Bolsover being in the 20% most deprived nationally in relation to the Education, Skills and Training domain.  Poor connectivity by public transport to locations where jobs are concentrated, especially where employment growth is driven by significant out of town retail and distribution centres is also a challenge.Although the pandemic has not generated the high levels of unemployment initially expected, there are groups disproportionately impacted including younger workers, the low paid and, some Black and Minority Ethnic (BAME) groups, and those with disabilities or health conditions. Moreover, there is evidence that jobs in some sectors including retail, hospitality and leisure remain below pre-pandemic levels despite the national boom in vacancies, with displaced workers moving into unemployment or inactivity rather than growing sectors such as health and social care. This indicates a skill mismatch which may be further exacerbated by changes in working patterns as a shift towards more hybrid forms of working penalise some without the space, access to technology or digital skills to embrace new opportunities.

title: Next Generation Kazakhstan
description: The British Council is interested in understanding the aspirations and opinions of young people in Kazakhstan and is commissioning Next Generation Kazakhstan, as part of the Next Generation Programme. Next Generation is a research programme that gathers data to explore the needs, potential and aspirations of young people globally. The overall aim of Next Generation is defined through 3 strands:• Research: Understanding youth attitudes and aspirations • Youth Voice: Amplifying youth voice • Policy Impact: Supporting better youth policymaking The research seeks to analyse the conditions that support young people and allow them to reach their potential as fulfilled, productive and active citizens. Research is initiated in countries that are experiencing a period of significant change, with the purpose of ensuring that young people’s voices are heard, and their interests properly represented in decisions that will have lasting implications for their lives. The research is always completed with a series of recommendations based on supporting policy change. This research has been conducted in countries including the UK, Colombia, Germany, Ireland/Northern Irelands, Myanmar, Sudan, South Africa, Tanzania, Turkey, and Vietnam. We look to see how one or more significant changes or periods of activity – particularly when a number of events or circumstance come together – affects young people’s view of themselves and their place in the world.

title: UK CONSULTANCY TO PLAN AND DELIVER CAPACITY BUILDING ACTIVITIES FOR THE STUDENT WOMEN ECONOMIC EMPOWERMENT PROGRAMME (SWEEP)
description: The British Council is collaborating with the EDHE programme to deliver specific activities under the SWEEP programme. This programme is envisioned to address the barriers to entrepreneurship faced by student and graduate women through dedicated skills and opportunities intervention with a strong focus on leveraging UK expertise in the design and delivery of the intervention.Key objectives: •	To develop an awareness of entrepreneurship and entrepreneurial activity as a means of economic participation amongst university female students and graduates.•	To promote the participation of women in entrepreneurship and entrepreneurial activities in universities with a focus on creating businesses that have a positive societal impact.•	To connect women with UK and South African entrepreneurship mentors with the skills and knowledge needed to guide and mentor student women and professional women entrepreneurs in creating businesses that have a positive societal impact.2.3	The purpose and scope of this Terms of Reference (TOR) is to explain in further detail the consultancy requirements of the British Council. 3	Specification  Background and objectivesAs a response to the realities of women’s under-representation in entrepreneurship and gender-based violence, the SWEEP programme was designed by Universities’ South Africa to equip student women and graduates across public universities in South Africa for entrepreneurial activities. The programme aims to empower student women and professional women entrepreneurs to become successful in the world of entrepreneurship and to create businesses that have a positive societal impact. Through a governance structure that includes coordinators of SWEEP in public universities, the project is designed to contribute to system-wide change by advancing gender equity and economic empowerment of student and graduate women at a national level. Overview of consultancy scopeWe are seeking a UK partner or consortium of partners who can lead on the planning and delivery of the joint activities. This will include capacity building, content development and identification of relevant UK expertise, event management and other related services. Key components: •	Content development & alignment to South African context Content to focus on three broad areas: 1.	Professional and employability skills and opportunities2.	Entrepreneurship and economic activation skills and opportunities3.	Sustainability and survival skills and opportunities.•	Capacity strengthening for women entrepreneurs/students/graduates including UK Ecosystem engagement.Objectives The overall objectives of the consultancy include: • To promote the participation of women in entrepreneurship and entrepreneurial activities in universities with a focus on creating businesses that have a positive societal impact.• To expose women to the UK entrepreneurial ecosystem and connect women with UK and South African entrepreneurship mentors OutcomesShort term:•	Female students and graduates upskilled with employability, entrepreneurship, and relevant soft skills for the development of businesses that have a positive societal impact.•	Contextualised curriculum/capacity strengthening content developed to support training and capacitation of South African women entrepreneurs in Higher Education Medium term: •	Development of online micro site/web page to provide open access to contextualised curriculum/content for any students/graduates from South African institutionsLong term: •	Improved employability and economic participation outcomes for female students and graduates.Deliverables and Milestones Below are specific deliverables expected from the organisation/consortium: •	Design one residential knowledge exchange study visit to the UK including face-to-face mentoring sessions for female entrepreneurs.•	Develop and align curriculum /training content. •	Coordinate and manage proposed activities.•	Reporting- Drafting and submitting a concise post-event narrative report.•	Dissemination: Support Dissemination of project outputs.Below are specific milestones related to this brief: 1.	Initial consultations/briefings with the British Council team.2.	Inception plan/work plan developed and signed off by the British Council.3.	Plan and deliver the agreed activities in consultation with the British Council and USAf- EDHE.4.	Submit the project report not more than 14 days after wrapping up- to be reviewed and signed off by the British Council.5.	Support a virtual/hybrid dissemination event/activity.

title: SSA_KEN_Event Management and Production Consultancy
description: We are seeking an individual or organisation to plan, produce, coordinate, and oversee the smooth delivery of British Council led stakeholder events, ensuring that it is a high quality, well organised event delivered on time and in budget. The supplier will be responsible for the following areas of work:•	Logistics and hospitality: Managing all aspects of logistics for all events. This includes negotiating and securing venues, catering, leading on décor and furniture hire, guest list and stakeholder management, booking talent (performers, sound & light engineers)•	Overseeing production of event materials (signs, plaques, badges, registration packet materials, etc) •	The British Council approved suppliers will lead on the booking and payment for travel and accommodation and the successful bidder will support the coordination of all travel and accommodation. This will include keeping track of all bookings, changes, oversight of airport transfers, managing and reporting risks and issues, coordinating transport between venues and all activities that are part of the event.  This will include working with our pre-approved vendors from time to time.•	Production: managing procurement and delivery of all technical aspects of the events which may include guest registration, hosting/ Emceeing, the livestreaming, entertainment, recording and editing of footage and photography of the event, venue layout and décor, and ensuring that the sessions run as planned.  •	Organise and participate in venue site inspections and negotiate an acceptable contract with the selected venue for approval by the British Council (as required). This might include working with pre-approved vendors.•	Communications: Provision of invitation management, communication with speakers and other key stakeholder, and organising and managing photographer, videographer to document the day.•	Marketing: PR management where needed from managing press, invitations to the press and ensuring that visibility of the event is created and press release management with authorisation from British Council Communications team. Manage photography and videography of the event and edits that are curated for social media campaigns based on the brief provided on award of the contract.•	Produce project management plans and reports for the events i.e. timelines, risk management, venues, suppliers, legal obligations, staffing and budgets;•	Evaluation: support the collection of feedback (pre and post events) from participants and produce a report that includes learning and recommendations for future activities.•	Successful bidder/supplier will be engaged on a need in the duration of the contract.

title: SSA_NGA_Provision of Adhoc drivers for Armoured vehicles (AV) And soft skin vehicles.
description: Service Provider shall provide highly skilled drivers to drive British Council vehicles (soft skin and armoured) as assigned by the British Council Facilities team, for the duration of this Agreement and under the terms and conditions stated herein.  Driver’s responsibilities   a)	The drivers must be appropriately and corporately dressed.  b)	Drivers should have a professional Indemnity Insurance c)	The drivers must be trained on Armoured vehicle defensive driving skill. d)	The drivers must be well mannered, groomed, and provide a comfortable, professional, and pleasant transport experience for customers. e)	The drivers must always maintain a strict no smoking policy and have air conditioning on before and during a trip.  f)	The vehicles must be washed daily and must be clean and comfortable before the journey commences.  g)	The drivers must have two 2 years valid driver’s License. h)	The driver must turn down radios and other mobile devices to a minimal volume when with a passenger.  i)	The driver must not engage in personal calls during a trip.  j)	Observe strictly the provisions of all applicable laws, including road transport legislation and all related rules and regulations.  k)	Driver should never smoke in or near the car prior to an assignment.  l)	The drivers must report any vehicle fault to the British Council Facilities team once it is noticed for prompt attention. m)	Drivers must never have inappropriate conversations with a passenger. Inappropriate topics of conversation include for the purposes of this agreement sex, religion, politics, etc. n)	The driver must conduct him/herself in a professional manner and never ask the customer for personal information. o)	All British Council vehicles must be kept in the office premises after every assignment. 7.3 The Customer may have a need for the provision of specialist requirements which may include   but not be limited to:

title: Unpacking the benefits of modest collaborative research grants

title: SSA_RWA_Provision of experienced e-trainers - STELIR
description: Secondary Teachers English Language Improvement Rwanda (STELIR) is delivered in collaboration with the Mastercard Foundation and implemented by British Council in partnership with Rwanda Basic Education Board (REB). STELIR aims to improve the English language proficiency of Lower Secondary Teachers in the Rwandan state education system to at least intermediate level, reaching 6,000 in-service teachers across 14 districts, plus 1,000 Lower Secondary Pre-Service teachers in training at the University of Rwanda College of Education (URCE), with the ultimate goal of improving learning opportunities for lower secondary pupils. STELIR aims to achieve a sustainable change in the Rwandan education system by adapting training materials for the Rwanda Education Board (REB) for face-to-face intensive and online delivery and by developing a cadre of local English Teacher Trainers (both face to face trainers and e-Teacher/ Moderators) who can deliver ongoing training after the project has ended. STELIR now requires an experienced organisation, for phase 2 in 2024 and potentially a further phase in 2025, to provide and manage experienced international e-trainers to lead and mentor teams of Rwanda eTeacher Moderators (eTMs) to deliver the live online sessions to pre-service and in-service teachers in Rwanda.The selected supplier will manage all aspects of this provision, from selection of suitable e-trainers with the required skills and expertise, onboarding, payment to e-trainers, and managing deployment and quality assurance of their work during delivery periods. The contract awarded will be a framework contract detailing the rates for this type of service provision.  The selected supplier must demonstrate that they have the capacity and experience to deliver at a large scale, to support a potential maximum of 85 Rwandan eTMs delivering online courses to approximately 4,000 in-service and pre-service teachers taking online courses simultaneously.

title: 2024 DPS for PTPs - Americas
description: The British Council is looking for Partner Testing Points (PTPs) to deliver IELTS on Computer test sessions in the following countries: Argentina, Bolivia, Brazil, Canada, Chile, Colombia, Guyana, Jamaica, Mexico, Panama, Paraguay, Peru, Trinidad, Uruguay, and Venezuela. Please note, we are seeking Partner Testing Points in Major Cities only. About IELTS: IELTS is a high stakes English Language test which is accepted by more than 12000 organisations worldwide.  IELTS is trusted because of its reliable content and secure delivery. Tests are subject to clear rules and requirements around the quality of the test environment, the security of the test and the actions of test day staff.The test consists of a 3-hour written test taken on computer and a 15-minute speaking exam, delivered via the internet. Tests usually start at 9am or 1pm and can be scheduled for any day of the week, although some days, especially Saturdays are more popular.What is a PTP: As a Partner Testing Point, you would be responsible for delivering scheduled IELTS tests at times and on dates agreed with British Council. To do this, you will need to supply:•	a computer testing room,•	at least one room set up for online speaking tests, •	secure storage for test materials and candidate belongings, •	a waiting area,•	appropriate staff to manage the test preparation and delivery. These staff will need to pass training and monitoring standards set by British Council IELTS.British Council manages test scheduling, candidate registration, payment, and certification. British Council pays a fixed rate per candidate for every IELTS test scheduled at your location.

title: UK_2023_Shaping organisational language policies, Phase 1: Strategies for effective policy development
description: This research piece is the first phase in a comprehensive review of language policy development and implementation which will be carried out in three phases: 1a. Shaping organisational language policies: Strategies for effective policy development – frameworks, tools and guidelines2. Publication of this research will enhance brand awareness, positioning CES as industry leaders in these areas. This research supports British Council’s mission and corporate plan through promoting English language learning and education for all and making an impact in our areas of expertise in a changing world to stay relevant and maintain competitive edge. title: Request for Proposal (RFP)-For: Consultant to develop evaluation framework, tools and conduct end-line evaluation of 'Building Agency for Youth in Climate Action' project
description: Over the past decade, Bangladesh has achieved significant economic growth, with the economy growing 6.9 percent on average between 2011 and 2019. After a deceleration during the COVID-19 pandemic, the economy has resumed its upward trajectory as Bangladesh aims to graduate from LDC (Least Developed Country) status in 2026, become an upper-middle-income country (UMIC) by 2031 and achieve high-income country status by 2041. The Youth population will play a pivotal role in moving Bangladesh towards that ambition. Youth have the potential to significantly contribute to Bangladesh’s socio-economic successes and are at a critical stage of development as they transition to adulthood.According to Bangladesh National Youth Policy (2017), any citizen between 18 and 35 years of age shall be regarded as youth. According to the ‘Population and Housing Consensus 2022’  report commissioned by the Bangladesh Bureau of Statistics, the total population (as in 2022) of Bangladesh is 165.15 million, and 35.16% or 58.06 million of the total population constitutes of the age group 15-34. Which means around one third of the total population of Bangladesh constitutes of the youth, which presents us with a great demographic dividend which Bangladesh must capitalize in order to cater to its ambition of becoming an UMIC by 2031 and achieve high-income country status by 2041.

title: Invitation to Tender (ITT)-For: 	British Council Colombo Office: Solar Power Project
description: We invite you to forward us an quotation for an implementation of a  Solar PV system  for the British Council Colombo office. These services are to be provided to the British Council, a leading Education and Childcare Client whom has significant pipeline work through Asia Pacific The British Council is the UK’s international organisation for cultural relations and educational opportunities. The British Council operates in six continents and over 100 countries, bringing international opportunity to life, every day This system is intended to generate electricity for a minimum of 15 years. The objective is to complete the installation before March 20, 2024. The primary power source for the British Council is a 400kVA CEB transformer within the premises, supplemented by a backup generator with a 550kVA capacity. The Solar PV system is anticipated to operate under either net metering or net accounting.We kindly request your engineering team to conduct a site inspection and provide a quotation based on the specifications outlined below. While we believe these specifications are optimal for the British Council, we welcome any suggestions from your engineering team that could potentially enhance power generation capacity or reduce costs without compromising quality and health and safety standards.	Identified Roofs: 7 different roofs for solar panel installation.	Inverters: Four 50kW units will be centrally positioned in the existing power room. The power room is equipped with 24/7 air-conditioning, maintaining a constant temperature of 23 degrees Celsius. Electronic monitoring and recording systems are in place to track both temperature and humidity levels.	Expected PV Generation: 189.84 kVA	Battery Backup: We have opted not to include a battery backup due to the generation capacity not meeting our current day time needs.	Bill of Quantities (BOQ): We have provided a BOQ, and any suggested changes should be clearly stated with accompanying reasons. Additionally, product specifications, quantity, cost. ( Annex b)To ensure value for money, British Council will compare CIF prices directly from manufacturers with local prices.

title: SSA_2023_Research Consultancy on Creative and Cultural Industries in Mauritius
description: Scope of ConsultancyThe British Council in Mauritius is looking for a consultant to design and implement a research mapping project which supports an understanding of the creative and cultural industries in Mauritius. The Consultant should have experience in the creative sector landscape of Mauritius and knowledge and appreciation of creative industries and inclusive communities. The key outcome of this consultancy is to develop a comprehensive report that illustrates a holistic approach to understanding of the arts sector in Mauritius.The consultancy work is within the British Council SSA Arts portfolio.•	the different artforms that are of interest to creatives aged between 18 – 35 and the opportunities that currently exist for them to practice their art •	the appetite that exists amongst creatives to collaborate either locally or with other creatives in SSA or the UK•	the different art spaces that exist in Mauritius for creatives to showcase their art•	the different arts organizations currently operating in Mauritius and the work that they do•	opportunities that are available to creatives from minority groups (including women, and those with disabilities) to be able to create art and collaborate with other creatives•	Provide programme approach, design and delivery recommendations which look towards connected and complementary programme delivery in Mauritius including: a)	The target groups who have the greatest potential to benefit from cultural engagement (including across creative economy, cultural exchange)b)	Opportunities for synergies with further British Council initiatives c)	The potential to support development and strengthening of local capacities, networks.•	Opportunities for taking a mutually beneficial cultural relations approach with the UK sector to support and strengthen local infrastructure alongside international collaboration the creation of a database of different arts organizations currently operating in Mauritius and the work that they do.Purpose of the consultancy.3.1.1	To conduct desk research and consolidate the findings from various internal and external research on Mauritius Arts sector with a specific focus on youth (18 – 35) 3.1.2	To conduct a baseline survey which will respond to:  a.	the different artforms that are of interest to creatives aged between 18 – 35 and the opportunities that currently exist for them to practice their art b.	Analysis of the ecosystem including the typologies, characteristics, business models and scaling model opportunities/present across creative economy and wider cultural arts sector c.	the appetite that exists amongst creatives to collaborate either locally or with other creatives in SSA or the UKd.	the different art spaces that exist in Mauritius for creatives to showcase their arte.	the different arts organizations currently operating in Mauritius and the work that they do. f.	opportunities that are available to creatives from minority groups (including women, and those with disabilities) to be able to create art and collaborate with other creatives.    3.1.3	To consolidate the findings from this research and provide recommendations to the British Council in Mauritius of how it can contribute to the Arts ecosystem. 3.2	Consultancy Deliverables: Outputs Research proposal including framework and plan to explore the questions to be agreed and signed off.Two engaging and accessible research reports which can be shared easily (one for internal British Council purposes and one for External Purposes). It should include the following within scope of the specification: 1.	Executive summary  2.	Summary of the purpose, objectives, and questions  3.	Methodology and limitations of the research 4.	Analysis of the ecosystem including the typologies, characteristics, business models and scaling model opportunities/present 5.	Analysis of clustering of the creative economy and cultural exchange opportunities and network with other creative industries 6.	Synthesis of findings and conclusions 7.	Identification of challenges and opportunities  8.	Recommendations for public launch of the report including online stakeholder sharing event  9.	Case study interviews with identified stakeholders and partners (online  meetings, document reviews, desk research) 10.	Conclusion

title: Request for Proposals For: Regional Perception Poll on ASEAN Creative Economy
description: We are seeking to appoint an experienced research supplier that can demonstrate its capability, capacity and the ability to work at speed across a complex range of partners and stakeholders to deliver this research commission over the next 6-7 months. Research Objectives:-	To better understand the changing landscape of the cultural and creative sectors in ASEAN region, it is proposed that we develop a regional perception poll that shall engage relevant stakeholders (particularly, creative enterprises, business and trade associations, authorities including the government agencies in charge of the creative sector, and individuals including creative makers) to understand the challenges and opportunities in the region. -	The regional online perception survey shall poll around 4,000 respondents from 10 AMS that may provide us with greater empirical analysis and draw out the gaps and challenges that may benefit from greater regional cooperation, and thereby resulting in the development of more targeted programme initiatives to support the ASEAN Creative Economy going forward. -	This envisaged online poll could serve as a substantive basis to frame future cooperation between the UK and ASEAN in the promotion of the development of creative economy. In addition, we can also make use of the poll findings (through for example, infographics and media launch of the Poll) to amplify awareness and appreciation of the creative economy among the public.Timeline and ApproachJanuary- June 2024: 5 months leading to Publication by end of June 2024Research Outputs-           Design of the questionnaire in the perception survey to be consulted with the British Council and relevant stakeholders in ASEAN including the ASEAN Secretariat and the sectoral body responsible for culture and the arts (SOMCA).-           A research report that will be published as printed book and PDF using The British Council Research branded design templates. The report will be highly visual on build on the model of The British Council Perception Survey Reports .-           Slide deck with the summary findings of the research.-           Up to 10 key Infographics of the survey results.

title: Request for Proposals: Mapping Creative Technology in ASEAN
description: Research Objectives:The purpose of the research and mapping will be to address the following needs:•           Building network capacity for creative practitioners in 10 ASEAN member states by mapping the arts x creative technology landscape and key players. •           To document and present the range of trends, gaps, opportunities and challenges faced by the arts x creative technology sector of ASEAN member states Providing a way of looking at the relation and intersection between the creative economy, digital economy, science, technology, arts and innovation.•           To document existing connections between arts x creative technology organisations in ASEAN member states and in the UK and to open a discourse on future shared challenges and opportunities.Proposed Research Methodology•           Desk-based research / mapping → literatures, data gatherings, interviews, etc.•           Targeted case studies per country, this includes a database of creative technology organisations with basic description of what they are, art form/topic focus, location, and approximate size. •           Survey to disseminate to the sector in ASEAN member states to capture descriptive data on a larger sample of festivals - to include location, art-form/topic, model and key challenges / opportunities.•           We also recommend utilising eco-friendly methods to minimise carbon footprint and effects of climate change.The core outcome of the research will be:•           A mapping of key players in the region, demonstrating the range and diversity of the creative economy sector and policy supporting the development of creative technology in Southeast Asia •           A set of case studies which illustrate the role of digital and technology in creative economy and highlight future development opportunities.•           A written overview of survey results - describing the key development trends, challenges, opportunities and needs•           A set of recommendations – to highlight opportunities for the advancement of digital technology and innovation in the creative economy sector in Southeast Asia•           A set of infographics that illustrate the key findings of the research.

title: SSA_SUD_Building Networks and Support for Business Start-ups Strategy
description: Since April 15th 2023, a conflict erupted between the Rapid Support Forces and the Sudan Army Force in Khartoum, the capital city of Sudan, subsequently extending to the five states of Darfur. Given the highly centralized nature of systems in Sudan, the disruption had a profound impact, virtually halting the wheels of life and production. This upheaval created significant gaps in the supply chain, affecting the availability of essential goods and services across the entire country. Start-ups and small businesses, predominantly operated by young entrepreneurs, bore the brunt of the crisis. Many fell victim to looting or complete loss, while others faced the harsh reality of unemployment. The Sudanese labour market is undergoing a noticeable downturn in employment opportunities, stemming from the suspension of operations in most factories, institutions, and both public and private companies in Khartoum. Consequently, emerging business owners find themselves grappling with a formidable crisis, yet they persist in their efforts to sustain or revive their ventures amidst challenging circumstances.In response to the current situation, it is imperative to re-evaluate our approach to providing support and networking. This reassessment should align with the demands of the current stage, aiming to assist young individuals in overcoming and navigating the prevailing challenges effectively. The required form of support and networking involves establishing direct connections with banks, microfinance institutions, investors, organizations, entities, companies, and stakeholders, including Chambers of Commerce and license and facility donors, to facilitate the initiation or continuation of emerging businesses.The overarching goal of this strategic support and networking initiative is to empower young people with innovative ideas and burgeoning businesses, enabling them to progress steadily. This, in turn, contributes to fostering positive change and growth at both a personal level and on a broader scale within the country. The ultimate aim is to enhance and facilitate the creation of improved job opportunities for the youth of Sudan. In navigating the multifaceted challenges of supporting young entrepreneurs and start-ups in a conflict-affected region like Sudan, this strategy takes into account the distinctive dynamics of the environment to ensure a comprehensive and effective approach.The purpose of this consultancy service is to provide training for Sudanese youth to empower entrepreneurship in addition to developing networking skills and strategy through engagement events.

title: UK_2024_Content Marketing Strategy English Teaching & Learning
description: The British Council English Marketing team recognises the critical importance of a strong and effective content strategy in supporting our business. We aim to provide high-quality resources and engaging content to learners, parents, and organisations across the world. We are seeking an agency in expertise of Content Marketing Strategy. The agency will play a pivotal role in addressing the existing gaps, devising a comprehensive content strategy, and leveraging cutting-edge technologies to future-proof our organisation's content initiatives.We are initially procuring services for this specific content strategy project; it is important to highlight that there is a clear intent to expand the scope of this work to cover Assessment and potentially other areas within the organisation. The decision to expand the scope will depend on the successful delivery of this initial project and the achievement of desired outcomes. We are seeking a long-term partnership with an agency that demonstrates the expertise and capability to support our broader content marketing needs.If you are interested in expressing an interest and/or bidding for this project, please go to https://in-tendhost.co.uk/britishcouncil . You may then have to register your company before you can express an interest for this project and get access the documents.
fifth_text: Motion picture and video tape production and related services

title: Mexico - The evaluation of curricula, study materials and assessment tools of a public higher education institution.
description: This project is part of the British Council ELT in Education Mexico and details the continuation of previous Continuous Professional Development (CPD) work done with Instituto Politécnico Nacional (IPN), one of the three most important public Higher Education (HE) systems in Mexico, and the only decentralised body of the Ministry of Education (MoE) at HE levelThe project with the British Council is a 3-year strategic collaboration. The objective is to suggest improvements to IPN DFLE English language teaching by reviewing and evaluating curricula, study materials and testing instruments supported by teachers’ performance and student, coordinators and directors’ opinion on ELT. The British Council will design and implement a CPD programme for English teachers based on IPN DFLE’s expressed needs and those identified in the evaluation.  **all are UK times**

title: SSA_2024_Zimbabwe_Secondary Travel Management Services
description: The British Council requires a suitable a secondary supplier to offer travel agency; to assist with travels arrangements, ground transfers and accommodation for its members of staff and sponsored external stakeholders for 24 months with a possibility of renewal of 12 more months for domestic and international travels. The renewal or extension will be based on the continuity of need, satisfactory performance of the supplier and availability of funds.The British Council intends to gain the advantages of an established and competent certified travel agent with demonstrated long running operations and license with the International Air Transport Association (IATA).The British council therefore seeks to benefit on the following key objectives:i.	Negotiated rates of fares, hotel bookings and ground transfersii.	Efficient and professional service deliveriesiii.	Consolidated periodic managed invoicing of for all the requests within a month.iv.	An automated or robust system for flight request approvals and issuancev.	Short turnaround time for requested quotes.vi.	Good network and close collaboration with agreed and endorsed hotels all over the world.Detailed Services RequiredThe travel agent will be required to:8.1.1 Provide the necessary travel booking services and support.8.1.2 Negotiate favourable and discounted rates for the British Council with air travel, road       transport and accommodation agents and implement them.8.1.3 Provide a transparent and inclusive service fee structure.8.1.4 Provide after-hours service.8.1.5 Ensure timely notification to the British Council and to travellers of airport closing, cancellations, or delays in flights.8.1.6 Update the British Council regularly on cancellation policies and fees of airline and the other relevant travel agents.8.1.7 Obtain any reimbursement which may be due on account of cancelled or reissued reservations and/or tickets, unless otherwise stated.8.1.8 Notify the British Council of air tickets for revalidation and/or reissue.8.1.9 Ensure booking confirmations and payments as required by the airlines and other relevant travel agents are made.8.1.10 Ensure prompt investigation and resolve on any complaints.8.1.11 Provide detailed reporting on the services provided, discounts and benefits received, upon request from the British Council.8.1.12 The travel agent shall keep abreast of and provide an information service to the British Council with regard to airport closings, carrier schedule changes, as well as all other alterations, safety conditions which may affect travel and new conditions affecting travel and to make appropriate adjustments for any change(s) in flight schedules prior to or during the traveller’s official trip, if possible. When necessary, tickets and billings shall be modified or issued to reflect these changes.8.1.13 the travel agent shall be given a copy of the British Council’s travel policy and procedures and the travel agent will ensure that this information is complied with for all official travel.8.1.14 Negotiated rates and deals and all corporate agreements must be communicated to the British Council the purpose should be to book the cheapest in-policy fare of the day. The travel agent must be aware of out-of policy bookings, or any trip not booked at the lowest rate.8.1.15 the travel agent must be able to create a temporary reservation with the suppliers and a requisition subject to approval based on Travel policy compliance.8.1.16 Travel itineraries must be generated for every approved travel request. This should reflect complete information on status of reservations on all carriers, road transport and accommodation. The travel booker must be made aware of fare restrictions, post ticketing.8.1.17 Pre – Ticket changes: the travel agent must have the ability to make multiple changes to the travel requirements prior to the approval of the travel request.8.1.18 Post Ticket changes: if open tickets are unused two months prior to expiry, refunds must be applied for by the travel agent. The British Council must be provided with assistance to ensure limited loss as a result of post ticketing changes.8.1.19 The travel agent must manage quality control issues and disaster recovery services for all bookings.8.1.20 Any other roles that shall ensure the British Councils’ travel business continuously achieves efficiency, value for money, savings in short, medium and long terms with a clear plan.

title: 2024_UK_227 - Cultural Preservation & Digital Innovation Pilot Research
description: The objective of this desk research and data analysis is to provide insight that will inform digitally focused programming for the British Council’s Cultural Protection Fund (CPF) in 2024. Building on seven successful years and £50m of investment in cultural preservation and taking into account the critical challenge of developing new means to safeguard heritage in a digital era, in 2024 the British Council’s CPF will be piloting a digital preservation initiative. The pilot initiative will support partners and projects in the Middle East, North and East Africa exploring novel applications of technology to preserve cultural heritage. This research will lay the foundations for the pilot.

title: British Council Arts: Online Audience Analysis Pilot: Focus countries: Kenya, China
description: We are seeking to appoint an experienced research supplier that can demonstrate its capability, capacity and the ability to work at speed across a complex range of partners and stakeholders to deliver this research commission over the next 4 months. The objective of this research is to understand the qualitative online behaviour of the British Council’s primary target audiences when engaging with arts & cultural content online, with a focus on two key markets: Kenya & China. For this study “art & culture online” or “digital art & culture” refers to content about contemporary arts (ie. film, music, literature, architecture, design, fashion, visual art, dance, theatre, digital art) that is consumed via social media platforms, video and streaming platforms, web apps, mobile apps, or other online platforms (ie. Twitch, discord, whatsapp etc).

title: Consultant for the supply of Entrepreneurship in TVET Research (SSA) to the British Council
description: 8.	The research will span understanding the role, forms, practice and value of entrepreneurial learning within the TVET system in making graduates more employable. The specifics are:•	Review existing research on how entrepreneurship manifests within the TVET system and TVET-private sector co-ordination more broadly for skills development outcomes o	What examples are there of TVET systems effectively supporting the different aspects of entrepreneurship (particularly in SSA) and what lessons can be shared internationally?o	Specifically, what examples are there of TVET’s mutually beneficial relationship with the private sector, and what is the nature, scope and structure of such partnerships?   o	What key recent developments and trends are emerging towards meaningful integration of entrepreneurship within the TVET sector in the study countries?•	Assess current practice and efforts on how TVET systems support entrepreneurship.o	What approaches are study countries taking to integrate the development of entrepreneurial learning into TVET? o	Aligned to the British Council’s TVET Theory of Change, what system level conditions and prerequisites enable effective delivery of different types of entrepreneurial skills in TVET?o	What specific systemic approaches and innovations in the study countries particularly related to entrepreneurial education in TVET could be of interest to other countries with similar TVET eco-systems so that ongoing and future TVET system reforms can be informed by the identified successful models and lessons learned? •	Generate insights into how entrepreneurial learning within TVET enhances employment prospects and versatile career paths for TVET graduates.  o	What evidence supports the attractiveness and relevance of TVET education (particularly to private sector and young people themselves)? o	What entrepreneurial learning most directly influences employability and self-employment success?o	How is/can TVET Career advice and guidance services support entrepreneurship as an option and provide links to other support services?  •	Recommendations for strengthening entrepreneurial aspects of TVET eco-system towards enhancing employability of TVET graduates. o	What framework, definitions and consistent language should be used to describe the different aspects of entrepreneurship?o	How do different parts of the TVET system support this framework and what aspects should be left to other support systems? (In particular, how can it support self-employment, employment and progression to other learning)?o	How much should entrepreneurial skills be incorporated into curricula and to what extent can broader/softer entrepreneurial skills be integrated into pedagogy approaches?o	What might a standard but flexible TVET system- private sector interaction/partnership model (entrepreneurial aspects nested) look like at policy and delivery fronts for optimising the ‘employability impact’ of TVET?•	Estimate number of days70 days

And of course, how can our brand best amplify the dynamism and impact of our work.We’re looking for a brand strategy partner who can work with us to drive forward our strategic thinking, bringing clarity, direction and inspiration. title: SSA_2023_Botswana_National Consultant to support the development of a roadmap for ‘greening’ TVET sector in Botswana
description: ObjectiveBuilding on the findings of the benchmarking exercise conducted in Botswana in 2023, this assignment aims to develop a strong framework to support the TVET system in Botswana in the transition to a green economy, by providing a roadmap and agreed action plan at policy, industry and implementation levels. Background to the assignment The British Council started working in the area of TVET in Botswana in 2020. In 2023, the Green Skills Benchmarking Tool was piloted in Botswana along with Morocco, Tanzania and England. The tool applied aimed to help governments, employers, and TVET providers assess how their TVET system can support the transition to a more sustainable and greener economy. The tool takes a broader view of what creating a TVET system that supports the green transition entails, looking beyond the narrow focus on occupational skills for particular 'green' industries. A wider, systems strengthening perspective, which also considers occupations in non-green industries has been taken. The tool consisted of 60 questions, grouped around the following sections:•	Policy coherence and vision  •	Labour market intelligence & skills anticipation  •	Employer engagement •	Curriculum and assessment •	Learner engagement and support •	Institutional strengthening and TVET workforce development •	Financing •	Quality assurance, monitoring, and evaluation A comparative analysis report has been produced and can be viewed here.The report highlights specific findings from the research countries and provides high level recommendations based on the above-mentioned research sections. With this assignment we are taking this work further, contextualising the recommendations and developing a roadmap to help the local stakeholders identify practical next steps Botswana can take to enhance their TVET system and ensure an effective transition to a green/blue economy. Scope To achieve the assignment objective, it is proposed that a team of a local expert and a UK TVET consultant work collaboratively between January and March 2024, to design of a roadmap (including stakeholder engagement) for greening TVET in Botswana, outlining short-, medium- and long-term priorities at policy, industry and implementation level and the respective action plan.The following activities will form part of this assignment:  1.	Review the findings of the benchmarking tool report produced for Botswana, identifying potential gaps and/or inconsistencies and producing a plan for addressing these. This will include desk research and consultations with local stakeholders (both online and in person) and includes arranging meetings and discussing information with key national informants to validate information previously shared or collect new information if needed.  2.	Production of a revised short report summarising the key findings of the benchmarking exercise and own findings outlining strengths, weaknesses, opportunities, and threads for the TVET sector in Botswana in the transition to green economy.3.	Development of a roadmap, including agreed objectives, outputs, outcomes and roles and responsibilities at policy, industry, and implementation levels4.	Design and deliver a one-day face-to-face interactive workshop with key stakeholders in Botswana to triangulate the findings of the benchmarking research and to validate the proposed roadmap.  5.	As part of the local stakeholder engagement investigate local partners appetite for investment and partnership projects with British Council and make recommendations for future interventions which British Council could potentially support through its programmatic work in Botswana in the area of greening TVET.Deliverables There are four main deliverables:  •	A short, revised report, providing a SWOT analysis in relation to greening TVET sector in Botswana. (Maximum 10 pages)   •	A roadmap for greening TVET in Botswana, outlining short-, medium- and long-term priorities and action plan including objectives, outputs, outcomes and roles and responsibilities of local stakeholders at policy, industry, and implementation levels.•	An interactive one-day workshop with key national stakeholders to triangulate the findings of the SWOT analysis and to validate the proposed road map. •	Outline of potential opportunities for partnership project(s) between the British Council and the local stakeholders in green skills transformation, and proposed implementation planOutcomesThe expected outcomes from this assignment include: •	Improved and shared understanding of the current landscape in respect of green TVET in Botswana, including existing models of practice, strengths, and weaknesses of the current system. •	A clear, shared vision of the direction of travel and strategic planning, including agreed objectives, outputs, outcomes and roles and responsibilities at policy, industry, and implementation levels.•	Enhanced relationships with key stakeholders in Botswana •	Improved awareness of the British Council’s offer in TVET by the local stakeholders

title: SSA_2023_Malawi_Consultancy Services to Lead the Monitoring and Evaluation of the ZANTCHITO- Skills for Jobs Project in Malawi.
description: Evaluation ObjectivesThe tender aims to secure the technical and professional services of an evaluation consultant.  The appointed consultant (individual or firm) will lead the monitoring, evaluation and learning required for the Skills Component of the Zantchito programme. The aim of the evaluation process is to facilitate adaptive management by making the necessary adjustments to maximise results and impact and the evaluation is to ensure effective delivery has taken place and any remedial action is taken throughout the process. The selected consultant will work closely with the Evaluation Advisor for British Council in Sub Saharan Africa, and the Zantchito M&E Manager.  The monitoring, evaluation and learning planned is to assess the programme’s delivery of it’s Theory of Change and the facilitation of skills development through TEVET as a component of enhancing national employment and competitiveness, especially the achievement of the programme’s specific objective and achievement of intended results. MEL activities are to produce actionable and strategically targeted information which, in turn, will effectively inform the performance of projects’ implementation and management against agreed objectives and results.The programme’s specific objectives are to:•	Improve co-ordination of the national TEVET system to realise governance that supports the improved quality and inclusiveness of outcomes •	Facilitate further development of TEVET delivery and outcomes that meet sector, local economic and social needsThere are two core result areas and expected results are:•	Result area 1.1 - Improved co-ordination of institutions, better clarity on responsibilities and greater use of inclusive and evidence-based decision-making that supports the development and implementation of policies and strategy for an effective TEVET system.•	Result area 1.2 - Enhanced participation of private partners in the TEVET ecosystem contributing to higher quality, relevant and inclusive TEVET outcomes.•	Result area 2.1 - A sectoral approach to skills development is piloted in four Centres of Vocational Excellence (CoVE).•	Result area 2.2 TEVET development, regulation and delivery is better able to respond to sector, local economic and social needs.Within the MEL framework, special attention will be paid to indicators related to inclusion, particularly related to disaggregation by sex and disability, including disaggregated Global Europe Results Framework (GERF). Specifications of the consultancy, key activities are to:•	Review the theory of change and the results framework and set evaluation questions that would guide this study in partnership with the project implementation team.•	Identify the mixed methodology and MEL tools for data collection (inception) •	Develop a MEL framework stipulating roles and responsibilities for all MEL functions within the programme team •	Identify capacity-building needs of the programme team in the use of data collection tools and support the team with capacity building such that they can use the data collection tools.•	Establish baseline•	Support relevant national stakeholders (including collaboration with Higher Education institutions) to embed the developed data collection tools and analytical framework to be used during and beyond the project for sustainability •	Quarterly monitoring data collection and analysis to produce progress reports for dissemination of results and impact to stakeholders•	Mid-term review to identify lessons taken away and successes to be disseminated•	Final evaluation and production of a report to be disseminated at closing events and shared with key stakeholders.The lead evaluator would be responsible for co-ordinating, in cooperation with the M&E Manager the activities highlighted above and for ensuring that the quality standards and timelines for MEL activities are met. The successful bidder will provide the overall framework for the evaluation, including the tools to be used and in addition, direct, co-ordinate and quality review the work before submission to the British Council.OutputsOutputs will include: 1.	an inception report in MS Word Format detailing finalised agreements with the Zantchito team, the MEL plan, including data collection tools and training slides on how to use the data collection tools, as part of a range of innovative approaches to         empower team members with the knowledge and skills required to gather evidence2.	Finalised project reporting templates for quarterly reports, policy briefs and insight pieces3.	Project Reports and policy briefs in MS Word Format with an accompanying interactive PowerPoint slide deck summarising the detailed report:o	Baseline Reporto	5 quarterly reportso	Mid-term reviewo	Endline reporto	Completion of British Council’s Executive Summary template required of all our evaluation reports.4.	Design and delivery of a learning and dissemination strategy and facilitate learning workshops to share lessons learned for internal and external audiences.

title: ITT – FH61EDU102023 - Continuing Professional Development (CPD) framework for School Councils
description: SCHOOLS CONNECT PROGRAMME. Please find below the details of the program and for further clarity please refer to clause 7 (Specification).IntroductionThe Schools Connect Programme is designed to respond to demand from Pakistan for connection to UK expertise on key educational themes and facilitating these connections through policy dialogue, advocacy and technical assistance.Schools Connect Programme will provide an opportunity to learn and share from successful school systems from around the world to improve quality domestically while enabling schools to internationalise their curriculum to support young people to become globally aware and competent.The Schools Connect Programme is designed to support young people in the UK and Pakistan to gain knowledge and skills to contribute to global society. We do this by engaging senior educators, leaders and policymakers to strengthen quality and inclusion in schools and building long-term connections with the UK.Objective:The Schools Connect Programme aims to bring about school system development and reform for quality and inclusion.Impact:To support inclusive and quality education for all learners, including for girls and marginalised children, and enhance the professional knowledge of school sector policy makers and leaders.Approach: The Schools Connect Programme will be delivered directly in collaboration with government and private sector and implementing partners using face-to-face, blended and digital delivery models as required. The project aims to engage with top tiers of the school sector - policy makers and school leaders (Principals and senior administrators) with an option of cascading the programme through government and private sector resources. British Council validated trainer and researcher pools will be engaged to offer oversight and technical expertise and to support project activities.Our signature training approach is grounded in coaching, mentoring and reflective learning. We focus on developing the ability of school leaders to deliver improved learning outcomes and implement their school development plans, with a focus on internationalising their school.

title: SSA_2023_Malawi_ Provision of Consultant Services as Sector Coordinator for the Zantchito Skills for Jobs Project - Technical Assistance Component implemented by the British Council
description: The British Council is the UK’s international organisation for cultural relations and educational opportunities. We work with over 100 countries in the fields of Arts and culture, English language, and education drawing on an intimate understanding of local contexts and contributing to achieving positive change, particularly for young people.In Malawi our focus is education and skills - enabling young people build the capability to create resilient pathways to better life prospects and more broadly helping to tackle Malawi’s unemployment challenge. These challenges are becoming increasingly acute due to Malawi’s youthful population. There is need for the rapid expansion of work opportunities and the development of skills to attain and create jobs. Better alignment of training to support the growth of the emerging labour market therefore makes the enhancement of Technical, Entrepreneurial and Vocational Education and Training (TEVET) in Malawi. The British Council in line with our TVET focus on Malawi is leading the design and delivery of the EU-funded Zantchito Skills for Jobs Technical Assistance Project, the overall objective of which is to increase employability and self-employment opportunities available to young TEVET graduates and entrepreneurs, with special attention to women's needs.The Zantchito Skills for Jobs Technical Assistance Project has selected four Malawi Technical colleges to be developed into Centres of Vocational Excellence (COVEs) in the following sectors in Malawi: 1)	Agricultural Mechanization, 2)	Tourism, 3)	Renewable Energy, 4)	Marine Transport. The COVEs are technical colleges which will spearhead the development of these four sectors by offering unique skills which are not currently available in the country. British Council seeks the services of four Sector Coordinators (Consultant role) to work with the COVEs in the respective selected sectors, one in each sector as indicated below: -1.	Sector Coordinator in Agricultural Mechanization, to be based in Lilongwe at Lilongwe Technical College2.	Sector Coordinator in Tourism, to be based in Blantyre at Malawi Institute of Tourism3.	Sector Coordinator in Renewable Energy, to be based in Mzuzu at Mzuzu Technical College 4.	Sector Coordinator in Marine Transport, to be based in Salima at Salima Technical CollegeThe Sector Coordinator will report to the Deputy Team Leader of the Zantchito TA project and will be responsible for coordination and liaison with relevant stakeholders in his/her designated sector. Each Sector Coordinator will be attached to one COVE (Technical College Institution) and will undertake the following specific tasks:Accountabilities, Responsibilities, and deliverables1.	Facilitate and coordinate the provision of technical support and capacity building services offered to the COVE and its TEVET provider network during project implementation.2.	Support Management of the COVE and those of its provider network in achieving the setting-up and operations of the COVE during the project implementation.3.	Support the management of information generated by his/her COVE and its provider network.4.	Support all monitoring, evaluation and research activities undertaken by the project, as well as the COVE and its provider network.5.	Facilitate the participation of the COVE and its provider network in the Sector Working Group for effective collaboration.6.	Facilitate the missions of the project consultants who will work with the COVE and its TVET provider network.7.	Monitor the work of project consultants assigned to work in a COVE and its TEVET provider network.8.	Monitor the delivery of training and capacity building provided to a COVE and its TEVET provider network.9.	Submit monthly reports to the Deputy Team Leader on the work being undertaken in a COVE.10.	Facilitate and support linkages between the COVE and employers from the private sector.11.	Promote the work of the Zantchito project at both the sector and regional level.12.	Undertake any other tasks that the Deputy Team Leader may assign to the Sector Coordinator.
