title: SSA_2023_South Africa_ Primary English Language Reading Test design and evaluation
description: This section details the scope for this assignment including the range of activities the supplier is expected to deliver, the qualifications and expertise required of the supplier, and the expected timeline for the task.OBJECTIVESPhase 1 - Develop a theoretical approach to testing reading comprehension for a comprehensive English Language Reading Test for primary school pupils in development projects contexts.Phase 2 – Using this theoretical approach, design a set of test specifications (overall test spec. identifying target reading construct, number of tasks and items, formats, etc), with detailed task/item specifications.Phase 3 – Use the test/task/item specs. to design and validate specific materials that can be used to evaluate the impact of reading projects in South Africa.                   (NB. We require proposals to cover all activities required to deliver all three phases, but Phases 2 and 3 will only commence upon successful completion of Phase 1 outputs.)PROJECT DURATION	Mar 2024 – Dec 2024PROPOSED TEAMThis project can be carried out by a small team of academics and/or practitioners with a strong track record in assessment from an academic institution that will be selected through a competitive selective call for proposals.  Suitable applicants will be able to demonstrate expertise and experience in following areas-	Teaching and learning of reading, research into reading comprehension for young learners, particularly for learners in the development contexts in which the test is likely to be used-	Clear understanding of the context for Phase 2 outputs (South Africa) as well as the wider context -	Demonstrated experience and expertise in language test development and researchIf the applicant has suitable testing experience in other subjects, but language test experience is a gap, there are several UK language testing research centres who could potentially partner on this project. If this is of interest, please contact us before the clarification question deadline.In addition to expertise in assessment, the team must also have a comprehensive understanding of the complexities, issues, and risks involved in conducting assessments in a low-resource development context where English is taught as an Additional Language, and a sound knowledge of the South African context and relevant features of the situation in relation to the education system and development partners working to support it.EXPECTED OUTPUTSPhase 1 (a report):a. Literature review of current theory and practice of primary aged pupil exams relevant to low resource contexts such as those in SSA, including considerations such as cognitive load, multilingual approaches, and different aspects of validity. Suppliers should consider the Socio-Cognitive Model as described in Chalhoub-Deville and O’Sullivan (2020)  as this is widely used by the British Council and other test developers. The Khalifa and Weir (2009)  reading model should also be addressed in the review.b. In light of this literature review, analyse and evaluate strengths and weaknesses of tests used in the SSA development sector (including EGRA and the BLF pupil test). c. Adapt and/or design a theoretical approach for a comprehensive English Language Reading Test for primary school pupils in development projects contexts. This must be based on a clear validity model emerging from the literature review in (a) above. Phase 2 (a test specification):a. Based on the theoretical approach, adapt/design a set of test specifications (overall test spec. identifying target reading construct, number of tasks and items, formats, etc), as well separate detailed task/item specifications which provide the detail for item writers to develop specific content that is predictable in terms of difficulty and fits the overall approach and reading skills that different task formats may need to focus on.Phase 3 (a set of validated test materials):a. Use this test specification to develop test materials and scoring rubrics for P1-7 pupils in South African state schools that align with the national curriculum and learning outcomes that are age-appropriate, culturally sensitive, and suitable for delivery at scale. (If feasible, include EGRA ORF questions in the test package to evaluate concurrent validity.) b. Throughout the test development process, collect appropriate evidence to assess specifications, content, and items for validity, reliability, and effectiveness in evaluating pupils' reading skills in line with the national curriculum and stated learning outcomes. We would expect at least three levels of evaluation rather than one summative validation: small scale trialling with small groups of students, collecting detailed qualitative information on how they have approached the test; larger pilot(s) in which the test is tried with a larger number of students after test content is reasonably settled; and a final larger scale field trial with the final test design and content that allows for precise scoring validation.c. In-depth analysis of trial results and refinement of the specification, content and items based on the trial outcomes throughout the development cycle.d. Produce a final testing toolkit with the validated materials, scoring rubrics, and assessor training materials.

title: UK_220_British Council Research and Insight Podcast – Podcast Production
description: We  are looking to pilot a research and insight podcast. This series (6-12 episodes) will bring together British Council experts, as well as global researchers and practitioners in the fields of international development and cultural relations. We are seeking a supplier to:•	In collaboration with the British Council, develop the podcast concept, strategy, identity, and plan of work, ensuring that the podcast pilot aligns with audience behaviour and best practice.•	Oversee and support the preparation for recordings – including formulate the script and structure for all episodes of the pilot, provide coaching on best practice for the podcast host(s), and brief guests for technical quality (episode research and guest recruitment will be handled by the British Council).•	Provide and set up the recording equipment, and direct and monitor the recording sessions to assure high technical quality for each episode.•	Edit, mix, and master the recordings to a high professional standard of audio quality.•	Set up the podcast channel, distribute it across all major podcast platforms, and provide access to analytics and audience insights. •	Provide promotional advice and strategy.The above is a summary of our minimum requirements – however, we are open to additional services that can improve our podcast design, quality, and reach (subject to these being deliverable within our timeframes). The selected supplier may also be offered the opportunity to continue working on the second phase of our podcast (future seasons), subject to the performance of our pilot and budget availability.

title: SSA Arts Technical Proposal Writer (Freelance contractors/Sole Proprietor/ Self- employed individuals encouraged to apply)
description: 1.	Background and context about the projectThe British Council is the UK’s international organisation for cultural relations and educational opportunities. We build connections, understanding and trust between people in the UK and other countries through arts and culture, education and the English language. Last year we reached over 80 million people directly and 791 million people overall including online, and through broadcasts and publications. Founded in 1934 we are a UK charity governed by Royal Charter and a UK public body. We receive a 15 per cent core funding grant from the UK government. We work on the ground in more than 100 countries. The British Council works with organisations, networks and leaders with shared interests to secure the financial resources, galvanise our combined influence and catalyse pathways to solutions that make a measurable difference. Together with our partners, we aim to maximise positive outcomes for Africa's next generation through mutually beneficial and innovative interventions that improve the lives of young people and their ability to contribute to the socio-economic development of their countries. The British Council Arts and Culture Programme in sub-Saharan Africa (SSA) is looking for about three experts with knowledge and in-depth insights of the creative and cultural sector on the continent to lead on writing technical aspects of service contract proposals for international organisations with approximate values ranging between £500,000 - £10,000,000, towards the above ambition.2.	About the role of the specialist contractor/s The contractor/s will review and analyse funding opportunities and develop strategically comprehensive proposals aimed at attracting partnerships.Taking on a lead role within the partnership’s pursuit team, the contractor is expected to provide market insights that enhance the quality of funding proposals, harnessing relevant aspects of the British Council’s track and experience to produce outstanding proposals. The contractor/s will work alongside the SSA Regional Arts Director, our programmes, insights and research and business development teams, virtually.3.	Outcome and outputsThe Consultant/s will deliver services including but not limited to the following:•	Act as the lead technical writer and work directly with the proposal team and consortium members to develop the full technical proposal including writing the proposal budget.•	Collect technical inputs (through workshops, interviews, and written questions) from the British Council and the partners and structure the proposal coherently using these inputs.•	Provide technical input for the rationale, strategy, log frame and draft of the timetable of activities sections under the ‘organization and methodology’ part of the technical proposal in line with the content outline and the timeline to be agreed with the British Council•	Analyse the Terms of Reference (TOR) which constitute a part of the invitation to tender for selected projects in target countries across the Sub-Saharan Africa region in line with requirements for the proposal.•	Provide revisions to the above-mentioned sections in response to the comments of the proposal team and the partners. •	In agreement with the British Council team, undertake additional activities within the scope of the preparation of the Technical Proposal.

title: SSA_2023_South Africa_ Provision of records management services for materials provided by the British Council and stored in boxes.
description: Records Management Services detailed below for Materials provided by the British Council and stored in Boxes. Such Services include but are not limited to storage, transfer, retrieval, and destruction of Materials stored in Boxes.Details of the Services are as follows: Box storage-Supplier stores the Materials provided by the British Council at their premises for a monthly storage fee.Boxes- Please specify the types of boxes available. Our default position would be the standard box size.New Box Purchase & Entry System	British Council is responsible to prepare Box shipment forms, upload new Materials into Boxes, affix barcodes/naming conventions to Boxes and use parcel tape to seal the Boxes by taping around the lid and across the top of the box. Supplier is responsible to enter Boxes barcodes and identification data from the Box shipment forms in the electronic inventory system. Supplier will reject any damaged Box upon collection (if packing is not performed by Supplier packing team). Supplier will reject any Box without being labelled with Supplier barcodeService Level Agreement (SLA)	Please specify SLA's available with focus on retrievals, entries onto system post collection, index reporting etcBox Preparation-Please specify if the boxes are reset once collected and entries are made onto the systemTransportation	Delivery and collection of boxes. Will the fee include a set of alternative sites (British Council remote locations) up to a max or would the charge be separateEmergency retrieval of files-Please specify processReturn of retrieved files-If the British Council returns the retrieved Materials for re-storage, Supplier will put the Files back in original place for easy recording and future retrieval.Destruction/Disposal	Please specify the process and schedules followed for this process. Additionally, please specify the destruction of paper and digital files.This Service includes the removal of files/materials from the facility, the preparation of the destruction report, the packaging of the boxes/materials, the loading of the materials/boxes into a vehicle, transportation to the disposal site and the safe and secure disposal of the items. Shredding method is applied for destruction. Materials will be irreparable after clipping/shredding. Supplier will ensure that the type of the Shredder is in line with the British Council Minimum standard (Cross-cut, DIN Standard 66399 Security Level 4 (Particle size ≤ 160mm2)). Since the Supplier does not examine the actual content, type, value and meaning of the Materials, the British Council is obliged to provide information in case the Disposal Service would be subject to special conditions due to the specific content, type, value, sensitivity or meaning of the Material in question, (in particular pre-official authorization, notarization, public archives permission, etc.).Missing/Damaged Boxes/Files	Please specify the process and levels of accountabilityDigital filing- Please specify what digital storage options are available, process and regulationsSecurity Standards	Please specify security standards (physical security, CCTV, temperature and humidity control, fire security, pest control, contingency plans etc)Inventory/Indexing report	This is critical to managing the contents stored. This must be included in the service fee as a mandatory reporting on a quarterly basisViewing Room	A viewing room should be available for use (either free of charge or at agreed fee included in the Services Price List).Naming conventions- Guidance is welcome here however this must be agreed in advance prior to commencement

title: SSA_Mozambique_2023_Services of a Consultant for Green Skills Benchmarking Exercise on the Going Global Partnership TVET programme in Mozambique
description: The Green Skills Benchmarking Tool The British Council has developed a self-assessment tool on Greening TVET that aims to identify and measure how green a country’s TVET system is at policy, industry and implementation levels by engaging all key stakeholders. The tool is designed to support governments in demonstrating and measuring progress in the transition to a greener society and will inform the enhancement and formulation of appropriate policy initiatives, identify exemplar areas of practice and success and shape Going Global Partnership interventions to help capitalise on strengths and address any gaps. It is proposed that a green skills benchmarking exercise takes place in Mozambique between December and February, which will be followed by the design of a roadmap (including stakeholder engagement) for greening TVET in Mozambique, outlining short-, medium- and long-term priorities. The following activities will form part of this assignment:  1.	Working with the UK consultant on conducting an assessment of TVET system in Mozambique using the Greening TVET benchmarking tool, through desk research and consultations with key national stakeholders (both online and in person). This includes arranging meetings and interviewing key national informants to collect and validate information for the self-assessment tool. 2.	Delivering a one-day face-to-face interactive workshop with key informants in Mozambique to triangulate and validate the findings. The UK consultant will support the design of the workshop. 3.	Work with the UK consultant on development of a report analysing the findings of the benchmarking exercise (including the ranking for each question in the tool, discussed and agreed by key stakeholders during the workshop), outlining strengths and opportunities for greening TVET in Mozambique, capturing examples of good practice which illustrate how the country is enhancing, or plans to enhance, its TVET system to ensure it supports transition to a green/blue economy, and making recommendations for potential British Council supported projects in this space as well as suggesting enhancements/refinements to the tool.4.	Support the UK consultant in development of a roadmap (including stakeholder engagement) for greening TVET in Mozambique, outlining short-, medium- and long-term priorities.       Overview of taskThe task focusses on five interrelated activities:1.	Briefing from the British Council. British Council to provide the benchmarking tool, the comparative analysis report and scoping report of TVET landscape in Mozambique. Arrange online interviews with key local stakeholders and conduct them in collaboration with the UK          consultant. 2.	Desk research to build understanding of the Mozambique TVET system in the context of green skills. In collaboration with the UK consultant, complete the benchmarking tool based on findings from desk research and online interviews with local stakeholders. 3.	Plan and deliver a one-day workshop to validate the findings and get stakeholders to complete selected sections of the tool through interactive sessions working in groups. The UK consultant will support with the design of the workshop. The British Council office in          Mozambique will provide the required logistical support. 4.	Collaborate with the UK consultant on production of a report detailing the methodology of the benchmarking exercise, capturing the findings and recommendations, outlining strengths and opportunities for greening TVET in Mozambique, capturing examples of good         practice which illustrate how the country is enhancing, or plans to enhance, its TVET system to ensure it supports transition to a green/blue economy, and making recommendations for potential British Council supported projects in this space as well as suggesting         enhancements/refinements to the tool.5.	Support the UK consultant with development of a roadmap (including stakeholder engagement) for greening TVET in Mozambique, outlining short-, medium- and long-term priorities.ObjectiveThe utilisation of the green skills benchmarking tool will elicit intelligence and insight into the current landscape of green skills in Mozambique. This will provide a strong framework for targeted support to build on the strengths and address gaps. OutputsThere are four core outputs:  •	An interactive one-day workshop with key national stakeholders to validate and triangulate the findings of greening TVET benchmarking exercise in Mozambique •	Detailed benchmarking report on green skills in Mozambique based on the results of greening TVET benchmarking exercise •	Outline of potential opportunities for partnership project(s) in green skills transformation and proposed implementation plan•	A roadmap for greening TVET in Mozambique, outlining short-, medium- and long-term priorities.Outcomes1.	Improved understanding of green skills in the Mozambiquan context including key stakeholders, current models of practice, current results and strategic planning 2.	Enhanced relationships with key in-country stakeholders, improved awareness of those stakeholders as to the support that British Council can offer and buy-in of those stakeholders to British Council’s proposed intervention.3.	A clear, shared vision of the following phase of work, including objectives, outputs, outcomes and roles and responsibilities.

title: SSA_ South Africa_  2023_ Supply and Installation of CMR CCTVs and Access Control Systems for British Council Office Johannesburg
description: Confidential Materials Room Scope of Work CCTV a.	Cameras should be located within the CMR facing the door area, providing. b.	recognisable* images of anyone entering the room and the general working area  of the CMR, including access to cabinets and to mini safes containing cabinet keys. In many cases, more than one camera will be needed to ensure complete coverage of all the working spaces. c.	The fire door must also be included in the internal camera coverage. d.	Where necessary, illumination will be required to provide a useable CCTV image during periods of low or zero light. This will ideally be in the form of Infrared lamps. e.	The cameras and recorders should be supplied with an uninterruptable power supply. f.	The recording software should be capable of using video motion detection to trigger recordings. g.	The capacity of the CCTV recording must meet the corporate record retention schedule, which is 90 days for a CMR. Where local legislation stipulates a shorter retention period, this period is applied. However, there should be evidence available to this requirement. h.	CCTV system and recording equipment should be rack mounted in the server room. i.	Appropriate password protection should be in place to access the CCTV recordings, and access to them must be restricted to authorised staff, which is included on the authorisation log and/or CCTV code of practice.  j.	CCTV must be clearly sign-posted via corporate notices wherever used.  *A Recognisable image is achieved by capturing the image of a person which occupies at least 50% of the screen height on a monitor.  ACCESS CONTROL SYSTEM An automated access control system is required to permit access into the CMR   1.	Each authorised individual must be given biometric access. 2.	An electronic lock controlled by the access control system secures the door when not in use. Preferably this should be an electronic strike lock. If a maglock is used it must be a high security model with a minimum holding force of 510kg or 5000 Newton’s. The door should also be fail tested in case of system failure, i.e. it remains locked and closed.  Electronic strike lock is installed into the door frame and uses a latch to secure it.    When power is applied to the lock the latch releases and the door can be opened.  This provides additional security as the door remains secure even if the power is removed.  It is much harder to force this type of lock open compared to a maglock, also its more likely the intruder will have to damage the door to gain access.  The disadvantage of this lock is they take longer to install as the installer has to modify the door frame significantly and therefore are more costly.  A maglock (or magnetic lock) (see picture) is located on the top corner of a door (on the inside of the door/room not the ‘attack’ or outside of the door/room.)  A maglock uses a powered magnet to hold the door secure.  When power is removed the door can be opened, also if you apply enough force by pulling the door the lock will eventually give way without damaging the lock or door. This is the main disadvantage of these type locks.  The advantage is they are easiest and cheapest to fit. With this lock an additional physical lock is needed to ensure door remains closed if power fails during out of office hours.   There must be a means to leave the room including in an emergency. a.	If you have a maglock, there must be a push to exit button fitted on the inside of the room to allow users to leave the room. An emergency break glass unit is required to leave the room in the event of a system failure.  b.	If you have an electronic strike lock, there must be a manual handle on the door to allow people to leave the room at any time including in an emergency.  An electronic system identifies and records who opens door when entering (name, date, and time) and when the door is closed (date, time). It would also capture door opening from inside (date, time) and closure (date, time). It also captures unsuccessful attempts to open the CMR door.   There should be an alarm sounder at the entrance door which is to activate if the door is left open for longer than 30 seconds, this will alert people to close the door or to investigate who opened the door and why the door is still open. An audible tone should be heard in the immediate vicinity.

title: Ukrainian Young People's current concerns, Needs and Hopes: Looking Forward
description: Following Russia’s full-scale invasion of Ukraine on the 24 February 2022, which constituted the largest attack on a European country since World War II, young Ukrainians have been subject to the profound effects of warfare. In addition to the direct consequences of the conflict, such as physical harm to themselves, family and communities, trauma/psychosocial consequences as well as displacement from region or country, they have experienced disruption to education healthcare, and other vital services. Ukrainian children and youth are showing signs of widespread learning loss as Russia’s invasion preceded by the COVID-19 pandemic have left them facing a fourth year of education setbacks. According to UNICEF (2023) only a third of children of primary and secondary age are learning fully in-person. Another third of enrolled students are learning through a mixed approach of in-person and online, and one-third are fully remote with secondary-age students most likely to miss out.The British Council delivers education, arts, and English programmes in Ukraine. The British Council have been working in Ukraine since 1992, and every year connect with thousands of students, educators, policymakers, academics, creatives, and entrepreneurs in Ukraine. The British Council, alongside the Ukrainian Institute, managed the UK/Ukraine Season of Culture. First envisioned in 2019, the UK/Ukraine Season of Culture gave a voice to Ukrainian creatives amidst the changing needs and priorities of the Ukrainian cultural sector. In the area of youth and society, based on successful projects focusing on citizenship, social enterprise and social cohesion and resilience, the British Council is currently developing and delivering a pilot project that aims to develop to develop a suite of activities to meet the needs of a diverse cohort of young Ukrainians, either currently in Ukraine, possibly internally displaced or recently resident under Temporary Protection in three potential partner countries, Romania, Poland and Bulgaria and promote their integration in their current social contexts. The British Council is seeking to understand more fully the challenges currently being faced by young Ukrainians both in Ukraine, and those who have moved outside its borders since Russia’s invasion. Much of our programming in Ukraine has been changed significantly since 2020, as both the COVID pandemic and Russia’s invasion necessarily altered British Council operations, and now it is important to get a clearer understanding of young Ukrainians’ needs, hopes, and aspirations as they describe them. The British Council is seeking a partner to conduct research that investigates, records, and makes explicit these concerns, needs, and hopes. Through the process of listening to, and understanding, the unique challenges young Ukrainians face, this research will aid in clarifying and evidencing British Council programming, and influence our work in Ukraine, and with Ukrainians. In addition, the British Council is seeking in our partner for this research the ability for that partner to take the insights gained from young Ukrainians and hold both internal and external round table discussions with key stakeholders, to facilitate learning across the organisation from what is learned.This contract will be given to a single supplier for the provision of research, management of that research, and subsequent associated activities including, but not limited to, round table discussions, internal dialogues, associated PPT slide decks, a final report, and guidance papers. All work associated with this contract will be completed by 31 March 2024.

title: SSA_RWA_Research on Innovations in blended / online learning on a continuing professional development (CPD) programme in Rwanda
description: Research on Innovations in blended learning on a continuing professional development (CPD) programme in Rwanda (Secondary Teachers’ English Language Improvement Rwanda - STELIR); A journal article / chapter in a book (on education technology) that describes project innovations in blended learning, including challenges and how overcome.The Ministry of Education in Rwanda has chosen English as the medium of education and, as per the current Education Sector Strategic Plan (ESSP), expects all teachers to achieve a B1 Level on the CEFR. The aim of STELIR is to improve the English language proficiency of up to 6,000 Lower Secondary Teachers in the state education system across 14 (out of 30) districts, plus 1,000 Lower Secondary Pre-Service Teachers in training at the University of Rwanda College of Education, to an intemrediate level, over a three-and-a-half-year period, with the ultimate goal of improving learning opportunities for lower secondary pupils. STELIR research plans focus on the themes of inclusion and equity in teacher CPD linked to the use of blended learning that includes innovations in education technology. This research piece and corresponding journal article is timed so that research can take place when one cohort of approximately 2,600 teachers will have completed Stage 1 (face-to-face) and Stage 2 (online) of their STELIR blended English courses at their appropriate language level, and will either be graduating at intermediate level (CEFR B1), or continuing taking subsequent courses through the levels until they reach intermediate. At the same time, a second cohort of approximately 2,400 teachers will be preparing to begin their STELIR blended English courses.

title: RFP_Sub-Saharan Africa Publishing and Literature Sector Study: Ghana, Kenya, Nigeria, South Africa, Uganda, and Zimbabwe
description: The British Council wishes to engage a researcher (“Supplier”) to conduct in-depth research into the trade publishing and literature sectors in six countries in Sub-Saharan Africa which provides market insights and focuses on innovative practice and the conditions for resilience in the sector. The six countries will be Ghana, Kenya, Nigeria, South Africa, Uganda, and Zimbabwe.The research will provide a comprehensive, accurate overview of the trade publishing and literature sectors in each country with a particular focus on the sector infrastructure and the creative individuals working within the sector. The research will identify innovative practice, opportunities for collaboration, specifically with other SSA countries and with the UK and challenges faced by publishers working in each country. The research will also identify opportunities for professional development and internationalisation of literature professionals working within the sector to strengthen the resilience of their organisations.

title: ITT for WOW Event 2024 UU15Arts12024
description: WOW – Women of the World is a festival in the UK which celebrates women and girls and looks at the obstacles that stop them from achieving their full potential. title: Research services on Gender-based violence in Moroccan universities
description: The British Council is conducting a piece of research that aims to define ways in which Moroccan universities can prevent gender-based violence. This research will design an action plan to prevent gender-based violence or negative behaviours and empower women in Moroccan universities. Addressing sexual violence is crucial as it directly affects women's access to education, hindering academic progress and deterring participation in campus activities. By promoting a safer environment, the project seeks to enhance equal access to education, particularly for vulnerable and marginalised population.

title: SSA_2023_Zimbabwe_Taxis & Transportation Services Tender
description: The British Council is the United Kingdom’s international organisation for cultural relations and educational opportunities. Its purpose is to build engagement and trust for the UK through the exchange of knowledge and ideas between people worldwide.  It seeks to achieve its aims by working in education, science, governance, English and the arts. In 2013-14, its programmes reached a total audience of 600 million people worldwide and we engaged directly with 10.9 million. In 2013 to 2014, the British Council had a total turnover of £864million.  Its income included a grant-aid of £165 million from the UK government, £573 million from fees and income from services such as English teaching, exams administration and £117 million from the management of client-funded contracts, and funding from a wide range of public and private sector partners. Taxis and Transportation Tender for Zimbabwe. Taxi and transport services are required to support the British Council Zimbabwe, operating through its offices in Harare and Bulawayo delivering work across Zimbabwe. General specifications1-	Provide transportation services to British Council colleagues nationwide.  The cities and locations will vary depending on business needs.  This will include but no limited to:a.	Office, airport, and hotel transfers in Harare and Bulawayo b.	Short and long distance pick up and drop off in urban and remote areas.c.	Professional chauffeur services from time to timed.	Group transferse.	Suitable and sufficient fleet to accommodate multiple trips in a busy environment.f.	Transportation of British council exams staff during sessions in Harare and Bulawayo2-	The overall purpose and aims of this service is to provide a safe, affordable and legally compliant service as per British Council health and safety standards.Expertise specificationa.	The Service Provider will be liable for all shortcomings of third-party vehicles and drivers.The Service Provider shall provide documentation demonstrating roadworthiness of its fleet. In addition to complying with government regulations regarding maintenance of the vehicles, the vehicles and the drivers to be used for the Services shall also conform to the norms set by BC transport department. The vehicles must also conform to emission standards set by the regulatory authorities in South Africa.3-	Maintain accurate receipts for each journey and vehicle, including names of passengers, time of pick-up, place of drop-off and time of drop off.4-	The Service Provider shall bear all overheads associated with the vehicles used for Services i.e., all expenses, relating to fuel (diesel/petrol), maintenance costs of the vehicles, taxes, insurance, repair and spare costs, etc. British Council does not have any liability as regards such expenditure. a.	All drivers must have police clearance and PDP’s.b.	The service provider must have a detailed company safety policy that all drivers abide by c.	The Provider agrees to invoice the British Council for services in a timely manner, in line with British Council finance policies.

title: RFP_Research to understand, articulate and evidence the value of working internationally with schools
description: The British Council is seeking a supplier to investigate the benefits and value brought to partner countries and to the UK from an international cultural relations approach to working with schools.The aim of this project is to build on the knowledge from a previous 2022 report (more detail in annex) and to build an evidence base of the value to partner countries and to the UK of working internationally and through cultural relations with schools.  Such evidence would help to articulate the value (in terms of influence, trust, long-term relationships, and ‘soft power’) of British Council activities in schools. Furthermore, the outputs from this exercise will help to articulate why the British Council is uniquely well placed to do this work on behalf of the UK (and should continue to be supported to do this), crucially with evidence to back up our claims.

title: Framework Agreement for Interpretation and Translation Services for British Council in Japan
description: Scope of WorkTRANSLATION SERVICESThe chosen providers will undertake the task of translating and localizing a wide range of documents such as: reports, newsletters, brochures, websites, presentations, press releases, emails, and legal documents, among others.The language to be translated s to Japanese to English, and English to Japanese only. Additionally, the services should incorporate proofreading and editing by native speakers and linguistic experts.INTERPRETATION SERVICESSimultaneous Interpretation· Effectively perform simultaneous interpretation through interpreting audio equipment. The interpreter listens to the speaker via headphones, while simultaneously speaking the translation into a microphone. The target audience then receives the interpreted speech through receivers and earpieces.· Simultaneous interpretation is suitable both for face-to-face conferences, where attendees gather in person, and online events, which utilize digital platforms for communication.· Interpreter Proficiency Levels: Interpreters can be classified into two proficiency levels: A Level and B Level.A Level Interpreters are highly experienced professionals who possess exceptional interpreting skills. They are thoroughly proficient in their working languages, allowing them to interpret with great accuracy and deliver smooth translations.B Level Interpreters have a good understanding of their working languages and a solid background in interpretation. While they may not possess the same level of expertise as A Level interpreters, they are still capable of providing accurate and effective translations. Their continuous learning and experience allow them to improve and advance in their profession.Consecutive Interpretation· Interpreters convey the speaker's message in another language during regular intervals or pauses. This approach allows for accurate translations while maintaining the original context and tone of the speech.Interpretation Equipment for Face-to-Face conferences and Online Events· Use of interpretation equipment such as Simultaneous Interpretation Systems, Consecutive Interpretation Equipment, Portable Translation Devices, Remote Interpretation Platforms, Assistive Listening Devices.III. Qualification· The service provider must have at least 5 years of experience in providing professional translation and interpretations services.· Certifications or equivalent quality management system accreditations is preferred.· The bidder must have a team of skilled translators, editors, and proofreaders with expertise in the required languages and subject areas.· Ability to handle high volume projects and tight deadlines without compromising on quality.· The bidder must use Computer-Assisted Translation (CAT), software or AI Platform to ensure consistency and efficiency.· The translations must adhere to guidelines and glossaries provided by the British Council.· The bidder must implement a rigorous quality assurance process, including multiple stages of review and editing.· The bidder must ensure the confidentiality of the documents and agree to sign a Non-Disclosure Agreement (NDA).Please note that British Council will not commit to a volume order, but historical total transaction for the last three financial years is JPY 9,919,006 (GBP 54,540). Supplier responsibilities include:

title: SSA_Zambia_2023_The consultant(s) to undertake a costing exercise to better determine the cost of educating a child in a public school in Zambia.
description: The overall objective of this consultancy is to support the GRZ to develop a costing framework that reconciles school and household-based costs of educating children while factoring in institutional type and spatial considerations (Rural, urban and remoteness). The costing framework will enable the GRZ to undertake equitable financing for schools to support the effective implementation of the EFA policy. Accordingly, the consultancy has the following sub-objectives:a.	Determining the real/true cost of educating a child in Zambia’s public schools. b.	Assessing the cost differential of running schools factoring in institutional type and spatial considerations (Rural, urban and remoteness); c.	Determining the school-level investment required to provide a quality education under the EFA policy.d.	Understanding the cost of sending children to school  for families (uniforms, supplies, transport, food, books, bags, shoes and other expenses necessary to send children to school) under the EFA policy. e.	Comparison of cost per child expenditures in public, private, community and church run or grant aided institutions;f.	Conducting an international cost comparison of spending per child especially with countries implementing the free education policy to inform government policy; g.	Informing the direction local communities and the private sector can play in education financing to ensure that cost issues are addressed without penalising vulnerable people especially girls and boys;h.	Determining a reasonable cost of education per child measure given the Zambian context; i.	Developing a costing framework that reconciles school and household-based costs of educating children while factoring in institutional type and spatial considerations (Rural, urban and remoteness); andj.	Supporting the GRZ to use the costing framework to inform equitable financing for schools.

title: SSA_2023_Higher Education Gender Analysis Sub Saharan Africa
description: The British Council is seeking proposals from potential suppliers (consultants, research organisations or universities) to conduct a contextualised analysis of the issues and challenges faced by students/young women and men in the context of SSA universities, in relation to how gender impacts their pursuit of entrepreneurship opportunities, as well as their access to opportunities that can enhance their employability.  Study objectives:1.	To produce a Sub-Saharan Africa regional analysis of gender inequality issues (focussing on barriers and challenges faced by students and graduates, particularly women and girls in accessing and participating in employability and entrepreneurship related opportunities) as relevant to the Innovation for African Universities (IAU) programme. 2.	To identify actionable recommendations or key steps that the British Council can take to ensure that gender issues are better integrated into our Higher Education programme offer. 3.	To consider the broader role of Higher Education in contributing to improved gender equality for students and graduates and develop recommendations for our Higher Education sector partners and stakeholders citing gender sensitive or transformative approaches, as well as best practices for addressing gender inequality. 2 Scope:•	The gender analysis will investigate the barriers to entrepreneurship and optimum graduate outcomes, considering the experiences of women as students (at undergraduate and postgraduate level), higher education structures such as  timetabling, flexibility of access and provision and any inherent biases that may exist around gender and the intersection with other social categories. •	The analysis will focus on a selection of countries in SSA (Ghana, Kenya, Nigeria, and South Africa). •	An intersectional approach will be taken, considering how other aspects of identity (race and ethnicity, religion, economic status etc.) intersect with gender and can exacerbate inequalities within the HE sector. Through the services provided by the supplier (through this gender analysis), the British Council will be able to:•	Have an increased and in-depth understanding of gender issues within the HE sector in Sub-Saharan Africa, particularly looking at barriers to women’s access to, participation and representation in structures and activities that promote better graduate outcomes and entrepreneurship. •	Identify pointers for how our work in HE, particularly the Innovation for African Universities can contribute to addressing gender inequalities and lead to improved outcomes for women and girls. This could include what would need to be added to our HE strategy that would enable specific consideration to be given during project design, planning, implementation, and measurement of impact.•	Determine the possible future pathways that can enable us to better addresses gender inequalities through our work with partners in the UK and SSA HE systems to better meet the identified needs of students, particularly girls and women.3. Services: To meet the objectives and comply with the scope guidelines described above, the supplier will provide the following services within the proposed timeframe: •	Undertake an initial briefing with relevant colleagues in the British Council to agree the shape and priorities of this piece of work and review relevant British Council reports and gender toolkit(s).•	Develop specific gender analysis questions and design final report structure and methodology.•	Utilise desk-based research to collect, collate and analyse relevant data.•	Plan and undertake primary data collection across the four priority locations.•	Develop a gender analysis report with actionable recommendations in response to the study objectives and the scope as described above. A first draft is expected by. 4. Deliverables/Outputs: •	1 X SSA gender analysis report •	4 X country-specific summary analyses reports and policy briefs The reports must include actionable recommendations for the British Council, as well as broader insights and recommendations for the HE sectors across the four priority locations. •	Dissemination: Workshops, presentations, webinars delivered for internal staff and possibly external stakeholders to present and explore findings and recommendations. •	Slide deck presentation compiling the key findings and recommendations which can be used to disseminate and showcase the report in a clear and effective way to internal and external stakeholders.•	Relevant collateral facts and figures in the form of graphics, tables, charts, and/or other visual language for data presentation. Facts and figures must be included in a way we can easily extract them to other presentations and/or contexts.

title: SSA_Zambia_2023_Consultancy to design and pilot an intervention to reduce non-educational barriers to wellbeing of adolescent girls in Zambia
description: Objectives. 1.	Review the current issues and approaches to addressing non-education barriers to better outcomes for adolescent girls in Zambia and identify what is working, key problems and gaps including on evidence and data to monitor progress; 2.	Review evidence relating to non-education barriers facing girls and synthesise conclusions on what the evidence shows works; 3.	Provide a technical review of UK funded programming  including bilateral support (on nutrition and social cash transfers), multilateral and centrally managed support (e.g. Global Financing Facility) to interrogate the underlying theory of change,          implementation approaches and lessons learned; 4.	Conduct a political economy and institutional analysis including at sub-national level on how a package of interventions may be best coordinated institutionally. (For example, this could be through District structures, a district/provisional line          ministry or through a school as a hub). 5.	Design an integrated package for addressing non-education barriers around existing support (e.g. Keeping Girls in School cash transfers) that could be scaled up by government with external support. Set out options for piloting looking at scale,          partnership and implementation levels (school, district etc).6.	Pilot 1-3 options for implementing this model at small scale to test/understand the issues/strengths of different models and document learning for GRZ and development partners.7.	Review and propose any linkages to potential investment options e.g. through current/forthcoming FCDO funded programmes, government investment channels e.g Constituency Development Fund or other development partner opportunities.          Assess the extent to which current programming can be adapted or redesigned to support these design options.8.	Present learning and recommendations included costings for a 3-year investment to GRZ and key stakeholders to facilitate a discussion on potential next steps.

title: SSA_Zambia_2023_Development of a Dashboard Concept and tool for Senior Education Officials and School Leaders
description: These terms of reference (TOR) guide an initial effort to develop a dashboard concept and tool for school leaders and senior education officialsa)	The first is to represent the status of the core aspects of education delivery (enrolments disaggregated by sex, class size, teacher pupil ratio, textbook pupil ratio, number of sessions, number of desks etc.) against accepted standards. b)	The second is to represent key expenditure areas against funding sources while constructing a spend pattern and trend starting from 2021 to 2023 as the government is implementing the Free Education Policy. c)	The third is to segment running costs based on school type and location relative to district and provincial administrative units. Hence, the overriding purpose of the dashboard concept is to determine key elements and assemble a tool for school leaders and senior education officials that allows ease of access to and aggregation of school level information on resourcing, spending and service delivery.The four key objectives for this dashboard concept and preliminary tool are, accordingly, to: •	Support the MOE to delineate helpful information points systemically, through a dashboard concept and preliminary tool, that school leaders and senior education officials can use to support policy making; •	Leverage the government’s implementation of the FEP to pragmatically devise an information tool that allows senior education officials to take make adjustments as policy learning happens; •	Segment policy information needs for senior education officials in order to address the diversity of schools given institutional type, geographical location and positioning relative to district and provincial administrative units to inform equity           objectives; and•	Identify the nature of multi-level actor interactions and determine gaps in the generation of education information and their impact on the system in terms of policy making, reforms management, and implementation of interventions needed to bridge those gaps. Ultimately, the overall objective of the dashboard concept and tool is to support an iterative process of policy reflection and adjustment. As such, the development of the dashboard is intended to spur ongoing research that further updates and refines the policy information needs of senior education officials. The FEP presents an opportunity to clarify how policy action can benefit from information tools that are developed pragmatically to benefit from real time policy implementation experiences.

title: SSA_ South Africa_2023_ Monitoring & Evaluation Consultancy for the Digital Standards Development
description: The British Council in collaboration with the South African Department of Basic Education and funded by the Foreign, Commonwealth and Development Office (FCDO) seeks to develop and embed a new policy related to Standards for Digital Technologies in Teaching and Learning in South African schools. The Digital Standards Development Project (herein referred to as DSD project) will be developed through sectoral engagement from academia, civil society, and government. The project delivery partners and other key stakeholders, will work with the British Council and the Department of Basic Education to support the development of such standards, and make recommendations for its implementation.The key deliverables for the project are as follows:●	Government engagement to agree and outline the methodology and approach for the project and sign off baseline and final report●	Input Document which outlines the current state of digital technologies policies in South Africa, current South African and international research, and relevant statistics.  ●	Two policy discourse roundtables held, each with participants drawn from academia, civil society, and government.●	Six working groups formed and meet 4 times, each with 10-20 participants from academia, civil society, and government, and focussing on themes such as teacher capacity, resources and infrastructure, labour market and future jobs, perceptions         and attitudes from parents and communities, curriculum, school leadership, and digital inclusion and the gender gap.●	Digital Standards Document published making recommendations including norms and standards in digital technologies for basic education. The British Council envisions that this project will address key questions:●	What should be the basic infrastructure at a school to enable integration?●	What should teachers be able to do?●	What should be in place at governance level?●	How should ICT be integrated? What is the basic understanding of ICT integration?The goal is to establish a community of practice where people feel they belong and contribute to something that will be taken up by schools around the country. To date, a Baseline Analysis Report (desktop research driven) and Input Document have been developed. The Input Document outlines the current state of digital technologies policies in South Africa, current South African and international research, and relevant statistics. This has been reviewed by the participants in the first consultative workshop held in June 2023.

title: Political Economy Analysis Services for Programme: Promoting Women's and Girls' Education in ASEAN
description: ASEAN has recognised the importance of access to quality learning for all in successive declarations and plans. The ASEAN Declaration on 'Strengthening Education for Out-of-school children and youth (OOSCY, 2016)' recognises that in parts of ASEAN, significant numbers of OOSCY call for action on achieving equal access to education, improved retention and completion of education. The 2019 Bangkok Declaration commits to advancing partnerships in education as part of achieving the Sustainable Development Goals. This will include promoting inclusive education at all levels of education and training to eliminate disparities for the vulnerable and marginalised, those with special needs, and OOSCY. The ASEAN Work Plan on Education 2021-25 sets out a plan to improve access to quality education for disadvantaged youth.British Council is seeking professional adviser for Political Economy Analysis services for Inception phase of Promoting Women and Girls' Education in ASEAN. The period of consultancy is August to October 2023 for up 12 working days. The purpose of the political economy analysis (PEA) is to establish and examine the factors and forces that generate and prolong learning poverty, in a variety of forms, across countries in the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) particularly among girls and members of marginalised groups from Cambodia, Laos, Myanmar, Vietnam (CLMV) as well as Timor-Leste; and to identify potential strategic pathways and opportunities for a new programme that seeks to address these problems.Deadline: Tuesday, 22 August 2023 23:59 UK time

title: Leasing of MPS/printers and maintenance services

The British Council would like to invite tenderers for the leasing of 14 Managed Print Services (MPS)/printers and the provision of maintenance services for our offices in Athens and Thessaloniki. The supplier should be able to support British Council Greece in the locations of Athens and Thessaloniki with a maintenance contract that will have a duration of 4 years.The description of the requirements is clearly defined in the RFP document. Further details can be found in the tender pack and supporting documents.If you are interested in the tender and/or bidding for this project, please go to https://in-tendhost.co.uk/britishcouncil . You will have to register your company before you can express an interest for this project and get access the tender documents. For more questions regarding the MPS/Printers project please contact Thanasis.Tsiroyiannis@britishcouncil.org , and for the procurement process or the in tend platform please contact  nektaria.theodoropoulou@britishcouncil.gr. We would encourage you to submit your questions through in tend platform and we will be able to respond to you in due course.

title: 2023 CPF Project design & management and bid writing training - Nepal
description: Purpose of the ConsultancyWe are looking for a consultant or team to lead a capacity building programme within the heritage protection sector in Nepal.  Apply online by 23:59 (UK time) 25 August 2023.  The Cultural Protection Fund and British Council Nepal team are aiming to strengthen heritage protection capacity in Nepal, through the mapping, networking and training of organisations in or related to the heritage sector. The training for potential applicants will cover project design, project management and proposal writing, signposting to different methods of income generation but specifically referencing the British Council’s Cultural Protection Fund and its application requirements. ObjectivesThe overall objective of the assignment is to equip and strengthen potential cultural organisations and leaders in Nepal with the skills needed to develop, design and write good quality, effective grant proposals – when in turn lead to effective delivery with strong impact and value for money. More specifically, the training should:•	Improve ability to design projects and writing skills of participants•	Increase participant’s understanding of how to develop effective grant applications•	Increase participants’ confidence, knowledge and capacity to plan and deliver outcomes in the heritage protection and related sectors•	Support teams to articulate their contextual challenges and strategic responses into cohesive business cases•	Increase participant’s understanding of grants management, donors’ landscape, models and processes – referring to the Cultural Protection Fund as the primary case study. •	Introduce project management framework and sample templates•	Enhance participant’s knowledge of relevant public resources and international networks See the full RFP for more details, should you have any questions, please email Daniel Head at daniel.head2@britishcouncil.org

title: SSA_2023_Zambia_Secondary Travel Management Services in Zambia
description: The travel agent will be required to:a) Provide the necessary travel booking services and support.b) Negotiate favourable and discounted rates for the British Council with air travel, road transport and accommodation agents and implement them. Provide a transparent and inclusive service fee structure.c) Provide after-hours service.d) Ensure timely notification to the British Council and to travellers of airport closing, cancellations, or delays in flights.e) Update the British Council regularly on cancellation policies and fees of airline and the other relevant travel agents.f) Obtain any reimbursement which may be due on account of cancelled or reissued reservations and/or tickets, unless otherwise stated.g) Notify the British Council of air tickets for revalidation and/or reissue.h) Ensure booking confirmations and payments as required by the airlines and other relevant travel agents are made.i)  Ensure prompt investigation and resolve on any complaints.j)  Provide detailed reporting on the services provided, discounts and benefits received, upon request from the British Council.k) The travel agent shall keep abreast of and provide an information service to the British Council with regard to airport closings, carrier schedule changes, as well as all other alterations, safety conditions which may affect travel and new conditions      affecting travel and to make appropriate adjustments for any change(s) in flight schedules prior to or during the traveller’s official trip, if possible. When necessary, tickets and billings shall be modified or issued to reflect these changes.l)  The travel agent shall be given a copy of the British Council’s travel policy and procedures and the travel agent will ensure that this information is complied with for all official travel.m) Negotiated rates and deals and all corporate agreements must be communicated to the British Council the purpose should be to book the cheapest in-policy fare of the day. The travel agent must be aware of out of policy bookings, or any trip not      booked at the lowest rate;n)  The travel agent must be able to create a temporary reservation with the suppliers and a requisition subject to approval based on Travel policy compliance.o) Travel itineraries must be generated for every approved travel request. This should reflect complete information on status of reservations on all carriers, road transport and accommodation. The travel booker must be made aware of fare      restrictions, post ticketing.p)  Pre – Ticket changes: the travel agent must have the ability to make multiple changes to the travel requirements prior to the approval of the travel request.q)  Post Ticket changes: if open tickets are unused two months prior to expiry, refunds must be applied for by the travel agent. The British Council must be provided with assistance to ensure limited loss as a result of post ticketing changes.r) The travel agent must manage quality control issues and disaster recovery services for all bookings.s) Any other roles that shall ensure the British Councils’ travel business continuously achieves efficiency, value for money, savings in short, medium and long terms with a clear plan.

description: This is a refresh of survey equipment to place our field archaeology research capacity at the forefront ofrapidly developing digital techniques including robotic totals stations and survey grade GNSS positioning.Archaeological fieldwork is the cornerstone of research in the discipline and requires systematic geospatialsurveying. title: Fluorescent Plate Reader
description: The Diabetes Research Group has recently been awarded a translational grant to study mouse and human immune cells in culture in real-time using fluorescent reporters in response to different therapeutic interventions.   At present there is no real-time fluorescent plate reader within the group and thus samples are studied at specific times post-stimulation and thus key cellular changes may be missed. Thus, we are seeking a real-time fluorescent plate reader that can be placed within a 37C incubator.

title: Knock-out Cell Line Generation
description: The title of the wider research project is ‘Repeat-induced mutagenesis in Huntington’s disease’ and the overall aim is to understand how expanded CAG/CTG repeats can cause mutagenesis at the Huntington’s disease locus.Huntington’s disease (HD) is a progressive neurodegenerative disease characterised by involuntary movements, apathy, and cognitive decline. Expansion of CAG/CTG repeats within the HTT gene cause HD. These repeats are genetically unstable, leading to dramatic changes in repeat size, biased towards expansion over an individual’s lifetime. Somatic expansion in affected tissues is thought to modify disease presentation and many genes identified in genome-wide association studies play a role in DNA repair and in repeat instability.Repeat instability, defined as gain or loss of repeat units relies on DNA repair processes although the exact mechanisms are still being elucidated. Although several DNA repair components have been implicated in repeat instability, how they work together and how potential sequence context may influence the process is unclear.Part of this project involves investigating the effects of genes associated with DNA repair on repeat instability. 10 different genes of interest have been identified and to investigate their effect on repeat instability, these genes need to be knocked-out in our custom HEK293 cell line.The requirement is for separate knock-out of 10 genes in an immortalised cell line, GFP(CAG)101, which is HEK293-derived. Vincent Dion et al will provide the original cell line as starting material. This material will be mycoplasma tested before being sent.

title: Archaeological Survey Equipment
description: This is a refresh of survey equipment to place our field archaeology research capacity at the forefront of rapidly developing digital techniques including robotic totals stations and survey grade GNSS positioning.  Archaeological fieldwork is the cornerstone of research in the discipline and requires systematic geospatial surveying.  Advances in technology mean that this refresh in equipment is necessary so that we are at the cutting edge of industry practice and remain competitive. Currently, we have outdated survey equipment to conduct in-field Archaeological research and training. We require a refresh of field survey equipment to bring us in line with current and best practices in the Archaeology profession. The survey equipment must be suitable for all weather fieldwork in the UK in urban and rural environments.To complete the refresh, we require an archaeological equipment pack including the following – Item no.	Requirement	Quantity1	Archaeological Equipment Pack – •	1 x Leica TS16 Package One-man robotic total station running captivate on instrument & controller.•	1 x Traverse kit for robotic total station (2x prism stations with tripods).•	2 x Leica GS16 GNSS packages running captivate on 1 controller provided as base and rover set (including GPS, Galileo, GLONASS and BEIDOU compatibility).•	Roaming Sim Card (12-month package) minimum 500MB per month for RTK link to correction service.•	Leica Smartnet Educational License for RTK correction service.•	Additional accessories and chargers, including full set of batteries and spare batteries, chargers for UK plugs, rugged carry cases, appropriate cleaning equipment (cloths for lenses), weather protection (protective covers).•	Hexagon X-pad fusion download/upload and GNSS post-processing module suitable for use with the Leica equipment listed above.•	The supplier must have a UK-based point-of-contact for after-sales support.•	Equipment operational manuals to be provided (electronic and hard copy).•	Necessary updates to software/firmware when they become available from the manufacturers throughout the life of the equipment at no additional cost.	1 – pack, as specified in requirement section

title: CBC-1641-T-LS Home Recovery Service
description: The Home Recovery Service is designed to be holistic in nature intended to support patients to recover from hospitalisation; to recuperate. The service will remain dynamic, delivered in a way that ensure flexibility to deliver what is necessary across the entire service. The service will foster a culture of independence, working with people to gain confidence with ordinary tasks of daily living. Call times will be agreed with person leaving hospital; specific calls for medication or management of skin integrity will be prioritised.HRS is one ‘whole’ service that is intended to be delivered by two providers. Having two providers ensures that risk to delivery is minimised. As such, providers are expected to work closely together, share good practice, share challenging periods in delivery to maintain the rate of discharges required, work to resolve complex situations and / or scenarios and most importantly put people in need of the service at the forefront of planning and every intervention; providers will be expected to work well in collaboration and support each other’s service delivery & continuity should the need arise.

title: CBC-1636-T-LS IDVA (Independent Domestic Violence Advocacy Service) - CORE - High Risk & Community
description: Central Bedfordshire Council together with Bedford Borough Council wish to commission a provider to offer an IDVA service. You are invited to tender for the IDVA provision to support high risk victims of domestic violence and abuse aged 16 years and over. ‘High risk’ is to be determined by use of the DASH risk assessment scoring matrix, also in use for MARAC referrals, alongside professional judgement where necessary.

title: CBC-1627-T-AS Householder Travel Survey 2024 & 2026
description: Every second year CBC commissions a telephone survey of a representative sample of residents to ask them about how they travel and what they think about transport in CBC. We used the same firm for a number of years (Public Perspectives), and have reached the point where we need to reprocure the work rather than going for a(nother) waiver. The last survey cost £30,000.We would like to let a contract for the 2024 and 2026 surveys. We will also be preparing the new Local Transport Plan, which may require additional research calling for supplementary survey work using comparable methodology so we would like an option to commission this from the same supplier. Estimated spend would be expected to be the maximum over the period including optional work.See full specification document attached.The Council will provide as much support and information as it can to help guide you through the quotation process. Questions asked together with the response, will be made available to all tenderers, to ensure a fair and consistent approach to all.  If there is anything you are not sure about or need clarification on, please use the Correspondence facility within the In-tend electronic tendering system. Last date for receiving questions on the In-Tend system: 6th February 2024 Completed Quotations and attachments should be submitted electronically by the due date via our In-tend electronic tendering system. Quotations must be uploaded via the “My Return” section of the system. Quotations submitted through the correspondence facility will not be considered. Your Quotation must be submitted via the In-tend system by no later than 09.00 on Monday 12th February 2024Quotations received after that time will be excluded.

title: CBC-1597-T-LS Preventative Mental Health Services for Vulnerable Adults
description: Central Bedfordshire Council is undertaking a competitive tendering exercise to secure a provider to manage, develop and deliver a new Preventative Mental Health Service to support vulnerable adults with their mental health who present a range of support needs. The aim is to deliver support within the community that reaches across Central Bedfordshire, ensuring the service is accessible to everyone in a way that suits their needs. This is to enable people who are receiving support to improve their mental health and wellbeing and ensure the service delivers good outcomes for the local population.

title: CBC-1622-P-AE Biggleswade Renewable Energy Development
description: Market Engagement: As part of its work to commission the new Biggleswade super grid substation the council applied for, and accepted, three connection offers for renewable energy connections.The council has always intended to dispose of some of these opportunities and retain others. The council has commenced development work and was progressing all schemes to planning application. The UKPN grid offers have recently returned from National Grid ESO project progression, which has resulted in connection dates being delay until potentially 2032.In light of the new proposed connection dates the council is taking stock of its existing position and determining whether it still wants to proceed to obtaining planning consent for the schemes, or whether it wants to bring additional specialist resources into the delivery of these renewable energy schemes.The council has already retained specialist development advice and grid connection advice, so is not seeking these services. Whether the council proceeds to a disposal or procurement will depend, to an extent, on this market engagement exercise. Prior to commencement of a formal procurement or disposal process, the council will undertake some structured market engagement through the issuing of a Prior Information Notice (PIN). Through this process, the council will seek to define both what the council, and potential partners require and use this to inform an options appraisal before shaping an offer to the market.

title: Refurbishment of public conveniences at Priory Park and Market Road in Chichester; East Beach in Selsey and Bosham Lane in Bosham and  demolition of Tower Street, Chichester, Public Conveniences
description: Chichester District Council invites applications from suitably experienced organisations who wish to be considered for selection to tender for the Refurbishment of public conveniences at Priory Park and Market Road in Chichester; East Beach in Selsey and Bosham Lane in Bosham and  demolition of Tower Street, Chichester, Public Conveniences.The Council`s full requirements and details of how to tender for this opportunity are available by clicking the Express Interest button - see below. The deadline for tender submission is 2pm on Friday 3rd November 2023How to obtain the Tender Documents Interested parties should register their interest in the project via the In-Tend website https://in-tendhost.co.uk/sesharedservices/aspx/Tenders/Current. The Tender documents can be accessed when logged into In-Tend by selecting ‘View Details’ on the relevant tender advert and clicking the ‘Express Interest’ tab. Once in the tender there are five tabs, namely ‘Tender’, ‘ITT – documents’, ‘Correspondence’, ‘Clarifications’ and ‘History’. Select the 2nd tab (ITT - documents) where you will find useful information under ‘Tender Details’. Continue to scroll down to the heading ‘Tender Documents Received’ where you will be able to view / download the documents. Please download all the documents and read very carefully. Opting In and Opting Out Please note you are required to ‘Opt In’ before you can access the ‘My tender Return’ to start populating your response. The ‘Opt Out’ functionality will also be available throughout the duration of the tender process. Opting out will give you the option of declaring you no longer want to receive any further communication in relation to this tender along with the opportunity of providing comments and feedback for this decision. You can choose to ‘Opt In’ at any time during the tender process if you initially decided to ‘Opt Out’. Further Guidance In addition, guidance on how to participate in a tender, download and upload documents / returns and if required, register your company (free of charge) can be found on the In-tend site under the ‘Help’ or ‘Information for Suppliers’ buttons. Receiving Notification Emails To ensure you receive email alerts and notifications from our system, please add the email domain `@in-tendorganiser.co.uk`  to your Safe Senders list.

description: The Services include the delivery of the following business coaching/mentoring services to either a graduate or supported employee or business owner identified by the College in one of the business sectors areas •	Mentoring Services.•	Workshop Delivery Services.•	Expert Speaker Service.Typically, the Services shall be delivered to small and medium-sized enterprises (SME’s) located in Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly however the College may require Suppliers to provide Services throughout the UK.The scale and scope of the individual Services shall be set out by the College within each Tender opportunity at Stage 2 – Further Competition.3.1 Mentoring ServicesFurther to the College identifying a graduate, supported employee or business owner the Supplier shall develop and provide suitably experienced facilitator(s) to deliver the mentoring services which shall include but not be limited to:•	the provision of bespoke external specialist coaching/mentoring services and business development support for a graduate; supported employee or business 1 Funding Body means the body that provides the College with funding for the provision of Training Services.owner focused on a particular SME or SME business sector.•	the provision of either a one-to-one or a one-to-many Service typically at the SME’s premises or at venue decided by the College.•	working with the College Manager to provide the appropriate level of professional support within a named SME.•	delivering the outputs/deliverables as set out in the College’s Stage 2 – Further Competition.3.2.	Workshop Delivery ServicesThe Supplier shall develop and provide suitably experienced facilitator(s) to deliver the workshop delivery services which shall include but not be limited to:•	the provision a single or series of workshops focused on a particular SME or SME business sector.•	the provision of bespoke (as opposed to generic) workshops tailored to:a graduate; supported employee or business owner located within a particular SME as identified by the College.a particular SME business sector area as identified by the College.•	the provision shall be delivered on a one-to-one or a one-to-many basis either as:a classroom learner led style workshop.coaching; mentoring; action learning style workshop.•	the delivery of workshop services which shall be:at either the College or at a venue organised by the College.in both full and half day sessions.at a time, suitable the College’s client.•	the provision of any equipment, materials, literature or handouts required to deliver the workshop service.•	working with the College Manager to provide the appropriate level of professional support within a named SME.•	delivering the outputs/deliverables as set out in the College’s Stage 2 – Further Competition.3.3 Expert speaker Services.The Supplier shall provide an industry expert facilitator(s) to deliver the expert speaker services which shall include but not be limited to:•	the provision a single or group of events focused on a particular SME, SME business sector or theme.•	the events shall be bespoke (as opposed to generic) and tailored to individuals in a particular SME, SME business sector or theme.•	the event shall be delivered on a one-to-many basis.•	the delivery of expert speaker services shall be at either the College or at a venue organised by the College.3.4 title: COV - MARKET ENGAGEMENT - Coventry’s Short Breaks services 2023 – Event 2
description: Are you a provider supporting children with disabilities? If so, we would love to hear from you. Coventry City Council is currently recommissioning its Short Breaks provision for children with disabilities in the city. Coventry’s Short Breaks services are available to all children and young people who have a disability and live in Coventry. They give them an opportunity to join in with an enjoyable activity away from their parents/carers and develop independence. We are holding a second provider event on MS teams on the 30th of November 2pm – 4pm to discuss the modelling stage of Short Breaks following on from our engagement sessions. If you are interested to learn more detail about joining the Coventry City Council framework and would like to take part in the provider event, please complete the provider registration form (see document available under the Synopsis button - top right-hand corner of this page).
