title: COV - Start for Life - Support for Dads
description: The City Council are commissioning a new service specifically for dads which will support father – infant relationships and fathers/non birthing partners mental health and well-being. The Council has received Family Hub and Start Life Funding, and we are a trailblazer site for improving outcomes around Perinatal and Infant Mental Health and Infant Relationships.

title: COV - Mental health support service for victims of domestic abuse
description: The Domestic Abuse Act 2021 introduced new statutory duties on local authorities to provide a range of support to victims in ‘safe accommodation’ (i.e. refuge / dispersed accommodation or sanctuary-type schemes). As an element of a range of support for victims, the City Council introduced a pilot for the provision of a new service, supporting the mental health needs of victims in safe accommodation. This pilot has operated since September 2021 and will expire at the end of June 2024.  Further to the pilot for the provision of a service supporting the mental health needs of victims in safe accommodation ending in June 2024, Coventry City Council wishes to put a new contract in place for this service to commence on the 1st July 2024.  The Provider of this service shall be required to provide mental health support for victims in safe accommodation and potentially additional provision for mental health support for victims accessing community-based provision (subject to new legislation placing a new statutory duty on local authorities and the availability of funding). It is not known at this stage if/when the legislation for victims accessing community-based provision requiring mental support will be approved.   See Invitation To Tender documentation for further details.

title: COV -  Adults Short Term Home Support (2023)
description: The recommissioning of short-term home support services is for adults living at home, to support service users to live as independently as possible. The service will be a short term (up to 6 weeks) reablement services, giving Service Users the opportunity, assistance, and confidence to regain skills they may have lost.   The service will support service users to regain or develop confidence and improve daily living skills.Short Term Home Support is a key feature in the delivery of good health and social care services.  The services support adults to remain living independently in their own homes and provide assistance to people and their carers. The service will be tendered in 8 Lots:  •	6 x zones for day services delivery (paid on a block plus spot basis)•	2 x areas for mobile night carers delivery (paid for on a block basis)

title: COV - Evaluation Consultant Services For St Mary’s Guildhall Transformation Project
description: Coventry City Council is seeking to appoint a suitably qualified and experienced consultant to set a framework for the ongoing evaluation of the refurbishment and new visitor offer of St Marys Guildhall, which will see the continued development of plans to attract new audiences and increase visitor numbers, to provide training to key staff/ volunteers, to produce annual reports of our activity enabling us to reflect and review our activities, and eventually write the final evaluation report in line with current National Lottery Heritage Fund guidance on evaluation.

title: COV - UKSPF - Business Support
description: The UK Shared Prosperity Fund (UKSPF) is a Government (Department for Levelling Up, Housing and Communities (DHLUC)) funded programme, managed by West Midlands Combined Authority. The objectives of the fund are: 	Boost productivity, pay, jobs and living standards by growing the private sector, especially in those places where they are lagging. 	Spread opportunities and improve public services, especially in those places where they are weakest. 	Restore a sense of community, local pride and belonging, especially in those places where they have been lost. 	Empower local leaders and communities, especially in those places lacking local agency.In Coventry the programme will coordinate activities to deliver: 1.) Business support to tackle barriers to: 	Starting and growing businesses developing and launching new products. 	Improving energy and resource efficiency and developing new low carbon products

title: COV - Family Hub AI digital solution
description: This requirement is to develop Coventry City Council’s family hub digital offering to create a digital front door for information for families throughout the City of Coventry. This will include improving access to information provided by the Council and our partners. This will include an AI solution that will enable parents and families to find and access services online. It will also be used by professionals to signpost families to support. The aim is to provide 24/7 access to information on services. This AI function will target and promote relevant topics to users, and a Chatbot to answer common queries. The scope of the contract is for the supply of the solution which includes its implementation (including any configuration), training (if required), annual licencing, hosting, data storage and annual support and maintenance.Please see the Invitation to Tender documents for further information.
first_text: Programming services of packaged software products

description: This contract is for valuation services related to the Council’s company investments, which is an essential requirement of producing the Council’s statutory accounts due to the value of the investments. The successful supplier(s) will be required to produce external valuation reports and provide valuation advice to verify the Council’s internal assessments.

title: COV - Physical activity and community development in Canley & Willenhall
description: Coventry City Council is tendering for organisations to lead and deliver place-based community development work in the communities of Canley and Willenhall. Both areas suffer from stubborn inequalities relating to health and wellbeing. Proposals should include creative engagement methods to connect with residents as well as a range of activities and programmes that are accessible and inclusive.

title: COV - Outdoor Advertising Approved List
description: This Approved List is being established to provide a mechanism for Coventry City Council (“the Council”) to work with selected and approved outdoor advertising organisations to develop billboards and other outdoor advertising initiatives on Local Authority Land in the city of Coventry.The Council are keen to encourage outdoor Advert Developers to work with the Council where opportunities exist to develop innovative advertising displays within the confines of the City of Coventry boundary. This Approved List will only relate to the development of outdoor advertising sites and new advertising initiatives located on COVENTRY CITY COUNCIL LAND and on the adopted highway. This Approved List only relates to the development of outdoor advertising initiatives in Coventry, no other Local Authority is party to this Approved List. •	For clarity outdoor advertising sites relate to: - -	6 sheet (FSU) advertising*. -	48 and 96 sheet billboards. (Backlit and digital)-	Special displays. (e.g., landmark sites, digital and Mega 6 displays).-	Building wraps. -	Other digital formats.-	Advertising on bridge panels.-	Static roundabout panel advertising**.-	Raised 6 sheet advertising***.-	Streetlight banner columns***.-	Static boundary / welcome sign advertising.-	Other outdoor formats.* 6-sheet (FSU) advertising is required from this Approved List, however, requirements within the CV1 postcode are subject to exclusivity rights under a separate agreement that expires during the term of this Approved List agreement.** Static roundabout panel advertising is required from this Approved List, however, a number of roundabouts are subject to exclusivity rights under a separate agreement that expires during the term of this Approved List agreement.*** Raised 6 sheet and banners on street lighting columns are currently not required from this Approved List as the Council is currently under a separate, city-wide exclusive contractual arrangement(s) for this advertising format. However, the Council is including this provision in the event of future requirements.

title: COV - MARKET ENGAGEMENT - Provision of Appointeeship Services
description: Coventry City Council is committed to supporting and stimulating a diverse market for care and support by offering a real choice of opportunities that keep our communities safe and improve their life chances. The aim of this engagement is to provide an outline of our commissioning intentions to potential service providers and to understand the market’s scope of interest and capabilities, before finalising the commissioning strategy for future commissioning of Appointeeship services. The information gathered from this exercise will help shape future proposals including any potential tendering process for new business.

title: COV - CVLR City Centre First Contractor
description: Coventry City Council (“the Council”) has been and will continue to develop the living and working environment within Coventry through a series of programmes that improve the transport infrastructure to attract inward investment and drive the transition from fossil fuel transport to sustainable transportation solutions.One key project in this drive for modal shift is the Coventry Very Light Rail (VLR) project. This project is to develop a VLR product that can be manufactured predominantly in the West Midlands that will drive modal shift within small to medium size urban environments, consistent with many cities within the UK where a standard tram system would not be economically feasible.This system will be a low capital cost for installation and will be environmentally clean at the point of use, which will have a positive impact on air quality, this modal shift is designed to reduce congestion, and as a result, open up the city for investment especially along the route. Please see - https://www.coventry.gov.uk/verylightrail for more background on the project. Following the procurement and delivery of Coventry Very Light Rail (CVLR) test tracks at locations in Whitley, Coventry (TP1) and Dudley (TP2); the Council is preparing to deliver the next project stage of delivering a City Centre First demonstrator.  City Centre First will be a test track facility constructed in a live environment and will be made up of a combination of single track and double track lengths. The purpose of the City Centre First is to prove the assertions made during the development phase of the track form in the real-world environment. City Centre First is broken into 2 sections (Phases) of approximately equal length (800m each).This procurement is to award a contract for a contractor to deliver the construction of City Centre First Phase 1 (and potentially extend to cover the construction of Phase 2) . The scope will include:•	construction of phase 1 of the test track (and phase 2 if extended)•	construction of a cycle lane •	the ordering of materials for Phase 1 as required by the Council for the construction  (and phase 2 if extended)Please see the Standard Questionnaire and accompanying Works Information for more details on the procurement / requirement.

title: External Audit Services
description: Coventry University is inviting tenders from firms of auditors to provide us with a comprehensive external audit service for a period of five years with the option for an additional two year extension.  Contract extension is subject to satisfactory contract performance reviews.  The firm appointed must satisfy the criteria for eligibility as external auditors of Higher Education Institutions as set out in the OfS accounts direction, including being Listed on the register of Statutory Auditors and in respect of any audits of registered companies to which they may be appointed, must satisfy the relevant requirements of the Companies Act 2006.Coventry University regards the following as key requirements in meeting its needs:•	maintaining a high degree of continuity of staff involved from the appointed firm as very desirable, especially senior levels i.e. the partner and manager, but also with the audit staff;•	thorough knowledge of UK Higher Education sector finance practice•	awareness of current strategic issues and challenges that face the HE sector.•	ability to respond dynamically to the challenges presented by the complexity of Coventry University group.Tender returns must be received by the Tender Response Deadline and must be signed by an authorised representative of the Tenderer. description: As part of Cranfield University’s decarbonisation process, it intends to remove gas fired boilers by extending the existing low carbon district heating network to the residential site on the campus. title: Crawley, Horsham, Mid Sussex and Mole Valley Electoral Print and Mail
description: Crawley Borough Council (lead procuring authority), Horsham District Council, Mid Sussex District Council and Mole Valley District Council each require a long term agreement, commencing 1st April 2024, for the provision of electoral print services.Each Participating Authority's contract will include for all the printing requirements of each Council's elections department, including but not limited to the poll cards and ballot papers for elections, the annual canvass exercises and for some Councils the Household notification letters.The appointed supplier will also be responsible for sourcing the materials to be printed on (card/paper etc.) and will be responsible for overseeing the posting/mailing requirements. It is anticipated that the postal element will be subcontracted by the appointed supplier but they will remain responsible for managing and overseeing this element.The appointed supplier must be capable of integrating with each Council's Election Management System; both their current system and their future system in the event Councils change their systems during the lifetime of their contracts.Each participating authority requires a contract lasting six years, up to 31st March 2030, with no extension options built in. This tender will have four independently awardable lots (one for each Council's contract).

title: CBC & HDC - Treasury Management Advisers
description: Crawley Borough Council and Horsham District Council (the Councils) invites tenders for the provision of Treasury Management Advisory Services as set out in these documents. For the purpose of this procurement exercise, Crawley Borough Council is the lead procuring Authority.The Commencement Date for the delivery of the services is scheduled to be on Monday 1st April 2024 at 00:00 hours.  The Contract will be awarded for a period of four years until Friday 31st March 2028.  The Councils are procuring this contract following the Open Procedure under the UK Public Contract Regulations 2015 and the Council’s Procurement Code.  The Councils will be awarding one Contract each for the provision of all services detailed in the Specification. Each Council will be issuing its own Contract to the winning bidder. The Councils are seeking to contract with an organisation that will manage the Services to the highest levels of satisfaction, professional standards and cost effectiveness.  The Contractor will be expected to deliver improvements to service delivery and value for money over the life of the contract.  This Information for Bidders document contains the information and instructions that Bidders need to ensure that a compliant and completed tender is submitted.  Please read the Information for Bidders document carefully as failure to comply with any instructions may result in the rejection or disqualification of your tender from this tender process.

title: 1877 Provision of Replacement Networking Solution for De Monfort University, Leicester
description: The University requires the Provision of Replacement Networking Solution.DMU has operated its existing campus network design and infrastructure since 2011. Our business model and demands of our customers have changed significantly during this period, as has the technical capabilities that network providers can deliver.  The existing solution, whilst functional, is now end of life and cannot deliver the functionality required to securely support the growing digital demands of our users. Unless our campus network infrastructure is upgraded, we are unable to provide the enhanced security benefits and functionality of a modern, supported network and deliver the foundational elements that underpin our approved digital strategy. Following the carrying out of a thorough network / market review at a vendor level, DMU has now identified that Extreme networks can provide and offer the best optimal technology to support DMU’s future requirements. The Extreme wired network will also integrate well with our existing HP Aruba WiFi technology, to allow us to maximise recent investments in this area. This choice will also support the desired move to a hybrid cloud architecture, providing fast, secure, resilient access to systems regardless of their locationAn internal business case has been produced and signed off within DMU and now DMU wish to proceed ahead with a competitive procurement to purchase such a replacement network. This procurement represents a Further Competition against the Crown Commercial Services (CCS) Framework RM6116 Network Services 3 (Framework), Lot 2a LAN: Local Connectivity Services; in order to now identify a trusted Extreme partner for the University to work with going forward that can provide a finalised design / Bill of Materials and implement / support a modern, secure and robust campus network in 2024 that will underpin the creation of a smart digital campus for DMU for the future.Full details of the University’s Requirements can be found in the Specification contained within this ITT (Schedule 2). As already alluded to in the preceding paragraphs above, DMU has now settled on a chosen technology platform going forward, following the carrying out of a comprehensive network / market review and now wishes to procure a Solution and associated working partner. This procurement is open to any supplier present on Lot 2a of the above-mentioned Framework, who is therefore certified / able at to provide the specified technology referred to in the paragraphs above, and as set out in more detail in our Requirements at Schedule 2 of this ITT.

title: Renewal of Microsoft Licencing and Associated Support Services
description: Renewal of Microsoft Licencing and Associated Support Services.De Montfort University (‘DMU’, also referred to as the ‘University’), the Member institution, requires to renew its’ current provision of Microsoft Licencing and Associated Support Services, for which this Invitation for Quotation (“ITQ”) is being issued in connection with; as a mini-competition procurement under the SUPC (Southern Universities Purchasing Consortium) SLRA (Software Licence Resellers Agreement) Lot 1 ‘Microsoft and Associated Services’ (OJEU Contract Notice 2020/S 033-078650, Ref: ITS4042SU).Only those suppliers present on the above-mentioned Framework and Lot may respond in connection with this mini-competition to provide the stated solution / services within this ITQ to De Montfort University. For the absolute avoidance of doubt, no suppliers not present on the above stated Framework and Lot will be invited to take part in this mini-competition.The University’s scope and objectives relating to the Renewal of its Microsoft Licencing and Associated Support Services provision, are as set out below and in the documents incorporated later on as part of this ITQ, for which you are asked to provide a costed and appropriately described Quotation.As part of DMU’s digital transformation journey, it is proposed that the use of MS365 services will increase to support modern, digital ways of working, as such the university is looking for an MS365 partner to support elements of this and ensure best value is received from the investment into MS365 licensing. DMU’s existing three-year Microsoft EES license agreement expires on September 30th 2023. The University wishes to procure Microsoft license for a further 3 (three) years from October 1st 2023, ensuring no loss of service during the transition. In parallel to the license procurement, DMU also wish to explore options available for MS365 support services, with the ability for DMU technical staff to raise proactive and reactive service tickets to support our environment. Pricing shall therefore be submitted separately for each of licencing and support services and DMU may look to make a single award for all this business or separate awards for each of licencing and support as a result of this mini-competition procurement exercise taking place. A number of Method Statements also require responding to in respect of accounting for Quality matters.

title: 1999 Provision of Career Platform Solution for De Montfort University, Leicester
description: A market leading careers system is a key element for the University achieving strong overall student destination outcomes, as measured by the Graduate Outcomes Survey. DMU currently has room for improvement on both Graduate Outcomes results rates and the amount of DMU students progressing into highly skilled employment. A careers system that provides a better student experience, and crucially delivers on improving our employer engagement capabilities could be seen as a game changer. With so many DMU students falling into a widening participation category, it is essential that we are providing them with market leading careers technology that will place them on a level playing field with more privileged peers. The University needs to offer a careers service platform that has a strong competitive positioning in the marketplace, which will frame the University’s future offer over the next decade and best supports the Empowering University strategy. This consequently requires a careers system that supports this strategic ambition and delivers the flexibility to enable the University Careers Team to deliver on its strategic aims.All Tenderers should have due regard for these wider high level strategic aims alongside responding to the stated Functional or Non-Functional Requirements at Schedule 2 forming part of the ITT.Full details of the University’s Requirements can be found in the Specification (Schedule 2).

title: Wellbeing Support Service for Carers
description: Dudley MBC are looking to commission a provider(s) to work in partnership with the councils Carers Network Team to deliver an all-age carers services ‘Dudley Carers Hub and Wellbeing Service’.   To achieve this the council will be commissioning the service in 4 separate lots•	LOT 1 – Carers Digital Service – to provide a new innovative and proactive digital based service which will identify, engage and support all carers through web-based, app-based and social media platforms to carers in Dudley.•	LOT 2 – Adult Carers Wellbeing Service – to provide targeted preventative support to carers aged 18 and above, to understand their rights as a carer and support available to them, through quality information, advice and awareness/training on aspects of caring such as:• financial and legal (i.e. navigating welfare benefits systems, power of attorney, preparing to pay for care)• practical training and awareness to support carers to care safely (i.e. first aid / mental health first aid)• wellbeing support and activities (i.e. recreational or relaxation activities, life planning, coaching and mentoring,) to enable carers to gain confidence, self-help and personal skills.•	LOT 3 – Preventative Carer Short Break Service – to provide a new innovative, flexible short term, short break service for carers at risk of carer breakdown or in need ad hoc support to access one off appointments / activities, providing a break from caring and enabling the carer to focus on their own personal activities to manage their health and wellbeing.•	LOT 4 – Young Carers Service – to provide targeted support to children and young people aged 5 – 17 years to achieve positive outcomes during childhood, the service will:• promote and identify young carers living in the borough, • support young carers to have the same life opportunities as their peers, • work in partnership with key partners and stakeholders to ensure that children and young people access support

title: Accommodation with Housing Related Support for Homeless Adults
description: Dudley MBC  is seeking provision of accommodation with housing related support for adult single people and couples aged over 18 years of age who are priority and non-priority homeless, at risk of becoming homeless or sleeping rough who need immediate access to housing and support in order to prevent homelessness in the Dudley boroughThe service must work positively and proactively with other accommodation-based services to identify a wide range of longer-term accommodation possibilities and facilitate access and referral to them. As part of individuals move on plans the service must include some transition work with appropriate community/floating support services where needed to ensure continuity of support to mitigate anxieties of moving onto independent living and setting up and sustain their new tenancy.   All aspects of support within the service should enable individuals to live independently and sustain their tenancy or home and prevent the need for more intensive support.   The service must provide person-centred, structured and outcome focussed support based on an individual’s identified support needs and work positively and proactively with other appropriate services to ensure those support needs are met in a co-ordinated and holistic way. The goal being to prepare individuals for move on to an independent tenancy elsewhere.
second_text: Property management services of real estate on a fee or contract basis

title: Dudley Child Vision Screening
description: The UK National Screening Committee (UKNSC) recommends vision screening in 4–5-years old children to detect reduced or abnormal vision in one or both eyes; primarily to detect amblyopia, a form of abnormal vision system development, including strabismus and refractive error. Early detection of amblyopia may result in the avoidance of permanent visual impairments by allowing earlyintervention. The direct health outcome is the optimal development of vision for children with amblyopia though prompt access to treatment. Children are not often able to recognise if they have poor vision, whether this be in one or both eyes, hence the need for an objective screening test to determine visual acuity.CohortThe target population is 4–5 years old primary school entrant age children across Dudley. There is estimated to be approximately 4000 children in this age group per academic year. The Service operates within the boundaries of Dudley Council and therefore will include children whose family live outside the Dudley area, but the child attends a school within Dudley. This includes children attending mainstream and special schools, independent schools and children who are not in education, including those electively home educated.The service also includes targeted screening for preschool children who are referred for assessment via their Health Visitor. Figures from recent years estimate these to be less than 200 children in a year.Safeguarding needs would always override any boundary discrepancy if services were needed.ExclusionScreening will not be delivered to any child where:• They are already receiving care from specialist optometry services.• Parent / carer consent is not provided.AimsThe aim of this service is to identify children, aged 4 to 5 years old, and preschool aged children who are referred in by health visitors, with impaired sight enabling timely intervention. The service will aim to assess the eyesight of reception age children attending mainstream, independent and special schools and children who are home-schooled; in addition to preschool children who are referred in by their Health Visitor.
third_text: Eye care products and corrective lenses

title: Shared Lives Re-Tender
description: The Provider will deliver a Shared Lives Scheme in Dudley that:-	Will be provided for all adult person’s assessed as being in need of care and support under the Care Act 2014 Eligibility Criteria, who live in the borough of Dudley, this includes adults 18 upwards with complex needs, mental ill health and older adults.-	Will provide support and accommodation to adults providing them with the opportunity to live in a family home with appropriate care and support.-	Provide support for young people preparing for adulthood  - The Scheme will attend Education and healthcare Plan (EHCP) reviews, Looked After Children (LAC) reviews and Pathway Plan Reviews to provide information and advice on Shared Lives for young people from 14+ as part of the initial planning. The Scheme will offer Short-Breaks post 16+, enabling the young adult to experience and become familiar with a Shared Lives Arrangement before they reach the age of 18. The Scheme will also provide guidance to Foster Carers on the assessment process to become Shared Lives Carers, should they wish to continue to support the eligible young adult post 18.  -	Provide arrangements that may be live in or short term including short breaks.Full details available in tender pack - https://in-tendhost.co.uk/blackcountryportal/aspx/Help

title: Central Co-ordinating Service for Dudley’s Peer to Peer Support Programme
description: Dudley Metropolitan Borough Council is looking to commission, by tender, a Central Co-ordinating Service able to deliver the Authority’s vision for Peer to Peer support. Peer to Peer support services are a keystone of the Governments Family Hubs and Start for Life Programme and this service will contribute directly to the expansion of reach; extension of scope and enhancing of accessibility highlighted in that guidance:https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/1096786/Family_Hubs_and_Start_for_Life_programme_guide.pdfIt will enable providers, who understand the context of Dudley Borough, to create the capacity and capability to deliver in aggregate the Peer to Peer support network described in the guidance.Delivery of the tender will be between September 2023 and 31st March 2025. The overall value of this tender will be £275,000 with a requirement that a minimum of 65% (£178,750) of this value must be used in grants to improve the capacity or capability of Peer to Peer Support Services and the balance will fund the co-ordination and development functions described within this document. The Authority seeks a high quality comprehensive network of peer to peer service to be available across the Authority area. This will require the successful bidder to undertake grant funding exercises with organisations that are well placed to deliver to families across Dudley Borough.

title: Dudley Holiday Activities & Food Programme 2023
description: Dudley is looking for a lead support provider who will facilitate the delivery of appropriate activity that will achieve the outputs and wherever possible the outcomes required of the HAF programme by the Department for Education (DfE).  The expectation is that the support provider will, as a minimum, lead on:a)	the promotion of the offer to both current and new providers as well as in appropriate communities (Both geographical and thematic) b)	managing all elements of the Grant programme within the HAF financial envelope, ensuring that it is fully inclusive (covering age, ability, ethnic minority communities) and that the amount of grant distributed is maximised to achieve the greatest impact in relation to: i)	numbers that access the activities on offerii)	 other outputs achieved and iii)	contribution to longitudinal outcomes at both the micro and macro levelc)	ensuring it is available to the appropriate children and young people across the Borough and what is offered meets the various needs that prevaild)	maximising the quality of what is offered by ensuring that third party providers who have received grants meet the requirements stipulated by the DfEe)	undertake mystery shopping principles, through sampling, around the delivery of different activities resourced via the overarching grant to ensure that the quality of delivery is of a required standardf)	Identifying added value opportunities that include but are not limited too those identified on page 4 of the Specificationg)	The ongoing development and delivery of a steering group whereby appropriate membership and attendance, including that from the Council, is evidenth)	the production of associated reports as required by the DfE’s terms of granti)	support the Council as needed around all statistical and narrative returns to the DfE terms of grantAll of the Programme delivery must be based on the National HAF Guidance Model which is accessible via the link identified below: https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/holiday-activities-and-food-programme/holiday-activities-and-food-programme-2023The primary purpose of the HAF grant that each local authority receives from the DfE is to make free places at holiday clubs available in Easter, Summer and Christmas to children and young people in the Dudley Borough who receive benefits-related free school meals.  The age range of children and young people who can access the HAF offer is for children and young people from reception to Year 11 (inclusive)The aim of the services offered during these three main holiday periods is to ensure that children and young people that are entitled to Free School Meals (FSM) have access to activities at no additional cost to their families. In addition there is also the ability to facilitate access to the HAF provision to other vulnerable children and young people that do not currently access FSM.

title: Business Case for Cafe and Visitor Facility at The Leasowes
description: Dudley Council is seeking a suitably qualified and experienced consultant to develop a business case for the establishment of a café / visitor facility for The Leasowes. We expect the work to entail as a minimum the following key elements;•	Review design work already undertaken and suggest improvements / enhancements or highlight risks associated with the design that Dudley has already produced  •	Assess the marketplace and the strategic context for the project (including current and potential visitors to the site and competitors in the local area). This should include an assessment of likely annual visitor figures at the site.•	Work with Council staff and other key stakeholders (including community groups) to gain an understanding of the wider view of The Leasowes and its likely future role as a day visit attraction. •	Provide lessons learnt from other projects, using the experience of your consultancy in advising on similar projects elsewhere.•	Provide options for delivery and operation of the facility to include an assessment of likely income to the Council from a lease to a third party as well as an assessment of other methods of operation with an assessment of the risks and benefits of each.•	Provide options for external funding for the project.

title: C241 Structured Coring Programme
description: The aim of the coring programme is to improve the service performance of Statutory Undertakers with regards to reinstatement works conducted on the highway and to ensure the integrity of the highway network and its asset is maintained. The coring programme will vastly improve the build quality of reinstatements on the highway, this in turn will reduce the risk of potholes, depressions, and remedial works on the highway. Dudley Councils intention is to select a sample size of approximately 2% of suitable permanent reinstatements registered by each Works Promoter during the chosen sample period (annum). The extent of the sites and the number of cores on each site cannot be pre-determined, however based on previous years’ experience and budgets going forward we anticipate between 1200 cores per year will be required however, this quantity is indicative only and cannot be the guaranteed quantity of cores for the contract years

title: Provision of Library and Archive Services

title: RFQ Belle Vale Retaining Wall, Halesowen -  Repair Works
description: The existing stone retaining wall adjacent Belle Vale supports Council owned land. The wall has been subject to several localised collapses and consequently works are required to stabilise the wall.It is proposed to lower the height of the existing wall to 1.3m and to fell the trees on the land up to 15m to the rear of the wall and regrade the ground to a suitable gradient.  The trees removed from the site will be replaced in a planting scheme approved by the Authority. The deadline for submissions to the InTend portal is 13:00hrs Monday 8th January 2024.https://in-tendhost.co.uk/blackcountryportal/aspx/Home

title: EBC - RB - Resident Survey
description: Elmbridge Borough Council would like to survey our residents on council services and their views on council services using the Local Government Association's (LGA) standard question set.We require a supplier to undertake a residents telephone survey on our behalf. We are looking for a representative sample of 500 responses representative of our demographics, taken within a maximum 6 month period.We will provide the question set and ask that you provide a strategy to record 500 residents responses via phone. Details of Resident Survey draft questions are in separate document Appendix A.We would like a weekly update on responses, plus a detailed evaluation / responses report when complete based on pre agreed criteria, probably a written report and data tables rather than raw data.Please provide costings based on the specification.The following criteria are important:•	Proven track record within Local Govt for residents surveys via phone and gaining the required responses.•	A cost-effective approach.•	Responsive account management•	Able to undertake work in the required timeframe.

title: NHLF Evaluation  - Berwick Barracks "The Living Barracks"
description: We are seeking to appoint an Evaluation Consultant to oversee the evaluation of The Living Barracks project to support staff, volunteers, and partners through training, advice, and mentoring, to monitor and analyse data through project delivery, and to collate and produce the final Evaluation Report for the project which should encompass outputs, outcomes, impacts, lessons learned and legacy. The evaluation must encompass both qualitative and quantitative factors as determined by our CDF grant and must meet pre-set 6-monthly and annual deadlines to provide evaluation information to the national-level evaluation team. Attached to this tender is the brief, as directed by the CDF, and an indicative programme of works.Fees for this body of work are limited to £50k and there is a requirement for an immediate start.This work can be compiled alongside the earlier tender of the NLHF evaluation however, it must be clear that both are separate pieces of work, with different schedules of reporting.

title: NLRV - Cottage Refurb
description: Overhaul of the cottage with associated servicesWorks to include:•	Overhaul and repair of the roof and rainwater goods.•	Replacement of joinery and introduction of timber shutters.•	Overhaul of the internal spaces.•	Formation of a WC.•	Creation of Services•	Bring the building to a viable use of the EH staff and Volunteers.
second_text: Roof works and other special trade construction works

title: Northington Grange - Roofing repair and replacement design
description: English Heritage are seeking to appoint a design consultant to:•	Design and evaluate re-roofing options through RIBA Stages 1-4 (EH Stages 1 – 2) to the Auditorium (Opera House) and Portico (Mansion House) at Northington Grange. •	Further assess minor works identified to the entire scope of the mansion house roof, including the lead flashing and asphalt covering of the central roof well; slate slopes; valley gutters and hips.•	Assess high-level masonry and render works required in association with the roofing works.•	Architect services through RIBA Stage 5 (EH Stage 3)
third_text: Roof works and other special trade construction works

title: Security Consultancy and Services at Stonehenge (2023 - Reissued)
description: English Heritage is seeking a contractor to provide English Heritage with security consultancy in respect of property, exhibits, ancient monuments and visitor operations at Stonehenge, monitoring and evaluating the effectiveness of the site’s manned security contract and sharing knowledge, policies and procedures with the Stonehenge operations and management team as well as acting as English Heritage’s main security consultant in respect of planning and managing the annual Solstice and Equinox ceremonies at Stonehenge, developing and implementing a security plan, working alongside other stakeholders and agencies in the delivery of safe and secure events.
third_text: Public security, law and order services

title: Site Admissions Buildings - Costed Design Guide
description: The project aims to streamline and standardised new and replacement SABs across the English Heritage Trust (EHT) property portfolio by developing a costed design guide including architectural concept drawings for the four different unit sizes. This will inform the employer’s requirements for individual SAB buildings at EHT sites.

title: The Connectivity Programme: Network Upgrade
description: English Heritage is embarking on a key digital upgrade. Our current project aims to transition from our existing MPLS network to a Software-Defined Wide Area Network (SD-WAN). This change aligns with our commitment to continually enhancing the experiences we offer our visitors.In preparation for the delivery of SD-WAN in 2024, there's also a need to update the LAN hardware at several of our sites. Consequently, the purpose of this tender document is to procure, pre-stage, and install the new network switches, ensuring our infrastructure is robust and ready for the upcoming advancements.We are seeking potential partners who can ensure that our network infrastructure meets the demands of the future.

title: Pensions Consultancy Service for English Heritage
description: We are seeking to appoint a pensions consultancy to:•	Review the appropriateness of our current defined contribution default pension fund, and provider, relative to the profile of our workforce•	Do a detailed governance review of the pension fund and provider annually, relative to investment performance, customer service, etc.•	Produce and update EH’s pensions literature for the workforce, so that it is accessible and easily understood•	Keep EH up to date with changes to pensions legislation and best practice and make suggestions as to how pensions operations could be improved.
fourth_text: Brokerage and related securities and commodities services

title: Building Carbon Reduction Programme Phase 2  BMS Upgrades at Osborne House
description: The heating systems at Osborne House are from a variety of generations, including original Victorian heating installations in the Durbar and Pavilion areas, through to modern heating installations in the Spur Wing, PoQ, and Barrack Block. The heating systems are all well maintained, with recent reboiler works completed to ensure suitable heating provision. The controls systems for these heating systems have not been upgraded and currently offer limited functionality which could reduce energy consumption.The intention of upgrading the controls systems is to raise the level of feedback and control functionality such that the site teams are able to more accurately control the heating to meet building needs and reduce energy consumption and carbon emissions by reducing overall heating use to meet demand.

title: English Heritage Electronic Point of Sales (EPoS) - System Implementation and Support Partner

title: Supply and Installation of Solar Home System for the Vulnerable Youth and Women in Southwestern Ethiopia
description:
GGGI invites eligible and qualified suppliers and service providers to submit their bids for the supply and installation of 300 solar Home Systems for vulnerable communities around southwestern Ethiopia under the ‘Conservation and Sustainable Management of Forested Landscape in Southwestern Ethiopia’ project.
 PROJECT BACKGROUND:
Having access to modern energy sources is essential for economic development and livelihood improvement. Access to modern energy supports both income generation activities and the national development agenda through improving education, reducing indoor air pollution, and enhancing environmental sustainability. The Ethiopian energy sector faces the dual challenges of limited access to modern energy and heavy reliance on traditional biomass energy sources to meet growing demand. While Ethiopia has seen dramatic economic growth in recent years, sustaining this growth into the future will require a dramatic expansion of energy supply. Power generation for the electric grid in Ethiopia currently depends almost entirely on hydropower. There are stark differences in the rate of electricity access in urban and rural areas—in urban areas 87% of the population has access to electricity, while in rural areas electricity access remains extremely low at about 5%. Eighty-three percent of the population resides in rural areas, largely relying on traditional biomass energy sources for cooking and heating. Electricity is mostly used by urban households and small industries. Ethiopia has less than 50% electricity access currently and the government of Ethiopia has planned to achieve 100% access by 2025 with 65% from grid power and 35% from off-grid power.
Under the NEP Implementation Roadmap, the GoE accords a targeted focus for achieving universal access for all social services delivery institutions as a top priority—especially in the education and health sector. While electricity access rates achieved to date in schools and health facilities are relatively higher than for households, they remain short of providing universal access, and they will hence be given priority.
 SCOPE OF WORK, SUPPLIES, and SERVICES: 
The objective of this project is to electrify 300 households for the vulnerable youth and women in southwestern Ethiopia found in Kaffa, Konta, and Dawuro zones to enhance the livelihood of the community in the off-grid area. This tender process relates to the solar off-grid electrification of home systems.
 The major Goods supplied and installed are listed below.
•	Supply and installation of the PV module, PV module structure, and complete mounting kit.
•	Supply and installation of the Battery Energy Storage System (BESS), control board, inverter, distribution board, cable and cable routing, and all relevant accessories and auxiliaries
•	Supply and installation of power cables and cable routing, and other materials as indicated on the bill of quantity
   For more details, please refer to the Request for Proposals (RFP) document attached. 
 IMPORTANT TIMELINES:
Design review, supply, installation, and commissioning of the system are planned for an estimated period of six (6) months.  
The tender submission deadline is 24 January 2024, 16:00 pm KST (Korean Standard Time).
If any bidder has any request for clarification on the TOR or any part of the tender documents, GGGI will be happy to clarify if they are received on or before 7 days before the deadline (namely: if the tender submission deadline is 16:00 15 April KST, then the due date for submission of request for clarification is 16:00 8 April KST).
 Interested parties will be required to register their details on the GGGI e-Green Procurement Portal (https://in-tendhost.co.uk/gggi).
 HOW TO OBTAIN THE DOCUMENTS:
Documents can be accessed via the e-Green Procurement Portal by selecting ‘View Details’ on the relevant notice and then clicking the ‘Tender Application’ button. If you are a new supplier, you will be required to register your details. If you have an existing account, you will need to login to the portal. Please refer to the guidance documents under the `Supplier Guidance` area of the portal for further information.
 ONLINE TENDER MANAGEMENT:
Once in the Tender Management Area for the tender, there are five possible tabs: ‘Tender’, `Tender Documents`, ‘Correspondence’, ‘Clarifications’ and ‘History’. Select the 2nd tab (`Tender Documents`) where you will find useful information regarding the RFP. Scroll down to the heading ‘Tender Documents Received’ where you will be able to view / download the documents.
 OPTING IN & OPTING OUT:

Opting out will give you the option of declaring you no longer want to receive any further communication in relation to this tender along with the opportunity of providing comments and feedback for this decision. You can choose to ‘Opt In’ at any time during the tender process if you initially decided to ‘Opt Out’.

title: Development of Project Concept Note and Pre-Feasibility Study for Agricultural Waste Circular Economy Project in the Philippines for Green Climate Fund
description:
GGGI Philippines is inviting eligible firms/entities to submit their proposals for the following scope of work:
 PROJECT BACKGROUND:
GGGI is implementing the “Strengthening Access to GCF through Project Pipeline Development (2022-2024)” project in partnership with Korea International Cooperation Agency (KOICA). KOICA has been accredited to the Green Climate Fund (GCF) since July 2021 and has developed a strategic direction to support the Government of the Philippines to better access the GCF through the KOICA – as one of the GCF’s accredited entity (AE) – by originating impactful projects alongside with the partner government and leveraging its own grant resources as co-financing resources to scale impacts. KOICA has partnered with GGGI as a technical partner to do a needs assessment and necessary pre-feasibility study to produce project concept notes (PCNs) which can be further developed as full funding proposals (FPs) for the GCF. 
 The ultimate objective of this undertaking is to develop two (2) Project Concept Notes (PCNs) for the Philippines with KOICA as an AE to be submitted to the GCF. The project’s targeted Outcomes, Outputs, and Activities are as follows:
1.	Outcome 1: Prioritized climate finance areas identified
2.	Outcome 2: Capacity to access to finance increased
3.	Outcome 3: Project pipeline development strengthened
 OBJECTIVE OF THE ASSIGNMENT:
GGGI seeks to engage a consulting firm to develop a PCN and prepare a pre-feasibility study under Outcome 3, for implementing agricultural waste circular economy projects in the Philippines. The development of the PCN shall be based on the completed agricultural waste circular economy needs assessment report (Outcome 1). During the preparation of PCN, the consulting firm is expected to conduct capacity building activities to the NDA and relevant organizations in enhancing access to the GCF as part of Outcome 2. 
 PROPOSED ACTIVITIES:
The scope of work for this assignment includes the following:
a)	Development of a Draft PCN  
b)	Preparation of the Pre-Feasibility Study 
c)	Final PCN
d)	Capacity Development 
 For more details, please refer to the Terms of Reference (TOR) document attached. 
 IMPORTANT TIMELINES:
The tender submission deadline is 10 January 2024, 16:00 pm KST (Korean Standard Time).

title: Development of Private Sector Engagement Strategy, Indonesia
description:
GGGI is inviting eligible firms/entities to submit their proposals for the following scope of work under Green Climate Fund (GCF) Readiness and Preparatory Support project (“the Readiness Project”) in Indonesia:
 PROJECT BACKGROUND:
Through the GCF Readiness project, the National Designated Authority (NDA) has conducted a study on sector prioritization for utilization of climate finance sources, in which two priority sectors are identified for mitigation: Energy, Forest and Land Use (FOLU), and two under adaptation: Food, and Water. Ministry of Finance (2021) has identified that most of the private climate financing in the past decade was dedicated to mitigation, dominated by renewable energy and sustainable transport. Despite its tremendous potential economic value, private finance flows for adaptation projects remain very limited. Private sector investment for climate finance face common issues that are centered around the risk level and familiarity with the sectors. The NDA has also conducted a study aimed at assessing appropriate provisions to encourage private sector engagement in climate change adaptation projects in Indonesia. The study could gather that the private sector investment in water, agriculture, and health sectors is quite limited. There is also the underlying cause regarding the private sector’s lack of awareness about climate change and the growing assumption putting the government as the sole responsible party.
Pursuant to one of the Readiness outcomes to encourage private sector investment in climate activities, a strategy for private sector engagement for the selected priority sectors needs to be developed.
 OBJECTIVE OF THE ASSIGNMENT:
GGGI seeks to contract an eligible consulting firm to develop the private sector engagement strategy for priority sectors in mitigation and adaptation, with the objective to enhance private sector engagement in financing, supporting and implementing climate actions and therefore contributing to the Indonesia’s NDC.
 PROPOSED ACTIVITIES:
The selected Firm shall perform the following activities:
a.	Conduct initial assessment of relevant private sector actors 
b.	Conduct a situation analysis for the selected sectors 
c.	Develop the private sector engagement strategy and workplans with a clear roadmap 
d.	Lead stakeholder consultations and workshop. 
 For more details, please refer to the Terms of Reference (TOR) document attached. 
 IMPORTANT TIMELINES:
This project is expected to be completed over a period of 6 months.
The tender submission deadline is 29 November 2023, 16:00 pm KST (Korean Standard Time).
If any bidder has any request for clarification on the TOR or any part of the tender documents, GGGI will be happy to clarify if they are received on or before 7 days before the deadline (namely: if the tender submission deadline is 16:00 15 April KST, then the due date for submission of request for clarification is 16:00 8 April KST).

title: SUPPLY AND INSTALLATION OF 3 WATER SAVING IRRIGATION SYSTEMS IN 2 DISTRICTS IN KARAKALPAKSTAN
description:
GGGI Uzbekistan Country Office invites eligible suppliers to submit their bids for the supply and installation of 3water saving irrigation systems in 3 districts in Karakalpakstan under the ‘Green Rehabilitation Investment Project for Karakalpakstan Republic to Address Impacts of the Aral Sea Crisis’ project.
 PROJECT BACKGROUND:
To effectively address the Aral Sea disaster in the Republic of Karakalpakstan, the Global Green Growth Institute (GGGI) is implementing a project - 'Green Rehabilitation Investment Project for Karakalpakstan Republic to Address Impacts of the Aral Sea Crisis'. The project aims to assist the green rehabilitation of the region through the achievement of the following 4 objectives:
•	Objective 1: Establish an effective green rehabilitation investment plan targeted on agriculture and agribusiness that reduces disaster risk, enhances rural food security and livelihoods, and promotes equitable employment in green and climate-smart value-chains in Karakalpakstan;
•	Objective 2: Respond to the most urgent needs of the workforce and micro-small-, and medium-enterprises (MSMEs) to tackle pressing human security needs, focusing on disaster related threats to health, livelihoods, productive assets, and agri-business risk management; 
•	Objective 3: Demonstrate viable climate resilient agri-business models to rebuild the economic foundation of Karakalpakstan’s agrarian economy;
•	Objective 4: Support the government and banks in mobilizing green/climate finance in support of green MSME development in Karakalpakstan. 
 SCOPE OF WORK, SUPPLIES, and SERVICES: 
GGGI aims to hire a consulting firm to design and propose technical specifications for suitable equipment that is aligned to the selected type of water saving irrigation technologies considering the project sites (Bozataw, and Chimbay) identified in GGGI’s Climate Smart Agriculture (CSA) Feasibility Study. Once the proposed specific design is agreed upon by GGGI, the contractor shall proceed with procurement and installation of the water-saving irrigation technologies with A/S services guaranteed for the industry standard 3 year period of time (TBC). More specifically, the contractor shall complete the following;
a)	Conduct the pre-visit to the project sites (Bozataw & Chimbay) to design the most suitable technical specification for the selected type of water saving irrigation system and equipment based on consultation with the relevant stakeholders identified in the CSA Feasibility Study, including, but not limited to, beneficiary farms, district hakhims, and etc.   
b)	Supply and delivery of equipment based on the design and technical specifications, approved by GGGI.
c)	Install, test and commission the equipment (report required) 
d)	Training of the beneficiary farmers on equipment operations with provision of demonstration and instruction. 
e)	Aftersales support & operations maintenance during the Defects Liability Period
 SITE LOCATION
1.	Chimbay JuzBasi farm (102.5 ha.)
2.	Bozataw Aktuba Jaylau farm (35.58 ha.)
3.	Bozataw MCHS Fruit Orchard (50 ha.) 
 PRE-BID CONFERENCE:
GGGI will convene a virtual pre-bid conference via M/S Teams on Friday, 12th January 2024 11:00 AM Uzbekistan Local Time (15:00 PM, KST) to address any queries/clarifications relating to the assignment and procurement process.
Interested parties should send the email addresses of the attendees through the e-Procurement Portal (Correspondence Tab) to receive the e-invitation.
 For more details, please refer to the Request for Proposals (RFP) document attached. 
 IMPORTANT TIMELINES:
The tender submission deadline is 26 January 2024, 16:00 pm KST (Korean Standard Time).
If any bidder has any request for clarification on the TOR or any part of the tender documents, GGGI will be happy to clarify if they are received on or before 7 days before the deadline (namely: if the tender submission deadline is 16:00 15 April KST, then the due date for submission of request for clarification is 16:00 8 April KST).

title: SUPPLY, DELIVERY AND INSTALLATION OF  16 WATER TANKS IN 8 SCHOOLS, SOUTH TARAWA.
description:
Project Background;
The project will support the Government of Kiribati to achieve its national development targets and international commitment by helping to develop a climate resilient, income generating agriculture sector that is backstopped by green technology solutions and which is accessible and inclusive to all i-Kiribati, through development of awareness raising and training materials in English and i-Kiribati to increase agricultural productivity for target groups. The project will introduce agriculture and health awareness raising initiatives to 20 school as part of extra-curricular activities; support training on agriculture and business skills development for 100 women and youth; and support 55 SMEs on climate smart agriculture practices and green entrepreneurship training and mentoring and provision of climate-smart agriculture technologies, its operations and maintenance.
 The overall objective of the project is to enhance adaptive capacity, strengthening resilience and reducing vulnerability to climate change of Kiribati island communities through a technology, education and capacity building and livelihoods development program for the agriculture sector.
 Proposed Activities; 
Specifically, under Outcome 1 of the project, Activity 2.5 that is focused on providing schools with climate smart technologies will facilitate the following;
(i)	Purchase of 16 tanks that will be supplied to 8 schools in South Tarawa namely:
S/n	Name of School	Location
1	Aratokotoko Primary School	Buota
2	Dai Nippon Primary School	Betio
3	Rurubao Primary School	Bairiki
4	St John Primary School	Betio
5	Taakenibwairiki Primary School	Bairiki
6	Tabontemwaneaba Primary School	Bikenibeu
7	Temwanoku Primary School	Betio
8	War memorial Primary School	Bikenibeu
 (ii)	Installation of the 2 tanks per school with a total of 16 water tanks installed at 8 schools.
(iii)	Testing the tanks & training the school authorities & student population on how to use or fix any issues with the tanks’ utility.
(iv)	Commissioning of the tanks .
(v)	Aftersales support & Operations Maintenance
 Based on the above background & context, GGGI Kiribati now seeks the services of competent suppliers & contractors to submit their tenders for the subject of procurement 
‘Supply, Delivery & Installation of 16 tanks to 8 Schools in South Tarawa’.
 INPORTANT
a) The tender submission deadline is 18 September 2023, 16:00 pm KST (KOREAN STANDARD TIME).
b) A pre-bid meeting shall take place on 31 August 2023 2:00 pm Kiribati Local Time (11:00 am Korean Standard Time) at GGGI Kiribati Offices Ministry of Environment, Lands and Agricultural Development, Bikenibeu, South Tarawa

title: Consultancy Services to Conduct Green Employment Analysis in Jordan
description:
GGGI Jordan is inviting interested firms to submit their bids for the consulting services to conduct Green Employment Analysis in Jordan.
 Jordan faces resource scarcity, particularly in water and fossil fuels, necessitating a transitiontowards a more sustainable and resource-efficient economy. Environmental challenges, such as desertification, land degradation, and water scarcity, can be mitigated through green jobs that minimize the negative environmental impact of industries and encourage sustainable practices. High unemploymentrates, especially among refugees, youth, and women, can beaddressed by generating new green employment opportunities,targeting marginalized groups, and promoting social equality. Green jobs also contribute to climate change mitigation, helping Jordan meet its commitments under the Paris Agreement. Furthermore, green jobs projects align with the UN SDGs. Thesustainable, inclusive green jobs project in Jordan willaddress the country’s economic, social, and environmental challenges.
 In order to address these issues, GGGI is implementing the project Creating Sustainable Green Jobs for Refugees and Host Communities through the Green Economy in Jordan’ financed by KOICA and co-financed by GGGI, for 3 years (2023-2026). The objectives of the Project are to 
(1) Provide evidence of the economic and environmental benefits of green employment to enable a green employment environment in Jordan,
(2) Enhance job seekers' employability in green sectorsthrough skill development and increased climate change awareness (especially women and youth) 
(3) Establish Greenbusiness incubation & acceleration on/offline programs for greenentrepreneurs / green start-ups for green entrepreneurs / greenstart-ups
 In order to achieve Objective 1, GGGIhas identified the need to conduct a comprehensive analysison green jobs, green growth potential in Jordan. The purpose of this analysis is to assess the status of green jobs, identify the potential for the creation of more green jobs, and provide evidence-based recommendations for policy interventions. 
 To achieve the purpose of the green employment analysis,the service provider shall conduct the following proposed activities:
 Activity 1:Green Jobs Assessment
Activity 2: Market Analysis for Green Growth Potential
Activity 3: Scenario Development and Analysis
Activity 4. Recommendations, Strategies, and Activity 5: Drafting of Report and Findings
Activity 6: Finalization and Presentation
 For more details, please refer to the Terms of Reference (TOR) document attached.
 IMPORTANT TIMELINES:
The tender submission deadline is 15 September 2023, 16:00 pm KST (KOREAN STANDARD TIME).
If any bidder has any request for clarification on the TOR or any part of the tender documents, GGGI will be happy to clarify if they are received on or before 7 days before the deadline (namely: if the tender submission deadline is 16:00 15 April KST, then the due date for submission of request for clarification is 16:00 8 April KST).

title: Consultancy for Market and Policy Assessment of Investment Needs, Barriers, and Opportunities - Bali, Indonesia
description:
GGGI Indonesia is inviting eligible firms/entities to submit their proposals for following scope of work:
 PROJECT BACKGROUND:
As part of the GGGI Indonesia country program and with the support of the Government of the Republic of Korea (ROK), GGGI is assisting the Government of Indonesia (GoI) in the transition to a more sustainable transportation system through electric vehicle (EV) implementation. Currently, the Province has a planning document, namely the Sustainable Urban Mobility Plan (SUMP) for the Sarbagita Metropolitan, that provides the comprehensive direction for a shift to a more sustainable transportation system. Additionally, a Regional Action Plan for EV implementation for the entire island has been published, covering the technical, institutional, and financial aspects of this transition. It shall be used as a reference point in developing the EV ecosystem in the province.
 In supporting the targets stated in these documents, GGGI is providing technical assistance through the project ‘Piloting Electric Vehicle Systems and Developing a Green Transportation Investment Roadmap for Bali, Indonesia’. The Project is designed comprehensively to include aspects of planning, investment mobilization, and capacity building to realize an inclusive EV system in the province. The project will also include piloting electric buses and supporting facilities. The project will emphasize inclusive and gender-sensitive development and address social and environmental safeguards. The duration of the project will be five years (2023-2027). GGGI is the delivery partner for this Project. 
 OBJECTIVE OF THE ASSIGNMENT:
GGGI is interested in procuring the services of a Consultancy firm with experience in the areas of e-mobility, transport engineering, renewable energy, and related fields. The Consultant should be familiar with undertaking project feasibility studies to support regulatory and policy interventions related to the decarbonization of transportation systems in Southeast Asia. 
The Consultant shall work closely with GGGI, Government of Indonesia or any agency acting on behalf of Government of Indonesia or its advisors (if any). The Consultant shall contribute to GGGI’s objective to address the current complex regulatory landscape for EV in Indonesia by developing a clear roadmap for rollout of inclusive e-mobility solutions in Bali. The general aim of the Project will be to design an effective policy and regulatory environment that enables investments, and to provide project options for investments in an EV-based green transportation system in Bali. To achieve this, an EV & Charging Infrastructure Expansion Roadmap and an integrated green transportation and EV ecosystem will be developed.
 PROPOSED ACTIVITIES:
Reporting to the GGGI Indonesia Country Team, the Consultant shall be responsible for undertaking the following responsibilities:
-	Full analysis of the existing status of EV implementation at the national level and in Bali.
-	Full analysis of the regulatory landscape and market trends in the EV sector.
-	Engagement with national and subnational stakeholders in Bali to conduct gap assessment and align the objectives of the Pilot Project accordingly, specifically regarding the selection of potential routes/bus corridors and charging infrastructure. 
-	Full analysis of the capacity-building needs across relevant national and sub-national stakeholders in the EV sector.
-	Support stakeholder consultations with the Government of Indonesia, including local government agencies, public and private sector energy companies in Indonesia, technology providers, multilateral and bilateral financing institutions, international investors, industry representatives, etc.
-	Provide analysis for the development of a gender action plan and stakeholder engagement plan to identify policy and regulatory gaps.
-	Draft recommendations based on assessments conducted.
 For more details, please refer to the Terms of Reference (TOR) document attached. 
 IMPORTANT TIMELINES:
This assignment will start from 15th of September 2023 and is expected to be completed by 31st December 2023.
The tender submission deadline is 1 September 2023, 16:00 pm KST (Korean Standard Time).

title: Framework Contract for Supporting Climate Change Mitigation Efforts in Zambia
description:
GGGI is inviting eligible firms/entities to submit their proposals for following scope of work:
Note: Service providers (in case of consortium, at least the lead entity) must be a legal entity incorporated and registered in Zambia.
 PROJECT BACKGROUND:
This Request for Proposals (RFP) is part of the activities in Zambia under the “Supporting Preparedness for Article 6 Cooperation” or SPAR6C Program, funded by the German Federal Ministry of Economic Affairs and Climate Action (BMWK) through the International Climate Initiative (IKI). The 5-year (2022-2027) program provides technical support to Colombia, Pakistan, Thailand, Zambia to kick-start the implementation of Article 6 activities. GGGI is the consortium lead of SPAR6C and the national partner of SPAR6C in Zambia is the Ministry of Green Economy and Environment (MGEE). 
The overall objective of SPAR6C is to facilitate readiness of countries to participate in cooperative approaches under Article 6 of the Paris Agreement by engaging the private sector and working closely with governments. This program will enable the development of the international carbon market created by Article 6, leading to cost-efficient, flexible, high integrity carbon markets with positive, transformational sustainability impacts.
 OBJECTIVE OF THE ASSIGNMENT:
GGGI is seeking to contract up to three service providers to support a range of activities undertaken under the SPAR6C program in Zambia. GGGI intends to sign a Framework Agreement (FWA) as a result of this tender but does not guarantee any actual or estimated volume of services in the contract. GGGI anticipates that the FWA will be effective starting September/October 2023. 
The SPAR6C project has identified three activities in Zambia to be carried out during 2023-2027 as part of Work Package IV: 
	A2. Medium and long-term low emission planning
	A3. Governance framework implementation
	A4. Pilot transactions
 SCOPE OF WORK:
This RFP will focus on the following areas:
 Area 1: Energy: With the objective of improving GHG emission estimates in the selected sub-sectors (e.g. transport) of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) category ‘energy’, the project seeks service provider to provide technical expertise for the following tasks: 
•	Supporting key stakeholders in estimating the GHG emission reduction effect of selected mitigation measures
•	Supporting stakeholders in conducting high level cost benefit assessments of mitigation measures and develop sectoral marginal abatement cost functions (i.e. using a social discount rate, for time period 2030)
 Area 2: Industrial processes and product use (IPPU): With the objective of improving GHG emission estimates in the selected sub-sectors (e.g. cement) of the IPCC category ‘IPPU’, the project seeks service provider to provide technical expertise for the following tasks:
•	Supporting key stakeholders in estimating the GHG emission reduction effect of selected mitigation measures, 
•	Supporting stakeholders in conducting high level cost benefit assessments of mitigation measures and develop sectoral marginal abatement cost functions (i.e. using a social discount rate, for time period 2030).
 Area 3: Agriculture, Forestry and Other Land Use (AFOLU): With the objective of improving GHG emission estimates in the selected sub-sectors (e.g. enteric fermentation) of the IPCC category ‘AFOLU’, the project seeks service provider to provide technical expertise for the following tasks: 
•	Supporting key stakeholders in estimating the GHG emission reduction effect of selected mitigation measures, 
•	Supporting stakeholders in conducting high level cost benefit assessments of mitigation measures and develop sectoral marginal abatement cost functions (i.e. using a social discount rate, for time period 2030).
 Area 4: Waste: With the objective of improving GHG emission estimates in the selected sub-sectors (e.g. solid waste) of the IPCC category ‘Waste’, the project seeks service provider to provide technical expertise for the following tasks: 
•	Supporting key stakeholders in estimating the GHG emission reduction effect of selected mitigation measures, 
•	Supporting stakeholders in conducting high level cost benefit assessments of mitigation measures and develop sectoral marginal abatement cost functions (i.e. using a social discount rate, for time period 2030).
 Area 5: Monitoring, Reporting and Verification: With the objective of improving the capacity of Zambia to undertake monitoring, reporting and verification duties under the enhanced transparency framework (ETF) of the Paris climate agreement, the project seeks service provider to provide technical expertise for the following tasks:
•	Support Zambia Environmental Management Agency (ZEMA) in incorporating its integrated Monitoring, Reporting and Verification (iMRV) system including inter alia:
o	Organizing and conducting capacity iMRV building workshops at provincial level;
o	Organizing and conducting national validation workshop of sectorial procedures and guidelines;
o	Organizing and conducting the official launch of the iMRV;
o	Support the development of the national registry for carbon projects (i.e. A6 and voluntary carbon market, VCM);
o	Support the development and approval of the rules and procedures for transiting CDM and VCM projects to A6 / crediting with corresponding adjustment;
o	Support the development and approval of the national carbon market framework.
 Area 6: Legal and financial advice. The project seeks service provider to provide legal expertise as it relates to environment, finance and climate regulations, laws and other statutory instruments, including but not limited to:  
•	Analyzing gaps in laws and other statutory instruments required for carbon market regulation and oversight, and provision of recommendations for government intervention
•	Drafting legal environmental documents (laws and statutory instruments) assuring appropriate legal form in line with national requirements;
In the technical proposals, Bidders shall specify the service Area(s) for which they are bidding (Areas 1 to 6 above).
 For more details, please refer to the Terms of Reference (TOR) document attached. 
 PRE-BID CONFERENCE:
GGGI will convene a virtual pre-bid conference via M/S Teams to address any queries/clarifications relating to the assignment and procurement process.  The date and time will be announced later on GGGI e-Green Procurement Portal (Clarifications). To sign up for the pre-bid conference please send us email addresses of potential attendees via the Correspondence tab.
 IMPORTANT TIMELINES:
The tender submission deadline is 22 September 2023, 16:00 pm KST (Korean Standard Time).
If any bidder has any request for clarification on the TOR or any part of the tender documents, GGGI will be happy to clarify if they are received on or before 7 days before the deadline (namely: if the tender submission deadline is 16:00 15 April KST, then the due date for submission of request for clarification is 16:00 8 April KST).

title: Website Refreshment Consultancy for GGGI
description:
GGGI seeks to recruit an experienced Website Developer to support the website refreshment for GGGI:
 PROJECT BACKGROUND:
GGGI wants to present to the world an innovative website that encapsulates the organization’s core mission, vision, and values. The website is envisioned to be audience and user friendly, professional, and visually striking. GGGI envisions a website that users will remember not just as approachable and easily navigable, but also as an aesthetic reference in modern website design. GGGI is aiming to launch a revised website at the end of December 2023.
The website's primary goal is to enable GGGI to connect with diverse audiences via gggi.org, facilitating the dissemination of GGGI's messages, results, and impacts through quality, consistent communication, as well as knowledge-sharing products and initiatives.
 OBJECTIVE OF THE ASSIGNMENT:
The objective of this consultancy is to support the revision of GGGI.org website and will include the following components: 
•	Objective 1. Analytical review of the current website analytics and identifying gaps and opportunities for improvement
•	Objective 2. Provide advice and direction to GGGI, drawing insights from the existing website and taking into account the perspectives of the target audiences.
•	Objective 3. Propose and develop a new look and organization for the website aligned with both the audience's requirements and GGGI's core values, building upon the lessons learned from the website's assessment.
•	Objective 4.  By the end of December 2023, achieve a successful launch of the redesigned and reoriented GGGI website, along with the seamless transfer of existing data, ensuring it meets the set objectives and effectively communicates GGGI's messages and impacts to a wider audience.
 PROPOSED ACTIVITIES:
The service provider’s main responsibilities are to: 
-	Assess the current website structure and analytics.
-	Design and develop a user-friendly web for use on computers and mobile devices. This includes developing an initial mock-up to solicit feedback, and then a full working product that can be integrated within the existing GGGI website
-	Provide creative suggestions on how to improve the user-friendliness of the website 
-	Create and update content of pages as agreed with GGGI 
-	Design a user-friendly front-end website while maintaining branding, color, and style in agreement with GGGI 
-	Provide onsite support and training of appointed GGGI staff in both the administrator interface and basic maintenance of the site architecture and design 
-	Participate in bilateral meetings, workshops, and conference calls as necessary for the successful completion of the assignment
 For more details, please refer to the Terms of Reference (TOR) document attached. 
 IMPORTANT TIMELINES:
The tender submission deadline is 11 September 2023, 16:00 pm KST (Korean Standard Time).
