title: GHG Inventory Methodology for Renewable Energy - Indonesia
description:
GGGI Indonesia is inviting eligible firms/entities to submit their proposals for following scope of work:
 PROJECT BACKGROUND:
The Ministry of Energy & Mineral Resources (MEMR) has requested GGGI to support the development of the “Methodology for Calculating GHG Emission Reduction and/or Increasing Carbon Sequestration in the Mitigation Action Verification Framework”. This is a strategic task that will provide a basis to increase transparency and quality of data collection on emission reductions from mitigation actions, both emission calculation, validation, and verification. This methodology will be reviewed by the methodology panel team and will be stipulated through a Decree of the Director General of Climate Change Control (Dirjen Pengendalian Perubahan iklim) under the Ministry of Environment & Forestry (MoEF). MEMR requested GGGI to help develop an overarching ‘methodology for renewable energy’ that can provide strategic direction and guidance for key sectors.   
 Developing a robust and standardized methodology for the greenhouse gas inventory of new and renewable energy sources is essential to ensure accurate and consistent emissions assessments. A reliable methodology provides a scientific framework to quantify the emissions associated with the production, distribution, and utilization of these alternative fuels. It allows for the comparison of different projects and systems, enables the tracking of emissions reductions, and facilitates the development of effective policies and regulations. A standardized methodology also enhances transparency and credibility, providing stakeholders with a common understanding of the environmental impact. It enables governments, investors, and industry players to make informed decisions, allocate resources efficiently, and monitor progress towards emission reduction targets. The results of this greenhouse gas (GHG) inventory methodology will be utilized for the National Referral System (SRN) and subsequently form the basis for the issuance of the Decree of the Director General of Climate Change Control (Surat Keputusan Dirjen Pengendalian Perubahan Iklim) by the MoEF on this matter. 
 The development of the Methodology to Calculate GHG Emission Reduction provides an opportunity to design a tool for capacity building for both MEMR and the private sector since the development process will include several FGDs, seminars, consultation & training. The output also includes several methodologies to calculate GHG emission reduction as a policy regulation from the issuance of the Director General of Climate Change Control, the Ministry of Forestry and Environment Indonesia (MoEF). Thus, it creates an opportunity to incorporate RE-ACT support on the capacity building and new regulation as stated in Decree of Director General of Climate Change Control (Surat Keputusan Dirjen Pengendalian Perubahan Iklim atau SK Dirjen PPI).
 OBJECTIVE OF THE ASSIGNMENT:
GGGI is searching for a consulting firm with experience in GHG methodology inventory assessment as technical input to government policy making and long-term planning, globally or/and specifically in Indonesia. Since the work will be undertaken in close cooperation with MEMR, GGGI and other partners, flexibility and a shared vision for the project outcome are essential. The successful consulting firm (hereinafter referred as “Consultant”) shall report to the GGGI Indonesia Energy Lead and RE-ACT Project Manager while also coordinating on a day-to-day basis with the appointed MEMR focal point(s), and where applicable cooperation with MoEF, Bappenas, and other required stakeholders.
 PROPOSED ACTIVITIES:
GGGI will procure the services of a consulting firm with experience in GHG methodology inventory assessment as technical input to government policy making and long-term planning, globally or/and specifically in Indonesia.
The Consultant shall carry out the scope of services with the below activities: 
1.	Development of Methodologies for GHG Calculation 
2.	Training/Workshop with MEMR – DG NREEC and MOEF – DG Garbage, Waste and B3 Management (PSLB3/Pengelolaan Sampah, Limbah dan B3) and DG Control of Climate Change (PPI/Pengendalian Perubahan Iklim)
3.	Finalization of Methodology and Report to Calculate GHG inventory for several different renewable energy types.
 For more details, please refer to the Terms of Reference (TOR) document attached. 
 IMPORTANT TIMELINES:
The tender submission deadline is 4 September 2023, 16:00 pm KST (Korean Standard Time).
If any bidder has any request for clarification on the TOR or any part of the tender documents, GGGI will be happy to clarify if they are received on or before 7 days before the deadline (namely: if the tender submission deadline is 16:00 15 April KST, then the due date for submission of request for clarification is 16:00 8 April KST).
 Interested parties will be required to register their details on the GGGI e-Green Procurement Portal (https://in-tendhost.co.uk/gggi).
 HOW TO OBTAIN THE DOCUMENTS:
Documents can be accessed via the e-Green Procurement Portal by selecting ‘View Details’ on the relevant notice and then clicking the ‘Tender Application’ button. title: Environmental and Social Impact Assessment for The Baganuur – Choir 220kv Transmission Line Project Under Mongolia Third Energy Sector Project (P178190)
description:
GGGI Mongolia invites interested firms to submit their bids for the subject tender "Consulting Services to conduct an Environmental and Social Impact Assessment for The Baganuur – Choir 220kv Transmission Line Project.
 Background
The Government of Mongolia has identified priority investments in the transmission grid. The Ministry of Energy has requested the World Bank finance a core transmission line in Central Energy System (CES). The proposed project aims to strengthen the grid by reinforcing interconnections with remote areas where the existing grid capacity is not sufficient and thereby contributes not only to providing a reliable and stable power supply to target areas but also to enable further variable renewable energy (VRE) integration to the grid. As a result, the project will help meet the rising electricity demand with clean renewable power resources in the country. Therefore, the project will not only help Mongolia achieve its economic recovery goal and long-term sustainable development objective but also contribute to the global climate change agenda by reducing GHG emission.
The project will consist of two components: 
1)	Transmission line construction and associated substations expansion: new construction of a 188 km 220 kV double circuit Baganuur-Choir  electricity transmission line and expansion of two associated substations in Baganuur district and Choir. The line passes through  Bayan, Arkhust, and Bayandelger soums of Tuv, Tsagaandelger soum of Dundgovi, and Bayantal and Choir soums of Govisumber aimags (provinces) and Baganuur district of Ulaanbaatar city of Mongolia.  The details of the transmission line are indicated in the table below and Figure 1 (see Table 1 below);
2)	The capacity building and implementation support, which will finance a technical study to enhance capability on power system planning and deploying smart grid technologies, long-term transmission planning focusing on determining options to improve grid flexibility and increase the integration of variable renewable energy; and forecasting analytics for power systems with high penetrations of VRE.
  Proposed Activities for the Overall Project
The Consulting Firm shall prepare both GEIA and DEIA report in compliance with all relevant Mongolian requirements as stipulated in the Law on Environmental Impact Assessment and ESIA in compliance with the World Bank’s ESF covering all aspects of the Baganuur - Choir 220kV transmission project.
Detailed documents on social part shall be prepared separately and the Consulting Firm needs to incorporate it in the ESIA report as necessary.
 2)	Scope of Work
 The Consulting Firm shall complete the following tasks according to the standards set by the World Bank and the law of Environmental Impact Assessment of Mongolia. 
 The Consulting Firm shall ensure that General Environmental Impact Assessment (GEIA), Detailed Environmental Impact Assessment (DEIA) and Environmental Social Impact Assessment (ESIA) reports have following inputs well included and highlighted:
1)	Prepared in compliance with the World Bank’s ESF, and meanwhile all relevant Mongolian requirements as stipulated in the Law on Environmental Impact Assessment
2)	Based on a review of the combined Feasibility Study and Baseline Environmental Survey, site visits to the project site, and collection of all relevant primary and secondary environmental data, including the various master plans on the development of the project areas.
3)	Review Mongolian regulatory framework and, its institutional arrangements and performance  related to E&S management of the project, along with mechanisms proposed to fill any major gaps if identified against ESF; 
4)	Review E&S baselines that cover various physical, ecological, ambient environmental quality, social and economic aspects pertaining to the project proportionate to the E&S risks;
5)	Compare the relevant domestic environmental standards with that of the applicable EHSGs of the WBG;
6)	Conduct screening (and assessment if any) on the associated facilities (AF) based on the definition of AF under the ESF
7)	Conduct E&S due diligence review for the two substations to be expanded;
8)	Include physical, biological, socioeconomic baseline environmental profile for the Baganuur – Choir transmission line alignment and proposed substation sites, including but not limited to descriptions of site listed in Clause 29 – Suggested Outline for Baseline Conditions and Project Impact Assessments 
9)	Conduct environmental risks and impacts screening, scoping, and assessment on the project activities, set out appropriate environmental assessment tools to analyze the environmental  risks and impacts, and propose recommendations for addressing potential environmental impacts that are consistent with Environmental standards of the ESF;
10)	Based on impacts assessed, develop mitigation measures following the mitigation hierarchy principle of ESF to avoid, and where avoidance is not possible, minimize, mitigate, and/or offset adverse impacts and enhance positive impacts by means of environmental planning and management for pre-construction, construction and operation stages, including (but not limit to) described in Clause 29 – Suggested Outline for Baseline Conditions and Project Impact Assessments.
11)	Conduct alternative analysis on transmission line alignments through an integrated consideration of technical, environmental, social, and economic perspectives in collaboration with the FS and social impact assessment team to design and propose alternative alignment avoiding potential sensitive areas.  
12)	Analyze, to the extent possible, potential induced and cumulative impactsfrom other major infrastructure projects in the project area, e.g. associated facilities (subject to guidance from the World Bank task team), or other related or non-related activities in the same region and timeframe;
13)	Include an environmental and social management plan (ESMP) as a chapter of the ESIA that includes the summary of the potential E&S impacts/risks， the proposed mitigation measures which includes an Environmental Code of Practice (ECOP) for the generic impacts/risks, and mitigation measures for the site-specific impacts/risks, environmental monitoring and reporting requirements, related institutional or organizational arrangements, capacity development and training measures, implementation schedule, cost estimates, and performance indicators. 
14)	Assess the capacity of the implementing and executing agencies for environmental assessment, management, and monitoring and recommend the required measures for capacity building as part of the ESMP chapter.
15)	Include an environmental monitoring plan in the ESMP, including parameters to be measured, methods, sampling locations, frequency of measurements, detection limits, and definition of thresholds that will signal the need for corrective actions. Monitoring can be ambient quality (air, water, noise, etc.), discharge quality (effluent, etc.), or compliance (inspections to see if mitigations are being implemented).
 The Consulting Firm shall take following actions and include the result in Environmental Impact Assessment:
16)	Assess the ESS3-related risks and impacts, and require that supply, transport, storage, use, and disposal of these hazardous materials need to follow both applicable domestic regulations/standards and GIIP in the Bank’s EHSGs – General and for Electric Power Transmission and Distribution. 
17)	In general, the DEIA and ESIA should apply pollution prevention and control technologies and practices consistent with international good practices as reflected in internationally recognized standards such as the World Bank Group’s Environmental, Health and Safety Guidelines (EHSGs). 
18)	Assess and include the GHG estimation in the ESIA with the help from the World Bank and GGGI team.
19)	Analyze the project impacts on biodiversity, natural habitats, or migratory routes of birds and terrestiral migratory animals (if any) and consult with relevant stakeholders including relevant government agencies with mandated roles in biodiversity conservation, and experts with local knowledge. 
20)	Identify the biodiversity and potential bird species (and terrestiral migratory animals, if any) and their habitats and migration patterns within the vicinity of the proposed transmission line corridor in the region.
21)	Assess potential impacts from the Overhead Transmission Line (OHTL) construction and operation to the biodiversity, bird species, or migratory birds or animals (if relevant), and the Occupational Health and Safety (OHS) issues on workers, including communities exposure risks to EMF for those residing near High-voltage Transmission Line. . 
22)	Assess the extent to which the project design could be improved to avoid or reduce impacts on the biodiversity and bird species or animals (if relevant).
23)	Integrate mitigation measures into the biodiversity mitigation measures in the ESIA/ESMP and the design considers birds friendly solutions. 
24)	Biodiversity Management Plan (BMP) will be prepared as part of ESIA/ESMP if the transmission line construction and operation are found to have significant risks or impacts to biodiversity or habitats consistent with Environmental Social Standards (ESS) 6. 
25)	Prepare the Environmental and Social Management Plan (ESMP), which shall be a separate chapter of ESIA, based on the impacts/risks assessment, including includes Environmental Code of Practice (ECOP) for the generic impacts/risks, and mitigation measures for the site specific impacts/risks.
26)	The DEIA and ESIA should ensure that project activities are not implemented in areas of critical habitats, unless (i) there are no measurable adverse impacts on the critical habitat that could impair its ability to function, (ii) there is no reduction in the population of any recognized endangered or critically endangered species, and (iii) any lesser impacts are mitigated. There is no net loss.
27)	If a project is located within a legally protected area, the DEIA and ESIA should include additional programs to promote and enhance the conservation aims of the protected area. In an area of natural habitats, there must be no significant conversion or degradation, unless (i) alternatives are not available, (ii) the overall benefits from the project substantially outweigh the environmental costs, and (iii) any conversion or degradation is appropriately mitigated. 
 The Consulting Firm shall take following actions and include the result in Social Impact Assessment:
 28)	Work together and support the social Consulting Firms on the identification of key stakeholders, preparation of the Stakeholder Engagement Plan as per ESF requirements and undertake meaningful consultation with affected people and stakeholders on the environmental and social impacts matters (including concerned nongovernment organizations, if any). The DEIA report and ESIA should also be disclosed in an accessible place and in a form and language(s) understandable to affected people and other stakeholders.
29)	Integrate social baseline conditions and findings of ESS2, 4, 5 andprovided by social impact assessment team into main documents (ESIA and DEIA).  
Following inputs and documents are expected from Social Impacts Assessment Team:
a.	Social baseline conditions listed in “Suggested Outline for Baseline Conditions below”
b.	Comprehensive Social Risks Impact Assessment in compience with WB’s ESS2, 4, 5 and  for pre-construction, construction and operation stages 
c.	Impacts on livelihoods, health and safety, vulnerable groups, social sructures, communioty cohesion, social well-being and gender issues
d.	Construction Phase Impacts:
i.	Occupational health safety risk for workers, such as working at height, with power, and exposure to electric and magnetic fields (EMF)
ii.	Camp environmental management (if applicable).
iii.	Traffice disturbance and traffic safety risks
iv.	Impact of access roads
v.	Health and safety risks for communities near the construction sites and access/transportation roads
vi.	Community impacts associated with cultural conficts, labor influx, sexual exploitation and abuse/sexual harassment (SEA/SH) and child labor risks
e.	Operation Phase Impacts:
i.	Occupational health and safety concerns for workers
f.	Stakeholder Engagement Plan (SEP)
i.	SEP to guide meaninful and effective stakeholder engagment thoughout the project lifecycle
ii.	Key stakeholders, their interests, and potentail impacts on them
iii.	Strategies for stakeholder engagement, including consultations, public hearings, and disclosure mechanisms
iv.	Detail mechanisms for addressing grievances and compliants in the Grievance Redress Mechaisms (GRM)
g.	Resettlement Policy Frameworkd (RPF)
i.	RPF that outlines policies and principles for the resettlement of affected communities
ii.	Compliance with national laws and regulations and international best practices
iii.	Detail compensation and livelihood restoration measures, social and economic rehabilihation plans, and GRM
h.	Labor Management Plan (LMP)
i.	LMP that outlines policies, principles, and procedures for labor management during the project
ii.	Compliance with national labor laws, interation labor standards, and good insudtry practices
iii.	Employment, health and safety, workers’ rights, gender equality, and capacity building
iv.	Worker specific GRM
i.	Traffic Management Framework
j.	Social management plan (SMP) as a chapter of the ESIA that includes the summary of the potential social impacts/risks， the proposed mitigation measures which includes international best practics and good industry practices for the generic impacts/risks, and mitigation measures for the site-specific impacts/risks, social monitoring and reporting requirements, related institutional or organizational arrangements, capacity development and training measures, implementation schedule, cost estimates, and performance indicators. 
Suggested Outline for Baseline Conditions and Project Impact Assessments are as following:
a)	Baseline conditions:
General Environment and Ecology 
•	Investigation area
•	Geography
•	Geology, seismic situation and soil
•	Landscape
•	Tourism
•	Meteorology
•	Water resources
•	Forests
•	Flora and Fauna
•	Protected areas
 Socio-economic conditions
•	Population within the Investigation area
•	Historical and Cultural Sites
•	Gender aspects
•	Land use pattern and agriculture
•	Livelihood and housing
 b)	Project Impact Assessment:
Pre-construction phase impacts: 
•	Potential land acquisition impacts and planning;
•	Screening of protected areas and cultural heritages and avoidance measures; 
•	Design of biodiversity protection measures (e.g. bird diverter measures etc.). 
 c)	Construction phase impacts: 
•	Impacts on wildlife habitats, e.g. fragmentation, removal of vegetation, loss of wildlife habitat, the introduction of non-native invasive plant species etc.;
•	Waste generation at construction sites;
•	Soil erosion and sediment impacts on surface water; 
•	Nuisance of construction noise and fugitive dust at project sites and along material transportation routes; 
•	Potential risks for hazardous materials and oil spills associated with construction equipment operation and fueling activities; 
•	Occupational health and safety risks of workers at construction sites, e.g. working at height, with power, and electric and magnetic field (EMF) etc.;
•	Camp environmental management (if applicable);
•	Traffic disturbance and traffic safety risks; 
•	Impacts of access roads;
•	Health and safety risks of the communities near the construction sites and access/transportation roads; 
•	Potential impacts on cultural heritages, and chance-find measures;
•	Community impacts associated with cultural conflict, labor influx, Sexual Exploitation and Abuse/Sexual Harassment (SEA/SH), as well as child labor risk;
•	Anticipated impact on pastoralists, their seasonal stops, restriction of access; etc.
•	Potential impacts on ethnic minorities if any;
 d)	Operation phase impacts: 
•	Disruption to wildlife and their habitats, migration routes disruption etc.
•	Fatal risk to birds and bats through collisions and electrocutions, which may also result in power outages and fire; 
•	Risk of the establishment of invasive species due to regular vegetation management measures (manual and mechanical); 
•	Risk of steppe fire with a splash of fuel from routine maintenance and underlying growth left unchecked; 
•	Occupational health and safety concerns for workers and communities nearby if any;
•	estimation of GHGs with the help from the WB team.
 The Consulting Firm shall consult closely with GGGI, World Bank and MET, and ensure that all MET comments and concerns are effectively addressed and MET approval of the DEIA is obtained. 
The Consulting Firmshall supplement the information and assessment appropriately according to the GGGI and World Bank comments and advice once there are new ES issues emerge during the ESIA preparation process. 
 Important Timelines;
The Tender Submisison Deadline is 28 AUGUST 2023 16:00 HOURS KOREAN STANDARD TIME.
For more details, please refer to the revised Terms of Reference (ToR) attached.
 Interested parties will be required to register their details on the GGGI e-Green Procurement Portal (https://in-tendhost.co.uk/gggi).
 HOW TO OBTAIN THE DOCUMENTS:
Documents can be accessed via the e-Green Procurement Portal by selecting ‘View Details’ on the relevant notice and then clicking the ‘Tender Application’ button. If you are a new supplier, you will be required to register your details. If you have an existing account, you will need to login to the portal. Please refer to the guidance documents under the `Supplier Guidance` area of the portal for further information.
 ONLINE TENDER MANAGEMENT
Once in the Tender Management Area for the tender, there are five possible tabs: ‘Tender’, `Tender Documents`, ‘Correspondence’, ‘Clarifications’ and ‘History’. Select the 2nd tab (`Tender Documents`) where you will find useful information regarding the RFP. Scroll down to the heading ‘Tender Documents Received’ where you will be able to view / download the documents.
 OPTING IN & OPTING OUT:
Please note that you may be required to ‘Opt In’ before you can start populating your response. The ‘Opt Out’ functionality will also be available throughout the duration of the tender process. Opting out will give you the option of declaring you no longer want to receive any further communication in relation to this tender along with the opportunity of providing comments and feedback for this decision. You can choose to ‘Opt In’ at any time during the tender process if you initially decided to ‘Opt Out’.
 SUBMITTING YOUR RESPONSE VIA THE PORTAL:
Please note that you may be required to ‘Opt In’ to be able to submit a response through the portal. Tenderers will be required to upload any mandatory Placeholders (i.e. specified documents) within the `Tender Documents` tab. The ability to attach additional documents may also be available. Your proposal will not be submitted until you click `Submit Return`, located towards the bottom of the screen. On clicking `Submit Return`, you will receive a receipt confirming that your proposal has been submitted to GGGI.
Please read Instructions on How to submit the Proposal.
 NOTIFICATION EMAILS
To ensure you receive email alerts and notifications from our system, please add the email domain `@in-tendorganiser.co.uk` to your Safe Senders list.

title: Climate resilient WASH in secondary towns of Cambodia
description:
GGGI Cambodia is inviting eligible firms/entities to submit their proposals for following scope of work:
 PROJECT BACKGROUND:
National Committee for Sub-National Democratic Development Secretariat (NCDD-S), as an Accredited Entity (“AE”) for direct access from the Green Climate Fund (GCF) for micro sized activities up to USD 10 million investments under GCF Support, is in the process of developing project concept notes for funding from GCF. NCDD-S have developed first draft of concept note on climate resilient water, sanitation and hygiene infrastructure (CR-WASH) in secondary cities of Cambodia. The concept note has received feedback from GCF. Based on the new sectoral guidelines from GCF, NCDD-S and GGGI envisage a re-think of the approach towards developing this concept note. 
NCDD-S and GGGI thus wish to identify an urban resilience Consulting Firm (hereinafter referred to as ‘Consultant’)  to (1) evaluate the resilience needs of secondary towns of Cambodia, (2) identify most vulnerable of the Cambodian secondary cities and (3) design a concept note for activities up to USD 10 M for increasing urban resilience in secondary cities aligning with GCF priorities and criteria. 
 OBJECTIVE OF THE ASSIGNMENT:
The Consultant shall design activities, approach and the methodology appropriate to meet the objectives of the study. The methodology and the workplan will be refined in consultation with GGGI and NCDD-S team during the kick-off meeting. 
 PROPOSED ACTIVITIES:
The following tasks / assessments are required to be undertaken by the Consultant under this assignment:
-	Collect and analyze climate change related data (climate change projections, vulnerability profiles, data on past disasters and damages, adaptation plans, ongoing resilience projects etc.) to articulate vulnerability of cities in Cambodia.
-	Identify, through a multi-criteria evaluation, the most vulnerable cities in Cambodia in need of resilient infrastructure and systems. This evaluation needs to be backed with adequate data and analysis to justify the selection of priority cities. Develop a methodology with key indicators for selecting priority cities. 
-	Engage with relevant stakeholders (Relevant Ministries, development partners, sub-national governments etc.) to validate the results of this multi-criteria evaluation. After stakeholder’s engagement, conclude a validation of the proposed weighting and cities selection with project owner.  
-	Collect additional data on infrastructure, urban development issues for three priority cities and detail the vulnerable sectors for these cities.
-	Based on this assessment, suggest at least two alternative approaches for building resilience for each of these cities. These approaches need to be aligned with what could be funded through the GCF. 
-	In making the above recommendations, the Consultant’s team shall also review the GCF guidelines, ongoing projects and nature of projects recently approved to form a view on the nature of approaches / interventions that are likely to be approved by GCF. This would inform the selection of the city and the approach to resilience.  
-	Recommend one city that in their view is most suitable for inclusion in the GCF concept note. 
-	Undertake consultations with GGGI and NCDD-S on the shortlisted cities and the approaches to select one city for development of the concept note.
-	Collect additional context specific data for the selected city which is required to satisfactorily complete the GCF concept note. 
-	Develop the draft project concept note including the log frame, activity design and other aspects required in the GCF template. 
-	Discuss this draft concept note with NCDD-S, GGGI and other key stakeholders and incorporate their feedback. 
-	Finalize the GCF concept note incorporating the feedback from the key stakeholders. 
-	After concept note submission, revise the proposal to integrate comments from the GCF Secretariat and CIC into an updated package, for up to three rounds of revisions. 
-	Undertake consultations with GGGI and NCDD-S on the PPF requirement for the full proposal development, and prepare a draft of PPF proposal including workplan and budget estimation. 
 For more details, please refer to the Terms of Reference (TOR) document attached. 
 IMPORTANT TIMELINES:
The tender submission deadline is 4 September 2023, 16:00 pm KST (Korean Standard Time).
If any bidder has any request for clarification on the TOR or any part of the tender documents, GGGI will be happy to clarify if they are received on or before 7 days before the deadline (namely: if the tender submission deadline is 16:00 15 April KST, then the due date for submission of request for clarification is 16:00 8 April KST).
 Interested parties will be required to register their details on the GGGI e-Green Procurement Portal (https://in-tendhost.co.uk/gggi).
 HOW TO OBTAIN THE DOCUMENTS:
Documents can be accessed via the e-Green Procurement Portal by selecting ‘View Details’ on the relevant notice and then clicking the ‘Tender Application’ button. If you are a new supplier, you will be required to register your details. If you have an existing account, you will need to login to the portal. Please refer to the guidance documents under the `Supplier Guidance` area of the portal for further information.
 ONLINE TENDER MANAGEMENT:
Once in the Tender Management Area for the tender, there are five possible tabs: ‘Tender’, `Tender Documents`, ‘Correspondence’, ‘Clarifications’ and ‘History’. Select the 2nd tab (`Tender Documents`) where you will find useful information regarding the RFP. Scroll down to the heading ‘Tender Documents Received’ where you will be able to view / download the documents.
 OPTING IN & OPTING OUT:
Please note that you may be required to ‘Opt In’ before you can start populating your response. The ‘Opt Out’ functionality will also be available throughout the duration of the tender process. Opting out will give you the option of declaring you no longer want to receive any further communication in relation to this tender along with the opportunity of providing comments and feedback for this decision. You can choose to ‘Opt In’ at any time during the tender process if you initially decided to ‘Opt Out’.
 SUBMITTING YOUR RESPONSE VIA THE PORTAL:
Please note that you may be required to ‘Opt In’ to be able to submit a response through the portal. Tenderers will be required to upload any mandatory Placeholders (i.e. specified documents) within the `Tender Documents` tab. The ability to attach additional documents may also be available. Your proposal will not be submitted until you click `Submit Return`, located towards the bottom of the screen. On clicking `Submit Return`, you will receive a receipt confirming that your proposal has been submitted to GGGI.
Please read Instructions on How to submit the Proposal.
 NOTIFICATION EMAILS:
To ensure you receive email alerts and notifications from our system, please add the email domain `@in-tendorganiser.co.uk` to your Safe Senders list.

title: Supply and Delivery of Vehicle Fleet for the Provincial Agriculture Center (PAC) in Oriental Mindoro (Republic of the Philippines)
description:
REQUEST FOR QUOTATION - GGGI Philippines is inviting suitable vendors to supply and deliver Vehicle Fleet for the Provincial Agriculture Center (PAC) in Oriental Mindoro.
 For more details on the Specifications and Schedule of Supply please refer to the RFQ document attached.
 1.	The Global Green Growth Institute (GGGI) hereby requests you to submit price quotation(s) for the supply of the items posted in GGGI’s e-Green Procurement Portal (https://in-tendhost.co.uk/gggi). Below documents are submitted for your review so that you may prepare your quotation.:
a)	Schedule of Supply
b)	Price Schedule of Goods form
If you, however, have been associated with the firm that prepared the design, and specifications of the contract that is subject of this procurement, you shall be disqualified.
 2.	You must quote for all items under this request. Price quotations will be evaluated for all items together and contract awarded to the firm offering the technically responsive items and lowest evaluated total cost of all the items.
 3.	You must submit only one set of quotations containing:
a)	Business Registration Certificate
b)	Mandatory Disclosure Form
c)	Personal Data Consent Form
d)	Mandatory Certifications Form
e)	Availability of Financial Resources  
f)	Schedule of Supply
g)	Adequate technical documentation, catalogue(s) or other printed material, pertinent information in English for each item quoted, including names and addresses of firms providing after-sales service facilities.
h)	Price Schedule of Goods for the items 
i)	Manufacturer’s Authorization/Certification for Third Party Reseller 
 electronically via GGGI’s e-Green Procurement Portal.
 4.	Your quotation written in ENGLISH.
 5.	The deadline for receipt of your quotation(s) by GGGI is specified in GGGI’s e-Green Procurement Portal.
  6.	Your quotation(s) must be submitted as per the following instructions and in accordance with the attached form of Contract. The attached General Conditions of Contract is an integral part of the Contract.
i)	PRICES: The prices must be quoted for supply and delivery to place(s) of destination. Prices must be in USD including Value Added Tax (VAT). 
 ii)	EVALUATION OF QUOTATIONS: Offers determined to be substantially responsive to the technical specifications will be evaluated by comparison of their prices. An offer is not substantially responsive if it contains material deviations or reservations to the terms, conditions, and specifications in this request, and it will not be considered further. In evaluating the quotations, GGGI will adjust for any arithmetical errors as follows:
 a)	where there is a discrepancy between the unit rate and the line item total resulting from multiplying the unit rate by the quantity, the unit rate as quoted will govern; and
b)	if a Supplier refuses to accept the correction, his quotation will be rejected.
 iii)	AWARD OF CONTRACT: The award will be made to the bidder offering the lowest evaluated price and that meets the required standards of technical and financial capabilities. The successful bidder will sign a Contract as per attached form of contract and terms and conditions of supply.
 iv)	VALIDITY OF THE OFFER: Your quotation(s) must be valid for a period of thirty (30) days from the deadline for the submission of quotation(s) indicated in GGGI’s e-Green Procurement Portal.
  7.	If you withdraw your quotation during the validity period and/or refuse to accept the award of a contract when and if awarded, then you will be excluded from the list of suppliers for the project for two years.
 8.	The bidder whose quotation has been accepted will be notified of the award of contract via GGGI’s e-Green Procurement Portal within the bid validity period.
  9.	Further information can be obtained via GGGI’s e-Green Procurement Portal (https://in-tendhost.co.uk/gggi).
  10.	Under GGGI’s Anticorruption Policy and Procurement Rules, bidders shall observe the highest standard of ethics during the procurement and execution of such contracts. GGGI will reject a proposal for award, and will impose sanctions on parties involved, if it determines that the bidder recommended for award or any other party, has engaged in corrupt, fraudulent, collusive, or coercive practices in competing for, or in executing, the Contract. At the time of submission of your quotation or contract signature, you must not be in UN’s sanctions list (https://www.un.org/sc/suborg/en/sanctions/un-sc-consolidated-list) or have been debarred for a period exceeding one year or for an indefinite period by any Multilateral Development Bank (MDB), including the African Development Bank Group, the Asian Development Bank, the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, the Inter-American Development Bank or the World Bank Group. 
  IMPORTANT TIMELINES:
The tender submission deadline is 13 September 2023 16:00 pm Korean Standard Time (KST).
If any bidder has any request for clarification on the TOR or any part of the tender documents, GGGI will be happy to clarify if they are received on or before 7 days before the deadline (namely: if the tender submission deadline is 16:00 15 April KST, then the due date for submission of request for clarification is 16:00 8 April KST).
 Interested parties will be required to register their details on the GGGI e-Green Procurement Portal (https://in-tendhost.co.uk/gggi).
 HOW TO OBTAIN THE DOCUMENTS:
Documents can be accessed via the e-Green Procurement Portal by selecting ‘View Details’ on the relevant notice and then clicking the ‘Tender Application’ button. If you are a new supplier, you will be required to register your details. If you have an existing account, you will need to login to the portal. Please refer to the guidance documents under the `Supplier Guidance` area of the portal for further information.
 ONLINE TENDER MANAGEMENT:
Once in the Tender Management Area for the tender, there are five possible tabs: ‘Tender’, `Tender Documents`, ‘Correspondence’, ‘Clarifications’ and ‘History’. Select the 2nd tab (`Tender Documents`) where you will find useful information regarding the RFQ. Scroll down to the heading ‘Tender Documents Received’ where you will be able to view / download the documents.
 OPTING IN & OPTING OUT:
Please note that you may be required to ‘Opt In’ before you can start populating your response. The ‘Opt Out’ functionality will also be available throughout the duration of the tender process. Opting out will give you the option of declaring you no longer want to receive any further communication in relation to this tender along with the opportunity of providing comments and feedback for this decision. You can choose to ‘Opt In’ at any time during the tender process if you initially decided to ‘Opt Out’.
 SUBMITTING YOUR RESPONSE VIA THE PORTAL:
Please note that you may be required to ‘Opt In’ to be able to submit a response through the portal. Tenderers will be required to upload any mandatory Placeholders (i.e., specified documents) within the `Tender Documents` tab. The ability to attach additional documents may also be available. Your quotation will not be submitted until you click `Submit Return`, located towards the bottom of the screen. On clicking `Submit Return`, you will receive a receipt confirming that your quotation has been submitted to GGGI.
 Please read Instructions on submitting quotation.

title: A pre-feasibility study of electric buses and routes in two cities, Pokhara and Bharatpur,  in Nepal
description:
GGGI Nepal is inviting eligible firms/entities to submit their proposals for following scope of work:
 PROJECT BACKGROUND:
In Nepal, GGGI is working under the guidance of the Ministry of Forests and Environment, and in partnership with the Ministry of Physical Infrastructure and Transport, to deliver the Electric Mobility Program (EMP). As a part of the program, GGGI partnered with Deutsche Gesellschaft für Internationale Zusammenarbeit (GIZ) in Nepal to submit a proposal to the Mitigation Action Facility’s (MAF) Ambition Initiative Call in 2022. The title of the project is “Sustainable Electric Transport for Nepal (SET4NPL)”. The project focuses on deployment of electric minibuses in the country. In addition to the SET4NPL, GGGI is providing policy and technical advisory support to the Government of Nepal and partners for effective and efficient transition to electric mobility. GGGI has recently approved a project to support deployment of electric public vehicles in the highway connecting Pokhara and Bharatpur as well as intercity routes of Pokhara and Bharatpur.   
 The objective of this assignment is to select a competent consultancy firm (hereinafter referred to as ‘Firm’) to develop a more in-depth techno-feasibility study, understand challenges and opportunities that will support deployment of electric buses in an intercity route (between Pokhara and Bharatpur) and intracity route (routes identified within Pokhara and Bharatpur). The Firm shall carry out a pre-feasibility study in Phase I and full feasibility study in Phase II for deployment of electric buses in the intercity route and intracity routes identified. 
 OBJECTIVE OF THE ASSIGNMENT:
The Firm shall develop a Pre-feasibility Study , which aims to identify viable electric vehicle technological options for routes identified within Pokhara and Bharatpur and the intercity route between Pokhara and Bharatpur. In the pre-feasibility study, the firm shall add preliminary considerations on environmental, social, and economic risks. 
 PROPOSED ACTIVITIES:
Through this study, the Firm shall complete the following tasks:
-	Conduct a market research to understand technologies available
-	Identify key stakeholders and establish preliminary relationship to understand challenges and opportunities of introducing electric buses in the said locations
-	Conduct a baselines study to understand power sector requirements, characteristics of the routes identified, challenges for women and disadvantaged groups in the transport sector, and particularly when switching to electric transport. 
-	Carrying out a simple financial analysis to understand viability gap of introducing electric buses in the routes identified. 
-	Develop stakeholder engagement strategy and establish initial contact with key stakeholders to understand challenges and opportunities
 For more details, please refer to the Terms of Reference (TOR) document attached.

title: Mainstreaming Energy Efficiency in MSME buildings in the Philippines
description:
GGGI Philippines is inviting eligible firms/entities to submit their proposals for the following scope of work:
 IMPORTANT NOTE:
Bidders for this RFP and consortium partners must be incorporated and registered in the Philippines.
 PROJECT BACKGROUND:
The growth of the Micro, Small and Medium Enterprises (MSMEs) sector, which makes up more than 99% of all private sector entities in the Philippines and provides employment for more than 60% of the workforce, is crucial to achieve the government’s priority of inclusive growth and job creation. In 2021, the MSME sector comprised 35.7% of the country’s economy, with manufacturing accounting for the biggest proportion at 6.9%, followed by financial services (6%) and wholesale, retail, and repair trades. 
 MSMEs are considered the backbone of inclusive growth. Accordingly, the Department of Trade and Industry (DTI) launched the Shared Service Facilities (SSF) Program to increase MSME competitiveness by addressing the limited technical and financial capacities of MSMEs. These SSFs provide grants for machinery, equipment, tools, and systems for the group use of MSMEs. 
 Since 2013, the government has invested a total of P3.2 billion (USD 58.5 million), funding the construction of 3,543 facilities and providing aid to over 600,000 beneficiaries, creating 300,000 jobs nationally. The DTI SSF Program is present in all 17 regions and has provided services to important industry clusters  including processed food, coffee, cacao, dairy, coconut, abaca, bamboo, gifts, decors, and housewares (GDH),), metal, and rubber.  In Palawan, there are seven (7) SSFs as of 2023; in Mindanao, there are around 1,210. 
 The EE&C Act (Republic Act 11285) institutionalizes energy efficiency and conservation to enhance energy supply, mitigate fossil fuel price fluctuations, and reduce carbon emissions. It establishes a framework for fundamental policies and designates the Department of Energy (DOE) as the lead agency for implementation, including raising awareness of its benefits.
 The project aligns with the objectives of the BKCF. It addresses the specific context of the Philippines, with a primary focus on MSMEs located in Palawan and Mindanao. The project’s Outputs are as follows:
1.	Output 1 - Situation analysis on potential for energy efficiency in MSMEs; in collaboration with DTI and DOE
2.	Output 2 - Identification of MSMEs buildings and walk-through energy audits
3.	Output 3 - Business case or investment proposal developed for energy efficiency project in selected MSMEs
 OBJECTIVE OF THE ASSIGNMENT:
GGGI is seeking to engage the services of a Firm (or consortium) with expertise in energy efficiency in the MSME sector, energy auditing, Energy Service Company (ESCO) projects, and EE&C policy analysis.
 The selected Firm shall collaborate closely with GGGI, the DTI, the DOE, and other state and non-state organizations that may become involved in this project, under GGGI's guidance. The Firm shall help the government’s ability to create and develop an appropriate institutional structure that can facilitate the expansion of possible investments.
 For Output 1, in order to perform the analysis, the Firm shall need to identify, research, and evaluate all relevant information (technical, commercial, regulatory, policy, etc.) in order to identify gaps and potential opportunities. 
For Output 2: the Firm shall gather substantial information from the List of Establishments of the Philippine Statistics Authority (PSA) to develop a short list of MSME candidates for the energy audit component. 
For Output 3, the Firm shall develop financial models (using MS Excel) for testing various business models and their financial returns in order to enable the potential beneficiaries to make full use of the intended investments.
 For more details, please refer to the Terms of Reference (TOR) document attached. 
 IMPORTANT TIMELINES:
The tender submission deadline is 25 January 2024, 16:00 pm KST (Korean Standard Time).
If any bidder has any request for clarification on the TOR or any part of the tender documents, GGGI will be happy to clarify if they are received on or before 7 days before the deadline (namely: if the tender submission deadline is 16:00 15 April KST, then the due date for submission of request for clarification is 16:00 8 April KST).

title: Social and Environmental Safeguards for non-AFOLU sectors in Carbon Markets
description:
GGGI for its project in the Colombia invites all interested firms to submit their proposals to support the SPARC Program in: a) developing guidelines of social and environmental safeguards in carbon market projects for sectors such as energy, housing, water and sanitation, industry and transport, among others
 PROJECT BACKGROUND & OBJECTIVES
The Service Provider required will support GGGI’s work in Colombia regarding social and environmental safeguards in carbon markets for non-AFOLU sectors. The products will be developed for one project of the current portfolio: Supporting Preparedness for Article 6 Cooperation (SPAR6C) Program.
The SPAR6C Program is funded by the International Climate Initiative (IKI) of the German government. Its objective is to use Article 6 (A6) cooperative approaches to engage the private sector in NDC implementation and to raise ambition in Colombia, Pakistan, Thailand, and Zambia. The program consists of six work packages, of which two are centrally managed and four are country driven. In the first two, best practice tools and approaches to implement cooperative mechanisms will be developed, underpinned by an international forum – a high ambition community of practice - that brings together countries and practitioners, who share the common objective of raising ambition through markets. Incountry implementation will focus on three areas of work in each of the four countries: 1) Long-term planning, 2) institutional readiness to transact, and 3) pilot design and transactions. More than eight A6 pilot programs will be implemented in Colombia, Pakistan, Thailand, and Zambia based on a toolbox of innovative guidance and approaches for transformative A6 design.
The SPAR6C Program is supporting Colombia in developing its institutional, regulatory, and technical framework and capacities to embark on Article 6 transactions of ITMOs during the NDC implementation period 2020-2030. The program's first stage was the development of a Readiness and Needs Assessment (RNA) for implementing Article 6, which examines the country's capacities and systems to consolidate a strategy and guiding principles, institutional and procedural framework and monitoring tools related to Article 6. The RNA included information about the progress of Colombia in structuring a National Safeguards System (SNS) consisting of: 1) the national interpretation of the Cancun safeguards (15 rules); (2) existing regulatory and institutional frameworks for compliance; (3) aSafeguards Information System; and 4) a Citizen Attention Mechanism. These advances occurred within the framework of the construction of the Comprehensive Strategy for Deforestation Control and Forest Management (EICDGB) in 2018 (Ministry of Environment and Sustainable Development, 2018). Due to international advances such as the Cancun Safeguards and the advance in REDD+ projects nationally, efforts have focused on the forest sector. In 2023, these safeguards have been extended to all the AFOLU (Agriculture, Forestry and other land use) sectors by Article 230 of Law 2294 of the National Development Plan 2022-2026. One of the needs identified in the assessment is to extend the safeguards to sectors different to forests and integrate other differential approaches (gender, LGTBIQ, age, rurality, affectation by the armed conflict, etc.), in addition to ethnicity.
GGGI is seeking for a Service Provider to support the SPARC Program in: a) developing guidelines of social and environmental safeguards in carbon market projects for sectors such as energy, housing, water and sanitation, industry and transport, among others
   OBJECTIVE OF THE ASSIGNMENT:
Develop a proposal of Environmental and Social Safeguards for carbon market projects in the energy, housing, water and sanitation, industry, and transport sectors, as a technical input for the Colombia Environmental and Social Safeguards System, through a literature review of national and international good practices, safeguard schemes, characteristics of mitigation activities and carbon market projects in these sectors and interviews with relevant stakeholders. This proposal will be the basis for government and stakeholder consultation in partnership with the Ministry of Environment and Sustainable Development
 PROPOSED ACTIVITIES AND SCOPE OF WORK:
 1) Proposed Activities for the Overall Project
The firm shall be responsible for providing support to the following programs related to the following activities:
1. Technical and legal literature review of the existing social and environmental safeguards for
carbon markets and mitigation actions from Governments, projects developers, and
validation/verification bodies (VVBs), at national and international levels, in relation to sectors
other than the forest sector, as well as existing national guidelines and tools on gender equality,
just transition, social inclusion and human rights in the energy, housing, water and sanitation,
industry and transport sectors.
2. Review of social and environmental impacts of mitigation actions in the aforementioned sectors
in Colombia to identify the most pertinent negative impacts to prevent through the
implementation of safeguards.
3. Carry out a detailed stakeholders mapping, using a stakeholder mapping methodology that
includes: a database of relevant entities and actors for each sector, as well as an analysis of
interests and relevance for the project.
4. Prioritize stakeholders and experts and guiding questions for conducting interviews to inform
the initial proposal.
5. Develop the conceptual approach of the proposal of social and environmental safeguards to
sectors other than the AFOLU. This initial document shall address the prioritized sectors and
have a proposal for inclusion in the National Safeguards System of Colombia.
6. Develop a methodology to hold a workshop/meeting with the SPAR6C team and the
Directorate of Climate Change of the Ministry of Environment and Sustainable Development,
for the presentation, and feedback of the Environmental and Social Safeguards proposal for
carbon markets in prioritized sectors.
7. Carry out a workshop/meeting with the SPAR6C team and at least 15 selected experts to
present, validate and provide feedback to the proposal for Environmental and Social Safeguards
for carbon markets in the prioritized sectors, under the methodology proposed in the previous
numeral.
8. Carry out the consolidation and systematization of the information generated in the workshop.
9. Develop a document with a proposal of Social and Environmental Safeguards in the energy,
housing, water and sanitation, industry, and transport sectors, including the elements and
different perspectives by sector, and a proposal to include them in the Environmental and Social
Safeguards National System.
10.Develop a handbook containing the proposal of Social and Environmental Safeguards for the energy, housing, water and sanitation industry and transport sectors that could be integrated into capacity building initiatives of the IKI Program and other counterparts, such as the Ministry of Environment and Sustainable Development.
11. Attend technical and team meetings, as required.
 2) Scope of Work
The Service Provider shall develop, with the technical accompaniment of GGGI, the following deliverables considering all the information described in these terms of reference:
 Deliverable 1. Workplan for both SPAR6C Program and AFI
One (1) detailed work plan (in English and Spanish) that includes at least the following aspects: management approach, activities, proposed methodologies to achieve the deliverables, development times, delivery times, and responsibilities.
 Deliverable 2. Literature review of national and international experiences of social and environmental safeguards in carbon markets and risks of mitigation actions.
One (1) document containing a literature review of national and international experiences of social and environmental safeguards in sectors other than the AFOLU sector, as well as existing national guidelines and tools on gender equality, just transition, social inclusion and human rights in the energy, housing, water and sanitation, industry and transport sectors.
The review and analysis of information should take into account the following variables or items:
• Specific risks of mitigation measures in the different sectors (both environmental and social)
relevant to Colombia.
• National regulations.
• International examples of safeguards in carbon market standards.
• Guidelines for safeguards of sectoral projects (not necessarily mitigation).
 Deliverable 3. Stakeholders and experts - SPAR6C Program
One (1) document containing the map of relevant actors from the energy, housing, water and sanitation, industry and transport sectors, public and private sectors, civil society and academia at the national and subnational levels. The document shall prioritize key stakeholders and experts and propose guiding questions for conducting interviews with the prioritized stakeholders to inform the initial proposal.
 Deliverable 4. Initial proposal of social and environmental safeguards to sectors different than the AFOLU sector
One (1) document containing proposed social and environmental safeguards in the energy, housing, water and sanitation, industry and transport sectors, including the elements and different perspectives by sector. The document shall include at least:
• Overview
• Conceptual framework
• Basic concepts
• International context and experiences
• National context and experience
• Regulatory background and progress in the regulation related of social and
environmental safeguards in Colombia.
• Proposed safeguards for each sector: energy, housing, water and sanitation, industry and
transport.
• References
• Annexes
• Final infographic for digital broadcasting
 Deliverable 5. Methodological proposal for a presentation and validation workshop with SPAR6C team and selected experts.
One (1) document containing the agenda, methodology and documentation of the workshop to present, validate and gather feedback about the initial proposal of environmental and social safeguards for the energy, housing, water and sanitation, industry and transport sectors.
 Deliverable 6. Guidelines of environmental and social safeguards for the energy, housing, water and sanitation, industry and transport sectors.
One (1) document with a Social and Environmental safeguards for carbon markets in the energy, housing, water and sanitation, industry, and transport sectors, including the elements and different perspectives by sector, and the feedback gathered in the above mentioned workshop.
 Deliverable 7. Handbook of Social and Environmental Safeguards
One (1) Handbook presenting pedagogically the social and environmental safeguards for the energy, housing, water and sanitation industry and transport sectors that could be integrated into capacity building initiatives of the IKI Program and other counterparts, such as the Ministry of Environment and Sustainable Development.
 Deliverable 8. Consultancy summary
One (1) word document no longer than 10 pages (in English and Spanish) and a PowerPoint Slide deck no longer than 10 slides (in English and Spanish) summarizing the main outcomes of this consultancy will be developed by the Service Provider, and with the most important milestones, achievements, and corresponding recommendations
  For more details, please refer to the Terms of Reference (TOR) document attached.
IMPORTANT TIMELINES:
The tender submission deadline is 8 January 2024, 16:00 pm KST (Korean Standard Time).
If any bidder has any request for clarification on the TOR or any part of the tender documents, GGGI will be happy to clarify if they are received on or before 7 days before the deadline (namely: if the tender submission deadline is 16:00 15 April KST, then the due date for submission of request for clarification is 16:00 8 April KST).

title: Consultancy Services to Undertake Detailed Feasibility Studies to Guide Establishment of Wetland Eco-Parks in Two Cities in Uganda
description:
GGGI Uganda is inviting eligible firms/entities to submit their proposals for consultancy services to undertake feasibility studies and prepare detailed feasibility reports to guide the establishment of wetland eco-parks in two cities, Kampala and Masaka.
 PROJECT BACKGROUND:
Despite Government of Uganda’s (GoU) efforts, wetland degradation has continued especially in urban centres which has contributed to the reduction of green spaces in the cities and an increment in water related disasters such as floods. Among the key reasons leading to degradation is the fact that the communities and other stakeholders do not appreciate the tangible benefits from well managed wetlands. In order to address this gap, the GoU through the Ministry of Water and Environment (MWE) is proposing to transform some of the urban wetlands into Eco-parks. Once established, Eco-parks are expected to provide a range of ecological, social and economic benefits to the communities, the environment and the economy. It is envisaged that the transformation of Uganda’s urban wetlands into Eco-parks and planning of green areas will have long term benefits in the two cities. Key benefits will include but not limited to; greening the cities, cushioning the cities against adverse impacts of climate change, generation of income for the cities and the communities but also enhance the ecological functioning of the wetlands among others.  
Eco-parks are of great national and international importance, since their existence can help to minimise wastes, reduce soil and water pollution, provide educational facilities for visual leaning and applied research, recreation centres, greening of cities and employment opportunities as well as climate amelioration. Based on research works, Eco-parks have been used to offer a better quality of life and employment to citizens especially communities that live adjacent to these ecosystems (Refaat, 2014). 
Once established, the Ecoparks will operate on Public Private Partnership model. In this regard, Government will set up the required infrastructures including Ecotourism infrastructure, Green hotels (restaurants and kiosks), Education centers to cater for higher and lower institutions of learning, Children leisure parks etc. The established infrastructure, will then be leased out to the private sector (companies and individuals) to run them as business. Funds and taxes raised from the different enterprises will be used to sustain the Ecoparks.
In this respect, the MWE is desirous to engage a competent consulting firm (the Consultant), possessing requisite qualifications to prepare Detailed Feasibility Report (DFR) to guide establishment and development of Eco-parks in Kampala and Masaka 
 OBJECTIVE OF THE ASSIGNMENT:
Under the main objective of the consultancy the selected Consultancy firm shall:
i.	Undertake in-depth DFR’s of technical, financial, legal, regulatory, environmental, social and economic feasibility of establishing wetland eco-park in the 2 cities of Uganda.
ii.	Develop detailed designs for the Eco-parks that adhere with city planning regulations, relevant Environment laws, regulations & other legal frameworks for infrastructure development in the country.
iii.	Undertake a Market analysis and generate a marketing and promotion plan to guide the implementation of the commercial elements of the Eco-parks.
  SCOPE OF WORK:
The scope of services intended to be provided by the selected bidders under this assignment shall include but is not limited to the following:
a.	Conduct a reconnaissance and preliminary assessment of the 2 proposed sites through field visits, review of existing documents, maps and existing data/information.
b.	Review available information on topography population, geology soils, ground water, storm water drainage, flooding, Land cover, land use, rainfall, human settlements, flora and fauna, pattern in and around dump sites.
c.	Review available information from other jurisdictions and countries that have successfully established Eco parks.
d.	Carryout the detailed topographic survey of the wetlands in the 2 cities and delineate the boundaries of the proposed sites highlighting areas of conservation, restoration and areas of modification,
e.	Produce detailed site layout plans for critical infrastructure and utilities showing land allotted for various proposed functions including walk boards, ramblers, education centres, restaurants, wetland protection and restoration sites etc.
f.	Carryout the plant and soil characterization of the site and recommend the suitable indigenous species of plants, shrubs and trees suitable for various sections of the Eco-parks
g.	Assess the community readiness, gender and social aspects of the sites in regards to the Eco-parks establishment
h.	Assess the environment for the likely environmental impacts during construction, operation and those that will arise from location & design and proposed mitigation measures 
i.	Carryout consultations with the stakeholders and wherever required conduct site specific consultations disclosing the project information but also identify number of people who will be affected by the ecopark.
j.	Undertake a Market analysis and generate a marketing and promotion plan to guide the implementation of the commercial elements of the Ecoparks. 
k.	Analyze the cost and financial aspects of the park for preparation of various scenarios pertaining to project financing and project cost.
  For more details, please refer to the Terms of Reference (TOR) document attached. 
 IMPORTANT TIMELINES:
The tender submission deadline is 26 February 2024, 16:00 pm KST (Korean Standard Time).
If any bidder has any request for clarification on the TOR or any part of the tender documents, GGGI will be happy to clarify if they are received on or before 7 days before the deadline (namely: if the tender submission deadline is 16:00 15 April KST, then the due date for submission of request for clarification is 16:00 8 April KST).

title: Supply and Installation of the Solar-powered Water Supply System for Biloya Coffee Processing Cooperatives
description:
GGGI Ethiopia Country Office invites eligible bidders to submit their bids for the supply and installation of the solar-powered water supply system for Biloya Coffee Processing Cooperatives.
 PROJECT LOCATION:
The location of the project is Biloya Coffee processing cooperatives in SNNP region, Gedeo zone, Kochore Woreda, Ethiopia
 SCOPE OF WORK, SUPPLIES, and SERVICES: 
The major Goods supplied and installed by the selected bidders are listed below:
•	Procurement of the PV module and PV module structure, mounting kit and accessories
•	Procurement of the pump motor set, control board, cables, and all accessories
•	Procurement of all accessories (cables, inverters, auxiliaries) to fulfill the operation need of the system

title: Consultancy Services for Development of Internal Standards for Entity Seeking Green Climate Fund Accreditation
description:
GGGI Indonesia is inviting eligible firms/entities to submit their proposals for the following scope of work:
 PROJECT BACKGROUND:
GGGI and the Fiscal Policy Agency (FPA) implement the Green Climate Fund (GCF) Readiness and Preparatory Support project (“the Readiness Project”) in Indonesia. The FPA is the National Designated Authority (NDA) of the GCF in Indonesia. In September 2022, the FPA started a multiyear Readiness Project “Enhancing Indonesia's Access to International Climate Finance and Private Sector Investments for Climate Actions” to support the NDA in enhancing national actors’ institutional capacities to build a pipeline of climate change projects and to increase country ownership. The NDA has selected GGGI as the Delivery Partner to implement this project. Overall, the project aims to mobilize international climate finance and private sector investment to close the financing gap across the priority sectors identified by the Government of Indonesia.
 Pursuant to the overall objective of the Readiness project, Indonesia has announced prioritization for national entities to get nominated for GCF DAE accreditation, which was directed to banking and financial institutions. As intermediaries, banking and financial institutions have more flexibility to offer financing schemes for various green sectors than NGOs or private institutions with more specific mandates or expertise on certain sectors only. Typically, banks are also better equipped to price risks and estimate returns more accurately of those companies applying for green financial products. Besides, the trend of financial institutions’ engagement with GCF or other forms of climate finance is likely to continue in the near future. Regarding the accreditation of national financing institutions, currently, Indonesia has one state-owned special mission vehicle under Ministry of Finance, that is accredited as DAE, namely PT SMI, and two commercial banks as nominated candidate DAEs, including Bank CIMB Niaga.
 Entities seeking accreditation to access GCF resources will be assessed against the GCF’s Fiduciary principles and standards, Environmental and Social (E&S) and Gender Policy. As initial support, the FPA has conducted a capacity needs assessment for the three entities. Based on the findings from the assessment, relevant internal standards for nominated candidate DAEs need to be developed to support their endeavor to GCF accreditation.
 OBJECTIVE OF THE ASSIGNMENT:
GGGI seeks to contract an eligible consulting firm (hereinafter referred to as ‘Firm’) to develop the required internal standards for financing institution nominated as GCF DAE candidate. This is to help prepare the nominated entities for GCF accreditation process and requirements. The assignment will contribute to achieving the objectives of Indonesia’s Readiness Project on building the capacity of direct access applicants in meeting GCF accreditation standards.
 PROPOSED ACTIVITIES:
The selected Firm shall perform the following activities:
a.	Conduct stakeholder consultations with NDA and nominated DAE candidate. 
b.	Select two types of Internal Standards Documents. 
c.	Develop the internal standards documents.
d.	Provide technical assistance to nominated DAE during the GCF accreditation process. 
 For more details, please refer to the Terms of Reference (TOR) document attached. 
 IMPORTANT TIMELINES:
The deliverables will take place over a period of twelve (12) months.
The tender submission deadline is 6 October 2023, 16:00 pm KST (Korean Standard Time).
If any bidder has any request for clarification on the TOR or any part of the tender documents, GGGI will be happy to clarify if they are received on or before 7 days before the deadline (namely: if the tender submission deadline is 16:00 15 April KST, then the due date for submission of request for clarification is 16:00 8 April KST).
 Interested parties will be required to register their details on the GGGI e-Green Procurement Portal (https://in-tendhost.co.uk/gggi).
 HOW TO OBTAIN THE DOCUMENTS:
Documents can be accessed via the e-Green Procurement Portal by selecting ‘View Details’ on the relevant notice and then clicking the ‘Tender Application’ button. If you are a new supplier, you will be required to register your details. If you have an existing account, you will need to login to the portal. Please refer to the guidance documents under the `Supplier Guidance` area of the portal for further information.

Select the 2nd tab (`Tender Documents`) where you will find useful information regarding the RFP. title: Thailand Country Readiness Assessment and Landscape Analysis in the Integrated Municipal Solid Waste Management
description:
GGGI Thailand is inviting eligible firms/entities to submit their proposals for the following scope of work:
 PROJECT BACKGROUND:
“Advancing ASEAN-Korean Cooperation in Integrated Municipal Solid Waste Management (IMSWM) for Environmentally Sustainable Cities” program aims to support ASEAN Member States (AMS) in moving towards a model of resource-efficient, circular society with enhanced national and local capacity to implement integrated municipal solid waste management practices and catalytic waste investment projects.
This project overall aims to: (i) formulate a strengthened and coherent regional framework for IMSWM in AMS to support ASEAN Vision 2040 and ASCC Blueprint 2025; (ii) accelerate investment for IMSWM projects; (iii) establish an online multi-stakeholder knowledge sharing and collaboration platform for AMS; and (iv) strengthen IMSWM capacity in AMS and AMS-Korea knowledge exchange, through policy, capacity development, knowledge and technology transfer, and investment mobilization across the region. The following are the key activities in the 3-year program:
1)	Assessing the solid waste management context of selected AMS from governance (policy, legal, strategic, planning), financial, environmental, operational and social perspectives. 
2)	Develop an ASEAN integrated municipal solid waste management strategy.
3)	Develop and initiate a project pipeline in the selected AMS.
4)	Implement capacity-building activities in Korea for governmental officials. 
5)	Develop an online platform to support exchanges among stakeholders involved in solid waste management at different levels.
 ASSIGNMENT OBJECTIVE: 
The objective of this assignment is to support the development of Activity 1 (above) in Thailand. Activity 1 involves the assessment of solid waste management, which entails analyzing the extent of policy development regarding solid waste management and its practical implications at the sub-national level in Thailand. The assignment encompasses analyzing two distinct levels, namely, the national level and sub-national level assessments. 
 For more details on the scope of work, please refer to the Terms of Reference (TOR) document attached. 
 IMPORTANT TIMELINES:

title: Diagnostics of the national climate project landscape: green innovation drivers, opportunities, and challenges - SPAR6C Thailand
description:
GGGI Thailand is inviting eligible firms/entities to submit their proposals for the following scope of work under “Supporting Preparedness for Article 6 Cooperation” or SPAR6C Program:
 PROJECT BACKGROUND:
The SPAR6C project has four activities in Thailand during 2022-2027 as part of Work Package V:  
•	A0. Needs and readiness assessment 
•	A1. Medium and long-term low emission planning 
•	A2. Governance framework implementation 
•	A3. Pilot transactions 
•	A4. Capacity building
 The objective of this call is to find a Service Provider providing technical support for the SPAR6C program linked to Activity 3 of the SPA6C program “Pilot transactions”. 
 SCOPE of WORK:
The activities under this technical assistance comprise of:
1. creating assessment criteria for green innovative business cases in line with A6 principles
2. mapping and profiling private sector green innovation cases suitable for A6 projects, selecting 10 business cases based on maturity and eligibility
3. evaluating these 10 cases against the criteria to shortlist the top 3
4. analysing challenges and opportunities for private sector participation in A6
5. offering recommendations to policymakers, organizations, and the private sector to enhance private sector-led climate innovation in Thailand, potentially informing the country's A6 strategy.
 The selected bidder shall engage with relevant stakeholders to systematically map and profile national climate project landscape, particularly focusing on green innovative business cases from private section with significant GHG reduction and/or removal potential. The bidder shall identify and characterize the innovations and/or technologies best suited to meet the additionality requirements for A6 projects.
 PROPOSED ACTIVITIES:
The five activities under this assignment are as follows:
1.	Development of a set of criteria for assessing green innovative business cases
2.	Mapping the green innovative business cases from the private sector with significant GHG mitigation potential
3.	Assessment of the selected green innovative business cases against a set of criteria.
4.	Assessment of the challenges and opportunities faced by the private sector for effective participation in A6 activities
5.	Provide insights and recommendations for policymakers, organizations and private sector to harness private sector-led innovation for enhanced climate action
 For more details, please refer to the Terms of Reference (TOR) document attached. 
 IMPORTANT TIMELINES:
The tender submission deadline is 9 January 2024, 16:00 pm KST (Korean Standard Time).
If any bidder has any request for clarification on the TOR or any part of the tender documents, GGGI will be happy to clarify if they are received on or before 7 days before the deadline (namely: if the tender submission deadline is 16:00 15 April KST, then the due date for submission of request for clarification is 16:00 8 April KST).

title: Development of Thailand Article 6 Operations Manual - SPAR6C Thailand
description:
GGGI Thailand is inviting eligible firms/entities to submit their proposals for the following scope of work under “Supporting Preparedness for Article 6 Cooperation” or SPAR6C Program:
 PROJECT BACKGROUND:
The SPAR6C project has four activities in Thailand during 2022-2027 as part of Work Package V:  
•	A1. Needs and readiness assessment 
•	A2. Medium and long-term low emission planning 
•	A3. Governance framework implementation 
•	A4. Pilot transactions 
 The objective of this call is to find a Service Provider to provide technical support for the SPAR6C program in Thailand. The support is linked to Activity 2 “Governance framework”.  
The project comprises two specific final deliverable objectives for the selected Service Provider, as well as supporting analysis and preliminary work required to deliver the main outlines. 
 The activities are as follows:
1.	Development of an Article 6 operations manual
2.	Analysis and assessment of current legal landscape and options 
 SCOPE of WORK
Proposed activities for the selected bidder are outlined as follows:
 1)	Development of an Article 6 Operations Manual for Thailand.
 A comprehensive A6 Operations Manual for Thailand shall be developed to guide the generation of Article 6 activities; all existing Thai carbon market regulations, including the CCMGM, shall be reviewed and considered. The operations manual shall be based on the activity cycle that has already been identified in previous gaps and needs assessment reports. 
 The identified activity cycle is the following:
I.	Project Idea Note (PIN) submission
II.	Memorandum of understanding (MOU) with the ITMO purchasing entity
III.	Letter of Intent (LOI) approval
IV.	Project Design Document (PDD) and SD & Safeguards Assessment Report
V.	Project registration under premium T-VER standard
VI.	Letter of Authorization (LOA) approval as an Article 6 project activity
VII.	Monitoring report with SD & Safeguards Report
VIII.	Carbon Credit Issuance
IX.	Cancellation-to-recreation of ITMOs
X.	Corresponding adjustment towards NDC and Reporting
  For more details, please refer to the Terms of Reference (TOR) document attached.
