title: Decision making on the sharing of mitigation outcomes and crediting periods for activities under the Article 6 of the Paris Agreement in Thailand
description:
GGGI Thailand is inviting eligible firms/entities to submit their proposals for the following scope of work under “Supporting Preparedness for Article 6 Cooperation” or SPAR6C Program:
 PROJECT BACKGROUND:
The SPAR6C project has four activities in Thailand during 2022-2027 as part of Work Package V:  
•	A1. Needs and readiness assessment 
•	A2. Medium and long-term low emission planning 
•	A3. Governance framework implementation 
•	A4. Pilot transactions 
 The objective of this call is to find a Service Provider to provide technical support for the SPAR6C program in Thailand. The support is linked to Activity 3 “Governance framework implementation”.
 SCOPE of WORK
Leaning on Guide 1 “Article 6 Strategy” developed by the SPAR6C project, this assignment shall describe the different steps and processes needed in in the future which Thailand may agree on to implement the tools and options listed above. Additionally, the project will engage relevant pre-approved stakeholders (either separately or as lead group discussions) for input and feedback. The selected Service Provider shall carry out the following activities:
 1.	Develop a report to describe the tools portrayed in this concept note, the different design decisions available for each tool, and the benefits associated with their application. Additionally, if there are additional tools that should be considered, they should also be added to the report. The Service Provider shall also include analysis on international application of these tools and the reason they were shaped as-so (to the extent this information is available).
 o	This should also include the detailed implications of each (but not limited to) of the following:
a.	Implications for the NDC and long-term low emission planning
b.	Implications for engagement of the private sector
c.	Implications for project development
d.	Implications for attractiveness to buyer countries
e.	Implications for the VCM
f.	Reputational implications and context of reputational discussions, including the spirit of the Paris Agreement
g.	Extension, renewal, or amendment options to crediting periods, and implications to potential activity types with reference to Thailand’s mitigation potential under the current NDC and future revisions
h.	Additional implications that the contractor shall identify and consider
 2.	Identify stakeholders involved in decision making in the context of Thailand (and why they are relevant). A preliminary list of stakeholders includes, but is not limited to:
o	Relevant government agencies
o	Thai project developers
o	International organisations in Thailand working on/with carbon markets
o	Other stakeholders from the private sector
o	Knowledge hubs / think tanks familiar with the development of carbon markets in Thailand, i.e., universities
o	Representatives of buyer countries to learn about needs or restrictions from their side regarding different contributions and payments
 3.	Identify the policies and regulations that might influence decision making in these areas in the Thai context.
4.	Draft a set of proposed "principles" identified for decision making around the tools associated with ITMO transactions to guide the government. 
 5.	Engage in dialogues with stakeholders as determined by the Thai government, specifically:
o	Carry out capacity building for key stakeholders on the topic and consult their views and expertise regarding the different options presented.
o	Consult with a list of pre-approved private sector stakeholders and international buyers on this issue to make sure proposed recommendations respond to the market.
 6.	Prepare recommendations for the design of such tools in Thailand based on the analysis and consultations.
7.	Map out proposed steps for decision making, including who should make the decision, in what policy/legal format they should be codified (if any) and when/how those decisions should be made.
8.	As a follow-up to this activity a workshop shall be organised by the Service Provider presenting results to relevant decisionmakers and stakeholders, allowing for a discussion with government officials on potential next steps for SPAR6C in support of a Thai A6 Strategy
  For more details, please refer to the Terms of Reference (TOR) document attached. 
  IMPORTANT TIMELINES:
The tender submission deadline is 9 January 2024, 16:00 pm KST (Korean Standard Time).
If any bidder has any request for clarification on the TOR or any part of the tender documents, GGGI will be happy to clarify if they are received on or before 7 days before the deadline (namely: if the tender submission deadline is 16:00 15 April KST, then the due date for submission of request for clarification is 16:00 8 April KST).
 Interested parties will be required to register their details on the GGGI e-Green Procurement Portal (https://in-tendhost.co.uk/gggi).
 HOW TO OBTAIN THE DOCUMENTS:
Documents can be accessed via the e-Green Procurement Portal by selecting ‘View Details’ on the relevant notice and then clicking the ‘Tender Application’ button. If you are a new supplier, you will be required to register your details. If you have an existing account, you will need to login to the portal. title: Assessment of biomass changes caused by wood removals for fuelwood and charcoal production in Zambia (Research Study)
description:
GGGI Zambia is inviting eligible firms/entities to submit their proposals for the following scope of work under SPAR6C Program, funded by the German Federal Ministry of Economic Affairs and Climate Action (BMWK) through the International Climate Initiative (IKI):
 Important note:
To bid for this tender firms/entities must have a legal registration in Zambia. Consortia led by a local (Zambia) entity are encouraged to bid for this RFP. Please note that all payments will be made solely to the local entity's bank account in Zambia. 
 PROJECT BACKGROUND:
Study objectives to improve the NDC reporting were identified through a Readiness and Needs Assessment conducted under the SPAR6C Program, funded by the German Federal Ministry of Economic Affairs and Climate Action (BMWK) through the International Climate Initiative (IKI). The overall objective of SPAR6C is to improve the readiness of countries to participate in cooperative approaches under Article 6 of the Paris Agreement by engaging the private sector and working closely with governments. SPAR6C’s activities will facilitate the development of the international carbon market created by Article 6, leading to cost-efficient, flexible, high integrity carbon markets with positive, transformational sustainability impacts.
SPAR6C will support the Government of Zambia to improve the database and calculation of emission from Forest Land remaining Forest Land (FF) on biomass changes a) caused by wood removals for fuelwood and charcoal consumption, b) in undisturbed forest areas, and c) caused by forest fires. The following two studies should be carried out:
•	Study 1:  
Assessment of biomass changes caused by wood removals for fuelwood and/or charcoal consumption
•	Study 2:  
Assessment of biomass changes in a) undisturbed forests (IPCC category: Forest Land remaining Forest Land) and b) forest areas disturbed through forest fires.
 OBJECTIVE OF THE ASSIGNMENT:
This assignment encompasses the scope of work to complete Study 1 “Assessment of biomass changes caused by wood removals for fuelwood and/or charcoal consumption”.
The national forest inventory describes the following five different vegetation classes: (i) Dry evergreen forest, (ii) Dry deciduous forest, (iii) Moist evergreen forest, (iv) Forest woodlands, and Forest plantations (compare IlUA report . 
 A “Demand and Supply” approach should be used to identify the impact of fuelwood consumption on the five major vegetation classes defined by the National Forest Inventory conducted in 2016. 
•	“Demand” - An in-depth analysis of current consumption of fuelwood for cooking/heating and charcoal production should be carried out. Afterwards, the area size of woodland needed to produce this amount of fuelwood has to be calculated. After the subtraction of deforested areas for fuelwood production (remote sensing analysis), the amount of fuelwood coming from forest areas remaining forest areas is estimated.  
•	“Supply” - The field survey must be structured according to vegetation types, which are suitable for fuelwood supply. After identification of fuelwood collection and charcoal production areas, socio-economic surveys will be conducted to estimate fuelwood consumption. 
 PROPOSED ACTIVITIES:
The selected bidder shall carry out the following analysis and activities: 
1.	Demand analysis 
1.1.	Analyze the five major vegetation classes regarding their potential to provide wood for fuel or charcoal production 
1.2.	Compare the current energy mix in rural and urban areas with the national fuelwood study 
1.3.	Predict future dynamics of energy consumption 
1.4.	Analyze population dynamics
 2.	Supply analysis 
2.1.	Identify fuelwood collection and charcoal production areas for socio-economic survey
2.2.	Conduct socio-economic surveys to estimate fuelwood consumption
 3.	Data analysis and reporting (compare chapter “Deliverables” below)  
 For more details, please refer to the Terms of Reference (TOR) document attached. 
 IMPORTANT TIMELINES:
The tender submission deadline is 8 January 2023, 16:00 pm KST (Korean Standard Time).
If any bidder has any request for clarification on the TOR or any part of the tender documents, GGGI will be happy to clarify if they are received on or before 7 days before the deadline (namely: if the tender submission deadline is 16:00 15 April KST, then the due date for submission of request for clarification is 16:00 8 April KST).

title: Acceleration Firm to support “Accelerating Innovative Startups for Energy Efficiency” (AIS4EE) project, Viet Nam
description:
GGGI and the EU Delegation in Viet Nam under the “Accelerating Innovative Startups for Energy Efficiency” (AIS4EE) project are inviting eligible firms/entities to submit their proposals to support start-ups in implementing marketable innovative Energy Efficiency (EE) solutions:
 For this assignment, a consortium with potential investor groups, e.g., venture capital, corporate venture capital, and impact funds, is strongly recommended to increase the probability of investment mobilization for start-ups at the end of the acceleration program. Thus, it is highly recommended for bidders to forge a strategic consortium for this opportunity.
 PROJECT BACKGROUND:
AIS4EE aims to achieve three main targets: 
•	Accelerating innovation through financial and technical assistance: the accelerator program will support energy efficiency start-ups with well-developed business models and near-market-ready solutions. (Outcome 1).
•	Enhancing policy framework for innovative start-ups in energy efficiency through policy gap analysis and consultation with relevant stakeholders. (Outcome 2).
•	Improving innovative ecosystem for energy efficiency start-ups through close collaboration with national and international universities; development of knowledge sharing products; opportunities for different stakeholder groups to engage through online platforms and in-person networking events. (Outcome 3).
 AIS4EE program, with its Outcome 1, aims to support the development of EE solutions by innovative start-ups through the implementation of acceleration programs. Activities under this Outcome will provide training and coaching to qualified start-ups selected through a competitive process to prepare them to mobilize investments, i.e., acceleration program.  This acceleration program will also connect startups with potential local and international investors through pitching events organized in Viet Nam and overseas. The acceleration will be designed to focus on energy efficiency solutions towards the targets under the VNEEP 3 in sectors such as industry, transport, and green buildings.  
 Among targeted results of the AIS4EE program, Outcome 3 aims to foster the development of a robust, innovative ecosystem for energy efficiency start-ups, with initiatives to build up a dedicated startup ecosystem on energy efficiency and develop a knowledge sharing and networking online platform. AIS4EE's networking initiative will focus on connecting startups with policy makers, scientists, businesses, and financial institutions who are interested in energy efficiency through sharing of knowledge and experience. This network will collaborate with the existing network for energy conservation and clean production organized by the Ministry of Industry and Trade. AIS4EE will develop a knowledge sharing and networking online platform for startups working in/for energy efficiency sector. The platform will serve as an information portal for the acceleration program.
 OBJECTIVE OF THE ASSIGNMENT:
Under the guidance of the GGGI Viet Nam Country Representative, supervision of the AIS4EE Project Manager, and close collaboration with the Project Team, the selected bidder shall design and implement high quality energy efficiency (EE) start-up acceleration program, with a main objective of facilitating deals between start-ups and investors. The bidder shall also design and implement networking activities, and develop and implement an online knowledge sharing platform, both of which significantly to the strengthened EE startups ecosystem in Viet Nam. 
 PROPOSED ACTIVITIES:
1)	Start-ups Acceleration and Investment Mobilization 
1.1	Design of the Acceleration Program 
1.2	Implementation of the Acceleration Program
1.3	Specific tasks in designing and implementing the program: 
 2)	Energy Efficiency Start-ups Ecosystem Development, Knowledge Sharing, and Communications
2.1	Development of Energy Efficiency Start-ups Ecosystem 
2.2	Development of Open Database on Innovative Start-ups for Energy Efficiency
2.3	Strategic Communications
 For more details, please refer to the Terms of Reference (TOR) document attached. 
 PRE-BID CONFERENCE:
The pre-bid conference for this RFP will be held virtually through M/S Teams. Date and Time shall be announced on the GGGI e-Green Procurement Portal ‘Clarifications’ tab. 
Interested parties should send the email addresses of the attendees through e-Procurement Portal (Correspondence Tab) to receive the e-invitation.

title: Pre-FEED study of Green Hydrogen-Fertilizer Site in Nepal (re-tender for 100008714)
description:
(RE-TENDER) GGGI Nepal is inviting eligible consultancy firms/entities to submit their proposals for the following scope of work under the Green Hydrogen Ammonia Project in Nepal:
 PROJECT BACKGROUND:
Hydropower can offer a cost-effective electricity supply solution compared to other sources of renewable energy (solar, wind, and geothermal) required for production of green hydrogen. The renewable energy sector of Nepal is expected to grow rapidly with hydropower as the dominant form of renewable energy. The technical potential for hydropower in Nepal is 83 GW; 42 GW is estimated to be commercially exploitable. According to Norwegian University of Science & Technology (NTNU), Nepal is expected to have an excess of 3.5 GW of electricity by the end of 2028, and Nepal has an opportunity to produce green hydrogen from its vastly available hydro power.  Given the availability of excess power and the enormous hydro potential provided by Nepal's geography, Nepal has the tallest mountains on earth all along its northern border. These mountains have glaciers that provide a more-or-less permanent source of water for the foothills and Indo-Gangetic Plain to the south. GGGI is supporting the Government of Nepal (GoN) to explore productive use of hydro power and set up the first green hydrogen and fertilizer plant in Nepal to alleviate the national need for fertilizer imports.
 OBJECTIVE OF THE ASSIGNMENT:
The objective of this assignment is to select a competent consultancy firm (hereinafter referred to as ‘Consultant’) to conduct a pre-Front-End Engineering and Design (FEED) study comprised of a technical, economic, and financial assessment of a green-fertilizer production plant coupled with a green H2 plant in Nepal. The technical specifications and the financial assumptions and considerations presented in the study should be backed by actual quotations or written/formal communication with market players, ideally global market leaders, in the technologies (vendor engagement).  GGGI will not accept assumptions and information unless they are backed by authentic quotes, technical data, and specifications provided by vendors/OEMs/manufacturing companies. 
 The assignment will build on a preliminary optioneering/review of 6 potential sites for a future green H2-fertilizer plant prepared by GGGI.
 PROPOSED ACTIVITIES:
The selected Consultant shall produce a Pre-FEED study on a green H2-ammonia fertilizer plant in Nepal. The Pre-FEED study should focus on the types of fertilizers that are most relevant for Nepal and the bidder’s technical component should therefore indicate the types of fertilizer to be included in the study. The capital cost estimates in the Pre-FEED study should meet AACE Class 4 level of accuracy (+/- 30% accuracy).
 For more details, please refer to the Terms of Reference (TOR) document attached. 
 IMPORTANT TIMELINES:
This project is expected to be completed by 1 March 2024.
The tender submission deadline is 30 October 2023, 16:00 pm KST (Korean Standard Time).

title: Development of a Climate Change Adaptation Finance Tracking System, Burkina Faso NAP Implementation
description:
GGGI Burkina Faso is inviting eligible firms/entities to submit their proposals for the following scope of work under “Integrating Adaptation into Local Planning, Strengthening Institutional Frameworks, and Developing a Financing Strategy and Project Concept Notes for the Implementation of Burkina Faso's NAP”:
 PROJECT BACKGROUND:
Burkina Faso is highly exposed to the adverse effects of climate variability and change due to its geographical location in the center of the Sudano-Sahelian zone of West Africa. The country is exposed to several natural hazards, including droughts, floods, epidemics, heat waves, windstorms, and insect infestations. These threats impede the country's development and contribute to problems such as desertification, land degradation, food insecurity, increased poverty, and migration out of the central part of the country. Aware of these challenges, the Government developed a National Adaptation Plan (NAP) in May 2015 with the vision: "Burkina Faso intends to better manage its economic and social development by implementing planning mechanisms and measures that take into account resilience and adaptation to climate change by 2050". The NAP is currently under review.
In view of its low level of development, Burkina Faso expects most of these resources from its external partners. According to ECOWAS, while there is a trend towards a steady increase in climate finance flows at the global level, they remain well below the levels needed to achieve the transition to low-carbon and climate-resilient development. The monitoring of these flows is now a priority for the countries of the Region, on the one hand given the obligations of "transparency of action and support needed and received" stemming from the Paris Agreement (Article 9 of the Paris Agreement) from 2024 onwards and on the other hand to better coordinate climate action at the national level.
 SCOPE of WORK:
The general objective of the mission is to provide the Government of Burkina Faso an operational and dynamic system for monitoring and verifying internal and external financing investments for climate projects in general and adaptation projects in particular in connection with the mobilization of adaptation resources at the national level. This operational system for monitoring climate financial flows will be hosted on the Adaptation Information Sharing website to ensure the dissemination of information and foster communication with stakeholders on climate finance.
 PROPOSED ACTIVITIES:
For the success of the mission, the selected bidder shall: 
1.	Collect the required data and information and process them; 
2.	Analyze the framework for monitoring financial flows in Burkina Faso as well as the barriers and assess whether or not climate finance is taken into account;
3.	Take stock of the state of internal and external climate/adaptation finance flows in the light of the guidelines set out in the national climate/adaptation resource mobilization strategy; 
4.	Organize and coordinate the contributions of stakeholders (ministry of the economy, accredited entities) to the supply of the system and confirm with the DNA/FVC and the SP/CNDD the alignment of the system with the adaptation web platform; 
5.	Propose a dynamic system for collecting/collecting and monitoring and verifying the different financing flows of climate/adaptation projects and make available to the SP/CNDD and the NDA/GCF the dedicated tools and instruments for collecting and feeding the system;
6.	Prepare the terms of reference for the training workshop for teams from the SP/CNDD, NDA/GCF, relevant financial institutions and relevant stakeholders; 
7.	Train the teams of the SP/CNDD, NDA/GCF, relevant financial institutions and appropriate stakeholders (i.e. About thirty people) on the use of the monitoring and evaluation tools for climate/adaptation finance flows developed; 
8.	Propose a user manual and test the functionality of the developed system;
9.	Accompany the SP/CNDD and NDA/GCF team over a period of six (06) months for the use of the system.
 For more details, please refer to the Terms of Reference (TOR) document attached. 
 IMPORTANT TIMELINES:
The tender submission deadline is 27 February 2024, 16:00 pm KST (Korean Standard Time).
If any bidder has any request for clarification on the TOR or any part of the tender documents, GGGI will be happy to clarify if they are received on or before 7 days before the deadline (namely: if the tender submission deadline is 16:00 15 April KST, then the due date for submission of request for clarification is 16:00 8 April KST).

title: Supply and installation of Solar Home Systems for 54 households in LIFE-AR initiative, Ethiopia
description:
GGGI Ethiopia Country Office invites eligible bidders to submit their proposals for the supply and installation of solar home systems for 54 households in Oromia regional state, Ethiopia. 
 PROJECT LOCATION:
The location of the project is three integrated kebele, in Kembibit woreda, North Shewa zone in Oromia regional state. 
 SCOPE OF WORK, SUPPLIES, and SERVICES: 
The project described below concerns the supply, and installation of off-grid electrification of public institutions, which are found in the Oromia regional state of Ethiopia. 
The major Goods supplied and installed by the selected bidders are listed below.
•	Supply and installation of the PV module and PV module structure
•	Supply and installation of the Battery, control board, inverter, distribution board, cables, and all accessories
•	Supply and installation of the fence with its appropriate door
•	Supply and installation of earthing materials, and other materials as indicated on the bill of quantity. 
  For more details, please refer to the Request for Proposals (RFP) document attached.

title: Supply and Delivery of 75 Waste bin units to business entities in Vang Vieng District, Vientiane Province, Lao PDR
description:
REQUEST FOR QUOTATION - GGGI Lao is inviting eligible vendors to supply and deliver 75 Waste bin units to business entities in Vang Vieng District, Vientiane Province, Lao PDR under the ‘ASEAN Municipal Solid Waste Management Enhancement' project.
 For more details on the Specifications and Schedule of Supply please refer to the RFQ document attached.
1.	The Global Green Growth Institute (GGGI) hereby requests you to submit price quotation(s) for the supply of the items posted in GGGI’s e-Green Procurement Portal (https://in-tendhost.co.uk/gggi):
a)	Schedule of Supply (Excel)
b)	Price Schedule of Goods form (Excel)
 If you, however, have been associated with the firm that prepared the design, and specifications of the contract that is subject to this procurement, you shall be disqualified.
 To assist you in the preparation of your price quotation we enclose the necessary technical 
specifications and required quantities. 
 2.	You must quote for all items under this request. Price quotations will be evaluated for all items together and contract awarded to the firm offering the technically responsive items and lowest evaluated total cost of all the items.
 3.	You must submit only one set of quotations containing:
a)	Business Registration Certificate
b)	Mandatory Disclosure
c)	Availability of Financial Resources Form
d)	Personal Data Consent form
e)	Mandatory Certification Form
f)	Schedule of Supply (Excel)
g)	Proof of past performances: adequate technical documentation, contract(s), certification(s), catalogue(s) or other printed material, pertinent information in English for each item quoted, including names and addresses of firms providing after-sales service facilities.
h)	Price Schedule of Goods for the items (Excel)
 electronically via GGGI’s e-Green Procurement Portal.
 4.	Your quotation shall be written in ENGLISH.
 5.	The deadline for receipt of your quotation(s) by GGGI is specified in GGGI’s e-Green 
Procurement Portal.
 6.	Your quotation(s) must be submitted as per the following instructions and in accordance with 
the attached form of Contract. The attached General Conditions of Contract is an integral part of the Contract.
 i)	PRICES: The prices must be quoted for supply and delivery to place(s) of destination. Prices must be in USD and should not include tax. Based on the Official Development Assistance Financial Management Rules No. 2695/MOF dated 1st November 2010, the Contractor shall be exempted from import duties, Excise and Value Added Taxes for the purpose of this works. All other taxes directly linked to the provision of the services or supply of the goods under this contract which the Tenderer may incur shall be included in the Financial Component.
 ii)	EVALUATION OF QUOTATIONS: Offers determined to be substantially responsive to the technical specifications will be evaluated by comparison of their prices. An offer is not substantially responsive if it contains material deviations or reservations to the terms, conditions, and specifications in this request, and it will not be considered further. In evaluating the quotations, GGGI will adjust for any arithmetical errors as follows:
a)	where there is a discrepancy between the unit rate and the line-item total resulting from multiplying the unit rate by the quantity, the unit rate as quoted will govern; and
b)	if a Supplier refuses to accept the correction, his quotation will be rejected.
 iii)	AWARD OF CONTRACT: The award will be made to the bidder offering the lowest evaluated price and that meets the required standards of technical and financial capabilities. The successful bidder will sign a Contract as per attached form of contract and terms and conditions of supply.
 iv)	VALIDITY OF THE OFFER: Your quotation(s) must be valid for a period of ninety (90) days from the deadline for the submission of quotation(s) indicated in GGGI’s e-Green Procurement Portal.
 7.	If you withdraw your quotation during the validity period and/or refuse to accept the award of a contract when and if awarded, then you will be excluded from the list of suppliers for the project for two years.
 8.	The bidder whose quotation has been accepted will be notified of the award of contract via GGGI’s e-Green Procurement Portal within the bid validity period.
 9.	Further information can be obtained via GGGI’s e-Green Procurement Portal (https://in-tendhost.co.uk/gggi).
 10.	Under GGGI’s Anticorruption Policy and Procurement Rules, bidders shall observe the highest standard of ethics during the procurement and execution of such contracts. GGGI will reject a proposal for award, and will impose sanctions on parties involved, if it determines that the bidder recommended for award or any other party, has engaged in corrupt, fraudulent, collusive, or coercive practices in competing for, or in executing, the Contract. At the time of submission of your quotation or contract signature, you must not be in UN’s sanctions list (https://www.un.org/sc/suborg/en/sanctions/un-sc-consolidated-list) or have been debarred for a period exceeding one year or for an indefinite period by any Multilateral Development Bank (MDB), including the African Development Bank Group, the Asian Development Bank, the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, the Inter-American Development Bank or the World Bank Group. 
 IMPORTANT TIMELINES:
The delivery shall be arranged in two phases with phase one delivering 40 units by November 2023 and phase 2 delivering the remaining 35 units by February 2024.
 The tender submission deadline is 25 October 2023 16:00 pm Korean Standard Time (KST).

title: Implementation of the Sustainable Finance Mobilization Strategy and the Sustainable Taxonomy of Mexico
description:
GGGI for its project in Mexico invites eligible firms to submit their bids for the consulting services to “Implement the Sustainable Finance Mobilization Strategy and the Sustainable Taxonomy of Mexico”
 BACKGROUND
Between 2019 and 2021, the Ministry of Finance and Public Credit of Mexico (SHCP, for its acronym in Spanish) as National Designated Authority (NDA) of the Green Climate Fund (GCF), through the GCF Readiness Programme, has received support to develop the activities that enhance and strengthen Mexico’s climate finance architecture to mobilize public and private, national, and international, climate financing for mitigation and adaptation projects and programs in the country.  
In 2022, a Multiyear GCF Readiness Programme started its implementation to continue strengthening capacities of the SHCP aiming to foster the sustainable finance ecosystem within the country. As part of this Readiness, it is necessary to effectively develop and adopt a Sustainable Finance Mobilization Strategy for Mexico (EMFS, for its acronym in Spanish). The objective of this Strategy is to serve as a comprehensive framework that encompasses the initiatives, actions, and goals required to facilitate the mobilization of sustainable investments within the country and complying with best practices such as, participation on sustainable debt markets, implementation of a sustainable taxonomy, ESG policies and performance, international sustainable funding, identification and disclosure of financial risks related to climate change and biodiversity loss, capacity building on sustainability topics, financial inclusion and cross-cutting attention to gender gaps. This will support to the achievement of Mexico's climate and sustainable commitments. 
In the process of developing the EMFS, several important milestones have been accomplished. Firstly, the establishment of a technical working group was crucial for the development of the EMFS. Additionally, a methodology was created to gather data from stakeholders regarding the essential objectives and actions that the EMFS should address. These achievements were accomplished in 2022. Looking ahead to 2023, on September 18th 2023, the EMFS was published by the SHCP. Furthermore, workshops will be organized to facilitate widespread awareness and understanding of the EMFS among various stakeholders.  The EMFS will be a living document to be enhanced in the years to come, based on country needs and the feedback from stakeholders. 
One important tool for the implementation of the EMFS is the Sustainable Taxonomy of Mexico (TSM, per its acronym in Spanish). The SHCP, in collaboration with other institutions in the financial sector, including the Sustainable Finance Committee, published the TSM in Q1-2023 aiming to have a better understanding on the level of sustainability of products and services from the financial sector and real-asset sectors. The primary objective of the TSM is to provide a classification framework that establishes criteria and thresholds to assess whether a project meets sustainability standards while also ensuring compliance with the principles of "Do No Significant Harm", “minimum safeguards” and addressing gender gaps. The first stage of the TSM focuses on three main objectives: 1) Mitigation of climate change, 2) Adaptation to climate change, and 3) Gender equality. Sustainable assets will generate impact investment on climate change on 124 activities from six main economic sectors (agriculture, forestry and livestock; generation, transport and distribution of energy and water; manufacturing industry; construction; transport and waste management). Moreover, the objective of gender equality is cross-cutting to all sectors of the economy and will direct funding toward projects that help close gender gaps. It is intended that credit institutions, institutional investors, and issuers implement the TSM to label their sustainable investments and projects according to this classification system.     
 To promote the implementation of both the EMFS and the TSM by stakeholders, there are a number of planned activities that will be led by the SHCP to contribute with their proper adoption. These activities involve the creation and strengthening of capacities of the entities in the financial sector, generation of reliable information for the market and policy makers, and the generation of conditions that provide greater certainty and transparency to the markets in terms of sustainable finance. GGGI supports the development and implementation of such activities within the SHCP, through funding from the UK Partnering for Accelerated Climate Transitions (UKPACT). The execution of the activities will prepare stakeholders for the upcoming regulation related to the implementation of the TSM and the alignment to the EMFS. In this regard, the SHCP and users of, both, the EMFS and the TSM, require technical support to institutionalization of capacities. For this, GGGI develops three tools: a) a website aimed to create capacities on general sustainable finance topics, including the scope of EMFS (Plataforma de Finanzas Sostenibles), b) a Massive Online Open Course (MOOC) on the Sustainable Taxonomy of Mexico and, c) a Pilot Programme for the implementation of the TSM and the application of the EMFS on proposed institutions as described in the scope of this consultancy. 
Within the Pilot Programme and application of the EMFS, 10 institutions will be participating, and they will be chosen by the SHCP reflecting the most systematical important financial institutions of Mexico in terms of their market share in regard to the number of assets, robustness and progress in the implementation of sustainability strategies, as well as its track record in the design and development of financial products and services labelled as sustainable and eligible from the TSM. These institutions include the participation of commercial and development banks, pension funds, insurance agencies, investment funds, and public equity firms. The pool of institutions will be composed by 3 commercial banks, 3 development banks, 1 pension fund, 1 insurance agency, 1 investment fund, and 1 issuer.  
Considering the steps needed for a successful implementation of the EMFS and the TSM, GGGI is seeking to engage a competent firm (hereinafter referred to as “the Consulting Firm”) for the below objectives: 
1) General identification of the level of alignment of the sustainable vision/strategies from chosen institutions to the objectives established in the EMFS; 
2) Provide general recommendations for the alignment of sustainable strategies from chosen institutions to the EMFS; 
3) Accompany the chosen institutions on a deep dive analysis of the alignment of their green portfolio to the Sustainable Taxonomy; 
4) Identify gaps and barriers for the process of adoption of the Taxonomy by the institutions;
5) Identify the mobilized funding marked as sustainable from the public and private sector which will serve as the baseline for an effective monitoring of increments or changes in the allocation of the resources under the EMFS
  PROPOSED ACTIVITIES & SCOPE OF WORK
The selected Consulting Firm shall help in the implementation of the EMFS and the implementation of the TMS. As part of the desk analysis and information to be communicated to key stakeholders, is necessary to further increase the level of knowledge on the funding that has been mobilized and earmarked as Sustainable in Mexico. For this, the Consulting Firm shall develop a deep dive study that evidence the amount of mobilized funding allocated in sustainable projects from governments, the private, and public sector in Mexico, from 2018 until Q3 of 2023. The amount of economic resources identified as sustainable funding will serve as a baseline for measuring the effectiveness of the EMFS in the future. 
 In the same line, the Consulting Firm shall perform an assessment of the Sustainable Strategies of 10 institutions (previously chosen by the SHCP based on the importance regarding the contribution to the financial system of Mexico) to analyze the alignment to the objectives stated in the EMFS such as participation in sustainable debt markets, implementation of sustainable taxonomy, ESG policies and performance, financial risks related to climate change and biodiversity loss, capacity building, capacity building needs, and cross-cutting attention to gender gaps. From the findings of this assessment, the Consulting Firm shall provide general recommendations to each institution on how to align their corporate strategies to the EMFS. The Consulting Firm shall also provide general recommendations to the SHCP of gaps needed to be addressed by the EMFS as part of the analysis mentioned in this paragraph.  
 Furthermore, the Consulting Firm shall work hand-to-hand with the proposed institutions to determine the alignment of their portfolios and projects financed in 2022, to the TSM, as a back testing exercise or as an exercise of a potential new issuing. The back testing will cover no more than two economic sectors of the TSM per institution, and this sector will be chosen based on the characteristics of each institution’s portfolio. For this, the Consulting Firm shall conduct a revision of the portfolio to identify the most adequate projects to be assessed according to risks, amounts, sector knowledge, and other aspects that will be defined jointly by the consultant, SHCP and GGGI. The Consulting Firm shall gather all information in spreadsheets and develop a document containing the findings of the Pilot Programme including gaps, barriers and common issues that emerged during the implementation of the TSM, as well as recommendations to surpass those findings and adjust/enhance the TSM.  
 SCOPE OF WORK
Under the scope of work for this assignment, the selected Consulting Firm shall complete the following:
•	The Consulting Firm shall conduct research to identify the mobilized funding earmarked as “Sustainable, Green or Social” from the public and private sector in Mexico, from January 2018 until September 2023. For this task, the Consulting Firm may use their own databases or resources, including gathering the information from public government reports or corporate reports, as well as from public or private databases. The quantity of sustainable resources identified will serve as the baseline for the further evaluation of the effectiveness of the EMFS in mobilizing new sustainable funding. 
•	The Consulting Firm assess the sustainability strategies from 10 institutions (chosen by SHCP) to identify the alignment of the institutional vision to the objectives stated in the EMFS in terms of participation in sustainable debt markets, implementation of sustainable taxonomy, ESG policies and performance, financial risks related to climate change and biodiversity loss, capacity building on sustainable finance, capacity building needs, and cross-cutting attention to gender gaps.
•	After the conclusion of the assessment mentioned above, the Consulting Firm shall elaborate general recommendations to align the sustainability strategies from each participating institution to the EMFS. In addition, the Consulting Firm shall make general recommendations to enhance the EMFS to the SHCP, based on feedback provided by the chosen institutions.
•	The Consulting Firm shall request information from each chosen 10 institutions about the projects or investments allocated in 2022 for any of the six sectors considered in the TSM.
•	The Consulting Firm shall perform a revision of the portfolio of each of the institution to identify the most adequate activities that shall be evaluated, as well as the recommended number of projects to be contrasted with the Taxonomy. The arguments to identify the most adequate projects shall be proposed by the Consulting Firm and agreed by the SHCP and the GGGI.     
•	The Consulting Firm shall provide advisory on the process to determine the level of alignment of projects and investments to the TMS, for the relevant economic sectors identified in each institution. This process will be performed as a back testing exercise with existing projects or investments allocated in 2022. If applicable, the pilot can be utilized as a preparation for a future issuing. The information for each case will be provided by the chosen institutions. The Consulting Firm shall accompany the chosen institutions in solving questions and orienting on how to align projects and investments to the TSM. For this exercise, the SHCP with GGGI´s support has developed a Sustainable Taxonomy Implementation Excel filter (Tool) that can be used by the Consulting Firm and the institutions in determining the alignment of their portfolios or projects to the Taxonomy. The number of projects that will be assessed will be those funded by investments made in 2022, in at least 2 sectors from the TSM, per institution.  
•	Assisting each chosen institution, the Consulting Firm shall oversee the classification of the projects and investments regarding the Taxonomy, the applicability, thresholds, avoidance of significant harm, and compliance with minimum safeguards. As a result, the Consulting Firm shall identify the Sustainable Asset Ratio (amount of the sustainable aligned assets divided by the total amount of assets in the portfolio). The assistance shall be provided mostly in live sessions (virtual and in-person) and by email. 
•	Provide feedback to the chosen institutions on the alignment of the projects or investments, to the Sustainable Taxonomy. The feedback shall be provided mostly in live sessions (virtual and in-person) and by email. The sessions and narrative for conducting feedback will be led by the SHCP with the participation of GGGI and the Consulting Firm. 
•	Consolidate the findings of the process on reports, identifying barriers, gaps, frequently asked questions, and opportunities for improvement for the implementation of the EMFS, the TSM and its Tool, to be further included in the actualized versions of these frameworks. 
The deliverables related to the implementation of the TSM must be developed first, and the deliverables related to the implementation of the EMFS in second, considering the timetable and agenda of the Ministry of Finance and Public Credit of Mexico. Deliverables will be owned by SHCP. The deliverables may not be published on any website, media, social network, or any other similar means of dissemination without the prior written consent of SHCP. The deliverable’s non-public content may not be published on any website, media, social network, or any other similar means of dissemination without the prior written consent of GGGI.
 For more details, please refer to the Terms of Reference (TOR) document attached.
 IMPORTANT TIMELINES:
The tender submission deadline is 7 November 2023, 16:00 pm KST (KOREAN STANDARD TIME).
If any bidder has any request for clarification on the TOR or any part of the tender documents, GGGI will be happy to clarify if they are received on or before 7 days before the deadline (namely: if the tender submission deadline is 16:00 15 April KST, then the due date for submission of request for clarification is 16:00 8 April KST).
 Interested parties will be required to register their details on the GGGI e-Green Procurement Portal (https://in-tendhost.co.uk/gggi).

title: Legal Advice for Building Open and Sustainable Carbon Market in Lao PDR
description:
GGGI Lao is inviting eligible firms/entities to submit their proposals for following scope of work:
 PROJECT BACKGROUND:
GGGI will support the Ministry of Natural Resources and Environment to implement the “Building Open Sustainable Carbon Markets in Lao PDR” program, funded by the Government of Australia through the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade (DFAT) during 2023-2026. GGGI will provide policy support and technical assistance to the Government of Lao PDR to create a multi-sectoral policy and regulatory framework for its participation in international carbon markets and to identify viable mitigation projects. The project’s first outcome during 2023-2024 focuses on establishing the policy, institutions, and systems to further build carbon trading readiness and enable the country’s participation to international carbon markets. A significant deliverable under this outcome is the formulation (and adoption) of a national carbon market decree by 2023. This decree should be adapted to the country’s context and aligned to international rules of engagement under the Paris Agreement.
 OBJECTIVE OF THE ASSIGNMENT:
The objective of this consultancy is to provide expert technical and legal advice to GGGI for the development of a comprehensive carbon market decree that aligns Lao PDR’s legal framework with the Paris Agreement’s Article 6, emerging international voluntary market guidance and international best practices, and existing laws and regulations in Lao PDR.
 PROPOSED ACTIVITIES:
Proposed activities for this Consultancy are as follows:
Activity 1: Undertake a rapid scoping of the legal and regulatory context with recommendations.
Activity 2: Provide a draft outline of a Carbon Market Decree
Activity 3: Formulate the draft Carbon Market Decree
Activity 4: Revise the draft Decree following initial consultations, towards finalization
 For more details, please refer to the Terms of Reference (TOR) document attached. 
 IMPORTANT TIMELINES:
The assignment shall be completed over a period of 12 months.
The tender submission deadline is 5 October 2023, 16:00 pm KST (Korean Standard Time).

title: Pakistan Climate Technology Roadmap for NDC Implementation
description:
GGGI is inviting eligible firms/entities to submit their proposals for the following scope of work:
 PROJECT BACKGROUND:
The significance of technology in the implementation of absolutely any policy on climate change is inevitable. The technology roadmap around NDCs for Pakistan is required to encompass areas such as technology needs; specific technologies to be deployed; technology innovation and research and development; policy, regulatory and legal aspects; and support to be provided to other Parties for technology development and transfer. This CTCN technical assistance, CTCN has contracted the Global Green Growth Institute (GGGI) to work with the Pakistan Ministry of Climate Change (MoCC) with the aim to develop a detailed Technology Roadmap for key NDC adaptation and mitigation sectors, namely waste and water, with Renewable Energy and Gender as cross-cutting sectors, to enable an effective implementation of underlying priority technologies. This will also play a critical role in providing the right enabling environment for effective incorporation of technology in its NDC implementation and improvement process.
The NDC Technology Roadmap is aimed to have a clear positive impact for gender and youth in terms of direct benefits of the mitigation and adaptation technologies, as well as their implication in their deployment and scale-up. This includes increased resilience, economic savings, and health benefits on one side, and improved professional opportunities on the other side. The Global Green Growth Institute will work closely with the Ministry of Climate Change (MoCC) to manage a team of national and international technical experts.
 OBJECTIVE OF THE ASSIGNMENT:
The selected bidder shall be responsible for ensuring effective stakeholder engagement and providing technical expertise into all phases of the Technology Roadmap development process.
 For more details, please refer to the Terms of Reference (TOR) document attached. 
 IMPORTANT TIMELINES:
GGGI anticipates that the assignment wil to begin in December and will continue until June 2024.

title: Feasibility Study to Identify Viable Business models for the Valorization of Organic Waste in Jordan
description:
GGGI for its projects in the Jordan invites all interested firms to submit their proposals for the provision of consulting services to conduct a feasibility study to Identify Viable Business models for the Valorization of Organic Waste in Jordan
 PROJECT BACKGROUND & OBJECTIVES
There is an increasing recognition globally to switch towards a circular economy approach to tackle the challenges of waste management. The transformation from a linear to a circular economy (CE) requires a much stronger commitment to sustainable management of waste and resources. Jordan has recognized the need for sustainable waste management and took several steps since 2015 through developing the National Solid Waste Management (SWM) strategy, The Waste Management Framework Law No.16 of 20201, and the National Green Growth Waste Management Action Plan2 regional and local SWM plans, establishing separation schemes for recyclables, and composting among other.
Oxfam, in partnership with GGGI, is implementing a 24-month project funded by the European Union aimed at identifying and assessing innovative approaches to promote circular economy in Jordan, with the following 3 main components:
1. implement demonstrative actions in Za’atari Refugee Camp and in a hosting community in the
governorate of Mafraq, piloting the separation, collection, and treatment of organic waste to
produce useful organic compost, and the reuse of treated grey water for irrigation.
2. Promote circular economy for SMEs in Jordan through the provision of sub-grants for business
models and innovative prototypes. This activity aims to provide financial and technical support
to circular/green enterprises in Jordan with projects/concepts designed to create industrial
systems change through redesign, reuse, and business model innovation.
3. Identify and develop business models targeting organic waste valorisation suitable for
subsequent investment, to provide sustainable solution for organic waste management in the
country
 OBJECTIVE OF THE ASSIGNMENT:
The objective of this assignment is to support the delivery of component 3, by conducting a country-wide study to assess key organic waste streams in Jordan and developing business models resulting from a feasibility study of the most valuable and effective solutions for organic waste management challenges in Jordan. GGGI is seeking to contract a Consultancy Firm to provide such services, as elaborated upon in this Request for Proposals
 PROPOSED ACTIVITIES AND SCOPE OF WORK:
1) Proposed Activities for the Overall Project
The Consulting Firm shall conduct the following 3 tasks with close consultation with GGGI and OXFAM:
• Task 1: Assessment of the key organic waste streams and existing treatment methods in Jordan
• Task 2: Shortlisting of feasible organic waste management schemes for local context
• Task 3: Conduct technical and economic studies on the top 2 selected projects including a
robust and sustainable financial model and implementation modalities
• Task 4: Presentation and validation of feasibility assessments and business models to key
stakeholders
  2) Scope of Work
The Consulting Firm shall execute the following scope of work and activities for each of the three main tasks described above:
 Task 1: Assessment of the main organic waste streams and existing waste treatment methods in Jordan
• Identify key sectors and major sources that generate organic waste in Jordan, e.g. organic
municipal waste, agro-processing waste (including liquid effluents, beverages, abattoir, etc.),
agricultural waste (e.g. residue from date palm farms, olive, fruits orchards, dairy farms, manure),
food industry, tobacco, garden, yard and park waste, wood and wood products, pulp, paper,
cardboard, etc.
• Identify existing major organic waste treatment schemes (landfilling, dumping, burning,
valorisation, etc.) in place in the country, with indicative volumes treated, a brief description of
the business model and ownership.
o A sub-task for this activity should look at existing activities and projects that are
implemented to address solutions for organic waste management in Al Hussainiyat
Landfill. This includes compost activities for the dumpsite.
• Analyse value chains and map out key stakeholders. This includes sources, types and volumes of
waste, generation, storage, transport, and processing. Match with potential valorisation
solutions such as compost, animal feed, biogas, fuel biomass, green methanol, etc. This should
include a quantification of total waste available at national level (in tons) as well as an estimate
of maximum treatment potential production for each waste treatment option listed above.
• Identify work and activities that have already been implemented, ongoing or planned in relation
to the subject.
• Identify synergies of solutions for organic waste management across different administrative
bodies (e.g. GAM, MOE, and MOLA).
 Task 2: Shortlisting of feasible organic waste management schemes for local context
• Based on the finding of Task 1, and in consultation with relevant public and private
stakeholders, develop a long list (around 10) of potential organic waste management schemes
suitable for investment into valorisation of organic waste and evaluate corresponding
technologies.
• The list can contain either large scale standalone waste treatment facilities (e.g. biogas,
compost or methanol), retrofitting equipment (e.g. in an abattoir or beverage company), or a
decentralized small scale program (e.g. rural biogas program at farm level).
• Develop a decision-making/screening matrix (e.g. methane emission reductions potential,
volumes available, willingness to take part, availability of technology, market for products, likely
financial viability) and select the two most promising projects, in consultation with main
stakeholders.
 Task 3: Technical and Financial Studies
• Conduct a technical and financial study on the 2 shortlisted projects. Estimate optimal scale,
feedstock supply, preliminary site assessment, suitable technology type, transport, equipment
required, CAPEX/OPEX, market study for the products, etc. Preliminary greenhouse gas
emission savings will be calculated, and climate resilience benefits will be assessed.
• Develop corresponding sustainable business models and propose implementation modalities.
• Assess barriers and enablers to implementation (regulatory, policy, financial, logistical, and
awareness), including requirement for a gate fee, other incentives (such as feed-in tariff) and
policy measures
 Task 4: Presentation and validation of feasibility assessments and business models to key stakeholders
• Development of explanatory power points and other relevant support material to present to
key stakeholders.
• Delivery of presentations, recommendations, and validation of the results with key national
stakeholders
  For more details, please refer to the Terms of Reference (TOR) document attached.
IMPORTANT TIMELINES:
The tender submission deadline is 2 January 2024, 16:00 pm KST (Korean Standard Time).

GGGI will reject a proposal for award, and will impose sanctions on parties involved, if it determines that the bidder recommended for award or any other party, has engaged in corrupt, fraudulent, collusive, or coercive practices in competing for, or in executing, the Contract. title: Efficacy and safety evaluation for buriti, cacay and seje oil for the production and merchandising of natural oils by Bioingredientes Amazónicos
description:
GGGI for its project in Colombia invites eligible firms to submit their bids for the subject tender ‘Efficacy and safety evaluation for buriti, cacay and seje oil for the production and merchandising of natural oils by Bioingredientes Amazónicos’
PROJECT BACKGROUND
GGGI has been working with the Government of Colombia to advance green growth policies and green investments through strategic partnerships such as with the Ministry of Environment and Sustainable Development, the Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development, the Ministry of Treasury and Public Credit, and the National Planning Department (DNP), among others. Since 2014, GGGI has supported the DNP in its objective of advancing a green growth vision and transition plan for Colombia that can support climate goals and SDGs achievement. GGGI supported the development of the Green Growth Taskforce led by DNP (2016-2018), which produced solid and relevant information for the design and concertation of the Green Growth Policy- GGP (adopted by means of CONPES 3934 of 2018).
One strategic axis of the GGP aims to promote the sustainable use of natural capital, which includes the Bioeconomy as one key strategy to foster the low carbon economy through adding value to generate products, processes, and services based on the responsible use of biodiversity and biomass. In that regard, GGGI supported the Ministry of Science, Technology, and Innovation - MinCiencias, the National Planning Department, and other stakeholders in the technical design and concertation of the National Bioeconomy Mission “Para una Colombia Potencia viva y diversa: hacia una Sociedad impulsada por el conocimiento”.
Besides, GGGI was awarded by the UKPACT program in Colombia to develop the project “Accelerating the development of new bioeconomy businesses and enhanced capacities for green jobs promotion and increased climate action ambition from policy implementation and integration”, in which a Bioeconomy Accelerator Mechanism is created and will enhance the capacity of bioeconomy business and strengthen the capability of MinCiencias to meet their target of 126 and 500 bioproducts endorsed by 2022 and 2030, respectively. Complimentarily, a knowledge-sharing component will disseminate case studies, lessons learned, best practices, and recommendations.
In that regard, GGGI, with Minciencias’ support, launched the third version of the Bioeconomy Projects Acceleration Mechanism – MAPBIO call, receiving (12) proposals that were evaluated through a multicriteria analysis by GGGI, Minciencias and INNpulsa, and selecting (2) enterprises as beneficiaries.
GGGI is working with Bioingredientes Amazonicos, a Company based in Putumayo, Colombia, that aims to produce and merchandise natural oils from buriti, cacay and seje in the Amazon Basin. GGGI is supporting Bioingredientes Amazonicos in strengthening the market strategy, validation of the functionality and security of the ingredients, and the legal requirements to access the American, Ecuadorian, and European markets. The present project is intended to enhance the efficacy and safety demonstration of three (3) natural oils
 PROPOSED ACTIVITIES;
The project involves the following activities:
Scope 1: Safety evaluation Scope 2: Efficacy evaluation
 For more details, please refer to the Terms of Reference (TOR) document attached.

title: Analyzing the legal and regulatory environment for promoting building energy efficiency in Mongolia.
description:
GGGI Mongolia seeks to hire a professional firm to perform cross-sectorial legal analysis in construction, energy and building energy efficiency sectors. Analyze current legal and regulatory environment and identify and recommend solutions for eliminating gaps, conflicts, overlaps and improve inter-sectoral coherence to allow the construction sector to fulfill their pledge in reducing CO2 emissions and create legal and regulatory environment that incentivizes energy efficiency in the construction sector. 
 PROPOSED ACTIVITIES FOR THE OVERALL PROJECT  
The work shall begin in December 2023 for a duration of up to two months. The Firm shall be responsible for conducting cross-sectorial legal analysis for coherence and promoting energy efficiency in the building sector in consultation with key stakeholders and work closely with GGGI and GIZ during the contracting process. The Firm, as a registered professional firm with knowledge of and expertise in Mongolian energy sector, construction, energy and construction regulatory environment shall analyze current legal environment, identify gaps, overlaps and conflicts, and propose appropriate options, solutions and approaches. It is the Firm’s role to take all action and carry out legal analysis in consultation with and subject to the approval of key stakeholder and where necessary with GGGI/GIZ. This shall be done by conducting discussions and stakeholder interviews, round table discussions and workshops with sector stakeholders such as Energy Regulatory Commission (ERC), MCUD, Construction companies, Construction development center, energy Auditors and the local government of Ulaanbaatar. 
 SCOPE OF WORK
Under this assignment, the Firm shall cover the scope of the cross-sectoral legal analysis for energy efficiency and/or conservation in the construction sector as described below.
Part 1. Analysis of the legal environment:
•	Review and analyze current circumstances, including legal, institutional, regulatory framework for energy efficiency and conservation in the construction sector. This includes energy, construction and building energy efficiency (sub)sectors. 
•	Conduct a comparative analysis of the regulations pertaining to energy-saving initiatives in the construction sector, as delineated in the national-level legal documents of Mongolia. 
–	Analyze coherence, gaps, overlaps among/between key legal and regulatory documents across subject (sub)sectors. The analysis should include institutional arrangements and coordination and coherence among key institutions. The NDC and Government policy on Construction sector includes targets and actions for energy efficiency in the construction sector. However, progress remains unsatisfactory, partially due to the inadequacy of legislation governing matters related to the enhancement of building energy efficiency. Moreover, despite the update of the norm pertaining to the overall enclosure of buildings that ensures heat consumption (Building code 23-01-09) within the Mongolian building code, there remains a deficiency in legal regulations aimed at improving the energy efficiency of existing construction and facilities.
–	Determine how relationships concerning the construction sector, including energy conservation in precast panel buildings, are regulated within the framework of the Law on Energy Conservation, Law on Construction, Law on Urban Development, Law on Housing, and other relevant construction sector legislation and regulations. 
–	Identify inter-sectoral relationships, particularly those involving construction, energy, social health, and more, concerning construction energy conservation.
–	Evaluate the legal environment for implementing the criteria for products and policy impact, as reflected in Provision 4 of the "State Policy on the Construction Sector," including financing aspects.
–	Determine necessary legal provisions to support the implementation of the Nationally Determined Contributions to Implement the Paris Agreement.
Part 2. Findings and recommendations:
•	Summarize lessons learned from other countries in ensuring coherence and interplay for facilitating and promoting energy conservation and energy efficiency in the construction sector.
•	Prioritize the gaps, overlaps, conflicts that need resolution first to facilitate practical implementation.
•	Present a clear conclusion and recommendations of the existing legal and regulatory environment and propose clear steps and phases. Where necessary provide recommendations for updating/revising key sectoral legislation, including but not limited to Energy conservation law, Construction law, Energy law etc. 
•	Recommend phased approaches on resolving the conflicts, filling in gaps and removing the overlaps. 
Working Arrangement
The project team and Project Steering Committee will be responsible for all final approvals pertaining to this contract.
The Firm shall prepare documents in English and Mongolian that are of professional quality in terms of grammar, style, and formatting, reflecting the standards of comparable documents in the field, in accordance with GGGI’s specifications
  For more details, please refer to the Terms of Reference (TOR) document attached.
 IMPORTANT TIMELINES:
The tender submission deadline is 21 November 2023, 16:00 pm KST (Korean Standard Time).
If any bidder has any request for clarification on the TOR or any part of the tender documents, GGGI will be happy to clarify if they are received on or before 7 days before the deadline (namely: if the tender submission deadline is 16:00 15 April KST, then the due date for submission of request for clarification is 16:00 8 April KST).

Retrofitting the Makerere University Urban and Physical Planning Training Centre, Uganda
description:
GGGI Uganda is inviting eligible suppliers/service providers for the services to the subject tender ‘Retrofitting the Makerere University Urban and Physical Training Centre’ detailed below:
 PROJECT BACKGROUND:
The above center will play a crucial role in shaping the future of cities and regions by providing expertise, research, and guidance to create more sustainable, livable, and resilient urban environments. Among the roles include providing training programs, workshops, and educational resources for urban planners, architects, engineers, and other professionals involved in urban development. These programs can help build capacity and promote best practices in the field. In addition, the centre will enable the conducting of research on urban and physical planning issues, such as transportation systems, housing affordability, environmental sustainability, and urban design. This research can provide valuable insights and data for policymakers and practitioners.
 OBJECTIVE OF THE ASSIGNMENT:
Specifically, under Outcome 1: Green City Development is pursued and developed in four (4) secondary cities, of the project, output 1.4 seeks to establish a knowledge and engagement platform at Makerere University. Acitivity 1.4.1.5 that is focused on furnishing of the Virtual learning centre office with equipment will facilitate the following;
1.	Provide internal finishes, painting, and tiling.
2.	Carry out walling and openings/ partitioning as may be appropriate.
3.	Demolition and removal as may be appropriate.
4.	Carry out general cleaning, signposts, and walkways.
5.	Provide mechanical and electrical installations as may be appropriate.
 PROPOSED ACTIVITIES:
The selected Supplier shall complete the following:
i.	Provide internal finishes, painting, and tiling.
ii.	Conduct walling and openings/ partitioning as may be appropriate.
iii.	Demolition and removal as may be appropriate.
iv.	Carry out general cleaning, of signposts, and walkways.
v.	Provide mechanical and electrical installations as may be appropriate.
 SITE INSPECTION:
Site inspection will take place at the proposed site (CEDAT, Makerere University) on 28th November 2023 from 9 am to 4pm Uganda Local Time. For more information please GGGI Uganda office on +256 (0) 782757919; Ministry of Water and Environment, Plot 3-7, Kabalega Crescent Road, Luzira. P.O. Box 20026 Kampala.

title: Scoping Studies on Pacific Technical Assistance Call-Down Facility and Pacific Climate Finance Evidence and Knowledge Platform
description:
GGGI for its projects in the Pacific Region invites all interested firms to submit their proposals for the provision of consulting services to conduct scoping Studies on Pacific Technical Assistance Call-Down Facility and Pacific Climate Finance Evidence and Knowledge Platform.
 PROJECT BACKGROUND & OBJECTIVES
Pacific Island Countries (PICs) are dispersed across the world’s largest ocean and while generally small in land area, have large oceanic resources and are highly diverse geographically, economically, ecologically and culturally. PICs are highly exposed to the adverse effects of climate change such as tropical cyclones, sea-level rise, droughts and increasing temperatures which are negatively impacting their economies, human and physical capital, and long-term resilient development. Access to finance for Small Island Developing States (SIDS) thus needs to be accelerated and funds mobilized and translated into project implementation with urgency. However, despite some success in project approval, the scale and pace of financial flows in the region is not commensurate with the existential threat posed by climate change to Pacific nations. Mobilisation and implementation of climate finance is beset by various challenges: international development and climate finance architecture is complex, there are data gaps for design of mitigation and adaptation projects and high transaction costs and small project sizes make it difficult to attract investments. 
A major barrier to access, absorb and deliver climate finance is limited preparedness and capability in key institutions such as government ministries, national funds, regional and national accredited entities and development banks. This means that even when climate finance is approved there can be considerable delays in deploying this funding. Lessons learnt from completed climate change projects are also not collated, shared nor proactively utilized to inform new projects. New mandates for fast-tracking climate finance delivery and implementation stemming from COP26 signalled that increased finance flows are about to be available to SIDS. PICs must be able to seize this opportunity. The next five years is therefore critical for unlocking access to finance in PICs and supporting them to strengthen absorption and delivery capacity to enable implementation before 2030.
For this reason, a program was developed “Strengthening Institutional Capability to Access, Absorb and Deliver Impactful Climate Finance in the Pacific” by the Global Green Growth Institute and the Foreign Commonwealth and Development Office of the Government of the United Kingdom and funded by the UK as part of the SIDAR Programme.
The Programme aims to increase PICs’ resilience and adaptive capacity to climate change and reduce their CO2 emissions in line with National Adaptation Plans and NDC commitments through enhanced capacity and institutional capability to improve access to climate finance and strengthen their absorptive capacity for efficient delivery of impactful climate change programmes. Its two main outputs are:
1)	Six Long-term embedded technical advisors to strengthen institutional capability to access, absorb and deliver impactful climate finance
2)	Strategic feasibility studies to strengthen long-term climate finance implementation and knowledge sharing
The two studies that are being delivered under this program are i) Pacific Technical Assistance Call-Down Facility Scoping Study and ii) Pacific Climate Finance Evidence and Knowledge Platform.  
 PROPOSED ACTIVITIES FOR OVERALL PROJECT
i) The Pacific Technical Assistance Call-Down Facility study will aim to establish the demand and modalities for a Pacific Call Down Facility to provide demand-driven, pre-paid specialized short-term technical assistance for climate change projects. The aim of the scoping study is to examine the options and modalities for a technical assistance facility. The technical assistance provided by the facility could meet needs such as up to 12 weeks of technical support on coastal defenses, renewable energy, proposal grant applications for the Green Climate Fund (GCF) or the Adaptation Fund. The technical assistance facility should be able to be accessed quickly and efficiently by PIC governments and other eligible institutions. 
The mechanism would ideally be pre-funded so that eligible institutions can submit a request for rapid access specialist TA to help them deliver climate finance projects. The aim is for the facility to enable access to and deploy of assistance rapidly, within 1-2 months of the need being identified. The Facility would be accessible to ODA eligible PICs and associated organisations. 
 ii) The Pacific Climate Finance Evidence and Knowledge Platform study will aim to assess demand and modalities to improve knowledge sharing and lessons learning from climate change projects in order to promote replication and scale up. 
 The underlying assumption for the study is that there is a growing body of knowledge from the implementation of climate change projects in the Pacific. However, this information is not readily accessible to climate change practitioners designing, developing, and implementing projects in PICs. This scoping study will assess how climate change project specific lessons, for example from end of programme/project evaluations, workshops and reporting, can be pro-actively disseminated. 
   SCOPE OF WORK
The Incumbent service provider named consultant in this ToR shall undertake the scoping study including;
 For i) the Pacific Technical Assistance Call-Down Facility study;
• An analysis of demand for a call-down facility 
• Review of existing mechanisms and their effectiveness incorporating recent reviews mechanisms such as that of the RTSM – Regional Technical Support Mechanism. Lessons learnt and best practice of existing mechanisms should also be captured.  
• If a new mechanism is proposed how it would be designed and function (to note the presumption is to work with existing mechanisms) 
• Costed options for delivery will be prepared (including a do-nothing option, and considering governance and accountability) 
• How to work with regional partners
 For ii) Pacific Climate Finance Evidence and Knowledge Platform;
The scoping study will examine how the lessons learnt can be made easily accessible and disseminated to climate change practitioners across the region including;
A review of the existing platforms for knowledge sharing and explore if a new mechanism could contribute in this space.  
The study will assess whether an existing regional institution(s) can act as a repository for key evaluation and learning documents and analyse such data and proactively share key lessons to promote replication and scale up. 
The scope for lesson learning with other regions, notably the Caribbean 
 The activities are described in detail below:
Activity 1: Kick-off meeting with GGGI and the British High Commission to validate the inception report agreeing on scope and expectations of the study.
 Activity 2: Scoping study for a draw down facility 
2.1 Review of existing mechanisms and their effectiveness
  	based on a desktop review data checking and guidance from key stakeholders 
2.2 Review of proposed mechanism or adaptation of current mechanism
2.3 Draft complete report and stakeholder validation meeting
2.4 Final report submission incorporating changes agreed in the validation meeting
 Activity 3: Pacific Climate Finance Evidence and Knowledge Platform
3.1 Review of existing platforms and their effectiveness based on a desktop review data checking and guidance from key stakeholders 
3.2 Draft report including recommendations for the region.
 GGGI will convene a virtual pre-bid conference via M/S Teams on Friday, 24th November 2023 14:30 Fiji Local Time (11:30 KST) to address any queries/clarifications relating to the assignment and procurement process. 
  For more details, please refer to the Terms of Reference (TOR) document attached.
IMPORTANT TIMELINES:
The tender submission deadline is 14 December 2023, 16:00 pm KST (Korean Standard Time).
If any bidder has any request for clarification on the TOR or any part of the tender documents, GGGI will be happy to clarify if they are received on or before 7 days before the deadline (namely: if the tender submission deadline is 16:00 15 April KST, then the due date for submission of request for clarification is 16:00 8 April KST).
