title: Technology Needs Assessment for: Energy, FOLU, Food, and Water Sectors in Indonesia
description:
9254
GGGI Indonesia is inviting eligible firms/entities to submit their proposals for the following scope of work:
 PROJECT BACKGROUND:
GGGI and the Fiscal Policy Agency (FPA) implement the Green Climate Fund (GCF) Readiness and Preparatory Support project (“the Readiness Project”) in Indonesia. The NDA has selected GGGI as the Delivery Partner to implement this project.    
  The Government of Indonesia has outlined the country’s transition to a low emission and climate-resilient future, which stipulates that Indonesia will reduce its GHG emissions by 31.89% compared to the business-as-usual (BAU) scenario in 2030 solely with domestic resources, and 43.20% with international assistance. Indonesia has set five prioritized sectors for NDC under mitigation: Energy, Industrial Process and Product Use (IPPU), Waste, Forestry and Land use (FOLU), and Agriculture.  To achieve its NDC commitment, Indonesia will also require significant technological advancement through international support for technology transfer, as well as finance and capacity building, emphasizing the need for technological innovation via multi-stakeholder engagement. Indonesia had its First Technology Needs Assessment (TNA) in 2010, focusing on mitigation, followed by the Second TNA in 2012 covering both mitigation and adaptation. The outcomes of ongoing TNAs that have been carried out since 2019 will guide technology development and transfer to support NDC implementation.  Additionally, the Government of Indonesia, through the Ministry of Environment and Forestry, is currently developing strategies for technology development and transfer. It will identify and analyze needs for adaptive and applicable technology in the NDC mitigation and adaptation sector to improve the effectiveness of NDC programs/activities, including the development and application of climate-adaptive green technology for remote areas. 
A strategic approach to guide investments in priority sectors is urgently needed to inform and enable state and non-state actors to better allocate their resources. Through the implementation of the Readiness Project, the NDA has conducted a study on sector prioritization for utilization of climate finance sources, in which two priority sectors are identified for mitigation: Energy, Forest and Land Use (FOLU), and two under adaptation: Food, and Water. A concept note reflecting a programmatic approach will be developed focusing on the priority sectors to access GCF funding. To better equip the development of programmatic approaches, both private sector investment and robust projects are needed, which includes using sound technologies with the highest impact.
As a part of the Readiness Project activities to enhance the enabling environment for GCF programming in low-emission investment, a Technology Needs Assessment (TNA) will be developed to identify and assess environmentally sound technologies that will, within national development objectives, reduce the impact of climate change in those prioritized sectors: Energy, Forest and Land Use (FOLU) for mitigation, and Food, Water security for adaptation. 
 OBJECTIVE OF THE ASSIGNMENT:
GGGI seeks to contract an eligible consulting firm to develop technology needs assessment for priority sectors in mitigation (energy and FOLU) and adaptation (food and water security). The TNA aims not only to identify the most important technologies for the prioritized sectors, but also to identify and analyze the barriers that hinder the successful deployment and diffusion of the technologies. 
Overall, the objectives of the assignment are:
1.	Through participatory processes, to identify and prioritize gender responsive technologies that can contribute to mitigation and adaptation goals for the sectors Energy, FOLU, Food, and Water;
2.	To identify barriers hindering the acquisition, deployment, and diffusion of the selected prioritized gender responsive technologies;
3.	To develop action plans and strategies specifying activities and enabling frameworks to overcome the barriers and facilitate the transfer, adoption, and diffusion of the selected prioritized gender responsive technologies. 
 PROPOSED ACTIVITIES:
The selected Firm shall perform the following activities:
a.	Develop stakeholder engagement plan and conduct information gathering 
b.	Assess Indonesia’s planning and strategy 
c.	Map out the climate change mitigation and adaptation technology ecosystem and stakeholders
d.	Conduct assessment
e.	Develop the action plans and strategies for the deployment and diffusion of the prioritized technologies, including the enabling framework.  
f.	Lead stakeholder consultation workshops.
  For more details, please refer to the Terms of Reference (TOR) document attached. 
 IMPORTANT TIMELINES:
The tender submission deadline is 11 December 2023, 16:00 pm KST (Korean Standard Time).
If any bidder has any request for clarification on the TOR or any part of the tender documents, GGGI will be happy to clarify if they are received on or before 7 days before the deadline (namely: if the tender submission deadline is 16:00 15 April KST, then the due date for submission of request for clarification is 16:00 8 April KST).

title: Legal, social, organizational, and financial accompaniment to the structuring of the "Energy Communities" model for Isla Grande and Isla Fuerte populations, located in Non-Interconnected Zones of Colombia.
description:
GGGI for its project in Colombia is inviting eligible firms to submit their proposals for the consulting services to provide legal, social, organizational, and financial accompaniment to the structuring of the "Energy Communities" model for Isla Grande and Isla Fuerte populations.  
  PROJECT BACKGROUND & OBJECTIVES
CONTEXT OF THE PROGRAM: GGGI has been a trusted advisor to the Government of Colombia (GoC) for more than a decade on the planning, structuring, and transitioning to an environmentally sustainable and socially inclusive economy. This has included giving valuable advisory support and capacity building to National Public Entities as the Ministry of Environment and Sustainable Development, the Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development, the Ministry of Finance and Public Credit, and the National Planning Department, among others, and to Subnational Public Entities as the Governments of Antioquia, Meta, Nariño, and Guaviare, also including the Departments of the CORPOAMAZONIA jurisdiction. 
In October 2022, the Global Green Growth Institute was awarded funding by the Foreign, Commonwealth & Development Office (FCDO) of the government of the United Kingdom to implement a project titled “Colombia – UK Partnering for Accelerated Climate Transitions”.
This project delivers demand-driven technical assistance to the Ministry of Mines and Energy (MME), the Institute for Planning and Promotion of Energy Solutions for Non-Interconnected Areas (IPSE) and selected private-sector developers to advance Colombia´s just energy transition and provide sustainable and affordable energy solutions to vulnerable rural communities and households. 
Project Description:
The adoption of renewable energy has the potential to stimulate private investments, foster economic expansion, create employment opportunities, and enhance access to clean, dependable, and cost-effective electricity. Collaborating with GGGI, the Colombian government is actively involving rural communities, particularly ethnic and marginalized groups, that are frequently excluded from decision-making processes, policy development, funding allocation, and equitable distribution of benefits. With the assistance of the UKPACT program, GGGI supports the Colombian government in its endeavors to guarantee that historically marginalized communities in Colombia also benefit from renewable energy projects and are part of Colombia’s just energy transition.
The Institute for Planning and Promotion of Energy Solutions for Non-Interconnected Zones (IPSE) is developing a set of projects for the 2023 budget period, which aim to implement energy solutions with Non-Conventional Energy Sources (NCRES) and hybrid types to expand coverage, as well as to improve the existing electricity infrastructure for the provision of electricity service in non-interconnected areas.
Electrification efforts are hindered by the lack of technical and institutional capacity of public energy operators: after public energy generation assets are built, their precarious ownership is transferred through a gratuitous loan contract to the local public energy company. Experience has shown that limited technical and institutional capacity of operating companies results in the deterioration of the installed systems and energy shortages for the population.
According to the 2022-2026 National Development Plan (NDP), the Government of Colombia will seek to advance in the coverage of energy services through 20,000 new Energy Communities (EC) users of Non-Conventional Renewable Energy Sources (NCRES), where individuals, households, businesses, and organizations will collectively produce, consume, and manage local energy resources.
In recent years, GGGI has provided technical assistance to IPSE in the structuring of renewable energy projects in Non-Interconnected Zones, and now supports the energy communities’ insular model in the localities of Isla Grande and Isla Fuerte, in the Department of Bolivar. IPSE is currently working on a project for the implementation of a hybrid solar-diesel power plant including medium and low voltage underground distribution network, for the community of Isla Grande.
GGGI is seeking a qualified service provider to provide legal, social, organizational, and financial accompaniment to the structuring of the "Energy Communities" model for Isla Grande and Isla Fuerte populations.  
 GENERAL OBJECTIVE;
The overall objective of this consultancy is to carry out the legal, technical, and socio-economic structuring of a sustainable operation model of Energy Communities to provide energy services in the Non-Interconnected Zones of Isla Fuerte and Isla Grande, Cartagena, Colombia.
 PROPOSED ACTIVITIES & SCOPE OF WORK:
Proposed Activities for the Overall Project
For the development of this consultancy, the following activities should be carried out:
Work plan
Elaborate and develop a detailed work schedule that includes a methodological framework and timeline for the activities outlined in these terms of reference and agreed with GGGI and IPSE, as well as the scope of each activity and the risks identified. 
Identification and analysis of communities
Carry out a socio-economic characterization of the population of the islands to identify individual and household beneficiaries as well as organizations with the potential to be involved in the community and associative scheme for an EC model in the islands. 
Identify existing and potential productive activities and vocations in the localities of Isla Grande and Isla Fuerte, which can be improved or promoted with the energy service provision and provide business model recommendations for the marketing of products and services.
Energy Communities model
Define with community representatives and articulate the legal model for the creation of the Energy Communities (EC) through a private-community associative scheme, in the communities of Isla Grande and Isla Fuerte, in accordance with the Colombian constitutional, legal, statutory, and regulatory framework, as well as the possibilities of the community.
Develop technical, financial, and legal studies to obtain the approval of a tariff by the CREG (energy unit cost-CU) for hybrid generation systems in the towns of Isla Grande and Isla Fuerte. These studies shall consider the socioeconomic conditions of the populations under study.
Develop a financial model for the operation and sustainability of the ECs under study. This model shall contemplate analyzing billing alternatives considering the existing and potential economic capacities in the territories and propose possible models of differential tariff schemes for ethnic communities.
Elaborate the operational and financial feasibility studies for the provision of Administration, Operation and Maintenance (AOM) services to local energy operators in the ZNI.
Develop efficient cost studies in order to present the technical studies required by 	the CREG for tariff approval. Deliverables should include at least the following   studies for each of the communities:
Statistical analysis of population growth.
Analysis of current and future energy consumption.
Study of operating costs, including fuel, transportation, maintenance, replacements, and contingency budget.
Projection of energy production.
Payment capacity of the population benefited from the energy solutions.
 Develop an operational governance model for the ECs under study, considering the existing organizations, capacities, and potential for improvement of the communities of Isla Fuerte and Isla Grande.Elaborate recommendations to improve services (for instance, health and education) complementary to the energy provision to trigger social development and achieve the SDGs, especially 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5.
Accompaniment to the communities of Isla Grande and Isla Fuerte in the implementation of the model of Energy Communities for a period of up to 5 months, in its process of conformation and beginning of operation as an EC. 
Identify and compile in a document the good practices and lessons learned during the development of the consultancy with the objective of generating a process of knowledge transfer and institutional strengthening with IPSE and MME professionals. The good practices and lessons learned shall have a focus on how EC trigger social development, helps eradicate poverty and close gender gaps.
Carry out monthly reports requested on the progress of the different activities of the consultancy.
This activities shall guarantee: i) Develop a participatory and co-creation process with communities to build a model of Energy Communities oriented towards the needs of the local populations; ii) Conduct focus groups with differential populations (women, youth, ethnic minorities, community organizations) to characterize and validate the socioeconomic conditions of the families (ability to pay for public services and differentiated uses of the energy service) and to define appropriate tariff schemes, as well to identify existing community organizations and their capacity to be part of the management of an EC model; and conduct field visits to Isla Fuerte and Isla Grande to identify vocations of existing and potential productive activities that can be enhanced with continuous electric power service.
The consultancy will respect the following conditions throughout the implementation of the contract:
All documents, contract drafts, and recommendations will be delivered in accordance with the guidelines and the regulations for the provision of services in the ZNI issued by the CREG, the Ministry of Mines and Energy, and the provisions outlined in the Energy Transition Law - Law 2099 of 2021.
The scope, format, and content of all deliverables will comply with relevant CREG regulations. 
The agreed scope and budget include all field works and site visits required to achieve the objectives of the consultancy. 
The scope includes the performance of all studies, designs, budgets, schedules, technical specifications, planning documents, etc., that allows the successful implementation of the project without any additional studies. 
The service provider will comply with GGGI’s social and environmental safeguards.
 SCOPE OF WORK;
The Service Provider shall provide expertise to develop and support the implementation of an EC model adapted to the needs of the local communities of Isla Fuerte and Isla Grande. The development of a sustainable and profitable EC model for the communities involves several key components. It requires the creation of a viable business model that outlines revenue streams, pricing strategies, and financial projections that include aspects such as energy generation, distribution, commercialization, and related services. Diversifying revenue streams through additional energy-related products is essential for financial sustainability. Identifying potential partners, particularly through a communitarian-private partnership program, is critical to establishing energy communities (ECs) on these islands while complying with national regulations and requirements for energy tariff approvals and subsidies. To ensure long-term viability, a sound financial plan shall be developed to cover capital investment, operating costs, and revenue generation.
Community engagement plays a key role by involving community members in the design and decision-making processes related to the community energy model, thus ensuring their active participation and influence in the management of the local energy provider. In addition, respecting and incorporating the cultural values and traditions of the islands into the knowledge transfer process is critical to aligning the project with the local community. Organizing knowledge-sharing events such as community events, seminars, or webinars where experts can share their knowledge and experience in renewable energy and sustainability facilitates educational outreach. Documenting the project's progress and successes as case studies is a valuable resource for other off-grid communities considering similar initiatives. Finally, training and capacity-building programs should provide community members with the skills and knowledge needed to operate and maintain renewable energy systems effectively.
In summary, the consultancy shall ensure that the EC model provided allows the adoption of a business model that guarantees sustainability in the provision of electric energy services in the islands and that the provision of the electricity service will contribute to poverty eradication, social development and to close existing gender gaps.
The development of an EC model for the islands of Isla Fuerte and Isla Grande should be focused on creating a sustainable and profitable venture while addressing the community's energy needs. Following is a brief overview of the key components:
Business Model: Develop a viable business model that outlines revenue streams, pricing strategies, and financial projections, considering factors like energy generation, distribution, commercialization, and energy-related services.
Service Offerings: Explore additional energy-related products to diversify revenue streams.
Partnerships: identify potential partners for the creation of the Energy Communities (EC) through a private-community associative scheme
Regulatory Compliance: Ensure compliance with national regulations, permitting requirements, and safety standards.
Financial Sustainability: Create a robust financial plan that outlines capital investments, operational costs, and revenue generation to ensure the project's long-term sustainability and profitability.
Community Engagement: Engage community members in the design and decision-making processes related to the Community Energy model, ensuring they have a voice in how the energy company and resources are managed and utilized. In addition, respect and incorporate the community's cultural values and practices into the knowledge transfer process to ensure it aligns with local traditions.
Knowledge Sharing Sessions: Organize community events, seminars, or webinars where experts and/or members of similar communities can share their knowledge and experiences in renewable energy and sustainability.
Documentation and Case Studies: Document the project's progress and successes as case studies that can serve as valuable resources for other off-grid communities considering similar initiatives.
Training and Capacity Building: Empower the community to actively participate in the development, management, and sustainability of their EC projects. Training programs and capacity-building efforts should aim to raise awareness and educate community members about the concept of energy communities, their benefits, and the transition to renewable and sustainable energy sources. This can include workshops, seminars, webinars, and public outreach campaigns.
  For more details, please refer to the Terms of Reference (TOR) document attached.
 IMPORTANT TIMELINES:
The tender submission deadline is 4 December 2023, 16:00 pm KST (Korean Standard Time).
If any bidder has any request for clarification on the TOR or any part of the tender documents, GGGI will be happy to clarify if they are received on or before 7 days before the deadline (namely: if the tender submission deadline is 16:00 15 April KST, then the due date for submission of request for clarification is 16:00 8 April KST).
 Interested parties will be required to register their details on the GGGI e-Green Procurement Portal (https://in-tendhost.co.uk/gggi).
 HOW TO OBTAIN THE DOCUMENTS:
Documents can be accessed via the e-Green Procurement Portal by selecting ‘View Details’ on the relevant notice and then clicking the ‘Tender Application’ button. If you are a new supplier, you will be required to register your details. If you have an existing account, you will need to login to the portal. Select the 2nd tab (`Tender Documents`) where you will find useful information regarding the RFP. Scroll down to the heading ‘Tender Documents Received’ where you will be able to view / download the documents.

title: Consultancy Services to Develop a National Methane Action Plan for Kazakhstan
description:
GGGI is inviting eligible firms/entities to submit their proposals for the following scope of work under the ‘Methane Gas Flaring Optimization Program in Kazakhstan’ project:
 PROJECT BACKGROUND:
Kazakhstan is the largest oil producer in Central Asia and a major gas producer. The CO2 intensity of Kazakhstan’s GDP is nearly 70% higher than the world average, reflecting the structure of its economy, which includes energy-intensive heavy industries. According to Kazakhstan’s latest national inventory report to the UNFCCC, energy-related emissions in 2020 accounted for around 80% of its total GHG emissions, excluding effects from land use supply needed to cover domestic demand. 
 Important environmental issues in the oil and gas sector include the flaring and venting of associated gas and fugitive methane emissions. Gas flaring, the process of burning excess gas released during oil production, wastes a potential energy source, and contributes to climate change. While much of the associated gas is used or captured, World Bank figures suggest that globally, more than 140 billion cubic meters of gas is flared annually, emitting 300 million tons of CO2. In addition to economic and environmental consequences, the practice of gas flaring also has a significant negative impact on the health of communities. In Kazakhstan, although routine flaring reportedly has been effectively eliminated in Kazakhstan, approximately 1.5 bcm was flared in 2021, according to the World Bank (WB, 2022).  According to data from the IEA’s Global Methane Tracker, oil and gas related methane emissions in Kazakhstan stood at 1.75 Mt in 2021 (IEA, 2022).
 GGGI intends to support Kazakhstan for developing National Methane Action Plan (NMAP), a policy road map for 5-years which will be helpful for the country to prioritize its action to achieve tangible benefits in a short and medium term. The NMAP will be developed with deep-drive studies, intense stakeholder consultations and international learnings to establish country’s baseline, potential of methane emission reduction, possible technology intervention, investment requirement and source of financing. The NMAP should also establish the quantitative and qualitative targets for Kazakhstan.
 OBJECTIVE OF THE ASSIGNMENT:
The objective is to identify an eligible firm (including consortiums) with experience in methane emission reduction and flare gas optimization in Oil & Gas Sector to develop a comprehensive NMAP, a policy road map for 5-years, which will be helpful for Kazakhstan to prioritize its action to achieve tangible benefits in a short and medium term. The Firm shall ensure that the study is in line with global standards and best practices and shall lead to bankable and scalable projects in Flare Gas Optimization in Oil & Gas sector in Kazakhstan.    
 PROPOSED ACTIVITIES:
 Under the scope of services for this assignment the selected firm shall carry out activities given below: 
A.	Landscape analysis of Gas sector to identify challenges, gaps and opportunities for Kazakhstan Oil and Gas sector in relation to gas flaring and identification of potential projects
B.	Develop Road map for scaling up gas flaring Optimization in Kazakhstan
C.	Conduct detailed Feasibility Assessment of one of the identified Gas flaring projects   
D.	Request for Proposals (RFP) from Potential Bidders and technology providers 
E.	Project Outreach and Knowledge Dissemination
  For more details, please refer to the Terms of Reference (TOR) document attached. 
 IMPORTANT TIMELINES:
The tender submission deadline is 16 October 2023, 16:00 pm KST (Korean Standard Time).
If any bidder has any request for clarification on the TOR or any part of the tender documents, GGGI will be happy to clarify if they are received on or before 7 days before the deadline (namely: if the tender submission deadline is 16:00 15 April KST, then the due date for submission of request for clarification is 16:00 8 April KST).

If you are a new supplier, you will be required to register your details. If you have an existing account, you will need to login to the portal. Select the 2nd tab (`Tender Documents`) where you will find useful information regarding the RFP. title: Design, Build, and Operate a Bio-Waste processing Facility at Nduba dumpsite, Rwanda
description:
GGGI Rwanda is inviting eligible firms/entities to submit their proposals for following scope of work:
 PROJECT BACKGROUND:
GGGI is implementing a Waste to Resources: Improving Municipal Solid and Hazardous Waste Management in Rwanda. The initiative is a 3-year project that aims to achieve three outcomes: A) Separation and valorisation of organic and plastic waste to minimize waste landfilled at the Nduba landfill in Kigali, B) Improved collection rate and management of e-waste in Kigali and Secondary Cities, and C) Improved policy and regulatory environment and enhancement of capacity through skills development and knowledge exchange main Objective.
With waste composition generated in the City of Kigali, organic waste takes up about 80% of the total waste generated. This has been confirmed by the waste characterization study developed as part of the project and in different literature. It is high time that Rwanda invests in organic waste valorisation to address challenges associated with improper management of such waste. Among the products that can be produced include compost, organic fertilizers, which can be applied to either gardening or farming to increase crop yield. GGGI plans a pilot to valorise organic waste as part of outcome A to Nduba dumpsite. 
Operations of the pilot will validate preferred business models and other lessons for future scale and expansion. Compost is a nutrient-rich product that is a by-product of the aerobic decomposition of organic matter, in a highly exothermic process, whose high Total Kjeldahl Nitrogen (TKN) content is utilised as a fertiliser and aims to reduce the disposed waste by valorisation of the organic waste.
 OBJECTIVE OF THE ASSIGNMENT:
The objective of this assignment is to identify an eligible Service Provider to Design, Build and Operation of a Bio-Waste Processing Facility.
 PROPOSED ACTIVITIES:
The proposed activities for the selected bidder (Contractor) are as follows:
i.	Design and build a biowaste facility
ii.	Operate the organic waste processing facility for a period of six (6) months, sharing experience and expertise with local staff that will take over the operation. The contractor shall produce of a high-quality by-product (compost) with the potential to compete in the fertiliser market.
iii.	Provide a plan for organic waste collection and specify a source and design a biowaste processing facility with the capacity to manage biowaste decomposition and accumulation for waste as well as the storage of the compost before the recycling. The Contractor shall also be expected to advise on the best method for composting such as the in-vessel, vermicomposting, windrow, or static and aerated static piles, with clearly stated pros and cons of each, and why a specific method is suggested, with clearly defined composting period for each method. The preferred method will be the one that has impact on overall methane production and good quality of fertilizers. 
iv.	Provide detailed designs including the civil works with clearly defined structural and architectural designs accompanied by detailed BoQs, Bar Bending Schedules and a Gantt chart for the management of the implementation works. 
v.	Conduct an Environmental Management Plan (ESMP) for the facility during the implementation of the project and the post-construction phase showing proper health and safety measures and identifying any possible hazards. The post-construction phase is to include important aspects like health and safety considerations for visitors and possible education rooms with anticipated visits from learning institutions.
vi.	Finally, the Contractor shall prepare an economic feasibility analysis, with a clearly stated plan, with good market research for a sustained tariff capable of sustaining the Operations expenditure (OpEx) sufficient to operate and maintain the facility operating at maximum capacity.
 For more details, please refer to the Terms of Reference (TOR) document attached. 
 IMPORTANT TIMELINES:
The tender submission deadline is 29 September 2023, 16:00 pm KST (Korean Standard Time).
If any bidder has any request for clarification on the TOR or any part of the tender documents, GGGI will be happy to clarify if they are received on or before 7 days before the deadline (namely: if the tender submission deadline is 16:00 15 April KST, then the due date for submission of request for clarification is 16:00 8 April KST).

title: Development of Project Concept Note and Pre-Feasibility Study for Nature-Based Solutions Project in the Philippines for Green Climate Fund
description:
GGGI Philippines is inviting eligible firms/entities to submit their proposals for the following scope of work:
 PROJECT BACKGROUND:
GGGI is implementing the “Strengthening Access to GCF through Project Pipeline Development (2022-2024)” project in partnership with Korea International Cooperation Agency (KOICA). KOICA has been accredited to the Green Climate Fund (GCF) since July 2021 and has developed a strategic direction to support the Government of the Philippines to better access the GCF through the KOICA – as one of the GCF’s accredited entity (AE) – by originating impactful projects alongside with the partner government and leveraging its own grant resources as co-financing resources to scale impacts. KOICA has partnered with GGGI as a technical partner to do a needs assessment and necessary pre-feasibility study to produce project concept notes (PCNs) which can be further developed as full funding proposals (FPs) for the GCF. 
 The ultimate objective of this undertaking is to develop two (2) Project Concept Notes (PCNs) for the Philippines with KOICA as an AE to be submitted to the GCF. The project’s targeted Outcomes, Outputs, and Activities are as follows:
1.	Outcome 1: Prioritized climate finance areas identified
2.	Outcome 2: Capacity to access to finance increased
3.	Outcome 3: Project pipeline development strengthened
 OBJECTIVE OF THE ASSIGNMENT:
The GGGI seeks to engage a consulting firm to develop a PCN and prepare a pre-feasibility study under Outcome 3, for implementing nature-based solutions (NbS) projects in the Philippines. The development of the PCN shall be based on the completed NbS needs assessment report (Outcome 1).  During the preparation of PCN, the consulting firm is expected to conduct capacity building activities to the NDA and relevant organizations in enhancing access to the GCF as part of Outcome 2.
 PROPOSED ACTIVITIES:
Scope of work for this assignment includes the following:
a)	Development of a Draft PCN  
b)	Preparation of the Pre-Feasibility Study 
c)	Final PCN
d)	Capacity Development 
 For more details, please refer to the Terms of Reference (TOR) document attached. 
 IMPORTANT TIMELINES:

title: Preparation of an NDC Investment Plan including Project Pipeline for the Solomon Islands
description:
GGGI for its projects in the  Solomon Islands is recruiting a qualified consulting firm that shall provide technical support to the activities within the Regional Pacific Nationally Determined Contribution Hub.
 PROJECT BACKGROUND & OBJECTIVES
The NDC Hub has 14 Pacific Country Members, a Steering Committee (Fiji as host country and representatives of the Melanesia, Polynesia and Micronesia sub-regions), an NDC Hub coordination group (composed of GIZ – the lead/manager, SPC, SPREP and GGGI). It also has an NDC Hub implementation unit, including a GGGI staff who will be managing this assignment. The objective of the NDC Hub is that PICs enhance and implement their country’s NDC driving sustainable and resilient development and transition to a low carbon development pathway. The NDC Hub promotes partnerships with the private sector for financing and implementation of NDCs in the Pacific Island region. The NDC Hub provides an opportunity to support countries in a collaborative manner and minimise the risk of duplication of support by individual agencies. To do so, the NDC Hub provides and facilitates technical assistance to the member countries. This is on a demand-driven basis with the NDC Hub responding to specific requests from countries to support NDC implementation. This assignment concerns a request received from the Solomon Islands Government.
Solomon Islands is one of the Small Island Developing States (SIDS), situated in the south-west of the Pacific. It is an archipelago of 994 islands combining mountainous islands as well as low lying coral atolls with the population of 721,455 in 2019 and a total land area of about 28,896 square kilometres (2,890,000 hectares) with 4,023 kilometres of coastline spread over 1.34 million square kilometres of ocean. The country’s location is within the earthquake belt or “Ring of Fire” results in frequent earthquakes and the geology, topography and rainfall of the country results in being extremely vulnerable to the effects and impacts of earthquakes, tsunamis and landslips.  In Solomon Islands, the NDC Hub focal point is within the Climate Change Division, Ministry of Environment, Climate Change, Disaster Management and Meteorology (MECDM).
 OBJECTIVE OF THE ASSIGNMENT:
As part of this assignment, the Consultant (the successful tenderer) shall work closely with Government of Solomon Islands and with the GGGI NDC Hub staff and Solomon Islands GGGI team to:
Support the Government of Solomon Island to develop an NDC Investment Plan focusing on mitigation priorities as detailed in Solomon Islands updated NDC. 
 Important notes. 
In this ToR:
-	Solomon Islands Nationally Determined Contribution (NDC) 2021 should be used as the main source of information for mitigation priorities. 
-	The NDC Investment Plan presents the country context (including the NDC targets), Targeted mitigation priority sectors (including information on the enabling environment and an analysis of the barriers to develop, finance and implement new projects) and strategy and solutions to overcome/remove the barriers to develop, finance and implement projects in the mitigation priority sectors.
-	Mitigation priority sectors in Solomon Islands NDC – in its effort to achieve its long-term mitigation targets, Solomon Islands is embarking on applying renewable energy and energy efficient technologies in the energy sector; in short, Solomon Islands is committed to low-carbon technologies to support sustainable development. This includes electricity generation through the application of Solar PV and hydro-power and other clean technologies in both urban and rural areas of the country. This will also promote renewable energy and energy efficient technologies in the sea and land transport sub-sectors. In addition, another priority mitigation area that the country will embark on is enhancing its carbon sink through sustainable management and protection of its forestry, land use, coastal and marine ecosystems. From these sectors, this NDC Investment Plan and project pipeline will be focused on following three sectors as identified by the Solomon Islands Government. 
 (i)	Renewable Electricity from Solar PV and Hydro 
(ii)	Lands Transport
(iii)	Forestry
 -	The project pipeline presents concept notes (4-5 pages) of projects that could be implemented in the near or medium term. A minimum of 15 projects should be developed, with a minimum of 4 projects per mitigation priority sector (as mentioned above). 
 Please find below (in the “deliverables” section) the expected structure of those NDC Investment Plan report.
 Those documents are expected to be succinct and focused on the actionability of the NDC Investment Plan, on the improvement of the enabling environment in the mitigation priorities and on the presentation of realistic projects which can be developed, financed and implemented in the short and medium terms.
 The Consultant shall base their work on existing relevant strategies, policies reports and workshop report available. Non-exhaustive list in the case of Solomon Islands, the relevant key national level strategies and plans consist of the following: 
•	Solomon Islands Low Emission Development Strategy (LEDS) 2023
•	Solomon Islands Second National Communication (SNC) 2017
•	National Climate Change Policy (2012-2017)
•	Solomon Islands National Energy Policy (SINEP) 2014-2019
•	National Development Strategy (NDS) 2016-2035
•	Medium-Term Development Plan (MTDP) 2016-2020 
 Non-exhaustive list of mitigation priority sectors include: 
 (i)	Renewable Electricity from Solar PV and Hydro
 •	National Energy Policy 
•	Electricity Act 
•	Renewable Energy Roadmap 
•	National Ozone Protection Act (in draft)
•	National Electrification Strategy 
•	Approved Standards for Electrical Products (2016) 
•	National Minerals Policy 2017 – 2021
•	National Water Resources and Sanitation Policy (WATSAN)
•	WATSAN Implementation Plan (2017-2033)
 (ii) Land Transport 
•	National Infrastructure Act 
•	MID Corporate Plan 2016-2020
•	Solomon Islands National Transport Plan 2017 – 2036
•	Traffic Regulations
•	Traffic Act 
•	Solomon Islands National Infrastructure Investment Plan (SI NIIP)
•	The Greater Honiara Transport Masterplan
•	Policy Roadmap for E‐Mobility in Solomon Islands
•	National Electric Mobility Policy and Market Readiness Framework for the Solomon Islands
•	Solomon Islands Electricity Act
•	National Energy Policy 
•	Petroleum Act
•	Consumer Protection Regulations (Approved Standards for Restricted Electrical Products) 
 (iii) Forestry 
•	MORF Corporate Plan 2020 – 2022 
•	Forest Resources and Timber Utilization Act (2004) 
•	Solomon Islands REDD+ Readiness Roadmap 2014-2020
 The documents delivered through this assignment will be the reference documents for all stakeholders involved in the implementation of NDC activities in the mitigation priority sectors. They will also be used for establishing contacts with potential support providers with the aim of leveraging climate finance and support for NDC implementation
  PROPOSED ACTIVITIES :
The Consulting Firm shall undertake the key project tasks below;
a)	Project kick off-meeting, desk-based research, consultation and data collection 
b)	Development of the NDC Investment Plan document for Solomon Islands
c)	Stakeholder Consultations
d)	Preparation of the final NDC Investment Plan including the project pipeline
e)	Validation Workshop and finalization of the final NDC Investment Plan report.  
See the objectives of this assignment above.
 For more details, please refer to the Terms of Reference (TOR) document attached.
IMPORTANT TIMELINES:
The tender submission deadline is 9 January 2024, 16:00 pm KST (Korean Standard Time).
If any bidder has any request for clarification on the TOR or any part of the tender documents, GGGI will be happy to clarify if they are received on or before 7 days before the deadline (namely: if the tender submission deadline is 16:00 15 April KST, then the due date for submission of request for clarification is 16:00 8 April KST).
 Interested parties will be required to register their details on the GGGI e-Green Procurement Portal (https://in-tendhost.co.uk/gggi).
 HOW TO OBTAIN THE DOCUMENTS:
Documents can be accessed via the e-Green Procurement Portal by selecting ‘View Details’ on the relevant notice and then clicking the ‘Tender Application’ button. If you are a new supplier, you will be required to register your details. If you have an existing account, you will need to login to the portal. Please refer to the guidance documents under the `Supplier Guidance` area of the portal for further information.
 ONLINE TENDER MANAGEMENT:
Once in the Tender Management Area for the tender, there are five possible tabs: ‘Tender’, `Tender Documents`, ‘Correspondence’, ‘Clarifications’ and ‘History’. Select the 2nd tab (`Tender Documents`) where you will find useful information regarding the RFP. Scroll down to the heading ‘Tender Documents Received’ where you will be able to view / download the documents.
 OPTING IN & OPTING OUT:
Please note that you may be required to ‘Opt In’ before you can start populating your response. The ‘Opt Out’ functionality will also be available throughout the duration of the tender process. Opting out will give you the option of declaring you no longer want to receive any further communication in relation to this tender along with the opportunity of providing comments and feedback for this decision. title: E Rostering System for Care Units - Market Engagement
description: Hampshire County Council Adults Health and Care Directorate (AHC)  is currently seeking the views of the market for an upcoming tender for the supply of an E-Rostering (Work Scheduling) System / Application for its Care Homes within Hampshire and or operated by Hampshire County Council. HCC Care is formed of seven areas within Hampshire County Council, Older Adults; Nursing, Residential, Younger Adults; Respite, Residential, Crisis & Day opportunities. Total of 37 Services. Fifteen of which are already using existing E-Rostering system.The aim is to get all thirty-seven units using the same system to ensure we have clear and concise data across the whole portfolio.As part of the process, we are looking to engage with providers who would be interested in delivering this service, and/or have experience of delivering similar services. To this end. the questionnaire (see via Synopsis button) is an information gathering exercise by Hampshire County Council (HCC) to help inform our approach to the procurement of an E-Rostering / Workforce Scheduling System for Hampshire County Councils owned and operated Care Homes which currently exist or will be in operation through the course of the contract which is ten years. title: Inspection and Maintenance of Structures In and Around Watercourses 2024-2030
description: Hampshire County Council (the Authority) is seeking to establish a single Contractor Term Service Contract for the Inspection and Maintenance of Structures In and Around Watercourses, to meet the Authority’s statutory requirements to provide these works and services, particularly where they form part of the Highways network.  Delivery of inspection and maintenance works on watercourse structures are constrained by specific Health and Safety legislation. Where these works fall part of Highways infrastructure the requirements are specified under the Highways Act 1980.Full details of the Authorities requirements can be found in ITT Annex 1 Section 4 where the Scope and Specification is detailed. The contract is valued at up to £3.5 million and has an anticipated contract start date of 1st May 2024.  The initial contract period is 4 years to 30th April 2028 with an optional 2-year extension to 30th April 2030.  The proposed works under the contract will be split into two distinct tranches; each tranche will be delivered as follows:o	Tranche 1 - the inspection regime, this is split over 2 years, with year 1 requiring a dive team of a minimum of 3 people; then year 2 made up of inspections in confined spaces or requiring robotic vehicles.o	Tranche 2 - repairs and maintenance, is delivered by the Authority undertaking repairs and maintenance of Watercourse structures including planned maintenance activities. Contractors may be expected to undertake larger structural and Civil works on Highways infrastructure where the structure is within a Watercourse.It is expected this contract will have a wider use for the inspection and maintenance of structures that are either in or around a Watercourse, that do not fall part of the Highways infrastructure, example being canals and other Watercourse structures where the Authority has a duty to maintain.Interested parties should register their interest in the project via the In-Tend website https://in-tendhost.co.uk/hampshire, and complete and submit the tender return document together with any supporting information requested by 14.00 hrs on Monday 19th February 2024. title: Domestic Abuse Dispersed Accommodation - Market Engagement
description: Hampshire County Council is seeking interested partners who wish to play an active role in supporting the development of a 2-year programme that will help build a model of dispersed safe accommodation for victims/survivors of domestic abuse in addition to the existing refuge offer. The Dispersed Safe Accommodation Programme will aim to provide self-contained safe and quality accommodation to victims/survivors who need to access emergency type accommodation but who are unable to access shared, communal refuge accommodation. The accommodation will be for victims/survivors who need a similar level of specialist domestic abuse support as provided in refuge to help them move away from the abuse and into safe and secure longer-term accommodation. The service may also accommodate victims/survivors who may not require the intensive support offered in refuge, but who are still at risk from the perpetrator of abuse.Suppliers are invited to attend a Market engagement event via Microsoft Teams on Thursday 8th February 2024 at 11.30am.To participate and book your place, please register at https://in-tendhost.co.uk/hampshire/We recommend that you refer to the e-tendering guidance for suppliers which can be found by clicking on `Information for Suppliers` at the top of the In-Tend home page.If your organisation is not registered on the Hampshire In-tend portal, please go to the website stated above and click on the `Register` tab - registration is free.Logging into In-Tend (once registered)- To view this opportunity please click on `Tenders` then `Current` and then scroll down to the project- Selecting ‘View Details’ on the relevant opportunity - Clicking the ‘Express Interest’ tab- Following the on-screen instructions- More information is available via the Synopsis buttonBooking InstructionsIn order to book a place(s) please confirm your attendance via the Correspondence function on the project and provide the contact email details of your attendee.If you would like to attend please confirm by 14:00hrs on Wednesday 7th February 2024.Receiving Notification EmailsTo ensure you receive email alerts and notifications from our system, please add the email domain `@in-tendorganiser.co.uk` to your Safe Senders list.

title: The supply of spoken word and large print material to Hampshire's Library Service - including authors Richard Osman and Lee Child
description: The provision of alternative format material, spoken word and large print, serves the needs of two interrelated and socially excluded groups for Hampshire County Council (the Council); the elderly and the print disabled. The provision of spoken word and large print is a key area of library service provision and is one of our unique selling points.The Council wants to identify from the market if any potential suppliers have the publishers rights to supply the books and audiobooks in the formats specified in the PIN (Prior information notice). The Council is looking to undertake a quotation exercise with suppliers that can demonstrate they can supply the identified authors in the formats requested.Additionally, any supplier wishing to quote will need to ensure any EDI quotes, orders, fulfilment and invoices must be compatible with Spydus, our Library Management System. The stock must arrive fully processed and shelf ready. This includes, for each title, supplier EDI appliance of specified rotation rotas with variable start libraries within each individual rota. Delivery of stock is currently to a central location on a monthly basis.If you are interested in delivering these services please attach yourself to the project via the In-tend system at https://in-tendhost.co.uk/hampshire/If your organisation is not registered on the Hampshire In-tend portal, please go to the website stated above and click on the `Register` tab - registration is free.Logging into In-Tend (once registered)- To view this opportunity please click on `Tenders` then `Current` and then scroll down to the project - 'The supply of spoken word and large print material to Hampshire's Library Service - including authors Richard Osman and Lee Child'- Selecting ‘View Details’ on the relevant opportunity - Clicking the ‘Express Interest’ tabOnce registered, you will need to send an In Tend correspondence providing details of the identified authors you have the publishing rights for with regards to supply the large print books, audiobooks and Playaway formats. Any supplier who can demonstrate they have the relevant publishing rights and meet the scope identified in the PIN (Prior information notice) will then be invited to quote for the opportunity. Interested suppliers need to have registered their interest by 14:00 Tuesday 19th December.The ‘Help’ or ‘Information for Suppliers’ buttons on the portal provide a detailed step by step guide.Receiving Notification EmailsTo ensure you receive email alerts and notifications from our system, please add the email domain `@in-tendorganiser.co.uk` to your Safe Senders list.

description: Hampshire County Council are looking for provider(s) to deliver the Community Wellbeing Workers Service across the Hampshire geography (excluding Portsmouth and Southampton).Older Adults community teams in Adults' Health and Care routinely work with individuals aged 65+, and their carers, who are often facing difficult and complex circumstances. The Community Wellbeing Worker service will provide short term, preventative support to these individuals, and will draw upon local community resources as required.The primary aim of the service is to enable individuals to increase their independence and to reduce their potential need for current or future involvement from adult social care services.The Service has been divided into 8 lotted contracts with geographical breakdowns.The Contract will commence on 1st February 2024 and will be for a period of one year with the potential option to extend for a further year.Interested parties should register their interest in the project via the In-Tend website https://in-tendhost.co.uk/hampshire, and complete and submit the tender return document together with any supporting information requested by 14.00 hrs on Friday 17th November 2023. Once in the tender there are five tabs – ‘Tender’, ‘ITT – documents’, ‘Correspondence’, ‘Clarifications’ and ‘History’. Select the 2nd tab (ITT - documents) where you will find useful information under ‘Tender Details’ continue to scroll down to the heading ‘Tender Documents Received’ where you will be able to view / download the documents.Please download all the documents and read very carefully.Opting In and Opting OutPlease note you are required to ‘Opt In’ before you can access the ‘My tender Return’ to start populating your response. title: The Supply of Spoken Word and Large Print Material to Hampshire's Library Service - including authors Danielle Steel and Ben Okri
description: The provision of alternative format material, spoken word and large print, serves the needs of two interrelated and socially excluded groups for Hampshire County Council (the Council); the elderly and the print disabled. The provision of spoken word and large print is a key area of library service provision and is one of our unique selling points.The Council wants to identify from the market if any potential suppliers have the publishers rights to supply the books and audiobooks in the formats specified in the PIN (Prior information notice). The Council is looking to undertake a quotation exercise with suppliers that can demonstrate they can supply the identified authors in the formats requested.Additionally, any supplier wishing to quote will need to ensure any EDI quotes, orders, fulfilment and invoices must be compatible with Spydus, our Library Management System. The stock must arrive fully processed and shelf ready. This includes, for each title, supplier EDI appliance of specified rotation rotas with variable start libraries within each individual rota. Delivery of stock is currently to a central location on a monthly basis.If you are interested in delivering these services please attach yourself to the project via the In-tend system at https://in-tendhost.co.uk/hampshire/If your organisation is not registered on the Hampshire In-tend portal, please go to the website stated above and click on the `Register` tab - registration is free.Logging into In-Tend (once registered)- To view this opportunity please click on `Tenders` then `Current` and then scroll down to the project - 'The Supply of Spoken Word and Large Print Material to Hampshire's Library Service - including authors Danielle Steel and Ben Okri'- Selecting ‘View Details’ on the relevant opportunity - Clicking the ‘Express Interest’ tabOnce registered, you will need to send an In Tend correspondence providing details of the identified authors you have the publishing rights for with regards to supply the large print books, audiobooks and Playaway formats. Any supplier who can demonstrate they have the relevant publishing rights and meet the scope identified in the PIN (Prior information notice) will then be invited to quote for the opportunity. Interested suppliers need to have registered their interest by 14:00 Tuesday 19th December.The ‘Help’ or ‘Information for Suppliers’ buttons on the portal provide a detailed step by step guide.Receiving Notification EmailsTo ensure you receive email alerts and notifications from our system, please add the email domain `@in-tendorganiser.co.uk` to your Safe Senders list.

title: Community Buddy Scheme.
description: Hampshire County Council invites applications from suitably experienced organisations who wish to be considered for selection to tender for the Community Buddy Scheme.The Community Buddy Scheme is part of Hampshire County Council’s Short Breaks offer, enabling children and young people with a disability and/or additional need to access their local community or an activity of their choice. Activities could include but are not exclusive to; support to join a community group, supporting access to community recreation such as parks and leisure facilities or supporting a child or young person with life skills such as shopping or eating out.  The buddy scheme support is subject to a flat rate hourly contribution from the child or young person’s family.The Framework will commence on 1st April 2024 and will be for a period of two years with the option to extend for a further two years.Interested parties should register their interest in the project via the In-Tend website https://in-tendhost.co.uk/hampshire, and complete and submit the tender return document together with any supporting information requested by 14.00 hrs on Thursday 8th  February 2024. title: Decoration & Minor Pre-decoration Repairs Framework 2024-2028 - Market Engagement
description: Hampshire County Council has an established Decorations and Minor Pre-decoration Repairs Framework for various works delivered via a multi-lot, multi-contractor Framework Agreement that caters for Hampshire County Council (schools and non-education) and other named authorities.As part of its maintenance programme, the Council undertakes external re-decorations of the built estate. Pre-decoration repairs will encompass repair or renewal of any element of the building which, if left unattended, would result in the premature deterioration of the decorative coating or of the building fabric itself.The Framework Agreement is due to expire in February 2024 with the replacement framework agreement set to last for 4 years up to February 2028.Suppliers are invited to attend a Supplier Engagement Day to raise market awareness and interest for this forthcoming opportunity on Friday 8th September commencing at 10am at the Hampshire County Council Offices, The Castle, Winchester SO23 8UJ.To participate and book your place, please register at https://in-tendhost.co.uk/hampshire/ The Council will guarantee Contractors up to two delegates a place at the presentation. Contractors can request additional delegates to attend and the Council will make a decision based on availability of space following request from all Contractors.We recommend that you refer to the e-tendering guidance for suppliers which can be found by clicking on `Information for Suppliers` at the top of the In-Tend home page.If your organisation is not registered on the Hampshire In-tend portal, please go to the website stated above and click on the `Register` tab - registration is free.Logging into In-Tend (once registered)- To view this opportunity please click on `Tenders` then `Current` and then scroll down to the project - 'Decoration & Minor Pre-decoration Repairs Framework 2024-2028 - Market Engagement'- Selecting ‘View Details’ on the relevant opportunity - Clicking the ‘Express Interest’ tab- Following the on-screen instructionsBooking InstructionsIn order to book a place(s) please confirm your attendance via the Correspondence function on the project. title: ESPH AB Hastings Castle and West Hill Cafe EOI (ESPH600 JB)
description: This is a call for proposals to develop, build, operate, and maintain the West Hill Cafe as an interpretation centre for the story of Hastings Castle, as well as a restaurant / café and retail space. The proposals should also include access improvements to Ladies Parlour and the Castle itself with improved setting and landscaping of the surrounding grounds.The Council has prepared this Expression of Interest (EOI) to gauge interest from the market on delivering its ambitions for the site and to test the viability of its aspirations as laid out below. Its purpose is to gauge stakeholder and market interest as well as engagement regarding the long-term future of the castle and the café site and its development as part of the Town Deal project.This is not a call for competition and offers no guarantee of entering into a competition at a future date. Stakeholders and market providers will not be prejudiced by any response or failure to respond to this exercise. Market providers should also note that a response to this communication does not guarantee an invitation to participate in any future tender opportunity that may be conducted.Full details are available in the expression of interest document.

buyer_name: HERTFORDSHIRE COUNTY COUNCIL  - ADULT CARE SERVICES
title: HCC Dec 2023 – The Provision of Advocacy Services for Adults in Hertfordshire
description: Hertfordshire County Council are out to procurement for the Provision of Advocacy Services for Adults in Hertfordshire.Hertfordshire County Council commissions independent advocacy services to ensure that our most vulnerable citizens can have their voices heard in conversations about their care and support and to promote individual choice and control in decisions that will affect their future.The current advocacy service supports approx. 4000 people per year through the provision of broad, complex and specialist advocacy in the community.  The service delivers a range of community advocacy services including groups.Commissioners have concluded review and evaluation activities to inform and shape the future commissioning arrangements. Considering the feedback received, the council are proposing a different approach to the delivery of advocacy services. It is the intention to award the new Contract to a single Service Provider, responsible for the delivery of an integrated service.Full details, including the benefits of this approach and partnership working, can be found in the Specification, Schedule 1 of the Terms and Conditions document.Organisations should be aware that due to the nature of the Services provided, any Contract formed as a result of this procurement process shall be executed as a deed. Organisations should seek independent legal advice on the implications of this prior to submitting their bid, where appropriate.Please Note the TUPE Employee Liability Information for this procurement has been provided along with other documentation for this procurement. TUPE related information is personal data and must be protected in accordance with the requirements of Data Protection legislation and must also be kept confidential. Therefore, by accessing this Tender via Supply Hertfordshire and then the View Details button and accessing the documentation for this procurement, Tenderers agree to undertake to treat the information as confidential and commercially sensitive at all times and take all reasonable steps to prevent any inadvertent disclosure to any third party.

buyer_name: HERTFORDSHIRE COUNTY COUNCIL  - ADULT CARE SERVICES
title: HCC - 02/24 - Pre-Procurement Market Engagement for Supported Living Strategic Review
description: Hertfordshire County Council (the “Council”) is carrying out Pre-Procurement Market Engagement (“PPME”) for Supported Living Strategic ReviewThe Council is seeking input from the market as to what might be the most attractive way of packaging and scoping any future opportunity for contracts.  This input will help inform any resultant procurement process. Please refer to the PPME document for more detailed information.The Council will consider the feedback received to help inform the Council’s options and further decision making. For the avoidance of doubt, this stage of the project is not part of a formal procurement process, and the Council is not committing, at this stage, to carrying out such a process. Participation or non-participation in the PPME shall not prevent any supplier participating in a potential future procurement, nor is it intended that any information supplied as part of the PPME shall place any supplier at an advantage in a potential procurement process. Participation in the PPME will be at each organisation’s own cost. No expense in responding to this PPME will be reimbursed by the Council.Further information can be found within the attached documentation. You are invited to submit a completed questionnaire by 12 noon on 23rd February 2024. Organisations which feel that they may be able to deliver the Outcomes and would like to attend an individual meeting with the Council should email their request via email tarn.gascoyne@hertfordshire.gov.uk by 12:00 noon on the 19th Feb 24. Please note that attendance requests for the subsequent supplier meetings on the 26 Feb – 1Mar (which should be no more than 2 representatives from each organisation) will last no longer than 60 minutes. Please note that the individual supplier meetings will be based on the Outcomes identified by the Council. Please log in or register at https://in-tendhost.co.uk/supplyhertfordshire/aspx/Home

title: HCC - 10/23 - The Provision of  Understanding my Autism and ADHD
description: Hertfordshire County Council is currently out to procurement for the Provision of Understanding my Autism and ADHDHertfordshire County Council seeks to put in place a framework of providers for Autism and/or ADHD support for Children and Young People (CYP) between 7-16 years old to understand their diagnoses; to enable Hertfordshire to have a flexible model in place that can respond to potential changes in levels of need and/or funding availability in future years. This contract is a pilot and will be designed to test out a variety of offers to help CYP understand their diagnoses. HCC are inviting providers to bid to be on the Understanding my Autism and ADHD framework which is split into 2 lots based on two levels of need. Providers will co-ordinate, delivery and evaluation outcomes for various offers for CYP to understand their own diagnosis. Lot number	Lot TitleLot 1	                Early Help CYP offerLot 2	                Targeted CYP offerThis procurement is an open process. title: HCC Sept 2023 - The Provision of Children and Young Persons Advocacy Services for Bedfordshire Borough Council, Hertfordshire County Council and Luton Borough Council
description: Hertfordshire County Council (hereinafter referred to as the Council), along with Luton Borough Council and Bedford Borough Council (hereinafter referred to as the Participating Authorities) are out to tender for a joint procurement for the Provision of Children and Young Persons Advocacy Services. Hertfordshire County Council are the leading on this procurement.The aim is for all children and young people to have access to appropriate support and representation to ensure their rights are protected and their wishes and feelings are listened to and taken into account.  To support this aim the Participating Authorities have a requirement for the provision of independent advocacy services for children and young people.  Services are expected to be delivered in line with the National Standards for The Provision of Children’s Advocacy.The Contract Period for this Contract is an initial period of three (3) years with the option to extend to a further two (2) years at twelve (12) month intervals. Therefore, the maximum duration of this Contract could be five (5) years. Full details, including the breakdown of spend by each of the Participating Authorities, are in the tender document set.Organisations should be aware that due to the nature of the Services provided, any Contract formed as a result of this procurement process shall be executed as a deed. title: HCC - 12/23 - The Provision of a Highways Services Term Maintenance Contract
description: Hertfordshire County Council is currently out to procurement for the provision of a Highways Services Term Maintenance ContractHertfordshire County Council (the “Authority”) wishes to appoint a service provider to deliver a highways services term maintenance contract (the “Contract”). The Authority is looking to forge a long-term collaborative relationship with a service provider that delivers a Contract that actively supports the Authority’s corporate objectives and provides added value to the County. The Authority wishes to facilitate the appointed service provider to identify and implement innovative solutions, establishing a new way of delivering the services to maximise the potential for success for both itself and the appointed service provider throughout the lifetime of the Contract. At present, the highways maintenance services are delivered through the Authority’s existing highways services term maintenance contract which is due to expire in September 2025.This procurement is a Competitive Procedure with Negotiation.  Organisations wishing to take part in this project are invited to ‘express an interest’ and also ‘opt in’ which will give access to the full procurement documents in the e-tendering system.To be considered as a Tenderer you must complete and submit a Supplier Questionnaire (SQ) by the deadline of 12 noon on the 26th February 2024Please allow sufficient time to make your return, as SQ submissions cannot be uploaded and submitted after this return deadline. Please ensure that where possible documents are uploaded as a PDF and that file names are succinct.  Any questions relating to this procurement must be made via correspondence on the website, in accordance with the procurement documents, and can be addressed to the main contact as shown in the details above.Tenderers should be aware that due to the nature of the Services provided, any Contract formed as a result of this procurement process shall be executed as a deed. Tenderers should seek independent legal advice on the implications of this prior to submitting their Tender, where appropriate.The use of Lots has been considered for this procurement, but have not been used, because it is a term service contract for the provision of ongoing services. As such, the requirements of the contract do not suit a Lot base structure, with a single supplier approach being the optimal delivery route for these services.  Please note that the contract requirements will be subject to available financial resources, supplier performance and flexibility to meet changing demands.Please Note the TUPE Employee Liability Information for this procurement has been provided along with other documentation for this procurement. TUPE related information is personal data and must be protected in accordance with the requirements of Data Protection legislation and must also be kept confidential. Therefore, by accessing this Tender via Supply Hertfordshire and then the View Details button and accessing the documentation for this procurement, Tenderers agree to undertake to treat the information as confidential and commercially sensitive at all times and take all reasonable steps to prevent any inadvertent disclosure to any third party.To access this opportunity please visit https://in-tendhost.co.uk/supplyhertfordshire/aspx/Home

title: HCC11/23- Framework Agreement for the Supply of Mobile Air Purifier Units
description: The Contracting Authority, acting on behalf of the Participating Authorities is leading on the procurement process to establish a Framework Agreement for The Supply of Mobile Air Purifying Units (herein after referred to as ‘Goods’) to Customers in various locations throughout the United Kingdom including: Offices, schools, colleges, universities, libraries, fire stations, police stations, hospitals, recreation centres, day centres and all other public sector establishments. The Contracting Authority is seeking suitably qualified Contractors to supply the Goods and any related Services under any Agreement resulting from this tendering exercise.  Details of the Goods required under this Agreement are given in the separate excel spreadsheet titled HCC2315269 – Pricing Schedule.  The requirement is for Compact high-performance air purifying mobile units developed for safe use in intensively occupied public spaces such as Schools and Children’s settings.The Council wishes to procure units that will sufficiently impact on the indoor air quality of a classroom setting without requiring multiple units in each classroom. Further technical information may be found within Schedule One, paragraph 8 of the specification. Delivery of these Goods will be free of charge to all Customers.Award will be a Multiple Contractor Award - Awarding to a maximum of 3 contractors, successful contractors will be placed in rank order.  This Framework Agreement will be open to all UK public sector organisationsThe estimated annual expenditure on Goods is circa GBP 100,000 Therefore the estimated total value of the Framework Agreement could be within the range of GBP 400,000 up to GBP 5,000,000The Framework Agreement may be awarded for a period of up to Four (4) yearsunless terminated in accordance with the provisions of the Framework Agreement.Please note that the requirements of the Framework Agreement will be subject to available financial resources, supplier performance and flexibility to meet changing demands. In addition, there will be no form of exclusivity or volume that is guaranteed under the resultant Framework Agreement and the Council will be entitled to enter into other Contracts and arrangements with other Suppliers for the provision of any, or all, of the requirements which are the same as, or similar to those specified under the established Framework Agreement.

title: Mobile Locational Analytics Data 2024
description: 1.3   	Description of scope/Specification1. Historic England is looking to purchase data collected through mobile platforms and other digital hardware to produce research for the Cultural Heritage Capital Programme (CHC). We need data for informed decision-making using locational analytics from mobile devices and other sources. The successful candidate will provide data and insights on movement patterns, visitor frequency, dwell time, and where visitors are residentially from.2. The research aims to explore the use of data from mobile devices and other sources for alternative sampling methods in economic valuation. The collected data will be used for econometric analysis and descriptive statistics.3. There must be scope for 15 separate heritage sites to be analysed. More will be preferred. Essential data on movement patterns, visitor frequency and where visitors are residentially from should be available for at least 5 heritage sites when the contract start date. All heritage sites will be expected within 28 calendar days of the starting date. If availability exists to change these locations afterwards, such time limits will not contain them.4. The successful candidate will be awarded up to £50,000 (including VAT) for the services pretraining to this tender. Not all of this funding must be used. If a candidate suggests a bid above £50,000 the bid will automatically be disregarded. The price of the service will be considered as part of the ‘Most Economically Advantageous Tender’. The award criteria in full can be seen in full in section 3.1.Data:5. Historic England must be able to use the data for aggregated and statistical analysis purposes. The findings from the statistical analysis will be published. Graphical representations of aggregated data may be published.6. Data should be provided in forms which allow further manipulation (e.g. SPSS, CSV or Execl files). Any additional mapping or access to software would also be welcome. Data will be shared internally within the organisation.7. The successful candidate must provide details on how long access to the data will be provided and how far back data can be viewed. The platform must also provide information on how quickly new data will be updated.Required Data -8. Failing to provide the required data will result in automatic withdrawal of the tender.9. The number of visitors: This data is necessary to understand how many visitors are visiting a defined geographical area of the researcher's choice.10. Visitor origin data (minimum MSOA level or equivalent geographical region): This data provides information on where visitors are coming from.11. We will require at least 1 year of data for each site. The methodological approach of collecting data must allow us to see what has happened for at least one year prior to the award of this contract.Optional Data:12. Optional data is not a requirement for the tender to be considered; however the addition of optional data will be considered when evaluating the price score in the MEAT. Tenders are welcome to separate the cost of required and optional data. We do not expect it to be possible to supply all forms of optional data.13. Dwell time: Dwell time refers to the length of time that visitors spend in a particular area. This information can help Historic England understand the length of visits to the site in question.14. Return frequency of individuals: This data provides information on how often individuals are repeating visitors to a specific site.15. Travel distance: The distance travelled by visitors to reach the heritage site, which can be used to estimate the cost of transportation, such as fuel expenses or public transport fares.16. Travel mode: Information on the various modes of transportation used by visitors (e.g., car, train, bus, walking, or cycling).17. Multi-destination trips: Information on whether the heritage site visit was part of a larger, multi-destination trip.18. Demographic data on visitors: Demographic data can provide insights into the types of visitors that are coming to cultural heritage sites.19. Catchment areas for visitors: Catchment areas refer to the geographic areas from which the majority of visitors are from.Submission20. As part of the submission we ask for the footfall figures for 1st April 2022 – 31st March 2023, for a specified polygon shared as part of this invitation to tender. We don’t need this split into months/days, and we don’t need any visualisations or access to platforms, a number would suffice. The details of this will be provided in a separate document along with the shapefile.21. Submissions will be scored on this submission as part of the MEAT.Access Requirements:22. The data should be easily accessible and provided promptly to ensure its relevance and timeliness for analysis.23. The data must be suitable for various uses, such as econometric analysis, aggregated descriptive statistics, and visual representations like infographics and GIS maps.24. Aggregated data must be allowed to be published in research and public communication while maintaining individual privacy and security.Data Collection and GDPR Compliance:25. The successful candidate must explain data collection methods and safeguards to ensure GDPR compliance. Data must be collected using GDPR-compliant methods, protecting individuals' privacy rights, and ensuring the security of personal data.26. The candidate must provide assurances appropriate technical and organisational measures are in place to ensure the security and protection of personal data.27. The successful candidate is expected to offer training or knowledge transfer sessions as needed, ensuring internal teams can effectively use and understand the data
