title: Compiling and graphically illustrating heritage sector carbon emissions data
description: The objective of this project is to collect data and be able to display it in an illustrative, engaging and impactful way to highlight carbon emissions that are associated with heritage organisations (generic organizational emissions and specific heritage related activities), accompanied by narratives and pointers of how behavior changes, improved planning, design, alternative solutions etc.… could be introduced to practices to reduce carbon emissions. This information (illustrated emissions data and narrative) will be used to highlight and raise awareness of the main areas of carbon emissions that are produced by heritage organisations and provide some examples of actions that could be introduced to reduce these emissions. This information will be used directly in carbon literacy and carbon accounting training and in a multitude of different environments, for example website use, presentations, tearoom posters etc.…  A media pack of carbon emissions data is required.

title: Flaxmill Creates Festival
description: The tenderer is required to submit a quotation and proposal for the provision of a three-day public festival called ‘Flaxmill Creates Festival’ to be held at Shrewsbury Flaxmill Maltings (hereafter referred to as ‘SFM’). The festival will celebrate heritage, craft and creative skills, reflecting the innovative past of the site and the recent story of restoration and renewal. Craft sessions and participative workshops will be provided by the site team for attendees to get involved in, and local artists and creators will showcase their work. Local singers and performers will be invited to perform and there will be a celebration of the engagement work the site team have undertaken with communities, schools and partners over the preceding two years. Art and performances by school children will also be scheduled. The Festival will be a flagship event in SFM’s engagement with the local community.

title: Historic Places of Worship - Contingent Valuation
description: Historic England is seeking an experienced organisation to implement surveys for residents associated with places of worship, as part of a broader contingent valuation study conducted by Historic England. The aim of the study is to understand and quantify public’s perceptions towards places of worship. The organisation is expected to survey a representative sample from an area designated by Historic England, with a requisite of at least 2000 respondents. Historic England (HE) is the public body that helps people care for, enjoy, and celebrate England's historic environment. The organisation plays a pivotal role in championing the broader value of heritage to society. In line with this mission, Historic England aims to quantify the perceived public value of preserving historic places of worship. To achieve this, a contingent valuation study has been designed. The contingent valuation method (CVM) is used to estimate economic values for all kinds of ecosystem and environmental services.  CVM involves directly asking people, in a survey, how much they would be willing to pay to repair and maintain historic places of worship. The results of the survey are expected to be instrumental in guiding policy decisions, resource allocation, and community engagement strategies related to the preservation of historic places of worship. This valuation technique is in line with HM Treasury guidance, which emphasizes the importance of quantifying the public value of non-market goods, such as heritage.

Although the MT building  is not independantly listed and doesn’t fall within the scheduling of Fort Cumberland, the external fabric of the MT building is subject to listed buiding consent as the building is in the curtiledge of the Fort. Fort Cumberland is a Scheduled Monument and a Grade II* listed building. A listed building application for the external works of this project has already been submitted to Portsmouth City Council planning office. The evaluation date is advised as the 17th January 2024.Works include: fire upgrading works including installation of fire dampers, firestopping, upgrading of fire doors; minor upgrades to electrical installation; alterations to the layout of the existing WC’s; relocation of fume cupboard space; merging of two rooms into one, that will require an upgrade to the rooms air conditioning system; internal decoration and upgrading of finishes; internal repairs; partial re-roofing.

title: E-learning Content Phase 1 ITT
description: Historic England (HE) are inviting suppliers to bid for e-learning training content for Historic England staff.  The provision will be provided by a single supplier, up to the value stated in the contract advertisement over the 2 year period.Suppliers should provide a separate written response of no more than 4 sides of A4, in line with the evaluation criteria detailed in 1.4 and including the minimum:•	At least 3 examples from different courses of their e-learning material, (please do not include any material that will breach individual’s personal data) and courses that are available in different languages.•	How content is made accessible to employees with Neurodiverse conditions, Hearing and Visual difficulties and is WCAG 2.1 AA compliant.•	Learning outcomes for their whole catalogue and how they will be assured and achieved.•	Any innovative delivery methods and mediums of delivery from video to activities and gamification•	The format of the content, which will be hosted or linked to our LMS platform, either as a download or as a SCORM package. •	Testimonies and data, which support and demonstrate how effective the e-learning content has been for individuals and organisations.  •	A completed pricing schedule (section 4.2) indicating the fee for delivery.

title: Heritage Sector Board Diversity
description: This invitation is to tender for work towards a wider Heritage Sector Board Diversity project, which aims to provide guidance and advice for organisations on diversifying their Boards, and for individuals on how to become Board members. In 2022, HE commissioned a qualitative research project into barriers and enablers to better Board diversity from Getting on Board, the leading experts in UK Board diversity. As part of the Strategy for Inclusion, Diversity and Equality 2020-2023, HE set out an ambition to improve the diversity of our own workforce, and to make the work we do more inclusive. We also began work to help shape and influence a more diverse and inclusive sector. The report from this research project highlighted several areas where barriers are holding back Board diversity and provides direction for actions to tackle these.

title: Physical Records Management Digital Solution
description: Background1.	Historic England (the Authority) uses a legacy software application (TRIM version 7) for the management of non-electronic physical records.  Physical records managed in TRIM range from documents of historical significance to business and personnel paper records.2.	TRIM has been through several iterations of product identity and original ownership since first implemented, prior to the establishment of Historic England, for English Heritage.  The version currently in service has been end of sale and out of vendor support for nearly a decade.  Historic England wishes to replace the functionality offered by TRIM through implementing a modern and fully supported digital solution that addresses operational risks and issues associated with continuing to run an obsolete and unsupported system.3.	This requirement relates solely to the management of physical records.  While it is known that some candidate digital solutions also offer such functionality, management of electronic records is not in scope and does not require discussion.Objectives and Desired Outcomes4.	Objectives of the work are:a.	The contract with the successful supplier to implement and provide the digital solution commences April 2024.b.	The solution is live by July 2024 and continues until April 2028.c.	Support and operation of the solution is transitioned to business-as-usual by Septem-ber 2024.5.	The outcomes that Historic England wishes to realise are:a.	Physical records are managed using a solution with full original vendor support until at least April 2028.b.	Historic England provides first and second-line support.  The successful supplier will provide third-line support.c.	Users are trained, familiar, and at ease with using the solution.d.	The solution enables the use of TRIM in Historic England to be discontinued and IT as-sets associated with TRIM to be decommissioned.Scope6.	Within the successful supplier’s scope in this engagement will be:a.	A digital solution to manage physical records.b.	Technical implementation of the solution.c.	Migration of data from the legacy TRIM application to the new solution.d.	Post-migration data validation.e.	Provision of user guidance and any necessary training materials.f.	Early-life support  following release to live.g.	Support for the solution for the duration of the contract period.7.	Outside of the successful supplier’s scope of work will be any decommissioning of existing IT assets. Constraints8.	Constraints on the solution are:a.	The solution must be capable of single sign-on using credentials from the Historic Eng-land Azure Active Directory.b.	The successful Tenderer must hold valid Cyber Essentials certification for the duration of the contract.c.	Data must be hosted in the UK or European Economic Area only.Assumptions9.	Assumptions made at this stage are:a.	A commercial off-the-shelf solution will meet most of Historic England’s requirements, and all those marked as mandatory, with no, or minimal, modifications.b.	Supplier support for implementation and operation will be available for the duration of the contract.c.	Classification of information stored in the solution will be no higher than OFFICIAL-SENSITIVE and the successful supplier and solution will have suitable technical and procedural controls to protect this information (refer to appendix 4.3 for guidance).d.	The successful supplier will, as part of their bid, offer a service to automate and man-age the migration of all required data from TRIM to the new solution, including post-migration validation of data.Technical & Delivery Strategy10.	An ‘off the shelf’ software-as-a-service solution that benefits from standard service and support is preferred, if one can be found that satisfies all mandatory requirements.  If a suitable off-the-shelf solution cannot be found, the next preferred option will be to modify an off-the-shelf product.  Development of a bespoke software application, that would require specialist support throughout its lifetime, is the least preferred option.11.	A ‘cloud first’ approach is also preferred, rather than an ‘on prem’ solution that would require physical datacentre space, utilities, and that would transfer a significant amount of responsibility for ensuring availability and resilience of the service to Historic England operational teams.12.	Tenderers are free to propose their preferred delivery methodologies.  Once appointed, the successful supplier will deliver the service in accordance with the agreed approach.

title: Identification of climate hazard and climate change adaptation resources
description: This project will assist Historic England in planning future activity around key commitments within our Corporate Plan and the Government’s third National Adaptation Programme.  Historic England is working to develop methodologies for understanding the long-term risk to cultural heritage from climate change impacts and to develop resources for owners and managers of heritage assets to help them understand the risks to their assets and consider management options for future climate. This project is focussed on climate change hazards which are defined as “the potential occurrence of a natural or human-induced physical event or trend that may cause loss of life, injury, or other health impacts, as well as damage and loss to property, infrastructure, livelihoods, service provision, ecosystems and environmental resources” by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (2022).

title: IT Support Specialist 2023 10 20
description: Historic England’s IT Department requires an IT Support Specialist with a strong depth and breadth of knowledge and experience across a broad range of technologies. The Specialist will contribute to planning, implementing and managing IT Enterprise Services for Historic England. They will also contribute to maintaining the stability, security and performance of Historic England’s IT infrastructure. To do this they will form a strong and collaborative working relationship with Historic England’s internal Technical Governance and Infrastructure teams as well as Third Party suppliers.

title: L&D Training provision- Writing Skills Training  Phase 1 ITT
description: Writing skills are vital in Historic England when working with internal and external stakeholders. A lot of our business is conducted through letters and papers, so being able to express a range of content through writing is essential. Some of our letters are used in legal cases, so need to adhere to certain standards. Internal board papers need to be concise and be able to outline an argument as well as being clear what the ask is of the board. Emails are still a major communication channel both internally and externally and staff need to learn how to write them concisely with clear action calls. Staff are writing for different audiences and sometimes what we write aims at different audiences with the same text. These courses need to help staff understand how different audiences like to be communicated with and how to vary one's style accordingly. Our topics are often complex, and staff need to be able to adapt their messages to the different knowledge of the audiences without feeling that they are “dumbing” down the content. Our communication needs to be clear, concise and inclusive.  ObjectivesHistoric England would like to achieve the following through delivery of these courses:•	Enable staff to o	Write effective emailso	Write clear and concise board papers o	Write letters in the planning application processo	Write for intranet and website•	Understand the basics of good writing•	Understand how different audiences like to be communicated with (colleagues, general public, execs, specialists)•	Adapt writing style for different audiences•	The risks and benefits of using AI as a practical tool for writing email, board papers etc. •	Understand how to craft an argument and make an ask of decision makers•	How to write inclusively without “dumbing” down the content

title: L&D Training provision - Project Management Tender Phase 1 ITT
description: This tender is split into two Lots and providers can submit a proposal for one or more Lots.  Lot 1 is for Project Management training at different levels but does not require a recognised industry assessment or qualification. Lot 2 is for recognised industry standard qualification in Project Management. Each Lot will be provided by a single supplier, with services being called off when required, up to the value stated in the contract advertisement over the 3 year period.Suppliers who wish to apply for more than one lot should provide additional information and assurance on how they would ensure quality and consistency of delivery as well as how they would ensure capacity to deliver all requirements.Lot 1 - Project Management Project Management has always been key to delivering Historic England’s work. Project Management (PM) skills can be beneficial in many roles outside of official project management roles. The Programmes Team in Historic England have developed guidance and tools for managing small and medium size projects. The guidance is influenced by Prince2 and the APM approach. We expect a supplier to take this guidance into consideration when designing the training.Lot 2 – Project Management Qualification trainingThere are a significant number of staff whose role focuses heavily on project management tools and techniques and some wish to have some formal qualification in project management. Others want to move into project management as a career and require a formal qualification.We are looking to provide those with the opportunity to gain a qualification to industry standard. It would be beneficial that the course is also in-line with APM and Prince 2 principles.

title: Levelling Up Places Service Active Design Review
description: Historic England is seeking to procure a consultant to provide Active Design review support to up to five identified Levelling Up funded projects. This support will provide a high-level critique of the individual projects against Sport England’s Active Design Guidance  (https://www.sportengland.org/guidance-and-support/facilities-and-planning/design-and-cost-guidance/active-design). This support will include reviewing the individual projects and making recommendations as to how the projects can further integrate the Active Design principles to help make healthier, happier and more active places.Historic England will be the lead client for the commissioning of this project, in partnership with Sport England.Sport England believes sport and physical activity has a big role to play in improving the physical and mental health of the nation, supporting the economy, reconnecting communities, and rebuilding a stronger society for all.  It has produced the Active Design Guidance, which is focused on encouraging the built environment to be shaped in a way that encourages and promotes physical activity (active environments). The Active Design guidance supports Active Environments, one of the five big issues of Uniting the Movement, Sport England’s ten year strategy to transform lives and communities through sport and physical activity and to create a nation of more equal, inclusive, and connected communities. Active Environments is about creating and protecting the places and spaces that make it easier for people to be active. Sport England has the ambition to make the choice to be active easier and more appealing for everyone, whether that’s how we choose to move around our local neighbourhood or a dedicated facility for a sport or activity.Levelling Up Fund projects provide the opportunity to create spaces that encourage activity, through integration of the Active Design principles.

title: National Collection of Archaeological Archives Operating Model: Museum and Research Institution Needs
description: The aim of this project is to assist with the testing of the business model for a national store and collection of archaeological archives, focusing on the requirements of museum and research institutions. The complementary work on the business model is already underway including cost modelling, building design and location review.We are developing a NCAA business model and, as part of this, further research is needed to develop the NCAA’s operating model. This will gather evidence on both museum and research institution interests. This approach will ensure a thorough understanding of the organizational structure and processes needed to effectively support and integrate the National Collection into England’s archaeological infrastructure

title: Historic England Web Technical Supplier Framework
description: Historic England is looking to appoint suppliers to a framework to provide web-development Services for selected projects and organisations across three financial years [23/24 to 25/26 – 2+1 approach] in support of Historic England website deliveries. The provider will support Historic England in planning, scoping, delivering and testing website developments, as well as supporting through deployment and providing any necessary knowledge transfer.The work involved will range from the creation of small, self-contained components that could be used across our websites (e.g. a component to display CMS content in a new way) to larger-scale, more complex deliveries to meet specific content needs (e.g. interactive functionality using a range of data sources).In some cases, we will require the delivery of a component or product that can be integrated into the website by our own developers (with appropriate handover from the supplier). In others, there will be a need for the supplier to carry out the integration work.

title: Appointment of an agent for the marketing and sale of Baguley Hall, Manchester
description: Historic England’s purpose is “To improve people’s lives by championing and protecting the historic environment”, with a focus on “Thriving Places”, “Connected Communities” and “Active Participation”. Located in an area of Manchester which is becoming increasingly economically dynamic, with Manchester Airport, Roundthorn Industrial Estate and Wythenshawe Hospital all nearby, and recent infrastructure upgrades such as the Metrolink ensuring fast connections in and out of the city, Baguley Hall could be a catalyst to improve further the lives of Wythenshawe’s inhabitants, bringing much-needed hospitality and/or community facilities to the neighbourhood. To that end, Historic England and English Heritage Trust commissioned an Options Appraisal in 2021, which identified the opportunities and challenges involved in bringing Baguley Hall back into a long-term sustainable use (this Options Appraisal is appended below – please note that it dates from 2021, and pre-dates our more recent repair works), and we have underaken works in the region of £250,000 as a first step in getting Baguley Hall ready for a new user, namely: •	To carry out essential repairs to the roofs and rainwater goods,•	To replace the fire detection system, •	To remove existing scaffolding in the main hall,•	To lay an insulated base slab in the fourteenth-century hall (in preparation for installation of services and relaying of the stone-flagged floor by the future owner). Now that these initial works have been completed, the Hall will be marketed to seek expressions of interest from potential purchasers, developers, or occupiers/operators. The outcomes of this marketing exercise and the conversations which develop from it, will shape the next steps for Baguley Hall, and set the parameters for its eventual disposal. The final use should engage the local community and create a use that allows and promotes public access in a commercially viable way. Uses including café, pub, restaurant or boutique hotel should be considered, as would be more community-related uses such as community hub and arts venue. A balance will be sought between the immediate viability and funding needs, and finding a long-term beneficial use for the site.

title: High Street Heritage Action Zone (HSHAZ evaluation) – footfall analysis using digital visitor insight data
description: Scope:1.	Historic England is looking to purchase data collected through mobile platforms and other digital hardware to contribute to the impact evaluation of the national High Streets Heritage Action Zone (HSHAZ) programme. 2.	We need locational analytics from mobile devices (and other sources) to provide a detailed picture of footfall to contribute to our innovative evaluation of this programme.3.	We want to purchase high quality visit insight data for at least:a. 10 sample HSHAZ locations b. 20 comparable counterfactuals (places without HSHAZ investment) c. Data for 7 HSHAZ high street locations to understand visitor insights for the Hi! Street Fest.4.	The data will help us to understand more about how people are using the high streets that Historic England has invested in. This data helps us understand footfall and person interactions across HSHAZ locations which we can use as part of our impact evaluation.5.	For 3a and 3b:•	 The successful Supplier will provide data between March 2018-March 2024. •	 This will include visits and visitors at a minimum •	 This could include insights on movement patterns, visitor frequency, dwell time, and visitor demographics and others. 6.	For 3c:•	 The successful Supplier will provide data for 2 weeks/months prior to the events, the event date (dates to be provided) and 2 weeks/3 months after.7.	The successful Supplier will work constructively with our evaluators, Amion Consulting, to make sure that this cutting-edge data can meaningfully inform the impact evaluation that will be delivered to Historic England in autumn 2024.

title: Evaluation Expert for Historic England’s Shrewsbury Flaxmill Maltings Project
description: Historic England (HE) is looking to appoint an experienced evaluation consultant(s) to carry out an evaluation of the restoration, regeneration and operation of Shrewsbury Flaxmill Maltings. The primary objective of this work is to deliver a report that will inform the project delivery and meet National Lottery Heritage Fund evaluation requirements and demonstrate the outcomes achieved, lessons learned and future recommendations. The overarching aim of this commission is to deliver an evaluation of the Shrewsbury Flaxmill Maltings project that will meet National Lottery Heritage Fund requirements. It is expected that the evaluation will draw on existing data and evidence provided by Historic England’s Socio-Economic Analysis and Evaluation team and operational data provided by the Shrewsbury Flaxmill Maltings Ltd, with additional qualitative primary research to provide a balanced, objective mixed methods evaluation. This includes understanding the role of the Friends of the Flaxmill Maltings, including the factors that contributed to their disbandment and what can be learned. The evaluation will explore dynamics between national heritage funding bodies and local partners, and to provide evidence that will be used to enhance future working partnerships between these distinct groups.
third_text: Museum services and preservation services of historical sites and buildings

title: Heritage Sector Workforce Diversity
description: This invitation is to tender for work towards a Heritage Sector Workforce Diversity project. In line with point 2 on Historic England’s Corporate Plan, Inclusion, Diversity, and Equality (IDE), the Inclusion team is developing a suite of resources and interventions for the sector, in particular to fulfil point 2.8 - “Develop a programme of interventions to increase diversity in the sector including building capacity and capability and developing and sharing our evidence and insight.” One strand of this is to provide a model, and supporting resources, on how to measure workforce diversity across the sector.   Auditing and monitoring workforce diversity is an important tool for IDE. Auditing workforce diversity can highlight where there are gaps in representation and help uncover why these gaps exist – identifying barriers and blockages. It can help prioritise resources towards actions to remove these barriers, and provide development opportunities for organisations to take concrete and specific actions. Working to remove these barriers not only improves inclusivity and accessibility, it also improves working conditions for all staff – as well as service users, visitors, volunteers depending on the type of organisation and its audience or customer base.

title: Skills Needs Analysis for the Repair, Maintenance and Retrofit of Traditional (pre-1919) Buildings in England
description: The supply of, and demand for, the knowledge and skills needed to maintain, repair and retrofit our existing traditional building stock is inconsistent. We need credible, up-to-date qualitative and quantitative evidence to illustrate the scale of the problem, and to prioritise future Historic England work, as well as wider sector investment in skills activities. We expect the data to be valuable to the new Cross-Sector Historic Environment Skills Forum as they take forward action plans for meeting skills needs. The forum, with secretariat provided by Historic England, was set up in 2022. It is providing the vehicle to help the sector prioritise the strategic and systemic skills issues that challenge us and lead the development of the interventions required to meet them. It covers heritage construction trades and professionals, archaeology, conservation and historic environment advice/management.

title: Heritage Carbon Literacy Training Framework
description: Historic England has a commitment to become Net Zero and to support heritage organisations on their own journeys to Net Zero. To support this initiative, Historic England wishes to roll out Carbon Literacy training, both to organisations in the heritage sector and its own staff over the next two years.Historic England seeks to engage around 6 trainers for the delivery of this training over a four-year period.  There will be three possible versions of the course depending on audience needs. (see section 1 for course definitions). 1					         The training courses to be delivered: a        Heritage Carbon Literacy courseThis course is primarily aimed at heritage organisations in the sector.Historic England has developed with partners a Heritage Carbon Literacy training course that is accredited by the Carbon Literacy Project (https://carbonliteracy.com/). Carbon literacy is ‘an awareness of the carbon costs and impacts of everyday activities and the ability and motivation to reduce emissions, on an individual, community and organisational basis.’The heritage course is closely based on the Museum Carbon Literacy course developed by the Roots and Branches project (https://mduk.org.uk/roots-and-branches/#:~:text=The%20Toolkit%20contains%20a%20day's,your%20museum's%20environmental%20responsibility%20goals). The main differences are that some of the content, including, case studies, activities and references have a broader heritage context, rather than just museum based. The course follows the classic classroom (virtual) delivery model of all carbon literacy courses with 8 hours training delivered over two or more days.

title: Replace DHWS Plant
description: Hereward College – Invitation to Tender to Replace ¬¬¬¬¬DHWS Address: Bramston Crescent, Tile Hill Lane, Coventry CV4 9SWIntroduction and BackgroundHereward College invites tenders to replace hot water boiler equipment in out main building plant room (site map below). Domestic hot water services to 4 major buildings are currently supplied by a pair 500 litre Lochinvar calorifiers, heated by a pair of Lochinvar direct gas fire boilers. This system was adapted from tank-fed to mains pressure unvented in the summer of 2022 to address both issues with airlocks in hot water and legionella control in tanked cold water. As part of continuous PPM programme, the College now seeks replacement of this equipment, which is now obsolete and end of life. Existing Plant: DHWS Unless familiar with the equipment a site visit will be essential prior to quoting.Please provide a formal itemised proposal for the any or all of the following options as you best deem technically appropriate:1.	To remove existing and supply and replace 2no unvented hot water boilers with suitable Lochinvar, Andrews or similar branded product, utilising the existing calorifier buffer vessels and pressurised mains cold supply. 2.	As option 1 but to also replace the calorifier buffer vessels. 3.	To replace boilers and calorifier buffer vessels with 2no direct gas fired calorifier water heaters. The College has significantly reduced hot and cold water outlets (more than 50) in 2 of the 4 serviced buildings as part of redevelopment of former residential spaces to teaching and so dependant on your survey it may be possible to reduce size and capacity of new equipment. All offered replacement plant items must be compatible with the existing Honeywell Trend 963 Supervisor BMS system.All proposals must include carting away and disposal of all decommissioned equipment and waste arising from the project. Standards and DocumentationAll plumbing products used should be WRAS certified where appropriate. Backflow protection must be installed in line with both manufacturers’ instructions and water regulations. Pipework must be in copper, with Geberit Mappress or similar brand press gun fittings and suitably routed, secured and fully insulated.  No blind ends/dead legs to be left over.  The installer must be suitably qualified and experienced in supply, installation, operation and maintenance of commercial gas fired hot water systems. The installer and employed engineers are required to be a member of the Gas Safe Register. Proof of Public Liability Insurance (minimum £10million), Risk Assessment and Method Statement (RAMS) and signed acceptance of The College’s Control of Contractors Policy are required to work on site. All staff must have the right to work in the UK.O+M Documentation to be supplied to the College at time of handover. TimescalesTimescales for this project are as follows:•	Invitation issued – 16.08.2023•	Submission deadline – 18.09.2023•	Award date – 21.09.2023•	Planned works date – Week commencing 30.10.2023 FinancialsProposals must be based on value for money, although the College is not obliged to accept the lowest value quotation.  No works may commence without a receipt of a formal written Hereward College Purchase Order. Invoices terms are 30 days although are generally settled within 14 days of receipt, once authorised following full completion of works and handover. Contact DetailsTo discuss this project further or arrange a site visit please contact:Simon Shackleton – Director - Technical, Estates and Facilities simon.shackleton@hereward.ac.uk	02476 426117Carl Osborn – Deputy Estates Managercarl.osborn@hereward.ac.uk		02476 426086

title: TEC Partnership - Replacement of B Block Roof Rev 1
description: The project comprises of replacing the roof covering on our B Block building. This will require removing the existing roof and insulation before replacing. There are some structural repairs required to the parapet walling that will need to be conducted during this process. The details of this can be seen in document Rde6334. In accordance with the Rde6334 recommendation, masonry repair is also required on the tower block, as seen in image 1. It is proposed that the parapet walling is reduced to the height required to provide the adequate uplift for the replacing roofing, so a replacement capping system can be installed. Enabling works for one section of roofing, will require the removal of an existing timber structure (image 2). The proposed roofs are to be Sika liquid plastic and installed to accompanying specification (alternative products will be considered). Full standards and services can be found in the Specification Document appended to this ITT – 0409764 Technical Specifications.pdf and PEU – 00734 cut to falls design. The final stage of the project will be installing edge protection (image 3)Other documents appended to this ITT: •	01 Site Location Plan•	02 B Block roof plan •	040964 Site Survey Reports.pdf•	Rde6334 Structural survey •	PEU – 00734 cut to falls design•	Image 1 – wall repair•	Image 2 – Timber frame removal•	Image 3 – indicating edge protection areaDocument 03 phase drawing is color coded into four sections. Section 1 (yellow) is the main focus of the works and the other elements will be decided on based on the overall project cost. Please ensure that your tender break down clearly states these itemised components. Section 1 – YellowSection 2 – BlueSection 3 – GreenSection 4 - Purple

Supply Teachers and Education Support Staff shall provide cover for daily supply engagements or long-term assignments.The core roles are mandatory; Suppliers must have the ability to provide Supply Teachers and Education Support Staff to bid for a position on the framework. Supply Teachers may be required to cover a variety of absences or vacancies, including in difficult to fill geographic areas or where there is a skill shortage. The non-core roles provided in this Framework Agreement include but are not limited to;-senior staffing positions including Headteachers and Senior Leadership roles;-other temporary staffing services including invigilators, admin and clerical staff, IT staff, finance staff, estates and maintenance, and cleaners.More information can be found within the procurement documents.

title: TEC Partnership - Immersive & Virtual Reality Spaces
description: This tender is being advertised for a period of 2 weeks only due to timescales with funding and having previously advertised this tender. It has been decided to split this into 2 lots, one for the immersive environment, one for the VR equipment.We require a complete immersive / virtual reality solution designing and implementing into four existing rooms, one at each of the colleges listed below, within the TEC Partnership.  Each room is of different dimensions, so a site visit is required to each college to survey the rooms and to ask any questions.  Attached to this document are the four rooms plans for each college.  Please note that these plans are just an idea of where we would like the walls.  It is up to the surveyor to accurately measure each room for design and costings.It is a requirement of the tender to have both the Immersive and VR solutions installed between 11th and 20th March 2024 at the Grimsby Institute campus only.  This is to meet the terms of the project.  We will require the invoices for payment immediately after the installation and commissioning of the equipment. The remainder of the rooms can be completed throughout the year with prices expected to be held.There may also be a requirement to work in conjunction with another company to align works and ensure the installation dates are met.

title: The Provision of Lead Architectural Design and Consultancy Services and Principal Designer -Stages 1-7 - for the delivery of the  Rawtenstall Market
description: Rossendale Borough Council (RBC) has been successful in its grant bid submission to the DLUHC for a Capital Regeneration Project funding.The Rossendale Capital Regeneration Scheme encompasses a number of projects, but split into two categories. The Rossendale Town Centres including the demolition and redevelopment of a new market facility and Union Street public realm in Bacup, and the refurbishment and development alterations of the Rawtenstall Market as the projects main priority. Subsequently and depending on the budget, there is the refurbishment of a Skills and Employability Hub ‘The Bridge’, and work to improve the connectivity and public realm environment of Rawtenstall.This tender is to cover the Architectural Design and Consultancy services and Principal Designer role from RIBA Stages 1 to 7 for the redevelopment/refurbishment of the Rawtenstall Market only. Further details and background of the scheme can be reviewed in the tender documents.

description: Rossendale Borough Council is seeking the procurement of an MEP consultant who will be responsible for delivering all services to support the progression of the RIBA Stage 1 to 7. The successful MEP Consultant will be expected, at this stage, to be novated to the main contractor from stage 4. Further information can be found within the procurement documents.

title: The Provision of Civil and Structural Engineering Design Services (Stages 1-7) for the delivery of the Rawtenstall Market
description: This tender is to cover the Civil & Structural Engineering Design services on the development of the Rawtenstall Market only. The successful Civil & Structural Engineers will be required to design the structural & civil elements for the existing Market building working closely with the Architects and MEP Design Consultants and in accordance with the IStructE Structural Plan of Work 2020 Stages 1 to 7. A similar pathological approach should be used to design the required civils including all water discharges to meet current regulations. Depending on budget consideration should be given to rainwater harvesting design and solar PVs on the roof. Additional structural support maybe required to the roof to carry solar PVs. All groundworks need to be sufficient to take required loads. Consideration should be given to levelling up the floor in the existing market hall. Although we are requesting for fees covering Stages 1 to 7, at this stage, please assume the successful candidate will be novated to the Construction Contractor from Stage 4 to 7.Further details and background of the scheme can be reviewed in the procurement documents.

These functions include the financial and value for money audit of central government bodies in Northern Ireland including Departments, Executive Agencies, Executive Non-Departmental Public Bodies (“NDPBs”) and health and social care bodies.

title: North Essex Heritage - Jumbo Water Tower - Quantity Surveyor Procurement
description: This procurement is for the commissioning of a Quantity Surveyor for the Development and Delivery Phase of the proposed Jumbo Water Tower Project in Colchester.Colchester and North East Essex Building Preservation Trust (North Essex Heritage) is planning a careful conservation to the current architectural elements whilst helping to provide both a commercial and public use for the presently unutilised water tower. This willhelp to turn this historical landmark into a new cultural destination.The project has been successful in securing Development funding from the Towns Deal and NLHF Heritage Enterprise scheme. This funding is to be used to prove the viability of the project, and provide confidence in the ability of the Trust and partners to deliver this project.Accurate Cost Planning will be critical in demonstrating this.

title: North Essex Heritage - Jumbo Water Tower - Activity Planner, Community Engagement and Evaluation Procurement
description: Colchester’s Balkerne Water Tower, affectionately known as ‘Jumbo’, is the largest Victorian municipal water tower in England. Completed in 1883, it is grade II* listed, and maintained its original use until 1984. It has local significance as a beacon of Colchester standing tall on the skyline, and national significance as the last remaining listed water tower still intact, a testament to the feat of Victorian engineering that brought a public water supply to the masses.Colchester and North East Essex Building Preservation Trust’s (North Essex Heritage) mission is to save Jumbo from dereliction and see it removed from the Buildings At Risk register, producing a commercially viable operation that opens access to the public allowing all to appreciate the engineering marvel and superb views. It will bring the magnificent Balkerne Water Tower back into use, creatively converting it to provide a fully accessible heritage visitor attraction for the city, combined with complementary commercial uses to add to revenue to achieve financial sustainability for the long-term future.The project has been successful in securing Development funding from the Towns Deal and NLHF Heritage Enterprise scheme.  This funding is to be used to prove the viability of the project, and provide confidence in the ability of the Trust and partners to deliver this project.North Essex Heritage is now seeking to separately appoint the following roles to support the development of the project:- an Activity Planner and Community Engagement officer to lead in the development of partnerships, engagement, and outreach to our community, being the on the ground person that will lead on developing projects throughout the life of the project for a 4 year period.  Total value of commission is £80,000.- Evaluation consultant to establish the evaluation framework and monitor and measure the project against its objectives, for the life of the project, a 4 year period in total.  Total value of commission is £35,000.

title: North Essex Heritage - Jumbo Water Tower - Business Planner and Development Appraisal Procurement
description: Colchester’s Balkerne Water Tower, affectionately known as ‘Jumbo’, is the largest Victorian municipal water tower in England. Completed in 1883, it is grade II* listed, and maintained its original use until 1984. It has local significance as a beacon of Colchester standing tall on the skyline, and national significance as the last remaining listed water tower still intact, a testament to the feat of Victorian engineering that brought a public water supply to the masses.Colchester and North East Essex Building Preservation Trust’s (North Essex Heritage) mission is to save Jumbo from dereliction and see it removed from the Buildings At Risk register, producing a commercially viable operation that opens access to the public allowing all to appreciate the engineering marvel and superb views. It will bring the magnificent Balkerne Water Tower back into use, creatively converting it to provide a fully accessible heritage visitor attraction for the city, combined with complementary commercial uses to add to revenue to achieve financial sustainability for the long-term future.The project has been successful in securing Development funding from the Towns Deal and NLHF Heritage Enterprise scheme.  This funding is to be used to prove the viability of the project, and provide confidence in the ability of the Trust and partners to deliver this project.North Essex Heritage is now seeking to separately appoint the following roles to support the development of the project:- A Business Planner to work with the Trust to explore the operational model and business plan for Jumbo, preparing a NLHF compliant Business Plan for Round Two submission, and remaining with the project through Delivery and into Operation to provide guidance and updates to the Business Plan so it remains a live working document.  Total life of contract anticipated to be a 5 year period.  Total value of commission is in the region of £40,000.- Development Appraisal that meets the requirements of the NLHF Heritage Enterprise funding regime, undertaking the valuation of the building and calculating the conservation deficit, as well as working with the Business Planner to establish the viability of different operating models.  Appointment will be for 9 months and value of commission is £15,000.

title: The Provision of MEP Design and Consultancy Services Stages 2-7 for the delivery of the Bacup Market and Union Street Public Realm
description: Rossendale Borough Council is seeking to procure the services of an MEP consultant who will be responsible for delivering all services to support the progression of the RIBA Stage 1 to 7. The successful MEP Consultant will be expected, at this stage, to be novated to the main contractor from stage 4.The brief is summarised as follows:    1. “Work Stage" shall mean any stage into which the Services are divided as set out below.    2. Where any service is identified in relation to any particular Work Stage the Consultant is required to continue to provide that service during subsequent Work Stages until such time as such service has been completed to the satisfaction of the Client / Contractor.    3. This scope of service document should also be read in conjunction with the attached Clients Brief / Design Standards document.    4. It is intended that the structural appointment would commence directly with the Employer from Work Stage 1, up to the completion of Work Stage 2. The appointment from Work Stage 3 will then be novated to a Design & Build Contractor (assuming the project proceeds beyond that stage). Whilst the Scope of Service detailed herein, describes the requirements to Work Stages 3, the Employer shall have no commitment to the Consultant beyond Stage 2 nor provide any guarantee that the project will progress beyond that Work Stage nor that a fee will be agreed. It is at the Consultants absolute discretion as to how the total project fee is allocated to each work section and the Employer shall have no responsibility in this regard.    5. For the purposes of this document, the “Client” is deemed to be Council and the “Contractor” is deemed to be the Design & Build Contractor who is yet to be appointed

title: Duty-Free Stores Operator Opportunity at Keflavik International Airport
description: Isavia is currently proceeding with this Procurement to select an experienced airport travel duty-free operator as Concessionaire to operate Duty-Free Stores at KEF, this being the first time the Duty-Free Stores at KEF have been taken to the market. Isavia is seeking to enter into a true partnership with an operator who can deliver all the key facets that Isavia believes are the hallmarks of a world-class duty-free operator. Isavia foresees further growth and development of the Duty-Free Stores at KEF, by continuing to offer good service, trending products, competitive prices, and attractive customer experience. We are looking for a compelling and unique execution of a traditional core-category duty-free concept that reflects KEF’s position as the largest gateway into Iceland. Products and brands should be showcased and celebrated and we welcome the creation of a store experience that encourages engagement with products and people. Therefore, Isavia places a great emphasis on distinct and exciting selection and promotion of products, as well as a broad range of products with great offers in different price and quality segments. The Opportunity currently comprises of the KEF Duty-Free Stores; • departures Duty-Free Store in the main terminal; • a recently refurbished arrivals Duty-Free Store; and • a transfer Duty-Free Store in the non-Schengen area. In addition, the Concessionaire will receive the use of a bonded warehouse (approx. 1600 sqm) located on KEF property, a storage (approx. 154 sqm) for the arrivals Duty-Free store which is in the East Wing and accessible from landside area and a storage (approx. 140 sqm) for the departures Duty-Free store, located airside.The proposed duration of the Contract is currently anticipated to be eight (8) years, with optional extension of one (1) plus one (1) years.

title: Tender - Spillway Repair Cringle Reservoir
description: Manx Utilities is taking forward remedial works to the overflow spillway to the Cringle Impounding Reservoir. The scheme involves lining of the sloping portion of the current masonry spillway with a reinforced concrete lining. The works include the entire length of the spillway i.e. from the tumble bay (excluding tumble bay) up to the stilling basin (excluding the stilling basin). Included in this scheme are the provision of longitudinal and cross drainage together with drainage outside the spillway running the full length each side. The works encompass localised raising of the spillway walls at the bend in the spillway.

title: Quick Quote - Landscape Character Assessment Review
description: Please find attached documentation for a quick quote competition to undertake a review of the Isle of Man Landscape Character Assessment Report 2008 for Cabinet Office to be carried out between 30th January 2024 and 31st December 2024.The appointed contractor will design the approach to and deliver, a refreshed version of the Landscape Character Area Report 2008.  The output will inform the Isle of Man Strategic Plan Update, future Area Plans and other planning policy guidance.  It is essential that the contractor is a Chartered Member of the Landscape Institute.  The work involves thorough research and assessment including the preparation of character area appraisals and strategic landscape management guidelines that will inform strategic landscape policy drafting.  Together, the Strategic and Area Plans represent a development plan framework that is taken into account when planning applications are being considered.    The contractor will also be expected to attend certain meetings, events and presentations (some meetings may be suitable to be undertaken remotely). description: The Authority invites expressions of interest from suitable suppliers to provide low voltage shielded distribution pillars and racks for use on our electrical network.Manx Utilities’ requirements for shielded distribution pillars and racks are:•	Multiway shielded pillars for applications outside of the confines of an MUA building or substation. No service terminations are required.•	Multiway shielded pillars for use inside MUA outdoor substations and which are directly fed by a distribution transformer at 415V three phase.  The number of termination fuse ways may range from 2 ways to 8 ways.  No service terminations are required.•	Multiway shielded LV wall mounted racks for use inside MUA indoor substations and directly fed by a distribution transformer at 415V three phase.  The number of termination fuse ways may range from 2 ways to 8 ways.  No service terminations are required.

description: Blue Light Service Buildings Options Appraisal, Design and Feasibility Study – DHA/2023/004The Department of Home Affairs (DHA) and the Department of Health & Social Care (DHSC) ("the Department") wishes to explore the market, to replace buildings for: the Isle of Man Ambulance (IOMA), Isle of Man Constabulary (IOMC), Isle of Man Fire and Rescue services (IOMFRS) (“Blue Light Services”) as well as the Head Quarters for the Department of Home Affairs, including the Civil Defence and Army and Air Cadet Forces.. title: Quick Quote: Management, Printing and Fitting of VillaGaiety Promotional Sites
description: Please find attached documentation for a quick quote competition to provide Management, Printing and Fitting of VillaGaiety Promotional Sites  to the Department of Education, Sport and Culture to be carried out between 1st February 2024 and 1st February 2026. The Department of Education, Sport and Culture invites expressions of interest from experienced printing companies to manage the poster sites around the Villa Marina and Gaiety Theatre. The VillaGaiety is the Island’s largest entertainment venue, providing a varied programme of  artistic, cultural, musical and theatrical performances and cinema screenings for the Island’s public. The programme, which comprises a mix of Department and hire events, is marketed via various activities but the use of print and posters continues to be a vital and popular marketing tool for both VillaGaiety and their stakeholders. Out-sourcing the poster site printing is the most efficient way of managing this process. As such all poster site bookings and print will go through the successful company only, with no other having permission to fit artwork in the promotional space around the complex.Service RequirementThe Department of Education, Sport and Culture is looking for an experienced printing company to take responsibility for:•	The management of the poster sites around the Villa Marina and Gaiety Theatre complex, liaising with the VillaGaiety marketing team for Department shows as well as any show promoters for hire shows•	The printing of posters in varying sizes for display in existing poster sites around the Complex•	Weekly monitoring of all poster sites, taking a timely approach to the fitting, removing and replacement of posters in accordance with any agreed, updated schedule•	A monthly meeting with the Marketing Manager to review processes, print schedule and address any issues•	Printing of flyers on an ad-hoc basis•	Any other ad-hoc printing and installation of artwork or posters VillaGaiety require including but not limited to signs, / stickers, and vinyl)The attached documentation consists of:-	The Quick Quote Request DocumentThe Quick Quote will remain available on the Portal for Expressions of Interest until  noon (12.00 hrs) on Wednesday 24th February and the deadline for submissions is noon (12.00 hrs) on Friday 26th February and your response must be submitted through the portal by this deadline.  Once you have selected `Express Interest` a `Quote Documents` tab will appear and this is where you will find the above mentioned documents.After the above deadline the Portal will `Lock-Out` and no further submissions can be made.If your organisation does not wish to submit a response to provide these services, please select `Opt-Out` and select a reason. You can also choose to stop receiving correspondence on this screen.Please note, unless otherwise advised, all Quick Quote Competitions will be subject to the Isle of Man Government Standard Terms & Conditions for Goods and/or Services, a copy of which can be found under the `Supplier Information & Privacy Policies` tab.

title: A complete rotational assembly for a Alpha  Laval NX 314-31 decanter
description: Please find attached documentation for a quick quote competition to provide A complete rotational assembly for a Alpha  Laval NX 314-31 decanter to Department of Infrastructure.The Department of Infrastructure uses an Alpha Laval NX 314-31 decanter as an integral part of the Animal Waste Processing Plant (AWPP). This rotational assembly section of the decanter requires servicing every four or five years and due to the nature of part the AWPP cannot operate long without it.Therefore a spare complete rotational assembly system is required. The AWPP holds a spare scroll in stock so the parts required are a gear box (including pulleys and clutch), bowl, GS coupling (2.5 Nm) and main bearings for an Alpha Laval NX 314-31 decanter. description: Please find attached documentation for a quick quote competition to provide  Curriculum Development/ Timetabling to St. Ninian's High School.St. Ninian’s High School on behalf of the DESC are looking to engage the services of a Specialist educational service to provide review, development and construction of the school timetables. This work must encompass both the school and all regulatory needs of the curriculum, utilising School management System SIMS Software. The successful candidate will be expected to do the following: •	Attend on-site meetings with Senior Leadership •	Attend CPD sessions with staff explaining the role and how to design the school timetable•	Cooperate with subject leaders in regards to the development of the curriculum and tailor its structure•	Expected to work within the schools requirements ensuring that the timetables meet the needs of the school and are delivered within the agreed timeframes•	The Successful candidate should be ideally based on the Isle of Man to allow for easy access and referral. •	The successful candidate will be given access to the school systemThe duration of the contract will be for 3 years with the option of an extension for a further two years pending a performance review with school management, starting academic year 2023’24.The attached documentation consists of:-	The Quick Quote Request DocumentThe Quick Quote will remain available on the Portal for Expressions of Interest until  noon (12.00 hrs) on 23rd August 2023 and the deadline for submissions is noon (12.00 hrs) on 25th August 2023 and your response must be submitted through the portal by this deadline.  Once you have selected `Express Interest` a `Quote Documents` tab will appear and this is where you will find the above mentioned document.After the above deadline the Portal will `Lock-Out` and no further submissions can be made.If your organisation does not wish to submit a response to provide these services, please select `Opt-Out` and select a reason. title: Quick Quote - Design of VillaGaiety Promotional Material
description: Please find attached documentation for a quick quote competition to provide design of VillaGaiety promotional material to the Department of Education, Sport and Culture to be carried out between 5th January 2024 and 4th January 2026.The Department of Education, Sport and Culture (DESC) is looking for a suitably experienced graphic design company to fulfil artwork requirements for promotional and informative materials using current VillaGaiety brand guidelines.The successful applicant will be working closely with VillaGaiety’s Marketing Manager and Events Team and is required to complete tasks to deadlines, using design briefs and brand guidelines set by VillaGaiety, all using task management software ClickUp or other agreed means of correspondence. Specific deliverables for this contract are to:•	Maintain design and overall brand image of VillaGaiety•	Create appropriate visuals using creative expertise which will help promote our programme of events and achieve our Divisional and Departmental objectives such as highlighting the importance of arts, culture and heritage across the VillaGaiety complex•	Manage the advertising schedule by working with us and the media suppliers•	Supply all design material in the instructed format by the timeframe provided•	Make recommendations, using the designer’s skills and experience, in order to continue to improve brand identityThe attached documentation consists of:-	The Quick Quote Request Document - VillaGaiety Graphic Designer VG001-	Deliverables VillaGaiety Graphic Designer VG001-	Draft Agreement VG001 - December 2023-       Example Artwork - Courier VG001-        Example Artwork - Whats On - VG001-        VillaGaiety Brand GuidelinesThe Quick Quote will remain available on the Portal for Expressions of Interest until  noon (12.00 hrs) on Friday 15 December  and the deadline for submissions is noon (12.00 hrs) on Tuesday 19 December and your response must be submitted through the portal by this deadline. title: Quick Quote - Town Audits for the Isle of Man
description: Please find attached documentation for a quick quote competition to provide Town Audit Reports to the Department for Enterprise (Business Isle of Man) to be carried out in eight specified locations around the Isle of Man. These town audits will look to assess what each of the Island’s major towns and villages already have in terms of service provision, healthcare, infrastructure, retail units etc. and should also review what the local community want by analysing recently conducted surveys and conducting new data collection from local residents, businesses and charities, increasing community engagement. These Town Audits should provide a greater level of understanding of each of towns to the Isle of Man Government, demonstrating each economic areas unique compositions, challenges and opportunities for future growth. The work should be carried out in accordance with the below stages: •	Stage 1: Undertake under-pinning data collection activities across the eight areas identified in support of the development of ‘Town Audits’.•	Stage 2: Produce individual ‘Town Audit Reports’, which include detailed analysis, insights and future recommendations for each of the eight areas identified.Optional additional stage:  •	Stage 3: Produce an ‘Executive Summary Town Audit Review’ that provides a high-level overview of the outcomes of the individual town audit reports.The attached documentation consists of:-	Quick Quote Request Document - Town Audits for the Isle of Man-	Supporting Document  - Town Audit Proposed Locations -	Supporting Document - References to existing data and reports-	Supporting Document - High Street Task Force (25 Priorities for High Street Success)The Quick Quote will remain available on the Portal for Expressions of Interest until noon (12.00 hrs) on 26th September 2023 and the deadline for submissions is noon (12.00 hrs) on 2nd October 2023 and your response must be submitted through the portal by this deadline. description: Bidders are invited for the provision of Car Parking and Security to meet the operational and clinical requirements for Isle of Wight NHS Trust henceforth the “Contracting Authority”. The Trust wishes to appoint a commercial partner to:•	Provide the Trust with a high-quality Security and Car Parking Management Service.•	Fund and construct one of the three potential infrastructure projects detailed in this specification.The Contractor is required to provide Security and Car Parking Management Services to all parts of the St Mary’s Hospital campus, on behalf of Isle of Wight NHS Trust. Site drawings are given in the appendices.  Services are required 24 hours per day, 365(6) days per year. The Contractor is additionally required to fund and construct one of the three infrastructure projects described at Section 5, on the St Mary’s Hospital Campus.For the avoidance of doubt, the car parking areas will remain the property of the Trust and the Contractor will have unfettered access at all times. The Contractor will be granted a simple licence to occupy and to operate as part of the Contract award.

title: Proposal for the Supply of Negative Wound Pressure Therapy Pumps and Consumables
description: The Trust currently has a 15-year-old fleet of Negative Wound Pressure machines which require replacements. The Trust is seeking a supplier to provide a rental contract for 12 months with an option to extend for a further 12 months. NHS Supply Chain would be the preferred route to market but the Trust would be willing to review this option if significant savings and benefits can be obtained from a different purchasing route. The Trust needs to make savings so price will play a big factor in decision, along with quality and the after-sales service. Evaluations of the bids received will be undertaken with a shortlisting of suppliers invited to give presentations to key clinical and non-clinical staff. Suppliers may be required to arrange clinical trials to assess their suitability against requirements.

title: Mandatory Training for Nursing and Midwifery Students
description: King's College London is seeking tenders from suitably experienced training providers to carry out in person timetabled training sessions for nursing and midwifery students at the Florence Nightingale Faculty of Nursing, Midwifery and Palliative Care. Training sessions are to be carried out in London. Tenders are invited for the following lots: Lot 1 Basic Life Support (BLS), Neonatal Life Support (NLS) and Paediatric Life Support (PLS). Estimated annual volumes are 150 x 2 hour training sessions. Lot 2 Immediate Life Support (ILS) and Paediatric Life Support (PILS). Estimated annual volumes are 60 x 8 hour training sessions. Lot 3 Personal Safety. Estimated annual volumes are 50 x 3 hour training sessions.Lot 4 Moving and Handling. Estimated annual volumes are 150 x 2 hour training sessions.Lot 5 First Aid. Estimated annual volumes are 40 x 3 hour training sessions.The initial contract(s) will run from August 2024 to July 2025, with the option to extend annually for a maximum of 5 years.

title: Provision of a MALDI-ToF/ToF Mass Spectrometer
description: The department of Chemistry at King’s College London is part of the faculty of Natural Mathematical and Engineering Sciences which is a vibrant faculty based in the heart of London with a long tradition of world-leading research and teaching in physics, mathematics, chemistry, computer science and engineering.The department of Chemistry’s approach enshrines the rigour of the discipline in a progressive interdisciplinary context, designed to produce a new generation of scientists fluent across traditional subject boundaries. description: Lancaster University and Lancaster University Students’ Union is inviting expressions of interest (EOI) from suppliers interested in tendering. The winning bidder will be required to provide both performance kit and leisurewear (male and female) to a variety of clubs for approximately 40 sports. This will support the Student Unions’ goal of standardising a Lancaster University image across all teams. Lancaster University requires any supplier awarded the contract to start mobilisation in April 2024 for a delivery date the end of July 2024. The Student Union would require any candidates to be able to provide an overview of their sustainability policy and procedures.  With the university sporting season spanning such a short window from October to March, lead times are significant for both team wear and leisure wear/personal items, and should therefore be made readily available within 3-4 weeks from the date of order. The successful supplier would need to be able to provide flexible garments with not just ‘male’ and ‘female’, but also unisex options, so that visually there is coherence.The successful supplier will also be required to provide individual Lancaster University Students’ Union branded products online where students can view products and place orders direct for themselves.

The system will be installed within a high performance controlled environment (CE) facility and integrated with a lysimetry platform as part of the Centre for Photosynthetic Diversity, jointly supported by the Wolfson Foundation and the University. title: Phenotyping platform – plant water use efficiency by mass balance
description: The University is inviting tenders for the provision of an integrated plant phenotyping platform. The platform will measure plant water use efficiency using mass balance, integrated with control of fertigation regimes and measurement of microclimate. It will be one component of a Centre for Photosynthetic Diversity, jointly supported by the University and the Wolfson Foundation. The Centre is scheduled for scheduled for delivery by July 31st 2024, and may become part of a future UK phenotyping infrastructure. The platform will be installed within a controlled environment facility, in parallel with an automated imaging system designed to capture leaf area development and leaf biochemistry. The controlled environment facility and imaging system are tendered separately, and we anticipate a need for the platform supplier to work in concert with the manufacturers of these systems to ensure compatibility. title: LJMU 2320 Legal Services One-stop shop Framework Agreement
description: The Liverpool John Moores University’s Legal Services Team (“LST”) is part of the Legal and Governance service division and consists of a small team of lawyers providing advice to the University on all its legal matters. Any matters that require external legal support are instructed out through the LST. The LST is headed by the Head of Legal and Deputy General Counsel, and consists of several commercial and employment solicitors, supported by the team’s PA. The University Secretary and General Counsel oversees the Legal and Governance Services division. Our objectives are to:•	deliver high quality and timely legal solutions to colleagues across LJMU•	work closely with partners to ensure that LJMU’s strategic aims are met and support colleagues to make better-informed decisions•	promote an awareness of the legal implications of activities and decisions, ensuring any risks are identified promptly and mitigated effectively•	pro-actively support our colleagues by providing innovative and creative legal solutions to practical issues•	ensure legal and regulatory compliance and promote good governance•	advise LJMU, its subsidiaries and associated companies•	provide advice to the Board of Governors, its Executive Officers, Directors and Faculty and Professional Services staff. The University intends to appoint up to four external legal services providers to the Legal Services – One Stop Shop Framework agreement.  The establishment of this Framework Agreement will support the University’s legal team in the provisions of legal support.   The duration of the contract will be three years with the option to extend for one further year (based on performance)The University requires support in the following practice areas:1.	Commercial law (this includes research contracts, collaboration and international collaboration agreements, non disclosure agreements, SaaS, PaaS, apprenticeship contracts, licence agreements, good, services and works contracts, IP, IT, franchise contracts, funding agreements, sub contractor agreements, general terms and conditions; marketing, procurement, competition and consumer law matters, cross-border/international matters)2.	Corporate law (advising on charity law, our wholly owned subsidiaries, spin-out companies and other commercial activities, corporate finance, corporate governance and constitutional matters)3.	Litigation (relating to all practice areas, including academic litigation and judicial review) 4.	Property and Construction (drafting and negotiating sale, purchase and lease documentation, deeds of variation, filing requirements with Land Registry, reviewing title documents and advising on the same, including restrictive covenants, drafting and negotiating property licence agreements, advising on forfeiture of leases, planning law advice, construction and major projects)5.	Student matters (fitness to practise, disputes (including discrimination), complaints, appeals, student contract and related policies) 6.	Employment law (advice on HR casework processes (discipline, grievance etc), TUPE, whistleblowing, discrimination, trade union/industrial relations, redundancy, policy and contract reviews, Employment Tribunal claims, pensions, immigration law, settlement agreements, international collaborations involving staff travel and work overseas)7.	Data protection matters (data subject access and Freedom of Information Act requests).8.	Regulatory compliance (including OfS regulatory framework compliance, health and safety, export controls, subsidy control)

title: RFI for Accessibility Software - LJMU 2319
description: The new Digital Accessibility Regulations became law in September 2018: Public Sector Bodies (Websites and Mobile Applications) (No. 2) Accessibility Regulations 2018. These regulations are designed to improve access to Further and Higher Education and contribute to the Government’s ambition to close disability attainment and progression gaps. Public Sector websites and mobile applications are required to comply with the international accessibility standard across a timeframe, with an end date of 23 September 2020. Institutions have an expectation to meet the international Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG) 2.1 AA accessibility standard.  The University is seeking to procure an accessibility software solution – Cloud Based. The aim of the is to address issues around equal access to digital content, with specific emphasis on supporting students with disabilities, and in addition to this, the development of staff around digital accessibility. Developing institutional practice in this area is key to change management, and a system such as this will provide continual opportunities for staff to adapt, create accessible content and learn through that process. The University seeks a solution which will enable the institution to provide exceptional opportunities for online learning.

title: Contract for LLM SQE 1 Preparation Course Materials and Learning Management System
description: LJMU are conducting an open tender for this requirement, following PCR 2015, Light Touch Regime (LTR) process.Given the recent change in qualification as a solicitor in England and Wales, LJMU Law School wish to develop a Masters programme which will provide students with the underpinning knowledge and practice required in order to pass the Solicitors Regulation Authority’s (SRA’s) ‘Solicitors Qualification Examination’ (SQE) which is in 2 parts (SQE 1 and SQE 2) and also to be awarded with a Masters degree from LJMU. The School of Law at LJMU has the expertise and ability to teach such students in all aspects of the SQE, but does not have the infrastructure or resources in place in order to provide the materials required in order to prepare for the SQE 1 examinations which are 100% MCQs.  The staff within the Law School do have the resources and ability to teach and deliver their own materials for SQE 2 examinations, however.   Therefore, the Law School, would wish to license the use of the SQE 1 prep materials only within their teaching and have students gain access to the provider’s learning management system for additional data analysis and support.The Law School is not able to provide SQE 1 materials in order to prepare for SQE 1 due to the nature of the assessment and the number of materials that would be required in order for the students to have sufficient training in this type of assessment. Bidders must be Higher Education providers who have expertise in legal education towards qualification as legal professionals, preferably solicitors
