title: Advocacy Services
description: Provision of Advocacy ServicesSandwell Metropolitan Borough Council invites tenders for the delivery of Advocacy Services. The purpose of the Advocacy Services is to provide high-quality support to Service Users who are legally eligible to receive advocacy under existing legislation, and to provide non-statutory advocacy to inpatients who are voluntarily in hospital due to their mental health diagnosis and treatment. These Services will ensure that as many people as possible in Sandwell who are legally eligible to access these services do access them, have their legal rights upheld, and are effectively supported to engage with the processes and decisions in relation to their health and social care needs. The services will ensure that the Service User’s voice (or best interests in the case of IMCA/IMCA DOLS) are at the heart of any decisions made and ensure maximum choice, safety and independence for service users.The services in this contract are:1.	Care Act Advocacy2.	Independent Mental Capacity Advocacy / Deprivation of Liberty (IMCA/ IMCA DoLS) and Relevant Paid Person Representatives (RPPR)3.	Independent Mental Health Advocacy (IMHA) and Inpatient Mental Health Advocacy4.	Independent Complaints Advocacy (ICAS)The successful contractor will be required to deliver Advocacy Services in compliance with legislation including the Care Act 2014, Mental Capacity Amendment Act 2005 and the Amendment Act 2019, Mental Health Act 1983 and NHS and Social Care Act 2012, and to ensure all services  are flexible and responsive to developments in legislation, policy and guidance, and to any variations in demand for any of the services. The successful contractor will also be required to work to outcomes, including:•	Improved awareness and take up of Statutory Advocacy•	Improved services and service practices The duration of the contract will be four (4) years from 1 April 2024 to 31 March 2028. Tenderers should note that the Council has a maximum budget for all services which is £246,242 per contract year, and a maximum total contract value over the duration of the contract being £984,968. Further details can be found in the Invitation To Tender (ITT) documentation. The Council will be using the In-tend e-Tendering System for this Procurement exercise, please visit https://in-tendhost.co.uk/sandwellmbc to access the Sandwell MBC In-tend Supplier Portal. From here you will be able to register your company, express an interest in the opportunity, and gain immediate access to the ITT and other related documents. In Order To View and Submit a Tender, you will be required to` Opt-In`.   For a Step by Step user guide to the Sandwell MBC In-tend Supplier Portal please click on the `Guidance for Suppliers` section of the website. All procurement responses must be carried out via the Sandwell MBC In-tend Supplier Portal.  If you require further assistance in respect of the system please contact the In-tend support team on 0844 272 8810.Closing date: 7 November 2023 at 13:00hrs

title: Printing of Sandwell Herald
description: Printing of Sandwell HeraldSandwell Council’s Communications & Corporate Affairs Team is seeking quotations from an experienced contractor to print the Sandwell Herald newspaper in line with its current look for a two-year contract covering the period 1 February 2024 to 31 January 2026.The most recent edition can be viewed at www.sandwell.gov.uk/heraldThe number of Herald editions per annum will be subject to demand and budget. However, we anticipate up to six editions over the two-year contract.The number of printed copies required per edition is up to approximately 147,000. This may be subject to change.The successful supplier will also be responsible for printed copies to be bundled, strapped and, where required, labelled, and to arrange delivery into distribution centres.The first edition under the contract will need to be delivered to distribution centres on Friday 23 February 2024. The council’s preferred print date for this edition would be either Tuesday 20 February 2024 or Wednesday 21 February 2024.We are seeking a high-quality print solution for the Sandwell Herald that helps to ensure residents in Sandwell are well-informed, can access key services and can take part in activities and events.Research shows the Herald is the top council communications channel by which residents receive news and information about Sandwell, including key cost of living, safety and health advice. The Herald is particularly valuable for tackling digital inequality as this is the main way the council communicates with residents who are not online.The content of the Herald represents and celebrates the diversity of Sandwell people as well as promoting a wide range of services, advice and community/voluntary groups that support people from all backgrounds and with various needs.The Council will be using the In-tend e-Tendering System for this Procurement exercise, please visit https://in-tendhost.co.uk/sandwellmbc to access the Sandwell MBC In-tend Supplier Portal.From here you will be able to register your company, express an interest in the opportunity, and gain immediate access to Quotation or other related documents.To submit a quotation you will be required to "Opt In".For a Step by Step user guide to the Sandwell MBC In-tend Supplier Portal please click on the `Guidance for Suppliers` section of the website. All procurement responses must be carried out via the Sandwell MBC In-tend Supplier Portal. You will be responsible for the statutory processes which will include coordinating annual reviews, writing and updating plans and ensuring that outcomes are set that focus on Preparation for Adulthood.  We are looking for an individual who has:•	Excellent Communication Skills.•	Excellent planning & organisation skills.•	An ability to work to deadlines.•	A Good working knowledge of SEND and relevant legislation.•	An understanding of the nature and importance of co-production and partnership working.  Our Values; Trust, Unity and Progress make us unique, they define how we do things and are reflected in the way we behave. They are important to us, guiding and shaping our organisational culture. Our values are key to us achieving Sandwell’s Vision 2030 and also guide us when we recruit.

title: Toxicology Services  2024 - 2028
description: Sandwell MBC (the “Council”) is the relevant authority for the Black Country Coroners Jurisdiction which covers four local authority areas namely; Sandwell MBC, Dudley MBC, Walsall MBC and the City of Wolverhampton. Annually approximately 5000 deaths are reported to the Senior Coroner for the Black Country.  When discharging his or her judicial responsibilities, a coroner will make whatever inquiries are necessary when endeavouring to establish a cause of death. Those inquiries although not exclusively may involve a Digital Autopsy scan, a Post Mortem examination and in some instances the use of Toxicology Services to ensure that service he or she provides meets the needs of the bereaved in a timely manner. The Council is therefore co-ordinating a tender exercise for Toxicology Services and wishes to invite interested suppliers (“Tenderers”) to participate in a tender exercise in relation to the supply of these services (“invitation to Tender” or “ITT”).

description: Job title: SEN Area Team ManagerRate of pay: £341.00 per day (Inside IR35)Hours: 37 hours per week Location: Sandwell Council House, Oldbury.Start date: ASAPContract type: Temporary (Agency) 12 weeks with a view to extend Job Description and Personnel Specification are attached, which also provides more information above the role.Brief description:We are looking for an Area Team Manager to join one of our Area Teams. You will be overseeing a team of EHCP Officer’s who maintain high standards of professional practice whilst working in the best interests of children and young adults. This is an exciting opportunity to make a difference and continue to develop the good work identified in our local area inspection revisit in March 2019. Your team will be responsible for the statutory processes which will include coordinating annual reviews, writing and updating plans and ensuring that outcomes are set that focus on Preparation for Adulthood.  We are looking for an individual who has:•	Excellent Communication Skills.•	Excellent planning & organisation skills.•	An ability to work to deadlines.•	A Good working knowledge of SEND and relevant legislation.•	An understanding of the nature and importance of co-production and partnership working.  Our Values; Trust, Unity and Progress make us unique, they define how we do things and are reflected in the way we behave. They are important to us, guiding and shaping our organisational culture. description: Job Title: Head of Building Safety and ComplianceRate of Pay: £600 - £800 per dayHours: 37 per weekLocation: Operations & Development Centre, Roway Lane, Oldbury, B69 3ESStart Date: ASAPContract type: AgencyBrief description:This role covers all areas of landlord compliance including Building Safety, The Big 6 of Asbestos; Gas; Electric; Water; Fire and Loler regulations and all remaining elements of HHSRS.  As well as the day to day management of the team the role supports the AD Building Safety and Compliance in performing their duties as the Accountable Person.  The role sets policies, standards and guidelines for all matters of compliance outlined above for the Housing Directorate.  The role acts as the main point of contact with the wider council and external stakeholders for all compliance matters contained within the remit; Monitors and develops best practice within the team though tracking best practice outside of Sandwell; ensures all relevant papers are developed for approval; ensures all ongoing documentation is produced, obtained and stored where required and ensures all legislative requirements are met.  Manages all budgets associated with the areas of responsibility and monitors and reports any variations to budget and takes corrective action where required.Experience and qualifications requiredA relevant qualification in one or more of the key compliance areas and relevant industry experience in managing and running a big six compliance function within a Social Housing Landlord Function.Please can the agencies send over a CV, 2x up to date references and a copy of Terms and Conditions. title: Housing Disrepair Claims Manager SA
description: Job Title: Housing Disrepair Claims ManagerRate of Pay: £26.70 per hourHours: 37 per weekLocation: Operations & Development Centre, Roway Lane, Oldbury, B69 3ESStart Date: ASAPContract type: AgencyBrief description:Local Authorities across the country have seen unprecedented rises in claims for Housing Disrepair. We are looking to recruit a suitably qualified and experienced individual to help manage our caseload alongside our resident team of surveyors and the councils legal service. You will need to review our management of cases to ensure an effective resolution that protects the council from excessive claims and provides appropriate solutions for residents. you will ensure the service delivers to set deadlines, has robust data management, manage and agree cost claims and lead case reviews to embed lessons into our processes and procedures which will improve our repairs service and in turn avoid the need for future claims. As our dedicated HDR manager you will coordinate activity, triage cases alongside our legal teams, assign resources more effectively to higher priority or higher risk cases so that we target our efforts toward maximum impact. From case studies and reviews you will help identify lessons learned and from that develop training needs, process reviews and areas for early intervention to minimise the councils exposure to future claims. Alongside this you will provide support to respond to repair related complaints in order to identify trends and areas for improvement. You will be required to attend court proceedings from time to time as the council’s representative to provide evidence of the councils processes and procedures for management of HDR claims.Ideal candidates will have experience of dealing with customers and is able to remain calm in often in stressful situations. Able to understand and interpret complex information and provide clear and concise reports to senior management on performance, service improvements and case outcomes as necessary. You will manage a small team of administrators. Please can the agencies send over a CV, 2x up to date references and a copy of Terms and Conditions. You will also need to include your agency on cost details to each submission.  Stated rates must be inclusive of all known costs and stated on each CV. No DBS is required for this role.Please note this advert is also out with our Master VendorYou will receive further information regarding invoice terms if your candidate is appointed to this role.  Invoices must be sent electronically on a weekly basis to templink_1@sandwell.gov.uk along with your workers authorised timesheet supplied by your agency. Payments are then released 14 days from the date of the invoice.The Council will be using the In-tend e-Tendering System for this Procurement opportunity, please visit https://in-tendhost.co.uk/sandwellmbc to access the Sandwell MBC In-tend Supplier Portal.From here you will be able to register your company, express an interest in the opportunity, and gain immediate access to the related documents.To submit your documents, you will be required to opt in.For a Step by Step user guide to the Sandwell MBC In-tend Supplier Portal please click on the `Guidance for Suppliers` section of the website. description: 1 -  Quotation for Supply of illuminated lighting and SFX display at Dartmouth Park, West Bromwich 2 –Sandwell Metropolitan Borough Council is hosting a celebration weekend on the 3rd and 4th November for our annual fireworks events. This will take place at Dartmouth Park, Reform Street, West Bromwich, B706TT. Our event will take place in the evening and we require illuminated lighting and SFX displays to light up the event field, splash pad and playground at Dartmouth Park. Last year, we had over 15,000 attendees visit the event across the weekend and are hoping for the same numbers this year. We require Dartmouth Park to be in colourful lights and with creative light up and engaging theming for Children. We will require the Dartmouth park building, the play area, paths and war memorial to be lit up in colour and projections with your own content creations. We require onsite lighting engineer and crew during the event and in the lead up to the event. We will also require the design, installation, and lighting for 8 7ft white ‘SANDWELL’ letters or equivalent for our entrance point. Letters will be retained by Sandwell Council for use at other future events. We’ve set out ambitious plan to help us achieve our vision that by 2030, Sandwell is a thriving, optimistic and resilient community. It’s where we call home and where we’re proud to belong - where we choose to bring up our families, where we feel safe and cared for, enjoying good health, rewarding work, feeling connected and valued in our neighbourhoods and communities, confident in the future, and benefiting fully from a revitalised West Midlands.This is a chance to make your mark and drive the transformation of a place with tremendous potential. You will be responsible for Operational Adult Social Care which includes the programmes, policies and services which promote independence, encourage choice, support vulnerable people and seek to protect our residents. The Operational management - includes Therapy, Hospital, Mental Health, Social Work Therapy and Safeguarding teams.  The successful candidate will have senior management responsibility for the Integrated Hub/Reablement, LPS and CQC inspections therefore you will understand how to deliver effective leadership, build good stakeholder relationships and develop a strategically aligned and values based organisational culture in order to achieve high quality outcomes.We are looking for someone with:-	Final professional qualification(s) in a relevant discipline related to the service areas/functions or significant working experience in the services relevant to this post.-	Evidence of management competencies.Enhanced Adults DBS and Social Work England qualification required.Please can the agencies send over a CV, 2x up to date references and a copy of Terms and Conditions. title: Quotation for Supply of fireworks display at Dartmouth Park, West Bromwich
description: This is an Invitation to Quote with information, instructions and guidance provided in this document, following consideration of which the Quotation submission should be completed and returned by all suppliers who wish to quote for the requirement described in the following pages. If not relevant, please state n/a.OverviewThis is an Invitation to Quote with information, instructions and guidance provided in this document, following consideration of which the Quotation submission should be completed and returned by all suppliers who wish to quote for the requirement described in the following pages. If not relevant, please state n/a.OverviewSandwell Metropolitan Borough Council is hosting a celebration weekend with a modern and musical firework display on Saturday November 4, 2023Date -Saturday 4 November 2023However, this is not a guaranteed requirement that the council will procure all the above and may be subject to change.Term of ContractThe contract period for supply will be for the duration of the above period.   Questions and Contact DetailsAll requests for clarifications (whether in relation to this document, the requirement or the Quotation submission) should be submitted as soon as possible via the In-Tend Supplier Portal.A copy of all questions and answers raised will be visible to all recipients of the invitation to Quote. If the Applicant expresses that the question is confidential and the Council agree that it is then the response will be sent only to the Applicant raising the question.The Council will make available via the In-Tend Supplier Portal complete list of answers to all questions submitted by Applicants (up to and including) 4 September at 17:00hrs.Questions received after this date may not be answered.If you do not wish to submit a Quotation, please notify the Council via the In-Tend Supplier Portal quoting the Quotation reference number.  Under no circumstances should you pass this document on to a third party. 2. REQUIREMENT (including Specification)This section provides Applicants with as much detail as possible regarding the requirements and will help Applicants to compile their Quotation submission, and provides a specification for the services.Service SpecificationSupply of fireworks display at Dartmouth Park, West Bromwich, 4 November 2022Sandwell Metropolitan Borough Council is hosting a weekend of exciting illuminations, play by night, and a finale of fireworks and live entertainment We require quotations from suitable suppliers to deliver the display. It is anticipated the displayed will attract an audience of around 10,000 people.The council’s event team are looking to procure the following:The supply, delivery, installation, firing, supervision and removal of fireworks at the park - where a minimum of a 25-minute multi-faceted display would be held with fireworks choreographed to music including a grand finale firing. There is also scope to include fire sculpture within the bid.The successful bidder will have membership of the British Pyrotechnic Association, the CBI Explosive Industry Group or equivalent.The successful tender will be awarded to a company that will provide all necessary transport, equipment, personnel, and material for set up, fireworks display performance, and break down. The scheduled time of the launching will be approximately 8pm. There shall be a three-phase display with an opener no less than one minute, a main body of the show lasting no less than eighteen minutes, and a finale lasting no less than three minutes. All fireworks to be included in the presentation are to be of premium quality. No consumer grade fireworks are to be used. Companies should agree to set up and deliver the fireworks display in accordance within BPA Guidelines and observe the safety recommendations outlined in working together on firework displays produces by the CBI Explosives Industry Group. All methods of working, paperwork and safe practices will be reviewed by the multi-agency Sandwell Safety Advisory Group.The Following Levels of Training are required;-•	BPA level 2 for the senior firer and BPA level 1 for any assistants assisting in the display.•	The company must have a DGSA (dangerous goods safety advisor)•	The company must have ADR qualified drivers (number 2-6 we will require proof as either a certificate or Identify Card)The successful company will be required to visit site with the event organiser to assess site and produce site specific risk assessment outlined below:Supporting documentation required;1.	Copy of the Company’s Health and Safety Policy and generic risk assessment detailing any hazards to risks associated with the work to be carried out.2.	Site specific risk assessment will be required from the successful tenderer which includes the nature of the site, the fireworks chosen for the event/site and the rigging and firing methods used. This should be provided 4 weeks before event date.3.	A copy of the Public Liability Insurance Certificate, which must be for a minimum of £5 million.4.	Audio Visual Evidence of the of Company’s work.5.	Details of displays carried out in the last 2 years with names and contact details of event organisers.6.	Two testimonials from recent previous clients.The budget for the fireworks is between £25,000 and £35,000, and bidders are required to submit: 1.	Options based on pricing between £25,000 and £35,000. 2.	A full breakdown of those options, costed against each, so it can be measured against other bidders. Please note the council reserve the right to reject any supplier that are not compatible with the above functionality

description: Social Worker Rate of Pay: From £24.00 up to £28.00 per hourHours: 37 hours per weekLocation: Hybrid Working/ Sandwell Council House, Freeth Street, oldbury Start Date: ASAP Contract type: Agency Job Description and Personnel Specification are attached, which also provides more information above the role.Brief description:This is an exciting time to join Sandwell Metropolitan Brought Council Adult Social Care. We are currently restructuring our community social work teams to create town teams and a separate Learning Disability and Autism Team for Sandwell adults. We are looking to recruit an additional full time (37 hour) agency Social Workers into or Learning Disability/Autism Team to bring it to full capacity until permanent staff are recruited to the team. We are looking for committed and hardworking qualified Social Worker with Adult Social Work experience working with people with Learning Disabilities/Autism. You will need to be motivated and flexible with high professional standards and sound knowledge and experience of current legislation including the Care Act 2014, Continuing Health Care, Mental Health Act, Mental Capacity Act 2005, and Community DOLS/LPS. You will be expected to work with vulnerable adults with Learning Disabilities/Autism and also have some knowledge around physical disability, people with profound & complex needs, carer’s and the wider community. You will need to be confident in undertaking safeguarding investigations, mental capacity assessments, best interest decisions, carrying out outcome focused assessments, with support planning, to meet their care and support needs. You must be able to work with a diverse group of individuals and with our partner agencies to deliver the best outcomes for our customers who have a learning Disability/Autism. You will be given an induction, appropriate training opportunities and regular supervision with an experienced manager. You will be working in a friendly environment, skilled, diverse and supportive team. An Enhanced DBS with Children’s and Adults Barring List Check is required for this role.You must hold a Degree in Social Work, Dip SW, CQSW or equivalent and be registered with Social Work England This role falls inside of IR35Please can the agencies send over a CV, 2x up to date references and a copy of Terms and Conditions. title: External Surveys to High Rise Blocks in Various Locations Throughout the Borough (2023 - 2027)
description: Providing external surveys to 55 no. high rise housing blocks with a height range of 6 to 18 storeys•	Reporting findings of surveys to the Client for each building.•	Using both abseil techniques and Mobile Elevated Working Platforms (MEWPs) depending upon the location and the access limitations of each individual block. •	Undertaking visual inspection surveys on site to determine the condition of the structure, claddings and render, identifying any defects & recommending future inspection programme frequencies or rectification solutions including structural engineering advice regarding these solutions.•	Cutting out or removing defective structures & materials and carrying out emergency repairs to minor defects which may cause a danger to the public if left untreated. •	Providing intrusive surveys, including removing and reinstating external brick cladding/structures to determine underlying structural defects•	Providing safety surveys to insulated render and making patch repairs where defective render is identified.•	Providing thermology studies to identified blocks•	Providing RF surveys to telecommunications installations to identified blocks•	Providing laboratory testing and chemical analysis of samples taken during the course of the surveys•	Providing Method Statements and Risk Assessments (to be returned with the tender submission)•	Providing an outline Programme of the Works (to be submitted for approval within seven days of request). •	Providing a written report for each block complete with defect locations, drawings and recommendations all cross-referenced with photographs and other information necessary to form the basis of future planned long-term maintenance of the blocksThe Council will be using the In-tend e-Tendering System for title: Market Engagement for a Reablement Service
description: The Older People’s Commissioning Team in Sandwell Council are currently developing a specification for a new reablement service. This is to support people being discharged from hospital, or to avoid an admission into an acute service. This will be a short-term service to allow a person to reach their fullest potential / independence and allow social workers a period of assessment to determine if there are any further requirements for care and support, after the initial assessment period has concluded. We are currently undertaking an information gathering exercise and are reaching out to you as a home care provider (or other if relevant), to seek intelligence around what you may already deliver, what works and what doesn’t / hasn’t worked, in your experience. The Council would appreciate it if you would provide a response to the following questions:1)	Do you provide a reablement service in any other local authority area, and if 	so, which area?2)	If the answer to Q1 is YES, please advise:         •	Hourly rate paid or how the service is remunerated        •	Any other additional fees / incentives / enhancements in addition to the hourly rate applicable to providing the service      •	Model – spot / block / 6 weeks / 12 weeks, etc.3)	How does your service currently support someone when they are discharged from hospital, for example, you may deliver a 72-hour fast response service?4)	Would you bid to deliver a reablement service in Sandwell?5)	What would encourage you to bid for a reablement service?6)	Is there anything that would discourage you to bid for a reablement service?Please respond via the Correspondence section of In-Tend by Friday 8th September 2023The Council will be using the In-tend e-Tendering System for this Market Engagement, please visit https://in-tendhost.co.uk/sandwellmbc to access the Sandwell MBC In-tend Supplier Portal.From here you will be able to register your company, and respond to the questions asked.For a Step by Step user guide to the Sandwell MBC In-tend Supplier Portal please click on the `Guidance for Suppliers` section of the website. All procurement responses must be carried out via the Sandwell MBC In-tend Supplier Portal.  If you require further assistance in respect of the system please contact the In-tend support team on 0844 272 8810.

title: SCT Residential Partnerships
description: The Trust is seeking to tender for up to a maximum of 20 block purchase beds within seven Residential Children’s Homes across Sandwell. This will be an incremental process split into two phases, Phase one will include three homes with a total of 10 beds, while phase two has the potential of a further four homes with a max of 10 beds The successful Bidders shall aim to create sustainable change to reduce long term social and welfare dependency, with the aspiration of equipping Children with the skills to become a self-sustainable adult, for example being able to secure employment, maintain their own tenancy agreement and contribute positively to the local community.    The successful Bidders shall work in Partnership with the Child, Stakeholders and the Trust to actively encourage and support the Child’s step down of support from the Provider to enable independence and the Child’s move on to an alternative care provision, back to the family home, foster placement or to supported accommodation, if appropriate and in the best interests of the Child.    The successful Bidders shall deliver a flexible service ranging from full time to phased care, which can support returns to families, foster placements and transition to independent living, this includes the provision of outreach support within the family home, foster or supported living placement in order to support the sustainability of the Child’s long-term Care Plan. The Trust will consider utilising beds within existing Residential Children’s Homes within Sandwell or homes to be opened within the Borough to timescales mutually agreed by the successful Bidder and the Trust, the contract commencement and go live date are negotiable in this instance.  In both cases the homes have to be exclusively available to Sandwell Children’s Trust, unless otherwise agreed in writing by the Trust. This procurement is for social care services which are considered Light Touch Regime services for the purpose of the Public Contracts Regulations 2015 as specified in Schedule 3 of the Regulations Regulations). The deadline for tender responses is 6 November 2023 at 15:00.  Please ensure you allow sufficient time to upload your response.

title: Enhanced Assessment Nursing Beds Service
description: The Metropolitan Borough of Sandwell wishes to appoint one (1) Contractor to provide ten (10) Enhanced Assessment Nursing Beds within a care home which is registered with the Care Quality Commission and is located within the borough of Sandwell. The successful Contractor will be expected to accept referrals for people with dementia and non-weight bearing care needs, as well as general nursing needs. The Enhanced Assessment Beds Service overall has as its primary function the prevention of admission to hospital or facilitation of discharge from hospital through a rapid, co-ordinated response and by operating 7 days a week. The service specification outlines the main aims of the provision, the service to be provided and the connections to other services in the community. Under this procurement, the Contractor will be required to actively participate and support the achievement of social benefits to the Sandwell community providing value for money on a whole life basis in terms of generating benefits to society and the economy whilst minimising the impact to the environment of Sandwell (Public Services (Social Value) Act 2012).Tenderers should note that the Council has a set bed rate for the Service, which can be found in the Invitation To Tender (ITT) documentation. The duration of the contract will be from 15 January 2024 to 31 March 2025, with no option to extend.The Council intends to use an evaluation model based solely on quality for this service. The criteria, on which the tender will be evaluated, inclusive of weightings attached to each question, are included in the ITT documentation. The Contract Value is estimated to be £598,670.90.The Council will be using the In-tend e-Tendering System for this Procurement exercise, please visit https://in-tendhost.co.uk/sandwellmbc to access the Sandwell MBC In-tend Supplier Portal. title: Toxicology Services 2024 - 2028
description: Sandwell MBC (the “Council”) is the relevant authority for the Black Country Coroners Jurisdiction which covers four local authority areas namely; Sandwell MBC, Dudley MBC, Walsall MBC and the City of Wolverhampton. Annually approximately 5000 deaths are reported to the Senior Coroner for the Black Country.  When discharging his or her judicial responsibilities, a coroner will make whatever inquiries are necessary when endeavouring to establish a cause of death. Those inquiries although not exclusively may involve a Digital Autopsy scan, a Post Mortem examination and in some instances the use of Toxicology Services to ensure that service he or she provides meets the needs of the bereaved in a timely manner.   The Council is therefore co-ordinating a tender exercise for Toxicology Services and wishes to invite interested suppliers (“Tenderers”) to participate in a tender exercise in relation to the supply of these services (“invitation to Tender” or “ITT”).

title: SANDWELL PROMOTING INDEPENDENCE REABLEMENT SERVICE
description: Sandwell Metropolitan Borough Council wishes to appoint up to 10 Providers for the provision of a Reablement Service to eligible individuals living in Sandwell. All Providers will be appointed to deliver the Service across the whole of the Borough of Sandwell.  It is anticipated that the Service will support approximately 2000 hours of care per week, however the amount of hours of care per week may vary during the duration of the Agreement.The Service will provide Reablement services to eligible adults (18 years old and over) aimed at enabling individuals:•	To safely leave hospital where they would otherwise remain in hospital or avoid a hospital admission and remain in their own home or place of residence;•	Provide a short term, time limited (up to 6 weeks) Reablement Service for Adults who have been assessed and have demonstrated the potential to benefit from home care reablement to regain their independence and live well at home after an illness, injury or period of reduced mobility;

title: Tender for Subscribed Garden Waste Permit Stickers and Printing Capability
description: Tender for Subscribed Garden Waste Permit Stickers and Printing CapabilitySandwell Borough Council subscribed garden waste collection service was approved by Cabinet in November 2022.  The pilot scheme introduced March 2023 with approximately 40,000 subscribers who are identified from a sticker affixed to their 240L garden waste bin lid. Following the successful pilot scheme, the Council now intends to establish a three-year agreement for the period 7 February 2024 to 6 February 2027. The Council is now seeking to appoint a contractor who will be able to supply 130,000 stickers over a 3 - year period (Annual Profile: 40,000;44,000;46,000;).The successful contractor will provide a product (stickers) and printing portal capability to integrate directly with the Councils Whitespace system, so new sticker requests are automatically received by the supplier on creation of a ‘worksheet’ in Whitespace. The portal should provide access for sticker requests to be reviewed retrospectively in case queries are raised by customers. This needs to be in place by February 2024.The Council will be using the In-tend e-Tendering System for this Procurement exercise, please visit https://in-tendhost.co.uk/sandwellmbc to access the Sandwell MBC In-tend Supplier Portal.From here you will be able to register your company, express an interest in the opportunity, and gain immediate access to the ITT and other related documents.In Order To View and Submit a Tender, you will be required to` Opt-In`. title: Advanced Practitioner (Part Time)
description: Job Title Advanced Practitioner Rate of Pay: £19.85 per hour (Inside IR35)Hours: 18.5 hours per week Location: Hybrid/Sandwell Council House, Oldbury, B69 3DEStart Date: ASAPContract type: Agency, 12 weeks from start dateJob Description and Personnel Specification are attached, which also provides more information above the role.Brief description:We are looking for 1 x temporary agency Social Care Lead Officer, for 3 months, 18.5 hours a week (Wed (PM), Thursday & Friday) to cover the Young adults Team (YAT) in the Adult Social Care while we recruit a permanent worker to fill that post.Person should be a qualified Social Worker with Adults Social Work management experience, to bring your knowledge, skills, and attributes to lead a team of qualified and unqualified staff to make a difference to the lives of young people of Sandwell.You will need to be motivated and flexible with high professional standards and sound knowledge and experience of current legislation and practice including the Care Act 2014, Safeguarding Continuing Health care, Community DOLS/LPS and Mental Capacity Act 2005, and Mental Health Act. Have knowledge of working with young people, transition from children to adult service/adulthood and be able to engage with partners such as Children’s Services, Health services, housing etc. in the processYou will be expected to support your staff to work with vulnerable adults with mental health issues, learning disability, physical disability, and older people. You need to be able to work with a diverse group of individuals and partner agencies. You will work alongside a supportive and experienced team of managers with regular supervision and development opportunities.Key features of this role:*Managing the day to day operational business of the team *Ensuring the successful delivery of team and service objectives *Managing expectations in terms of the Care Act, Mental Capacity Act, statutory safeguarding duties and corporate policies *Driving the improvement and performance frameworks, with regular staff supervision. *Implement, monitor and review the use of Prevention and Re-ablement services and the use of community offersCVs required urgently please. JD and PS attached.Please can the agencies send over a CV, 2x up to date references and a copy of Terms and Conditions. You will also need to include your agency on cost details to each submission.  Stated rates must be inclusive of all known costs.An Enhanced Adults Barring DBS check is required for this role. Please note this advert is also out with our Master VendorYou will receive further information regarding invoice terms if your candidate is appointed to this role.  Invoices must be sent electronically on a weekly basis to templink_1@sandwell.gov.uk along with your workers authorised timesheet supplied by your agency. title: Trusted Assessor Service
description: Trusted Assessor Service. Sandwell Metropolitan Borough Council wishes to appoint a single Provider to the ASC113 Trusted Assessor Service to provide assessments for eligible individuals ready for discharge from hospital in Sandwell.People can sometimes wait too long for discharge from hospital resulting in poor experience of the health and care system and poorer outcomes. Trusted Assessor schemes are a national initiative designed to reduce delays when people are ready for discharge from hospital. Providers accept assessments carried out by suitably qualified ‘Trusted Assessors’ working under formal, written agreements.Research has shown that delayed discharges can have a significant negative impact on people’s well-being. There are also risks associated with premature or poorly planned discharges.The use of a Trusted Assessor Service can reduce the numbers and waiting times of people awaiting discharge from hospital and help them to move from hospital back home or to another setting speedily, effectively and safely thereby improving patient experience, clinical safety and patient flow.The Service will operate 7 days a week. The Specification, attached as Appendix 2 to the Invitation to Tender, details the aims of the service to be provided within the contract and the connections to other services in the community. The Provider will be required to provide a high-quality service that aligns with the Council’s vision for Adult Social Care.The Trusted Assessor Service Agreement will commence on 1st April 2024 for an initial period of 2 years with the option of extending for up to a further 12 months.Suitably qualified and experienced persons and organisations can view the full tender documentation that includes the Invitation to Tender, which contains details of the evaluation criteria and methodology, and Tender Response Documents; detailed Specification(s) and a copy of the Council’s standard Terms and Conditions of Agreement by registering on Sandwell’s In-Tend Supplier Portal. The Council will be using the In-Tend e-Tendering System for this Procurement exercise, please visit https://in-tendhost.co.uk/sandwellmbc to access the Sandwell MBC In-tend Supplier Portal. From here you will be able to register your company, express an interest in the opportunity, and gain immediate access to the ITT and other related documents. In order to view and submit a Tender Response, you will be required to 'Opt-In'. For a Step by Step user guide to the Sandwell MBC In-Tend Supplier Portal please click on the `Guidance for Suppliers` section of the website. description: Sandwell Libraries and Archives - Home Library Service BRIEF DESCRIPTIONSandwell Metropolitan Borough Council (the Council) provides a Home Library Service to customers who cannot visit a library.The service has been in operation for many years. However, we wish to outsource part of the operation of the Home Library Service.The Home Library Service delivers a range of materials directly to residents of any age who, because of illness, disability or frailty, are unable to visit their local library.  The service is also available to carers who have difficulty accessing the library service due to their caring responsibilities. Currently, it forms part of the Outreach Library Service (OLS), based at Central Library, West Bromwich. Home Library Service staff prepare the items for service users and deliver directly to them. title: Expressions of Interest for Long Term Plan for Smethwick
description: Expression of Interest - Long Term Plan for SmethwickWith a Regeneration Pipeline currently consisting 67 projects with an estimated £2.9 billion total investment, the borough has recently been successful in securing £67.5m from Towns Fund, £20m Levelling Up Fund for a new Leisure Centre in Cradley Heath and a further 20m awarded for Tipton in the Spring Statement.  The Levelling Up Partnership is investing £20m in regenerating Wednesbury to complement the £3.4m received from Historic England as part of the High Streets Heritage Action Zone.  A further £20m will be invested as part of the Levelling Up Fund Round 3 in Smethwick.  In addition to the above, in early October 2023, Government announced the ‘Long-Term Plan for Towns’ which sees £1.1 billion investment into 55 towns.  This funding is to be spent on local people’s priorities including the regeneration of local high streets and town centres or securing public safety.  Smethwick has been chosen as Sandwell’s town to receive a £20m endowment-style fund to invest over a ten-year period commencing 2024/25 up to 2034/35.The Council will be using the In-tend e-Tendering System for this Procurement exercise, please visit https://in-tendhost.co.uk/sandwellmbc to access the Sandwell MBC In-tend Supplier Portal.From here you will be able to register your company, express an interest in the opportunity, and gain immediate access to Quotation or other related documents.To submit a quotation you will be required to "Opt In".For a Step by Step user guide to the Sandwell MBC In-tend Supplier Portal please click on the `Guidance for Suppliers` section of the website. title: ScM Flight Gallery – Lighting Upgrades
description: The Flight gallery on Level 3 of the Science Museum was originally installed in 1963 and underwent its last major update in 1993. A project is underway for review and minor update to the gallery in 2023. Maintenance upgrades are planned, including lighting upgrades (as per this tender), interpretation updates and accessibility improvements.In terms of content, the main changes will be made to the graphics, interpretation panels and object labels. The layout of the gallery will remain the same, with objects both within cases and on open display remaining in situ. The current lighting has been in place since the last gallery update in 1993 and has only been maintained. As light fixtures and fittings have become obsolete or stopped working these have been allowed to go out of service and so light levels in the gallery have become increasingly low and inconsistent. There are also large windows across the north wall of the gallery, with higher level frosted windows to the north and south so the natural light levels vary significantly throughout the day and with the seasons.

It will be the destination for our audiences to discover and learn about the most exciting and impactful science stories transforming lives today, finding solutions to our biggest challenges, and extending what we know about ourselves, our planet and our universe. The Authority wishes to establish an Agreement for the provision of Project Management and Contract Administration, including Masterplan programme wide collaboration as required, to ensure the successful planning and delivery of Horizons.

title: Zaha Hadid exhibition Front End Research
description: The Audience Research & Advocacy team is looking to appoint an audience research consultant to conduct front end research for the Zaha Hadid exhibition [working title]. This will be a major retrospective exhibition and the most comprehensive exploration of Zaha Hadid’s life and work to date. Developed in a partnership between SMG and the Zaha Hadid Foundation (ZHF), the approach will unite science and technology with the arts and humanities through the mediums of architecture, painting and design. Opening first in London, the city where Zaha Hadid made her home and her practice, the exhibition will then tour internationally.

title: Fit out and fabrication for Locomotion New Hall Interpretation
description: As part of the delivery of the Vision 2025 transformation of the National Railway Museum and Locomotion   Shildon, New Hall is the new collection building currently under construction at Locomotion Museum in Shildon, referred to as “Locomotion New Hall”. The hall will house 47 of the 1000 vehicles in the National Collection, the rest of which are in Locomotion Main Hall and across the other museums in the Science Museum Group (SMG). The delivery of Locomotion New Hall looks to support the care and management of SMG’s rail vehicle collection, with the interpretation design playing a key role in communicating between vehicle and visitor. The design has been developed by AOC through collaboration with Graphic Thought Facility and SMG to support the visitor experience through a series of vehicle interpretation panels around six road themes. This invitation to tender is for the fabrication of the permanent exhibition structures and fit out of interpretation layout within the scope of the of work laid out in RIBA Stage 3 report.

title: Zimingzhong graphic production and installation services
description: The Science Museum plans to open its exhibition called Zimingzhong Clockwork Treasures from China’s Forbidden City on 1 February 2024. This is a temporary exhibition that will run until June 2024. We are seeking a supplier for the production, installation, and deinstallation of all exhibition graphics for Zimingzhong. For this special exhibition the Science Museum will borrow 23 remarkable clocks from The Palace Museum in Beijing. Produced in Britain and China in the 1700s these remarkable horological treasures contain clocks, automata and music boxes. Called Zimingzhong – bells that ring themselves – they tell a fascinating story about a meeting of technologies, people, cultures and skills. The Zimingzhong are supported by a small selection of SMG objects, local loans, mechanical interactives and films.

title: SMG Four Waves of Market Awareness Survey
description: The Science Museum Group (“SMG”, the “Authority”) is the world’s pre-eminent Museum devoted to the history of science, technology, industry and Medicine. The SMG incorporates the Science Museum (South Kensington, London), the National Railway Museum (York), Locomotion: The National Railway Museum (Shildon), the National Science & Media Museum (Bradford), Museum of Science and Industry (Manchester) and collections stores at Blythe House (Olympia) and National Collections Centre (Wiltshire).The Authority wishes to appoint an agency to conduct online survey of culture market with 2,500 households in North West/Yorkshire and the Humber ("North") or London/South East ("South"). Tracking with results from 2022 and 2023 (awareness, visitation, perception) plus additional questions on a 'hot topic'. Looking to procure four waves of the survey ("North" in February 2024, "South" in February 2026, "North" in 2028 and "South" in 2030).

title: Engineers Gallery Summative Evaluation
description: ‘Engineers’ is a new gallery at the Science Museum which opened in 2023 and has an initial lifespan of five years. A partnership with the Queen Elizabeth Prize for Engineering (QEPrize), the gallery will take innovations awarded the QEPrize as a jumping off point to explore how engineers can change the world. The museum wishes to appoint a consultant to undertake a summative evaluation of the Engineers gallery to understand how successful it was in meeting its aims and learning outcomes, as well as to explore visitors’ response to the gallery environment, content, interpretation, and people representation. Lessons learned from the evaluation will be applied to future exhibitions and galleries developed by the Science Museum Group.
second_text: Museum services and preservation services of historical sites and buildings

title: NRM WONDERLAB SUMMATIVE EVALUATION
description: The National Railway Museum’s new interactive gallery, Wonderlab: The Bramall Gallery, invites audiences to play through 18 hands-on challenges, test their engineering skills, and immerse themselves in an explosive live show. Dynamic, dramatic and multi-sensory, it showcases the principles of engineering and science that relate to the railways. The gallery helps visitors to think like engineers. It showcases the ingenuity of engineers and allows visitors to engage in designing, building and testing. The gallery also promotes the fundamental skills engineers use such as problem solving and creativity.The Science Museum Group (SMG) wishes to appoint a consultant to undertake a summative evaluation of the gallery to understand how successful it was in meeting its aims and learning outcomes, as well as to explore visitors’ response to the gallery environment, content and interpretation. Lessons learned from the evaluation will be applied to future exhibitions and galleries developed by SMG, particularly other interactive galleries.
third_text: Museum services and preservation services of historical sites and buildings

title: SIM Power Hall Exhibition Illustration and Animation Production
description: The new Power Hall will be a must-see Manchester experience - a living gallery which showcases a unique collection of historic working engines, powered by 21st century, carbon-neutral infrastructure. The gallery’s new narrative tells the story of Manchester as an epicentre of industry and explores the story of our complex relationship with engines. The Science Museum Group (SMG) are seeking to appoint an animator-illustrator to deliver a series of engaging, dynamic and peopled digital animations and graphic illustrations that will play a key role in the gallery experience. We require: - 6 short digital animations (3 x touchscreen/interactive and 3 x video only). - 37 graphic illustrations / icons. The digital animations will help enliven the gallery and enable us to visually explain the key science, technology, engineering and maths (STEM) principles that underpin how our engines work. Five of the digital animations will be stand-alone experiences and one will be part of a physical interactive. The graphic illustrations will support visitors to use the interactives, engage with the objects on gallery and make links to everyday, relatable objects or scenarios.

title: SIM Main Contractor Services for Power Hall Exhibition
description: The Power Hall is a Manchester institution – a 2,500m² Grade II listed goods shed, housing one of the most significant industrial heritage collections in the world, including Europe’s largest collection of 19th and early 20th century steam engines. The new gallery will be an iconic living gallery showcasing the historic working engines that made Manchester the economic powerhouse of the world.  SIM, Manchester, seeks to appoint a Main Contractor to provide services including fabrication and installation of a permanent exhibition in the museum’s Power Hall, The Law Family Gallery. The exhibition will comprise a number of different component elements, including exhibition setworks, display cases, interactives, lighting and graphics. The exhibition will fit seamlessly into the building’s base build design which is due to commence construction in November 2023. Installation of the exhibition will take place following the completion of the base build.

title: SMG Sites Health and Safety Management System Audits
description: Science Museum Group (SMG) require the completion of annual health and safety audits of each site in order to ensure the management systems for safety are adequate against ISO 45001 and current legislation. To note - SMG does not require certification to ISO 45001. However, SMG works to this standard, and the audits should review compliance against this. Where it is found that these systems do not meet with ISO 45001, legislation or other relevant guidance, SMG requires the auditor to identify non-conformities or opportunities for improvement for implementation by SMG. In line with ISO 45001:2018, identification of legal and other requirements remains the responsibility of the client. However, every effort will be made to cover a wide range of sampling during the audit. This should include the provision of an audit report which is to be provided no more than 7 days after the final audit day.

title: NSMM - City Of Wonder - Digital Commission
description: The National Science and Media Museum (NSMM) and Bradford 2025 UK City of Culture are delighted to announce a major new commission opportunity - City of Wonder. This project will explore the sound and vision technologies that have changed how we experience our physical and virtual worlds. We envision this as an internationally significant interactive digital experience, forming a key part of Bradford City of Culture 2025. The museum, which is part of the Science Museum Group (SMG), is seeking proposals from prominent experience designers, artists or creative studios to lead on the creation of a newly commissioned storytelling experience in Gallery One of the museum.

title: SIM Power Hall Interactives Development
description: The new Power Hall will be a must-see Manchester experience - a living gallery which showcases a unique collection of historic working engines, powered by 21st century, carbon-neutral infrastructure. It tells the story of Manchester, an epicentre for the engine-driven ideas and industry that shaped the world as we experience it today.  The gallery’s new narrative explores the story of our complex relationship with engines. Interactives are key to helping our visitors understand the human-engine relationship, focusing on the skills and senses used to run engines and their impact on people’s lives.We are seeking an interactive exhibit maker to create three interactives for the gallery:- Care for the engine – visitors use their senses and skills to tend to an engine.- Get in gear – visitors change the speed of a film by tinkering with a chain of gears.- Stay on track – visitors create and test different shaped wheels.These interactives will be sensory, fun, and inspired by tinkering. They will be suitable for ages five and up and will help deliver an imaginative, playful, and active setting for adults, families, and school groups.

description: The extra care housing schemes in Solihull offer specialist housing designed for older people aged 55 and over that are able to live independently with some care and support. The care service will be available 24 hours a day, each day of the year to meet the assessed care and support needs to meet the outcomes detailed in the care and support plans.  During the day the care provider will be required to determine staffing levels according to the current assessed needs and risks for people in the scheme, responding to care calls and be able to respond to emergencies. title: SOL - Long Term Care at Home and Sitting Services
description: Solihull MBC is seeking to create a framework of providers in respect to Care at Home and Sitting Services in in the borough Solihull.This contract opportunity is split into TWO lots. Bidders may apply for either or both lots.Lot 1 - Long Term Care at HomeLot 2 - Sitting ServicesLong Term Care at Home (Lot 1) and Sitting Services (Lot 2) aim to allow people who use the service to live as independently as possible in their own homes and to sign-post people to other services where needed. The service provided should help to delay and reduce the need for additional long term care through a focus on promoting wellbeing and independence. It should safeguard adults, protecting them from avoidable harm. Care and support should be delivered in line with the person’s wishes, as best as it can be. The care and support delivered should meet the person’s cultural needs and maintain their dignity and respect.  Sitting Services (Lot 2) are required when a carer needs a break, but replacement care is required to look after their loved one in their own home.  The expected outputs of the Service are that the chosen Providers will:Respond to all appropriate referrals in their prescribed zoneSupport individuals in line with their care and support plan and how they wish to be supported  Support individuals to maintain and maximise independence as far as possible  Deliver safe, quality and compliant care and support to individualsDeliver care and companionship to a person in their own home whilst their carer is having a break or attending appointments (Lot 2 only).  The tender will be let under "Light Touch" arrangements under the EU Procurement Directives and implemented in English Law in the Public Contracts Regulations 2015 (PCR 2015).To apply, please log on to Solihull MBC's e-tendering portal, https://in-tendhost.co.uk/csw-jets/aspx/Home  and search for reference SOL - 17320

title: SOL - Fairer Futures Fund Early Implementers Scheme - Grant Application
description: The Fairer Futures Fund (FFF) is a mechanism to support the Birmingham & Solihull (BSol) Integrated Care System to move to new ways of working that bring teams together to think, plan and deliver in a different way.  The Integrated Care Board has delegated responsibility for allocation and management of the Solihull fund to the Solihull Place Committee to administer in line with the needs of local citizens.The fund is designed to seed-corn and support activities that will contribute to improved integrated working which in turn will improve outcomes and help to tackle inequality. Initially, the majority of these may be on a very localised or team-based level, with a view to some initiatives creating new ways of working that can be scaled up and adopted across Birmingham and Solihull.The Fund will be allocated and managed fairly with particular reference to:•	Impartiality and transparency in decision-making by the Place Committee;•	Objectivity in evaluating projects;•	Projects to be informed by expertise of practitioners, as well as communities;•	Co-production and equal partnership with the voluntary sector and communities.The purpose of the fund is to: •	Bring teams and organisations together to think, plan and deliver in a different way;•	Support the core purpose of the ICS – improve outcomes, reduce inequalities, enhance value for money and support broader social and economic development;•	Support the Leadership Transformation Priorities – Integrated Neighbourhood Teams, technology, workforce, estates, inequalities, and using excellence to standardise care; •	Deliver against the Solihull Outcomes Framework (see below).The Fund is not intended to be used to standardise existing delivery models or plug funding gaps in existing services. We are looking for new, innovative schemes.

title: SOL - Domestic Energy Advice
description: Buildings in Solihull are the largest source of emissions, accounting for 56% of the total emissions in the borough. Nearly half of these emissions come from domestic dwellings. Like the rest of the UK, Solihull faces a significant challenge to transform our housing and make it more energy efficient. In 2020, the Council produced a Net Zero Action Plan which set out the actions that will need to be considered to enable the borough to meet net zero carbon emissions by 2041. The action plan looks at a number of areas relating to domestic energy efficiency. The Council has recently produced a 10-year Housing Strategy (2023-2032). The strategy covers areas relating to tackling climate change and also identifies plans to address fuel poverty. The council is committed to working towards a reduction in fuel poverty throughout the borough and providing a range of support for residents and in particular vulnerable households and those on low income. Energy bills have increased significantly over recent years. This increase is having an impact on households in Solihull and is likely to push even more people into fuel poverty. Vulnerable households need advice and assistance so that they can make energy efficiency improvements and save money on their fuel bills.The Council is looking for a specialist partner to help households in the borough, especially those who are in fuel poverty to access expert energy advice, support and funding so that they can lower their fuel bills and save energy.Core energy advice services need to be available for all households in Solihull, including those who are homeowners or who are renting their home, either from a private or social landlord.The service needs to have an element of flexibility to enable the Council to respond to a changing domestic energy landscape. The Council is aware of a number of schemes in the pipeline and is also expecting new schemes and priorities to be announced over the next few years.

title: SOL - Sanctuary Scheme: Target Hardening Security Measures
description: The frequency and severity of domestic abuse and/or the vulnerability of the victim and their children leads to many victims of domestic abuse having little option but to move out of their accommodation and possibly out of the area. Many of whom continue to live in fear of their perpetrator tracking them down to their new accommodation, which may lead to further episodes of homelessness. Those who make the decision to be re-housed often have to leave their possessions behind and risk losing contact with or weakening their support network. Nationally domestic abuse is a leading reason for women’s homelessness and is consistently within the top three reasons for homelessness in Solihull.  During the period 01.10.22 - 30.09.23, domestic abuse accounted for 22% of all main duty homelessness acceptances in Solihull. This equates to 43 individuals/families. In addition, 12% of the total number of households approaching the homelessness service in 2022-23 gave domestic abuse as the main reason for approach. This equated to over 100 individuals / families.Refuge and other temporary accommodation can provide a safe space for households that are at risk, however many victims do not want to leave their homes or would like to return to their home after a stay in temporary accommodation. Interventions that improve the physical security of the family home are evidenced as good practice (CLG 2010)  and can give some victims a realistic opportunity to remain in their home. Commonly these are called ‘Sanctuary’.  The Homeless Reduction Act (2017) introduced new duties on local authority homelessness services to prevent homelessness and provide support to those at risk of homelessness and the Domestic Abuse Act 2021 places a statutory duty on Local Authorities to provide domestic abuse safe accommodation. Both pieces of legislation require local authorities to develop interventions which will enable households at risk due to domestic abuse, to have access to safe accommodation. Sanctuary schemes are recognised as having a role to play in delivering the requirements of both duties, as they give victims/survivors a choice to remain in their property. Solihull Sanctuary is one part of a multi-agency response to households at risk of domestic violence and is delivered alongside wider support to the household. It is one element of the Solihull’s ‘Housing Pathway: Victims of Domestic Abuse’. Prevention and protection from domestic abuse are key themes in the Solihull Domestic Abuse Strategy.Target hardening is used to describe the improvement of the security of a property to reduce the risk of crime from a sanctuary perspective, the aim is to make the survivor/s of domestic abuse feel safer as well as to reduce the risk of the perpetrator accessing the home. There are currently two levels of support available depending on the level of risk posed by the perpetrator and taking into account the individual circumstances of the household.The physical improvements to the security of the building are always carried out in conjunction with an offer of support through an Independent Domestic Abuse Housing Advocate. This can then become DA Safe Accommodation in line with new DA legislation.The incumbent provider has been delivering a Target Hardening Service as part of the Solihull Sanctuary since April 2021. Previously the target hardening service was delivered by Solihull Community Housing. Solihull Metropolitan Borough Council (SMBC) is now looking to commission delivery of the Target Hardening Service to an independent specialist for an initial 2-year period from 01.05.24.

title: SOL -  VCSE Infrastructure Support
description: Solihull Council values the positive contribution that the voluntary, community, social enterprise and faith (VCSEF) sector organisations make within the borough. The services and activities delivered by this sector is essential for our communities to thrive. The Council is committed to investing to support this sector to develop and build capacity. The current contract to deliver VCFSE Infrastructure Support is due to expire on 31st March 2024. The specification was designed in 2018 and a lot has changed in Solihull since then. This includes the operating environment following the impact of the pandemic, increases in the cost of living and the war in Ukraine. There have also been internal changes to priorities which are now increasingly focussed on prevention, early help, and the contribution of the VCFSE sectors and communities in community services. The Councils relationship with and understanding of the VCFSE sector has also significantly changed, which is most noticeable in the growth of the Solihull Metropolitan Borough Council (SMBC) Communities division.The expiry of the current VCFSE support contract has provided an opportunity to redesign the model of VCFSE support and engagement to better reflect the new operating environment, the changes, strengths and characteristics of the borough.As such, a programme of engagement and consultation took place from April to September 2023 to understand the needs and views of the sector, partners, and stakeholders. This included an online survey, VCFSE engagement event, focus groups with internal and external stakeholders.In addition, an analysis has been undertaken of current support services available locally, regionally, and nationally as well as models and procedures employed by other local authorities.The review and redesign of the infrastructure model for Solihull has led to a model which has four distinct areas (Appendix 1), which are as follows:1.	North Localities Community Anchor Organisation (CAO)2.	The SMBC Communities Team (including Community Development)3.	VCFSE infrastructure support4.	Specialist supportThis market engagement exercise is to consider only one element of that model, which is VCFSE Infrastructure Support.This is not a procurement/tender exercise and the final decision to procure this service is subject to information gathered and funding being approved and confirmed.

title: SOL - Holiday Activity Fund FCA (2024)
description: Solihull Metropolitan Borough Council is to establish a Flexible Contracting Agreement (FCA) covering Holiday Activity Fund Services which will be open for use by SMBC (linked to SOL - 14927). As a result of this programme, we want children who attend this provision to:• eat healthily over the school holidays• be active during the school holidays• take part in engaging and enriching activities which support the development of resilience, character and wellbeing along with their wider educational attainment• be safe and not to be socially isolated• have a greater knowledge of health and nutrition• be more engaged with school and other local servicesHoliday provision is for school aged children from Reception to Year 11 (inclusive) who receive benefits-related free school meals. Benefits-related free school meals (referred to as FSM) are available to pupils if their parents are in receipt of one of the qualifying benefits and have a claim verified by their Local Authority. As of November 2023, there were 9665 children who attend a Solihull school, registered as FSM from Reception to Year 11.Providers are asked to ensure that the offer of free holiday club provision is available for all children in receipt of FSM in their area, though this does not mean we expect all to attend as the provision is voluntary.All children in reception, year 1 and year 2 in England’s state-funded schools receive a free meal under the Department for Education’s universal infant free school mean (UIFSM) policy. Infant pupils who receive a free meal under UIFSM must also be eligible for benefits-related FSM to be able to access a place on the HAF programme.This FCA broadly covers:1. ActivitiesEnrichment activitiesHoliday clubs must provide fun and enriching activities that provide children with opportunities to:• develop new skills or knowledge• consolidate existing skills and knowledge• try out new experiences• have fun and socialiseThis could include but is not limited to:• physical activities, for example, football, swimming, table tennis or cricket• creative activities, for example, putting on a play, junk modelling or drumming workshops• experiences, for example, a nature walk or visiting a city farm• free play, for example, fun and freedom to relax and enjoy themselvesPhysical activitiesHoliday clubs must provide activities that meet the physical activity guidelines on a daily basis. In line with those guidelines, we expect:• All children and young people participating in the HAF programme should engage in moderate-to-vigorous physical activity for an average of at least 60 minutes per day. It should be noted that this does not have to be in the form of a structured activity session, but can include active travel, free play and sports.• Children and young people participating in the HAF programme should engage in a variety of types and intensities of physical activity to develop movement skills, muscular fitness, and bone strength.• Children and young people should aim to minimise the amount of time spent being sedentary, and when physically possible should break up long periods of not moving with at least light physical activity.2. Food ProvisionThe requirement is that at least one meal a day (breakfast, lunch or tea) is given per four-hour session (For providers who are unable to supply food then please see section 3.7). All food provided at the holiday club (including snacks) must meet school food standards. Our expectation is that the majority of food served by providers should be hot, however, we acknowledge that there will be exceptional circumstances when this is not possible and cold food should be used where it is appropriate.3. Nutritional EducationProviders must include an element of nutritional education each day aimed at improving the knowledge and awareness of healthy eating for children. These do not need to be formal learning activities and could for example include activities such as:• getting children involved in food preparation and cooking• growing fruit and vegetables• taste tests• discussing food and nutrition• including food and nutrition in other activitiesWe would expect to see providers using their own resources and a variety of already existing materials such as:• NHS Food Scanner resources• Eat Well Move More Guide• Healthy recipe handoutsEntrance will be by a qualitative questionnaire.  You will need to opt In to view the questionnaireReturned Questionnaires will be assessed and upon meeting the required criteria suppliers will be admitted to the DPS.The FCA will be established for an Initial Term of 3 Years with a 3-year (3 x 12 months) extension option up to a maximum 8-year contract term. The FCA will be re-opened for new applicants to apply to join up to as required by the CouncilEntry to the FCA does not guarantee any work with the Council. Resultant individual call off contracts will be between the Council and the successful supplier

description: SMBC are renovating three properties in Solihull to become Children’s Homes, all will be registered to care for up to three Children with Emotional and Behavioural Difficulties:•	Property A – A three bed home, for moderate needs, long term placement. •	Property B - A three bed home, for moderate to high level needs, medium to long term placement •	Property C - A two bed properties, for moderate to high level needs, medium to long term placement. Property C has an additional with a self-contained 16+ provision. The approach to care delivery will be child focused and therapeutically informed. The homes will work to best practice standards with an emphasis on developing nurturing, positive relationships with children and young people which enable positive outcomes. While the homes will not follow one specific model the trained approach will be rooted in a social pedagogy approach.Each of the three homes should be individually visited once per month by a person independent of the council. The visits should be mostly unannounced to allow for some pre-arranged visited when required. The visitor should in attendance within the home for three hours. Any conflict of interest should be immediately brought to the attention of the contract manager.  A quality comprehensive report covering the specifics cited in Regulation 44 of the Children’s Homes Regulations 2016 is to be produced within three working days of the visit. The completed report is to be sent to the Registered Manager (RM) and Responsible Individual (RI) for comment before submittal to HMCI (Ofsted).
