title: SOL - Oracle CX Consultancy
description: SMBC have been using Oracle Service Cloud as the corporate customer relationship management system since 2017. Oracle Service Cloud includes a suite of online pages called ‘Customer Portal’ which enables customers to interact with us by way of integrated forms, a customer account, live chat channel, interactive knowledge base (FAQ) and Ask a Question functionality. The original implementation of Customer Portal was carried out by in-house skilled development resource as part of the upgrade to the Cloud based system. Focus required for this project, and dependencies to deliver the upgrade on time, meant that the portal was designed specifically to meet the colour scheme and theme of the existing website but no further development. There has been little investment by SMBC to review and improve our Customer Portal and as such this has caused some negative feedback from customers and difficulties in opening digital channels for self-service.
third_text: Programming services of packaged software products

title: SOL - North Localities Community Anchor Organisation (CAO) 2024
description: Solihull Council values the positive contribution that the voluntary, community, social enterprise and faith (VCSEF) sector organisations make within the borough. The services and activities delivered by this sector is essential for our communities to thrive. The Council is committed to investing to support this sector to develop and build capacity. The current contract to deliver VCFSE Infrastructure Support is due to expire on 31st March 2024. The specification was designed in 2018 and a lot has changed in Solihull since then. This includes the operating environment following the impact of the pandemic, increases in the cost of living and the war in Ukraine. There have also been internal changes to priorities which are now increasingly focussed on prevention, early help, and the contribution of the VCFSE sectors and communities in community services. The Councils relationship with and understanding of the VCFSE sector has also significantly changed, which is most noticeable in the growth of the Solihull Metropolitan Borough Council (SMBC) Communities division.The expiry of the current VCFSE support contract has provided an opportunity to redesign the model of VCFSE support and engagement to better reflect the new operating environment, the changes, strengths and characteristics of the borough.As such, a programme of engagement and consultation took place from April to September 2023 to understand the needs and views of the sector, partners, and stakeholders. This included an online survey, VCFSE engagement event, focus groups with internal and external stakeholders.In addition, an analysis has been undertaken of current support services available locally, regionally, and nationally as well as models and procedures employed by other local authorities.The review and redesign of the infrastructure model for Solihull has led to a model which has four distinct areas (Appendix 1), which are as follows:1.	North Localities Community Anchor Organisation (CAO)2.	The SMBC Communities Team (including Community Development)3.	VCFSE infrastructure support4.	Specialist supportThis market engagement exercise is to consider only one element of that model, which is North Localities Community Anchor Organisation (CAO).This is not a procurement/tender exercise and the final decision to procure this service is subject to information gathered and funding being approved and confirmed.

title: SOL - Homelessness Case File Audits
description: The Council needs to ensure that it is carrying out a quality homelessness service in line with legislation and good practice guidelines. As part of this quality and compliance review we need to ensure that the decisions we are making are the right ones, and that individuals and families who approach as homeless / at risk of homeless receive an excellent service, and one that takes into account their personal needs and circumstances. SMBC previously commissioned the National Practitioner Support Service (NPSS) to carry out external case file audits. On a quarterly basis, NPSS carried out a desk top review of all cases on Housing Jigsaw and looked in-depth at two cases per officer. The 360-degree reviews looked at the cases from the customer but also in relation to legislation, statutory duty, and from a case management perspective. Cases were a mixture of prevention, relief and main duty. After the audits a training session was arranged with Managers at SCH / St. Basils, and SMBC commissioners, to review findings and focus on recommendations.NPSS ceased trading in November 2020 and there is a need to commission an alternative organisation to carry out the case file audits. In January 2022 the SMBC audit team carried out an audit on a smaller sample of case files but are not able to provide this service on an on-going basis.  Solihull Community Housing and St. Basils already have an internal audit system which reviews cases in line with legislation. Every three months Team Leaders look at a percentage of case for the officers they support and capture feedback through a standardised case management checklist. The checklist is designed to cover all key areas in the assessment and case management process. Management staff have previously found external case file audits useful not just in identifying areas for improvement, but in identifying areas that were done well so that this good practice could be shared with the team. The external perspective ensures independence.

title: Feasibility Study – Sustainable Drainage Solution, South Downs Way,  Kings Ride, Alfriston
description: The South Downs Way National Trail is a 100 mile long-distance path that spans the entire length of the South Downs National Park. It is a mainly off-road route that is comprised of public rights of way and is well used by walkers, cyclists, and equestrians all-year round.  We have identified a section of path that has deteriorated from heavy use and surface water erosion. This section requires repair and drainage improvements to maintain the high standard of access along the National Trail. This section of Trail has public bridleway status yet also serves private vehicular access for several residents and for agricultural operations.  A feasibility study for a sustainable draininge solution that will integrate with our proposed surface repairs is required, in order to undertake consultation with stakeholders prior to implementation.

title: Roofline Climb Protection Replacement
description: The primary objective of this procurement is to procure a suitably qualified provider and  installer of roofline climb protection systems to Newton Lodge, Fieldhead Hospital in Wakefield.  This is a three year programme of works to remove, dispose and replace the current Belfast Coving throughout the unit. The replacement requires:Removal & disposal of current ‘belfast coving’ style anti-climb eaves protection along with the existing soffits, fascias down pipes and down pipe covers.  Anti-climb roll should integrate with the soffits and gutters to minimise opportunities for tampering.Replacement of soffits and facias with a tongue and groove style aluminium finish (RAL tbc) Replacement of aluminium box guttering, down with swan necks and anti-climb down pipe covers and any supports/stopends/corners as required for each courtyard layoutReplacement bullnose eaves protection. Bullnose solutions only are acceptable, no anti-climb rollers, spikes or toppers are acceptable for this project.Products should be robust for use in a medium secure mental health setting, installation requires no sharp edges on the finished product and to allow no ‘holes’ gaps which could permit the nefarious storage of items by service users or anything that could be a climb aid to the roof or cause injury/harm.Providers should have significant experience of working in a secure hospital setting and must be prepared to work within the time, access and tool management restrictions required within the secure unit and allow for all site personnel to undertake a security briefing and induction prior to the commencement of work.Works can only be undertaken in one courtyard at a time in order to ensure service users have access to outdoor areas at all times.The plan attached identifies all areas across the 3 years of the project.  Costing should be provided for Year 1 only to minimise bid preparation work but bidders should be prepared to stand by the per metre rates provided in the Commercial Schedule for the full 3 years.

title: SBC0923 Replacement of Obsolete Intercom and Door Entry Systems
description: Stevenage Borough Council (SBC) requires a competent contractor to  replace the current obsolete Intercom and Door Entry Systems and the main security doors including the lobby area enclosure for both Brent and Harrow Court tower blocks.SBC has currently invested in over 100 installations of the Neon / KMS systems across its portfolio and as such will require all Bidders to use Neon and Came/KMS equipment for this tender.  This ensures the Council retains consistent technical, operational and maintenance effectiveness and that this installation fully functions and integrates with the current web-based access control system. These works will require the replacement of existing wiring and containment used to carry cable to each of the flats on each floor.  It is essential that these works cause as little disruption to the residents as possible.The Contractor must hold all relevant and up to date certification required to carry out the works.  All certificates will be validated as part of the tender process. It will also be required prior to commencement of the works that resident engagement has taken place to ensure they are fully informed of the works to be carried out and the requirement to gain access to properties as part of the planned installation.IMPORTANT - Mandatory site visits are required as part of the procurement process – please see ITT and Appendix 11 for details of dates and booking process.Please note the deadline for returns and allow sufficient time to make your return as late returns will not be permitted. title: SBC 1023 Provision of cycle hire scheme
description: Stevenage Borough Council is currently out to procurement for the Provision of a Cycle hire schemeThe Contract requires  a provider with a long and successful track record in working with Local Authorities or other organisations in the UK public delivering cycle hire schemes. Stevenage expects the scheme will initially require a minimum of 220 cycles (including minimum of 50% e-bikes) for the commencement of the scheme with at least 45 docking stations. Stevenage's preference is that the bikes be predominantly physically ‘docked’, whether through stands, traditional physical docking infrastructure or integration with existing street furniture.The scheme will run for an initial trial period of 4 years in Stevenage with a potential to extend for a further 2 years as 2 x 1-year extensions. Depending on the success of the scheme and availability of funding, it may be extended and/or expanded into other areas of the Borough and adjoining areas.This procurement is an open process.  Organisations wishing to take part in this project are invited to ‘express an interest’ and also ‘opt in’ which will give access to the full procurement documents in the e-tendering system.To be considered as a Tenderer you must complete and submit a Tender by the deadline of 12 noon on 19th November 2023Please allow sufficient time to make your return, as Tender submissions cannot be uploaded and submitted after this return deadline. Please ensure that where possible documents are uploaded as a PDF and that file names are succinct.  Any questions relating to this procurement must be made via correspondence on the website, in accordance with the procurement documents, and can be addressed to the main contact as shown in the details above.Tenderers should be aware that due to the nature of the Services provided, any Contract formed as a result of this procurement process shall be executed as a deed. Tenderers should seek independent legal advice on the implications of this prior to submitting their Tender, where appropriate.The use of Lots has been considered for this procurement, but have not been used, because we need a town wide solution.  Please note that the contract requirements will be subject to available financial resources, supplier performance and flexibility to meet changing demands.To access this opportunity please visit https://in-tendhost.co.uk/supplyhertfordshire/aspx/Home

title: Procurement of a Design & Build Contractor for the Construction of a Proposed New Prison
description: Procurement of a Design & Build Contractor for the Construction of a Proposed New PrisonThe island of St Helena is an internally self-governing Overseas Territory of the United Kingdom located in the South Atlantic approximately 4,000 miles from the UK.  The Government comprises a Governor (who is appointed by the Crown) an Executive Council, which has the general control and direction of Government, and a Legislative Council.  The Governor retains responsibility for internal security, external affairs, defence, the public service, finance and shipping. The island’s population is around 4,440 (2021 Census) and it has a typical small island economy with a high import dependency, a narrow economic base, a large public sector and significant outward labour migration.  St Helena receives UK Government financial assistance to support recurrent and capital expenditure as part of their obligation to ensure that the reasonable needs of the population are met. The island is currently served by a weekly flight from Johannesburg, and a 6-weekly supply ship from Walvis Bay, Namibia.The Government of St Helena has received planning permission and is committed to constructing a new prison development on a rural, greenfield site in the north-east of the island.  A concept design has been developed for the new prison to house approximately 60 inmates.  It is envisaged that the detailed design of the new prison will be based on the UK Ministry of Justice (MOJ) Category C requirements, incorporating appropriate relaxations/exemptions to suit the particular circumstances of St Helena. The Government of St Helena intends to procure the new prison under design & build arrangements (FIDIC Yellow Book).The proposed prison will be located within the Longwood Area (Bottom woods) and will require for the provision of a new access road, civil works to form the proposed site, associated service provisions (anticipated to include for a sewerage treatment plant which may be required to service properties in the Longwood locality), full build and subsequent fit out.Therefore the Government of St Helena would now like to invite firms, who have an appropriate track-record of designing and/or building prisons, to submit a design and build tender for the construction of a new prison in St Helena.Interested firms or consortiums should register on the St Helena Government eProcurement Portal by pasting the link https://in-tendhost.co.uk/sainthelena/aspx/Home into a browser. After registration, navigate to the appropriate opportunity and download a number of additional documents.All communication, clarifications, general questions and submissions of your response must be made via the eProcurement PortalHelp guides to assist registration can be found on the Supplier Information tabThis project is being delivered under the £30m UK funded Economic Development Investment Programme (EDIP).

title: Suffolk-Wide Skills and Employment Programme
description: Suffolk County Council are currently out to tender for the provision of Suffolk-Wide Skills and Employment Programme.   With the closure of European Social Fund projects and the increasing need for supporting local people into work, or progressing in their careers, using funding from the UK Shared Prosperity Fund, Suffolk County Council (SCC) have been commissioned by Suffolk District and Borough Councils (Babergh District Council, East Suffolk Council, Ipswich Borough Council, Mid Suffolk District Council and West Suffolk Council) to appoint a Single Service Delivery Provider or Group with a ‘Lead Operator’ to deliver employment and skills support to those who need support to get back into/or progress in work. Procurement Policy Note 09/21 requires us to calculate the value of contracts inclusive of VAT, however we can advertise them exclusive of VAT.  The advertised value here is £2,060,000  exclusive of VAT. Please note that funding has been agreed for the 12 month contract period, potential additional funding may be made available to extend the contract beyond the initial 12 month contract period. This open procurement with negotiation complies with the Light Touch Regime under the Public Contracts Regulations 2015.The deadline for clarification questions is Thursday 30th November which must be generated via the correspondence option on the website.   Please note late tender returns will NOT be permitted

title: Integrated Sexual Health Services
description: The service will provide high-quality, open access, equitable, all age and cost-effective integrated sexual health services that is part of a Suffolk health and social care system, addresses population need and contributes to a reduction in inequalities in health and life chances. The service will improve sexual and reproductive health by delivering a range of interventions across the life course, with a focus on prevention, thus reducing the demand on specialist services and increasing the emphasis on community based preventative services.   The service will provide easy access, cost-effective, high-quality provision for contraception and prevention, diagnosis and management of sexually transmitted infections, according to evidence-based protocols. This will be achieved through outreach, partnership working and clinics at targeted locations and convenient times to the service user ensuring that high risk groups are supported to achieve good sexual health. The service will ensure that it provides equitable access to services across the geography of Suffolk and that local people can access sexual health and contraceptive support effectively.  Innovation will be a key component of the new service, and the Provider will be expected to use creative, flexible, and innovative approaches throughout the lifecycle of the contract to meet the changing needs of the local population.  Key areas of focus will be using innovation to: a)	Increase access closer to where people live b)	Increase targeted outreach c)	Integrate multi-disciplinary approaches across the local system d)	Service reach across diverse populations e)	Meet the needs of underserved groups and those with multiple disadvantage f)	Embed prevention

title: Information, guidance and support services for Small and Medium sized Suffolk employers to address health and wellbeing
description: Development of a Good Work and Health Support Pathway for Suffolk Small and Medium Sized Enterprise (SME) employers to enable them to develop and/or maintain a healthy workforce through good work and healthy workplace principles. The overall aim of the Good Work and Health (GWAH) programme is to improve the health and wellbeing (H&WB) of the working age population in Suffolk, particularly Suffolk SME employees most at risk of health inequalities, e.g., those on a low income or with long term health conditions. This programme will enable engagement with, and support to Suffolk SME employers, through the provision of three distinct by connected services, culminating in the development of an evidence-based GWAH Pathway for Suffolk SME employers. The 3 Lots are: Lot 1 - Good Work & Health Resource Hub - The provider will develop and manage a curated online resource hub for SME employers that enables them to easily access and navigate existing information, advice & guidance and evidence-based tools, services & interventions on enabling and maintaining a healthy workplace, and healthy workforce underpinned by good work principlesLot 2 - Good Work & Health Ambassador Network - The provider will establish and coordinate a network of employers with expertise or interest in demonstrating good work and healthy workplace principlesLot 3 - Good Work & Health Navigator Service -  The provider will develop a GWAH support pathway for SME employers through exploratory engagement with small employers in targeted sectors (TBD) and geographical locations. This will enable development of a bespoke service that offers employers an opportunity to discuss workforce issues and access advice, guidance and support to find solutions using good work and healthy workforce principles. The provider will undertake process evaluation (with an allocated partner) to understand the process of the service implementation and how the outcomes are achieved. This will enable refinement of the pathway throughout the contract term The total contract value for all Lots (including the extension period) is £765,000 inclusive of VAT. Please note the submission deadline is 2nd February 2024 at 12noon.

description: Construction Works for small public realm projects in Tewkesbury Town CentreBackgroundThe High Street Heritage Action Zone (HSHAZ) is a four-year project which started in 2019. It is funded by Historic England and Tewkesbury Borough Council to deliver, among other things, grants to conserve historic buildings in the traditional town centre and a stream of public realm enhancements. (More information is available at Tewkesbury High Street Heritage Action Zone — Tewkesbury Borough Council). Because of the way the funding has been structured for the public realm works, money is only now coming on stream to pay for enhancements to the historic town centre, but works must be completed before the end of the scheme in March 2024.One Creative Limited has been commissioned to create designs for four discrete areas of the Tewkesbury’s historic town centre to enhance the public space in:•	Post Office Lane•	Warder’s Alley•	Smith’s Lane•	High Street at Bishop’s WalkThe first three projects listed above involve repaving, lighting and elements of planting and minor construction work. title: BFI Luminous 2024  Gala Production Management
description: We are seeking a creative collaboration with a production company that can design and execute a spectacular vision for LUMINOUS 2024. Our aim is for an elegant and beautiful evening that successfully highlights the importance of our charitable work and the incredible resources we have to share that are held by the BFI National Archive. Guests will feel honoured to attend this high profile and glamorous night which feels contemporary, inclusive, fresh and slick. We are looking for a reliable and inspired team that can design and produce all creative elements seamlessly whilst working closely with the Head of Events (F&E, BFI) and BFI Fundraising & Enterprise team colleagues on the charitable messaging.We would like the chosen company to: •	Help the BFI to create an elegant and beautiful evening that celebrates the best of British film and the work of the BFI.•	To be responsible for creating, designing and rolling out all design elements for the Gala from the creation of the overall aesthetic, visual identity, hero imagery to rolling out all collateral. Crucially, we are          looking for a team who can ensure the same high level, luxury aesthetic carries through from the invitation to the atmosphere of the venue on the night. •	This includes the red carpet arrivals, the auction exhibition, the reception and dining area ambience and entertainment.•	This will involve creating all on-screen video content as well as designing and installing screens to wow and capture the imagination of our guests. •	Advise on maximising the venue, including the best event layout and set up – producing detailed floor plans and visuals of the event spaces and guest flow throughout the planning period •	To adopt  innovative thinking and cover all logistical plans and preparation of the event in liaison with the Head of Events (BFI), and in-line with the agreed budget, including:o	Delivering all production for stage, stage management, lighting, live auction, party atmosphere for live performers, sound, rigging, decorative and logistical personnel.o	Support the delivery of sponsorship requirements.o	Manage the requirements of the live musical acts and act as showrunner for the night.o	Booking and briefing talent cars.o	Overseeing all production installation and de-installation according to rules and procedures determined by the venue and within allotted hours of venue hire (8am-8am - 24 hour hire).o	In collaboration with the BFI, feed into a detailed Event Schedule with timings for catering, press, talent arrivals, speeches, filmed-material, auction, live performances.o	Provide all stage management and production management personnel.o	Film, edit and create all on-screen content including graphics as well as specific VT: Additional information regarding the requirement is provided in the ITT.

buyer_name: THE HEALTH & SAFETY EXECUTIVE'S HEALTH & SAFETY LABORATORY
title: Gas Safe Register Services Concession Agreement
description: The Health and Safety Executive (HSE) is the independent regulator of health and safety and has responsibility for regulating consumer gas safety in GB and does this largely through the Health and Safety at Work Act 1974 and the Gas Safety (Installation and Use) Regulations 1998 (GSIUR). A key component of the consumer gas safety regime is the Gas Safe Register, the official gas registration body for the United Kingdom, Isle of Man, Jersey and Guernsey, appointed by the relevant Health and Safety Authority for each area. By law all gas engineers must be on the Gas Safe Register. Gas Safe Register deals with all aspects of the downstream gas industry covered by the following regulations:• Great Britain: The Gas Safety (Installation and Use) Regulations 1998• Northern Ireland: The Gas Safety (Installation & Use) Regulations (Northern Ireland) 2004The regulations cover both piped natural gas and liquefied petroleum gas (LPG). The gas registration scheme is owned by HSE and exists to protect the public from unsafe gas work.The current service concession agreement will end on the 31 March 2025 and HSE is seeking to put in place a new service concession agreement to operate the Gas Safe Register for a four (4) year and nine (9) month period beginning 1 April 2025. The provider will be required to undertake a number of tasks and, in doing so, protect and inform the public of the risks of unsafe and illegal gas work, and of other dangers such as carbon monoxide (CO).The operation of the scheme will be ring-fenced from any other of the successful bidder's commercial and operational activities to prevent any conflict of interest on the part of the successful bidder.There are currently around 80,014 gas businesses registered on the Gas Safe Register, with approximately 155,653 unique engineers, generating approximately £23m revenue per annum through registrations and notification fees for the concessionaire.Please see documentation for further information

buyer_name: THE HEALTH & SAFETY EXECUTIVE'S HEALTH & SAFETY LABORATORY
title: The Provision of  Technical Adviser to HSE
description: The Health & Safety Executive is seeking to appoint a Technical Advisory Service to operate as a ‘one-stop shop’ provider of multi disciplinary advice, to include specification development, project management and cost/Quantity Surveyor (QS) management. The majority of works will fall under the following disciplines, mainly at the Buxton Site:•	Principal Designer/Architect.•	Project Manager (Expected duties: planning, project controls, contract administration).•	Civil Engineer (including public health and road works).•	Structural Engineer.•	Mechanical & Electrical engineer (including ATEX Electrical & Mechanical Design).•	Building Services Engineer.•	Cost consultant/QS•	Contract Administration.•	Building & Land surveyor.•	Technical evaluation of HSE tenders.Other areas of technical advice across our built portfolio may include, but are not be limited to:•	General security advice/counter terrorism advice/design.•	Compliance risk assessments – Water/Asbestos/Fire/Radon.•	Environmental services advisor (including buildings, land, ecology, and flood RA).•	Energy and waste management advice.•	Space planning, office design services and office churn management.•	General Health & Safety Advice.•	Acoustic engineer.The service provider will be capable of undertaking all 7 Stages of the RIBA Plan of Work 2020 and HSE will typically expect the following activities:•	Gather and understand the customer brief.•	Develop into a specification. •	Produce pre-tender cost estimate. •	Produce tender evaluation plan.•	Evaluate tenders.•	Project manage the project to completion and handoverHSE would expect all site attendees to be qualified and competent in their specific discipline, for which the HSE requires bidders to provide evidence to demonstrate the level of qualifications and competency of the various disciplines that they will provide.Where projects are deemed to fall within the scope of the Construction, Design and Management Regulations (CDM), the Technical Advisor may be required to carry out the role of Principal Designer.The Technical Advisor may be required to attend HSE sites to typically:•	engage with customers to understand requirements.•	attend face to face progress meetings (Note: only when online meetings will not produce the desired outcome)•	view locations, topography and existing structures and constraints•	monitor key stages of contractor progress.

buyer_name: THE HEALTH & SAFETY EXECUTIVE'S HEALTH & SAFETY LABORATORY
title: The Provision of an  Adventure Activity Licensing Authority
description: The Health and Safety Executive (HSE) is the independent regulator of health and safety and is sponsored by the Department of Work and Pensions (DWP). HSE is designated as the Adventure Activities Licensing Authority (AALA) in GB. The Adventure Activities Licensing Authority (AALA) is administered by HSE’s Local Authority and Safety Unit (LASU).  LASU sits within HSE’s Operational Strategy Branch.  LASU's Entertainment Leisure, Commercial and Consumer Services Sector team provides the policy lead on health and safety within the adventure activity sector, regardless of whether HSE or the Local Authority is the enforcing authority.  The AALA was created following the Lyme Bay canoeing tragedy in March 1993. The MP for Plymouth Devonport, who represented the parents of those who died, introduced a Private Member's Bill, which became the Activity Centres (Young Persons’ Safety) Act 1995. Tourism Quality Services (TQS) was the original AALA, until responsibility was transferred to HSE in 2007 however HSE contracted TQS to continue to operate the service on its behalf. From then TQS were formally known as the Adventure Activities Licensing Service (AALS).  The Adventure Activities Licensing Regulations, created under the 1995 Act, apply to four groups of outdoor activities only: caving, climbing, trekking and water sports. These are defined in the Regulations.The Contractor, on behalf of the AALA, is under contract to inspect providers of licensable activities and make a judgement on their suitability to hold a license, in accordance with the legislation. The Contractor will adhere to the requirements of Regulation 6 (a) of the Regulations and only award licenses to applicants who meet the necessary criteria.The aim of adventure activities licensing is to provide assurances to the public that activity providers who hold a license have demonstrated that they have suitable safety management systems in place to manage risk. The aim being that young people can enjoy exciting and stimulating activities outdoors without being exposed to avoidable risks of death or disabling injury.HSE was designated as AALA from 1 April 2007, and retained the existing operators to manage the day-to-day operation of the service until 2020, when administration of the system was brought in-house. The current contract for inspection services is due to expire in March 2024.

PFPD employs around 100 people comprising of various roles including cost recovery, administrative, accountants, fraud, estates, assurance and risk at HSE’s headquarters in Redgrave Court, Bootle. The Cost Recovery and Expenses (CRE) Team are responsible for invoicing and debt recovery, and are seeking to appoint a DCA to form part of the debt recovery area of work.HSE requires a Contractor to improve debt collection through effective use of data and analytics and effective supplier, contract, and relationship management.

description: The Environmental Sustainability Team in the House of Commons arranges for a Dr Bike service to be offered to all bicycle users on the Parliamentary Estate, in association with the Parliamentary Bicycle User Group and the All-Party Parliamentary Cycling & Walking Group.  The SQ/ITT documents are accessible via UK Parliaments e-procurement portal: http://in-tendhost.co.uk/parliamentuk. Tender submissions must be uploaded to the e-procurement portal; electronic responses submitted via e-mail are not acceptable. To access these documents select the tender reference GSV2614 in the ‘current tenders’ list, click on the ‘view tender details’ and express interest by clicking on the button provided. You will need to register your company details, thereafter you will be issued with a username and password. If you have previously registered with In-Tend, please follow the link shown which will redirect you to the home page where you can log on using your existing username and password to collect the tender documents. If you have registered and forgotten your username and password, click on the ‘forgotten password’ link on the In-Tend homepage. Please keep this username and password secure and do not pass it to any third parties. If you are experiencing problems, please contact the PPCS Business Support team via email: pcd@parliament.uk for further assistance. You are advised to allow sufficient time when responding to this ITT, and for the full uploading of documents, prior to the closing date of 12.00 (noon - UK time) on 22/01/2024. Late tenders will not be accepted. If you are uploading multiple documents you will have to individually load one document at a time or you can opt to zip all the documents in an application such as WinZip or WinRAR.

The function is to supply printed items requested by customers for the performance of their Parliamentary duties and promotion of public events.  Printed and promotional items are outsourced to external printers on the framework where Print Services (the in-house digital production unit) cannot produce the requirements due to quantities required, time scales, specialist printing or finishing, such as embossing, foil blocking, die-stamping and thermography. The Print Procurement section operates Monday to Friday throughout the year. The volume of business tends to remain consistent throughout the year but peaks towards February and March.

title: STC1173 Principal Contractor: Events
description: DescriptionParliament maintains a variety of contingency options .  These options provide flexibility to respond to a range of scenarios. The plans identify venues where Parliament could be re-located to ensure that the business of Parliament can be carried out without interruption and with minimum disturbance.All current or future options may apply to this Contract, although the Client reserves the right to ask for the build/rehearsal elements of the plan as part of other contingency planning projects where appropriate (within the overall value of this contract).The ability to deliver these options must be maintained 24/7 x 365 with the ability to activate each with minimal notice, with successful delivery occurring within the specified timeframe of the relevant option and to the relevant standard and quality.ScopeThe contractor will be expected to carry out the build in any venue as required across the UK. title: Provision of Apprenticeship Training Services to the University of Birmingham (Dynamic Purchasing System)
description: The University of Birmingham is planning to recruit a number of apprentices over the next 5 years in support of the University strategy to develop local talent and support entry points into the University talent pipeline. In addition, the University will utilise apprenticeship training for existing staff where a role clearly meets the definition of an apprentice.The University of Birmingham will look to sustainably optimise use of its apprenticeship levy (In excess of £1million per annum) to support genuine apprenticeships and career development for University employees.The University of Birmingham is looking to engage training providers to deliver apprenticeship training in key areas. The successful suppliers will deliver apprenticeship training where training cannot be provided in house.The tender process will follow the restricted procedure under the Public Procurement Regulations 2015 (PCR 2015). It is following the light-touch regime permitted under Regulations 74 to 77 of the Public Contract Regulations 2015. The University intends to implement a Dynamic Purchasing System (DPS) to deliver these requirements.  This requires the release of procurement documents at the same time as publication of the OJEU notice which comprise the following:o	Dynamic Purchasing System Instructionso	Supplier’s Questionnaire (SQ) – must be completed and returnedo	UoB Terms and Conditions Establishing a DPS with multiple suppliers will help to create an environment which encourages fair competition, allowing suppliers to join at any time and choose whether to compete for all or any of the services under the DPS.The DPS will remain open to allow new suppliers, previously rejected suppliers, to apply for admittance to the DPS at any point throughout its five (5) years’ duration.The University reserves the right at its absolute and sole discretion not to proceed with a Contract Award and end the process at any stage if it wishes to do so.

title: Tender for the Supply and Implementation of Procure to Pay Solution Services, catering
description: The University of Birmingham wishes to establish a contract with a Single Provider for the provision, implementation and ongoing support and maintenance of a fully integrated Central Billing, Procure to Pay and Stock management solution and the procurement of UOB Food, Beverage, and disposable suppliers inc Light Equipment. The annual procurement spend is in the region of up to £4M.The successful provider would be able to provide a fully integrated service of both “systems and procurement” to support Campus Services, they would provide monthly summary billing and have appropriate systems in place to provide the University with excellent value for money and an excellent service level demanded by a large Russell Group University with over 34,000 students with the potential to expand on Edgbaston Campus to 50,000 over the next 10 years.The system must cater for the different functions operating in the university, namely purchasing, finance and Food, Beverage and Retail operations. The system should ideally provide modules which provide the functions listed below and further be able to maximise market price across a wide category of food and drink products able to deliver contract price compliance whilst providing an end to end contract management solution for the institution:1.1	E-invoices and supplier payments with detail analysis1.2	Financial systems integration with existing UOB systems1.2.1 Integration with Delivered catering solution1.3	Procure to Pay1.4	Recipe management inc Legal Allergen and Nutritional requirements1.5	Full stock management combined with production planning system facility both from and internal and external supplier basis 1.6	Supplier management 1.7	Full Epos integration and sales analysis, linking to one true source1.8 	Sustainability product carbon impact and food waste monitoring

title: Tender for the Supply of Services - Independent Central Review Of Primary Outcome Data For The GLO-BHNL Platform Clinical Trial - University Of Birmingham
description: Please refer to Appendix A for full specification of requirements.The University of Birmingham invites tenders for independent central review of the primary outcome data for the clinical platform trial, Glo-BNHL. The platform aims to test a wide range of therapies over its lifetime in order to find better treatments for the rare paediatric cancer, B-cell non-Hodgkin’s Lymphoma.  The design allows addition of new treatment arms as novel therapies become available for testing.  There are currently 2 treatment arms.Independent central review of the clinical data that informs the primary outcome measures is required, to include: cross sectional imaging by CT or MRI, PET-CT scan, bone marrow aspirate, bone marrow trephine and lumbar puncture pathology reports.  Glo-BNHL is an international trial with participating sites in the UK, Europe, USA, Canada, Australia, New Zealand and Israel.  A total of 45 sites will participate, with international sites’ activity coordinated by 15 National Coordinating Centres.Glo-BNHL recently received ethics approval in the UK and will open later this year.    Approval in the other participating nations will follow. An expedient solution to independent central review is therefore required.This project may be funded by the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF) or;-	European Structural and Investment Fund (ESIF) or;-	Research Councils UK (RCUK), the strategic partnership of the UK's seven Research Councils.

title: Conversion and Data Insights Services for the University of Birmingham
description: The University of Birmingham invites tenders to manage the engagement and communications with our international offer holders to drive conversion through to the point of enrolment and provide strategic insights into market and competitor trends. The successful tenderer will play a crucial role in supporting the University's ambitious international student recruitment efforts. In the preceding year of 2022, our existing service provider effectively engaged with circa 14,000 offer holders. However, considering our vision for growth, we anticipate a substantial increase in this figure over the next five years. Companies whose sole business is as an agent specialising in the referral of international student applications should not submit tenders for consideration.Tenderers will be required to * Provide evidence of experience within the field of international student engagement, conversion, and marketing within the higher education sector in the UK. * Provide evidence of overseas hubs to cater for various time zones around the world.* Provide a suitable implementation plan to swiftly set up operationally to start engaging prospective students due to join the University from September 2024.* Provide a single point of contact to handle queries regarding international recruitment/conversion and administrative matters for the university.* Enhance international conversion rates for various courses/countries at undergraduate and postgraduate level (scope of courses and countries yet to be determined).* Swiftly review and develop plans to complement the university's international UG and PG marketing and recruitment strategies.* Manage inbound enquiries promptly and effectively.* Provide market intelligence on a regular basis to enable the University to quickly respond to changing market conditions and drive competitor advantage.* Support diversification away from high dependency markets.* Demonstrate the ability to drive up the conversion rate of international applicants / offer holders to enrolled students.* Demonstrate how they can support the University in driving efficiencies in international recruitment.Subject to the provisions of the Framework Agreement, the University will place an Agreement for a period of three (3) years with the option to extend for a further two (2) years up to a maximum of five (5) years, subject to annual reviews and performance monitoring of the service provided.

title: Tender For The Supply And Installation of a High-throughput Droplet-based Microbial Single Cell Screening And Sorting Platform
description: The University of Birmingham invites tenders for supply of a versatile platform for encapsulation of millions of single microbial cells in micrometer-sized liquid or gel-based droplets for high-throughput droplet sorting and selection. This platform will be operated by the Institute of Microbiology and Infection (IMI) at the University of Birmingham (UoB). The platform will support existing and planned research projects, and will lead to the establishment of a facility to extend analytical capability for UoB and its collaborators, and will increase the capacity for high-throughput cell sorting and screening, across the UK. The platform should be able to rapidly produce large numbers of droplets, with the capability to adjust reagent input. For cell screening and sorting, the platform should be equipped with multiple lasers and fluorescence detection wavelengths, as well as forward-scattered light (FSC) and side-scattered light (SSC), due to the vast range of planned applications. The platform must be compatible with aseptic techniques for handling various microorganisms, of pathogenic and non-pathogenic varieties, and therefore be easy to clean.  The platform should ensure damage-free sorting of cell droplets, even with fragile cell types. The platform must have the capability to dispense a single droplet into microwell plates, and be able to sort cells with high purity (i.e. >90%) in high-throughput fashion (approx. 1000 events per second). The instrument should be capable of using a variety of sheath fluid types, and should be compatible with custom made or easily accessible consumables, including Fluorinate-oil.This project may be funded by the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF) or;-	European Structural and Investment Fund (ESIF) or;-	Research Councils UK (RCUK), the strategic partnership of the UK's seven Research Councils.

title: I-CLAIM Survey
description: I-CLAIM Survey - Information for Tenderers  Project Reference SC12109/23  closing date 5th January 2024 at 12:00 noon.I-CLAIM aims to investigate the living and working conditions of undocumented migrants in six European countries. Its goal is to uncover the spectrum and drivers of migrants’ irregular status, as well as the impact it has on migrant families, through an intersectional and intergenerational lens. The project combines the need to advance scientific knowledge and theorisation on the production of irregularity with the urgency to contribute to policy and public debates aimed at improving the lives of undocumented migrant households in Europe. Each tender has to state in their submission that they can complete the work in the given timescales as follows:-1) They have the resources to deliver the project.2) They have clear understanding what the project is required to deliver.3) They can meet clear milestones in this project.

title: ITT310 Provision of a WordPress Web Hosting Service Provider
description: The University of Northampton existing managed hosting contract is due to expire and so are seeking a managed WordPress hosting service from Spring 2024.  The University is looking for a partner to host our public website as well as blogs sites and other sites related to the university.  The host will have a minimum of six years experience, with at least 1,000 plus customers.  There is a requirement for the ability to install multiple WordPress sites with the facility to allow a multisite system on a WordPress site where needed. The University of Northampton existing managed hosting contract is due to expire and so are seeking a managed WordPress hosting service from Spring 2024.  This service needs to be hosted in preferably in the UK.  The hosting service will be required to host several WordPress sites, including a Restaurant site, Hotel Site, a Blog site with multi-sites enabled, Virtual Tour and the main University public website which runs multi sub-sites for areas of the university which require a public facing website.   The main University public website had over 3 million visitors in the last year and so the successful tenderer will need to be able to handle peaks of high activity/traffic.  Also, the successful tenderer will need to provide 24 hours per day monitoring of the public website ensuring issues can be detected and resolved quickly.  Over the period of the contract the University’s AV, Digital and collaborative tools Team will also be moving websites, microsites and blogs which are used elsewhere within the university to the hosting solution.  This will include having multi-site enabled for some sites so that microsites and blogs can sit under their respective sites.  An example of this is Awards and Module catalogue ( https://www.northampton.ac.uk/awards/ ) currently sitting under the public website ( https://www.northampton.ac.uk/ ) installation.  The total hosting of at least 30 sites (A mixture of Live and Development/Staging sites) will be needed with expansion as more sites are brought into the hosting environment.  Our bandwidth usage is around 1.2TB a month with 959GB of this being taken up by our main public website and can go higher in our super busy periods such as Clearing and Welcome Week.  The total storage for all our websites is approximately 250GB at the present time but this is growing by approximately 2Gb a month.  However, we are unable to calculate two sites growth patterns as they have only recently come online.The ideal supplier will become a strategic partner for the duration of the contract which will be two years.  The supplier will need to add value by providing the University with support services, such as consulting and possible assistance with assurance of code along with the core provision of the managed platform and hosting.  This should include all software version and security updates as applicable during the term of the contract.There is a requirement to be able to access the service via a management Graphical User Interface (GUI).  An example of this access would be for managing domain names and any redirects, enabling SFTP user access, accessing logs, etc.  The GUI would also be used to access and view information about bandwidth, storage, number of visitors, PHP versions, WordPress version, updates pending, etc. Management of the core of WordPress will be expected to be controlled/managed by the successful host as well as any server updates and WordPress updates and patches (plug-ins not included, unless hosting companies).  There will be a requirement to create further instances of WordPress.  There is also an expectation that any new hosting supplier will provide project management and resources to migrate the University off the existing platform and hosting arrangement and on to the new hosting provider in time for contract expiry which is the 21st May 2024. This service needs to be hosted in preferably in the UK.  The hosting service will be required to host a number of WordPress sites, including a Restaurant site, Hotel Site, a Blog site with multi-sites enabled, Virtual Tour and the main University public website which runs multi sub-sites for areas of the university which require a public facing website.

title: 1831 / ITT /SC - Ultra High Field Magnetic Resonance Imaging (UHF MRI) Magnet, Gradient Coil Set, and Scanner Back-End
description: Synopsis:  This procurement relates to the establishment of a National Facility for Ultra High Field (“UHF”) Magnetic Resonance Imaging (“MRI”) to be located at the Sir Peter Mansfield Imaging Centre at the University of Nottingham. The tender is divided into three lots; Lot 1 – Magnet, Lot 2 – Gradient Coil Set, and Lot 3 – Scanner Back-End. Since Lots 1-3 will need to be integrated to form the UHF scanner, cooperation among the appointed suppliers is critical to the success of the awards.  Further development will be required for the Passive Shielding and RF Cabin which will be tendered later in the process when the magnet design is finalised. Objectives: •	To secure value for money goods and services for the UoN and UKRI;•	To create an innovative and world leading national facility for ultra-high field magnetic resonance imaging;•	Establish a contract which agrees quality, price, delivery timescales, installation schedule, and aftermarket services accordance with UoN’s requirements; and•	Eliminate risk of modern-day slavery within the supply chain.Estimated Value: The overall budget for this project (1831/ITT/SC) is around £20,000,000.  A guideline budget for each Lot is outlined in the Specification Documents (appendices E, F, and G).  Consideration will be given to each proposal, or combination of proposals, which provides the best value for money in line with the Objectives. The University of Nottingham (“the UoN”) is not a contracting authority for the purposes of the Public Contracts Regulations 2015 (as amended) and its procurement activities are not subject to the Public Contracts Regulations 2015.  Advertisement of any contract in the ‘Find a Tender’ and / or ‘Contracts Finder’ is at the sole discretion of the UoN and is undertaken on a voluntary basis with no obligation to comply with the Public Contracts Regulations 2015 (as amended).  The UoN reserves its rights in full to adapt or step outside the procedures in the procurement legislation as the UoN considers necessary.Please review ITT Pack and Tender Documents for more information

The research group are looking to purchase a Surface Grinding Machine, the machine will be used to produce complex components which make up parts of our electrical motor/generator assemblies. title: UoS Environmental Analysis ICP-OES Upgrade to ICP-MS
description: The University is looking to replace an aging (>15 years old) and increasingly costly ICP-OES that has been heavily used for environmental elemental analysis as part of teaching and research activity to an ICP-MS in an environmental suite, Cockcroft building. Upgrading to an ICP-MS will make a strong contribution to the analytical facilities of the school with applications across several areas of research and teaching and generate further commercial / consultancy income.• Quadrupole ICP-MS giving 10x higher matrix tolerance.• Needs to tolerate aqueous acidified samples (mainly Nitric and HCL and sometimes high salt samples). Potential for HF acid use.• Helium gas line for more precise and wider range of environmental analysis.• Capability to acquire and analyse nanoparticles in a single particle mode.• Recirculating chiller with temperature control.• Compact autosampler for restricted bench space but high throughput.• Ability to add on components later to facilitate new research activity as they arise.• On site expert training for operation and maintenance.• 5-year maintenance contract.• Upfront software license fees.

description: The University of Salford wish to procure the services of a Principal Contractor to carry out reconfiguration works to the existing Photography Suite to create Dark Room, Film Development Room and Light Room, to New Adelphi Building, located within the Frederick Road campus of the University of Salford, M6 6PU.The project will briefly consist of;- Strip out of existing internal fixtures and finishes- Modifications to external windows to ensure light-tightness is achieved- New fire doors- New 2-way revolving doors- Installation of new partitions and ceilings- Plumbing/sanitary installations- New ceilings- Fixed furniture installation- Decorations.

title: ESports Lab Equipment
description: This tender is for the design, provision and installation of equipment and ‘decoration’ for the University of Salford’s (UoS) Salford Business School (SBS). SBS wishes to partner with an Esports and PC specialist to design & implement an EsportsLab in Maxwell Building rooms M713 and M716.  The Lab must  support traditional academic seminar and workshop teaching activities as well as gaming activities using individual PCs and game consoles. The design and layout of the room should be flexible enough to allow reconfiguration as an Esports arena , requiring space and facilities for competing teams, small audiences and broadcasting facilities. The vendor will work with the University’s Estates department who will provide enabling and operational services to the identified space in preparation for the implementation of the agreed room layout The vendor is to provide the full turnkey solution, design, and installation, highlighting power / data and any additional structural requirements.Further details can be found within the ITT
fourth_text: Articles for funfair, table or parlour games

title: Loads Balance Component for low speed Wind Tunnel No.2
description: The University of Salford is procuring a new loads balance for its low-speed Wind Tunnel No. 2. Tunnel No. 2. This is an open-return subsonic wind tunnel achieving speeds up to 40 m/s. It has a test section of approximately 1 m (width) by 0.8 m (height) by 2 m (length). The study of low-speed flows forms a major part of the Undergraduate Aeronautical and Aircraft Engineering Programmes. Each year, more than 150 students across several years of study successfully achieve learning outcomes by conducting laboratory experiments using the low-speed wind tunnels. In addition, the research portfolio around the low-speed aerodynamics and flight dynamics of fixed and rotary wing vehicles will be expanding over the next 5 year. The new balance will support accurate measurements of aerodynamic loads across a wide range of applications and projects.

title: Graduation Services 2023
description: The University events team deliver two sets of graduation ceremonies each year, one in the traditional summer period in the third week of July which is held at The Lowry Theatre, MediaCityUK and a winter graduation event in early December, currently held at the University on our Peel Park Campus. At our Summer Graduation event there are approximately 3800 students in attendance, and our Winter Graduation event there are approximately 1500 students. The University also has a small number of overseas partners who host in-country ceremonies.At present there are two suppliers one for the gowning and one for photography. To streamline the service and provide a simple, easy, and high-quality offer for students and their guests, the University is now inviting sufficiently experienced and qualified suppliers to tender for a package delivering both of these products/services. The appointed supplier will be required to provide gowning and a photography service for students and their guests as well as gowns for our Vice-Chancellor’s executive team, academics, and staff volunteers at both graduation periods each year.

title: Media City MC218 Upgrade
description: The MC218 facility which is extensively used across undergraduate and postgraduate teaching is using out of date software, and missing hardware pieces which would give it parity with industry and with our own dubbing theatre (also housed in MCUK).The software required includes the industry standard convolution package, Altiverb, the Sonnox bundle (both already in the dubbing theatre but not in the labs), Oeksound Soothe 2, and upgrading our Izotope packages as they are now several years out of date.Hardware required includes portable audio and video recorders, and additional microphones as the current provision available in the MCUK stores is not enough for the students to carry out industry standard work. This will support tighter integration with the immediate industry neighbours and give confidence to students seeking work placements etc.Full details can be found within the ITT

title: International Relocation Support Services
description: We have supported over 40 international colleagues across the past 4 years, to relocate to the UK to join the University of Salford (UoS).  We anticipate our volume of international recruitment to be relatively low over the next 12 months, with forecasts for around 5 relocations, however it is anticipated this will increase over the coming years, currently forecasting up to or above 20 international candidates per year by 2028.  Many of our international colleagues will join the University for Research purposes.Those colleagues that have relocated with us historically have been paid HMRC related expenses, however throughout these relocations, new colleagues have had typically negative onboarding experiences for a number of reasons:-	Lack of support through the logistical process of relocating from their home country to the UK – e.g. issues with shipping of belongings and storage on arrival-	Lack of support upon arrival to the UK with difficulties experienced in orientation and settling in.  Basic information around setting up bank accounts, transferring driving licenses, arranging healthcare services etc have been common areas of concern-	Significant issues around securing short and long term accommodation in the Greater Manchester are...Full details can be found within the ITT

title: 3837.PS.LWM.23 Data Collection Services - Indian Food Systems for Improved Nutrition (INFUSION)
description: INFUSION (‘Indian Food Systems for Improved Nutrition’) is a new research project with two UK and four India partner organisations. INFUSION has a major focus on village markets, or haats, and the role that they play in the food consumption and nutrition of rural communities. The project seeks to collect extensive data from a sample of haats and from rural communities in Bihar, India during 2024-25. There are two major streams of data collection: (i) haat (market)-level and (ii) population (household)-level. Given that each of the two levels of data collection will be substantial undertakings, we have split the data collection into two Lots.The full technical specification can be found in the ITT documentation which will be available after you have expressed your interest on In-Tend. title: 3993/JN/23 - Closed-Cycle Cryostat System (2 Lots)
description: The University of Sheffield’s department of Physics and Astronomy are looking to procure 2 types of closed-cycle cryostat systems for optical spectroscopy of semiconductor quantum dots (QDs).Lot 1 – Optical Table Cryostat for Photoluminescence Imaging:A closed-cycle cryostat system is required for optical spectroscopy of semiconductor quantum dots (QDs). The principal uses will be for micro-photoluminescence and photoluminescence imaging from self- assembled InGaAs QDs in the Department of Physics and Astronomy.Lot 2 – Standalone Optical Cryostat for Long Duration Measurements:Up to 2 closed-cycle cryostat systems are required for optical spectroscopy of semiconductor quantum dots (QDs). The principal use will be for micro-photoluminescence measurements of self- assembled InGaAs QDs in the Department of Physics and Astronomy, in particular long-duration measurements under resonant laser excitation that require very high stability and low vibration.This is an FTS open exercise. title: 4014/JN/24 - High Resolution and High Positional Accuracy 3D Microscope
description: There is currently the need for a high resolution, high positional accuracy 3D microscope to aid component quality inspection (form & textural) at the AMRC. The research will involve manufacturing defect detection, with non-contact scans for geometry profile, metallic burring, CFRP delamination and uncut fibres. Automated scanning, easy machine configuration changes (for example lens changes) and variable light setting will aid in rapid inspection for multiple non-connected regions per workpiece. The components/features of interest will range in geometries. Most inspection will be within a working area of 200 x 200 mm in x and y, however scans with working areas up to 300 x 300 mm would be desired. Cutting tool scanning is another research area of interest, using the equipment to be purchased to scan cutting edges for tool wear analysis, requiring the ability to grip and rotate cutting tools.This is an FTS open exercise. The ITT can be downloaded by registering and expressing your interest on the University`s e-tendering system https://in-tendhost.co.uk/sheffield If you have any questions or comments in relation to this tender they must be submitted via the In-tend system, this can be accessed at https://in-tendhost.co.uk/sheffieldCompleted tenders must be returned through the same e-tendering system.Closing date of receipt of tenders: 6th March 2024 at 12 noon (UK time).

title: 3954/JN/23 - Hybrid Hot Press/Spark Plasma Sintering
description: Royce at the University of Sheffield is part of the Department of Materials Science and Engineering and partner to the Henry Royce Institute for Advanced Materials (with the main Hub in Manchester) which aims to grow the UK world-leading research and innovation base in advanced materials science, fundamental to all industrial sectors and the national economy. Royce at the University of Sheffield focuses on Advanced Materials Processing and operates mainly through the Royce Discovery Centre (RDC) and the Royce Translational Centre (RTC). Our state of the art facilities allow materials discovery, materials manufacturing and prototype production and will act as an open access centre of excellence for the UK. With funding from EPSRC we seek to purchase a hybrid-hot press/SPS for the consolidation of various powdery raw materials by combined uniaxial pressing force and heating in vacuum or inert atmosphere. Typical material types to be processed in the SPS include ceramics, metals, hard alloys, nanomaterials, functionally graded materials etc.This is an open FTS exercise. title: 3955YW Digital Anatomy Teaching Devices
description: The University requires large, touch-screen-based, interactive teaching devices that are capable of displaying human anatomy in a digitally-illustrated or digitised format. Students will use them to learn human anatomy by zooming in and out on areas of interest, adding or removing layers of tissue, adding or removing labels, rotating the imagery to their needs, or focusing on specific anatomical structures. These devices will complement a number of other anatomy teaching modalities such as plastic models, plastinated human specimens, ultrasound and surface anatomy, and face-to-face tutorials using large monitors.In total we would require a maximum of 20 devices to be delivered in two batches. The first batch will be delivered in June 2025 and the second in the Summer of 2026.CONTRACT REF : 3955/YW    NAME: Digital Anatomy Teaching Devices                                  PERIOD:  Delivery between 2025 to 2026DEPARTMENT : Faculty of Health and Faculty of Science  	LOCATION: 	The University of Sheffield TENDER RETURN DATE	:   Wednesday 31st January 2024 at 12 noon (UK time).

title: 3785/COMPASS/PRESS/JS/23-Press for COMPASS (Composites at Speed and Scale) Facility
description: 3785/COMPASS/PRESS/JS/23-Press for COMPASS (Composites at Speed and Scale) FacilityThe University of Sheffield wishes to invite tenders for a 'Press' on behalf of the Advanced Manufacturing Research Centre, Castings Group at Catcliffe, South Yorkshire.Scope of RequirementThe AMRC has recently won funding for an ‘automated, large scale composites manufacturing centre’, including a ‘fully automated layup and consolidation cell’ which will incorporate a 10.5m (length) x 3.5m (width) x 2.3m (daylight) Press. Within the ‘Fully Automated Layup and consolidation cell’ the Press will sit alongside a variety of other equipment, and will be in close proximity to the following:-•	High Volume Deposition Cell – including Robot arms and guide rails;•	Press Heater System;•	Press Injection System;•	Oven Feed table.The Press is to be used for manufacturing research into the production of large polymer composite components using several potential processes, including (but not limited to):-•	Dry fibre pre-forming;•	Resin Transfer Moulding (RTM);•	Gap RTM/ Infusion;•	Wet Compression Moulding and Compression Moulding of pre-preg. Brief Summary of RequirementsPlease see G1, G2, G3, G4 and G5 for our exact technical and functional requirements, however at a high level these can be summarised as:-•	The Press will have cold platens and that any heating for processing will be applied to the tooling rather than through the platens. A system of automated tool clamping, and location will need to be included within the tendered press platen package.•	The Press is expected to have a stroke of a minimum of 1500mm within the minimum daylight of 2.3m.•	The Press is required to have a moving lower platen that will enter and exit along the long axis from one end only. All controls and connections for the lower tool will remain active when the lower platen is fully extracted from the press.•	The AMRC is looking for flexibility in the size of tooling that can be used within the Press. The maximum size of component is defined for the purpose of this specification as 10m (length) x 3m (width) x 1.5m (depth) and this will require a minimum programmable force of up to 8 bar across the entire area of that part. Cost options for an incremental increase of this force up to 20 bar are requested (if possible).•	It is anticipated that the platens’ size will exceed the maximum component size by approx. 0.5m in the X and Y axes (10.5m x 3.5m) to accommodate a part of 10m x 3m. To this end the tenderer is expected to recommend a suitable platen size within its proposal.•	The Press must be able to control the platens in a way that allows for tools shorter than the full length to be safely used. The limits to this function must be stated within your tender response.•	The Press will be expected to maintain the platens in an accurate Z plane whilst holding a full-sized tool open against a tool internal vacuum.•	The Press must be capable of monitoring and controlling forces during both closing and opening operations, this control will have set limits in both directions.•	The Press control system must should be capable of controlling additional functions, such as hydraulic actuators, ejectors, or tool features. •	The Press will require an on-board integrated high performance vacuum system for tool vacuum with a full control capability from the Press control. This system should be capable of creating and maintaining a closed tool vacuum level down to better than 0.1mbar.•	The Press will need to control the heating and cooling of a loaded tool, as part of an automated process cycle. Tooling utilised within the press will be heated to a maximum of 220°C.•	The Press will be contained within a fully automated manufacturing cell demonstrator, and as such will need to be integrated into an overall cell control system. This integration specification will require some discussion with the selected suppliers following completion of the tender process.•	Safety features and mechanical interlocks to allow the cleaning of tools in the upper platen to be included in the supply of the Press. The Press must lock open by a mechanism that will remain operational despite loss of power to the Press.•	Access to the Press for cleaning purposes and application of release agent with the ability to stand under the upper tool needs to be included in your tender response.•	Safety Systems to EU (CE) and/or UKCA standards.•	A comprehensive Press Control SystemFor this reason, the Press is expected to have significant flexibility in its range of use and application, unlike a more dedicated production solution.Tender Process and Documentation:This procurement is an open procedure.The ITT can be downloaded by registering and expressing your interest on the University`s e-tendering system https://in-tendhost.co.uk/SheffieldIf you have any questions or comments in relation to this tender they must be submitted via the In-tend System, this can be accessed at https://in-tendhost.co.uk/SheffieldCompleted tenders must be returned through the same e-tendering system.Closing date for receipt of tenders: Friday 22nd September 2023 at 12 noon (UK time).

title: 250kN Servo-Hydraulic Test Machine
description: The Testing and Structures Research Laboratory (TSRL) is part of the UKCRIC National Infrastructure Laboratory (NIL) and is based at the University of Southampton (UoS)., It is a multidisciplinary facility that covers a wide range of application areas. The purpose of the facility is to provide the University of Southampton with a state-of-the-art materials and structures testing facility that enable developments in measurement methodologies with a focus on utilising imaging systems to provide information on material and structural performance. The laboratory has a wider range of mechanical testing apparatus encompassing electro-mechanical, electro-dynamic, servo-hydraulic and other test machines enabling testing of materials across a wide range or forces, temperatures, dimensions and strain rates.https://www.southampton.ac.uk/research/institutes-centres/national-infrastructure-laboratory The Testing and Structures Research Laboratory (TSRL) has a number of 100kN test frames and a larger 630kN frame. Recent strategic research directions have meant that we require samples that need more force than 100kN but are dimensionally too small to fit in the 630kN machine. Subsequently, the University requires a new servo-hydraulic test machine with load capacity of approximately 250kN to compliment our existing capabilities and fill in the gap between our existing machines.The TSRL has capacity within its existing hydraulic infrastructure to include this additional machine in terms of hydraulic flow and available outlets of the existing 210bar ring main. The scope of this procurement is to provide, install and commission a ~250kN test machine with a t-slotted (or equivalent) base alongside an appropriate load cell, hydraulic grips, control system and associated software and hardware interfaces. The system will be used for both static and dynamic testing and thus must be fatigue rated for large numbers of cycles.

title: Internal Training Management System Soft Market Testing
description: This is a Soft Market Test Exercise (SMTE) being conducted by the University of Southampton (the University), this is not an invitation to tender.Project DescriptionThe University currently relies on manual processes, legacy systems, and a patchwork of tools, which do not effectively meet its training management needs. The University recognises the pressing need to address this issue, as it impacts staff development, compliance, and reporting.The University is seeking to modernise and enhance the management and delivery of internal training delivery for its approximately 5000 staff members. The University needs to be able to advertise a catalogue of courses for consumption by internal staff, students, and some specific external groups to register, attend and complete training, then to store and report on the resultant training records. All forms of training need to be accommodated from Face to Face to fully digital and asynchronous. The training will include mandatory training and cyclical training need to be supported for organisation wide requirements like Health and Safety, and area specific, specialist training. Various roles across the organisation need to be able to report on training activity.Please Note: The University is conducting this soft market testing exercise to allow interested parties, with appropriate experience, to outline their views and provide impartial information to the University with no commitment to themselves or the University. This is not a call for competition at this stage.

title: North East Quadrant (NEQ) Development - Design and Build Contractor
description: The University is seeking a Design and Build Contractor for the development of the North East Quadrant (NEQ) Project in Southampton, Hampshire. The North-East Quadrant ("NEQ") site forms part of the Highfield Campus. The site area is approximately 12,290m². Phase 1 consists of the construction of a 4-storey teaching facility (GIFA of c. 15,574m2), with 5 storeys, a basement, and ancillary facilities hub.The building is split into three interconnected areas arranged around a central atrium. The west block consists of a concrete structure with the east / south proposed to be of a steel frame. The external wall solution will be evolved during stage 3. Sustainability and low energy solutions are key to the success of this building due to lack of local power. The works include amendments to external landscaping, and all associated works to meet all planning and building control requirements stipulated elsewhere within the Employer's Requirements. Any S278 works will be delivered as part of an agreement between the selected contractor and Southampton City Council.The successful Contractor will be required to work alongside the Client design team via a PCSA agreement through Stage 3 and Stage 4, at which point a contract sum can be agreed. It is the intention that a separate "Enabling Works"contract will be completed during the Pre-Construction period.The University proposes to enter into a Contract for the delivery of the NEQ Project by Q1 2027 with the successful contractor. The University will appoint the successful contractor via a PCSA appointment in 2024 to deliver pre-construction services, but also a separate enabling works contract, which should de-risk the site prior to agreement of the contract sum for the main works.The successful Contractor will be required to work alongside the Client design team via a PCSA agreement through Stage 3 and Stage 4, at which point a contract sum can be agreed.  It is the intention that a separate “Enabling Works” contract will be completed during the Pre-Construction period.Procurement Process:  The procurement process is being conducted using the Restricted Procedure, consisting of the Selection Stage, followed by the Invitation to Tender (ITT) stage.
