title: Laser Ablation Micro Sampling System
description: The University of Southampton is looking to purchase a Laser Ablation Micro-sampling System for connection to various ICP-MS instruments for the purpose of carrying out spatially resolved elemental and isotopic measurements in a wide range of earth, anthropogenic and biological materials. We have a particular interest in fast imaging/mapping applications. The supplied laser ablation micro-sampling system will be coupled to a range of mass spectrometers in our Research Facility including a Nu Instruments Vitesse TOF-ICP-MS, a Thermo Scientific Neoma MS/MS-MC-ICP-MS, a Thermo Scientific Neptune MC-ICP-MS, Thermo Scientific Element XR HR-ICP-MS, Agilent 8900 QQQ-ICP-MS and a Thermo Scientific X-Series ICP-MS. The laser ablation system will be used principally for fast mapping/imaging applications in conjunction with our Thermo Scientific Neoma MS/MS-MC-ICP-MS and Nu Vitesse TOF-ICP-MS. As such, it must be capable of achieving repetition rates of up to 1KHz with fast sample transport/washout. It is anticipated that the system will also be used for more conventional ‘analytical-type’ analyses on all of our ICP-MS instruments. The supplied system must seamlessly integrate with the hardware and software of our ICP-MS instruments to permit fully programmed/automated analyses. The laser within the system must be capable of coupling with a wide range of materials in a range of formats.

title: Tunable Broadband QCL System
description: The University of Southampton's Optoelectronics Research Centre  (ORC) is looking to purchase a tunable mid-IR laser system that can be used in the frame of the MISSION EPSRC programme grant. The ORC already possesses a tunable laser systems that cover the 6-12 m spectral range, however it does not operate in CW regime, has low output optical power and it has no beam pointing control. The MISSION is a flagship project with the main objective to demonstrate medical and environmental sensors based on absorption spectroscopy using silicon photonics platforms. It is a multi-institutional, multi-disciplinary project which requires a widely tunable mid-IR source with large CW output power and excellent beam pointing control. Since we are developing various sensing platforms it is crucial we get such a source to be able to efficiently test our sensors. The system will be used for research and will be based in Building 53 (Mountbatten building at Highfield campus). The OCR are using in-plane coupling and therefore the laser beam divergence needs to be minimal to ease coupling of MIR light to Si/Ge waveguides. Currently, a great deal of time is spent when change QCL modules and coupling different wavelengths to the Si/Ge waveguides. This significantly slows down our experiments. A small beam divergence would enable much easier coupling and more efficient data collection and analysis.

title: Ultra Pure Water System - Soft Market Testing
description: This is a Soft Market Test being conducted by the University of Southampton, this is not an invitation to tender.The University is looking to purchase an Ultra-Pure Water System for the Mountbatten Building on the Highfield Campus. The Mountbatten Building at the University of Southampton currently generates pure water via a Quattro 3000 Unit and final polishing/UV/filter equipment. This unit is now considered obsolete and the University is looking for a suitable replacement Ultra-Pure Water System (UPW) to be sited within the Mountbatten Building on the Highfield Campus, which needs to be compatible with existing pipework, storage tanks, pumps and motors where possible. The Mountbatten building is a highly technical building supporting the research within the Cleanroom complex (nano fabrication, lithography, optical fibre production and novel glass research) and the Optical lab areas (mainly lasers and characterisation), with demand for high quality, ultra-pure and Reverse Osmosis (RO) water.Document to be returned as part of this Soft Market Testing - 2023UoS-0845 - Soft Market Testing Questionnaire V2.pdfThe deadline for clarifications is 18/09/2023 at 12.00 Noon. The deadline for Questionnaire submissions is 25/09/2023 at 12.00 Noon.

title: Wafer Dicing Saw and Post Wafer Cleaning
description: The University of Southampton seeks to acquire a complete dicing system for the University's optical and semiconductor materials processing capabilities for a number of high-impact projects in the major engineering themes of Quantum Technologies, Photonics  and Advanced Manufacturing. This system is a replacement for the current dicing saw for B53 back-end of line cleanroom facility and an upgrade to meet the demands of current projects and technologies.  Dicing is a fundamental part of the cleanroom and underpins a significant number of ongoing and future grants. The acquisition of this system will enable university researchers to machine surfaces and micron sized ridge structures with nanoscale surface roughness and low amounts of topside chipping in optical and semiconductor materials. This dicing machine will allow the fabrication of new devices that will tackle fundamental research problems in quantum light-matter interactions, quantum sensors,  and telecommunications.

title: Large Laboratory Testing Frame
description: The Large Structures Testing Laboratory (LSTL) at the University of Southampton requires the design completion, manufacture, and delivery of a Large Laboratory Testing Frame: specifically, a reaction frame to enable vertical loading using the 2.5MN actuator. This reaction frame will support a previously procured and commissioned Instron Hydropuls 2.5 MN (both tension and compression) linear actuator with a total displacement stroke 500 mm. The actuator includes a dynamically rated 2.5 MN load cell, and the ability to attach hinged swivel joints at each end (when needed).To include an element of future proofing the frame design should also be capable of supporting a 4 MN actuator (unfactored) which is the next actuator largest available.The large test frame project consists of four phases:Phase 1: The Contractor is to complete the final design of the testing framePhase 2: The Contractor is to manufacture the frame componentsPhase 3: The Contractor is to deliver these components to LSTL at the UniversityPhase 4: The University will assemble the reaction frame onsite as per the Contractor’s guidance

title: IT Services:  Supply & Installation of a High Performance Computer Facility
description: The University is seeking to provide a high performance compute (HPC) facility to support research and teaching. This will be vital resource for existing high-profile staff in many areas of current research and its importance is expected to grow in an era of expanding digital research and increasingly larger datasets, including computationally intensive approaches such as machine learning and generative artificial intelligence.The proposed solution should provide at least 15,000 x64 compatible compute cores at 2GB RAM per core, excluding log-in nodes and peripheral devices. An alternative configuration providing the same or better level of performance would be acceptable.The proposed solution should provide high-memory nodes containing at least one 4TB RAM and two 2TB RAM. An alternative configuration providing the same or better level of performance would be acceptable.The proposed solution should provide a number of GPU Nodes whose combined cost equates to 20% of the combined cost of requirements above.Data Storage===========The University requires the following storage tiers as a minimum:1TB of scratch storage per node100TB of fast scratch storage to service parallel tasks2PB of fast shared scratch storage1PB of archive storageNetworking==========The proposal must include a low-latency 100Gb network fabric connecting all nodes.Extensibility==========The proposed solution must provide a seamless means to extend to make use of public and private cloud resources.Scalability=========The proposed solution must be able to scale for each use case (fast throughput parallel processing, single-node high core-count and high memory processing, and GPU workloads).Additional Support================The responses should include an optional proposal for the provision of user support services.Please see ITT documents for full details.

title: Estates:  Renewable Energy & Solar Deployment Survey, Scoping & Options Appraisal - Phase 2
description: The University of St Andrews wishes to increase renewable energy available to buildings to decarbonise site energy supply, through the installation of roof-mounted solar panels. The overarching aim being to provide improvements to future energy costs and security, throughmaking use of largely underutilised roof spaces.The purpose of this scope of works is to expand on the viability of respective solar installations options against University technical requirements, and development of Employers Requirements and procurement options for deployment of the options selected.The University instructed an initial desktop study for Solar installations across the 3 core areas identified. Initial findings from the study undertaken indicated potential for installation of solar arrays totalling 1.39 MWp. This would have an indicative capital cost of aroundGBP1,650,000 and could save the University GBP307,000 per annum, equivalent to almost 220 tonnes of carbon.The University aims to progress to Phase 2, developing a clear strategy for delivering Solar installations across its estate.

The broker will be responsible for advice on insurance strategic direction, programme placement, negotiating wordings and extensions, being aware of market options, handling and monitoring completion of day to day queries, ensuring a satisfactory tripartite relationship with underwriters, advising on overseas exposures, facilitating claims handling on certain classes, acting as arbiter and point of escalation for claims on other classes, and providing a point of referral for property loss control advice to market norms, including accompanying insurer risk control surveys.Where we have existing in-house capability, we expect the broker to augment that capability and present it to the market. The broker will be responsible for issue of satisfactory policy wordings, negotiating suitable terms and conditions within those wordings, checking those wordings, and issuing statutory and other certificates on a timely basis.Please see tender documents for full details.

title: Roll to Roll Coater & Dryer
description: In order to express interest in this opportunity please go to the University of Warwick In-Tend supplier portal (https://in-tendhost.co.uk/universityofwarwick).The University of Warwick is not a contracting authority for the purposes of the Public Contracts Regulations 2015 (as amended) and its procurement activities are not subject to the Public Contracts Regulations 2015 or the obligations under the European Public Procurement Directives, including the European Remedies Directive. Advertisement of any contract in the Official Journal of the European Union or Contracts Finder is at the sole discretion of the University and is undertaken on a voluntary basis with no implied obligation to comply with the procurement legislation.The University of Warwick has a requirement to purchase a new roll-to-roll coater and dryer as part of the recently announced UK National Battery Materials Scale-up Facility called Advanced Battery Materials Industrialisation Centre (AMBIC) https://iuk.ktn-uk.org/news/delivering-the-uks-national-battery-materials-scale-up-facility/. The coater will designed to process the wide range of battery materials (chemistry/particle size/morphology) produced by the centre and mixed at a scale of 1L, 5L or 10L (or multiples) and produce electrodes suitable for a range of cell formats including pouch (70x50 mm, 300x100 mm) and intermittent coated materials for multi-tabbed cylindrical cells (21700 and 46XX) for high energy (high coat weight) and high power (low coat weight) applications producing 10s or 100s of meters of single and double sided coatings. Machine automation is required for coating width and patch alignment between top and bottom coatings for produce high quality and yield. The coater where possible should have the flexibility and space protected to be upgraded in the future to meet industry processing (coating/drying), metrology, digitalisation and control for novel processing of next generation advanced battery materials. The offering should be designed to allow the processing of multiple different small mixes e.g. 1L per day by ease of cleaning of parts or duplication of parts for high efficiency and to avoid cross-contamination for the different materials processes.

title: Controlled environment (CE) chambers
description: The University of York has a diverse plant biology research portfolio covering fundamental mechanistic work to applied plant breeding and near-field research. We have world-leading capabilities in exploiting novel agricultural products such as biopharmaceuticals, enzymes and other high-value chemicals from plants. Our work utilises a broad range of plant species, including global agricultural crops such as rice, oil-seed rape and cereal crops as well novel biopharmaceutical crops such as Poppy and Artemisia. Much of our fundamental plant science utilises the model plants Arabidopsis thaliana, Nicotiana benthamiana and Brachypodium distachyon. This portfolio of research is dependent on a range of controlled environment growing facilities including 8 controlled temperature rooms, 36 reach-in controlled environment (CE) chambers and 5 glasshouses. We are seeking to expand our range of reach-in controlled environment chambers, replacing end-of-service units with modern, energy efficient chambers that will ensure our research capacity into the future. In this tender we are seeking multiple CE chambers of two distinct kinds:Lot 1 – Single-tiered CE chambers for the cultivation of larger crop plants.Lot 2 – Multi-tiered CE chambers for the cultivation of model plants, mainly Arabidopsis thaliana.

title: Property Works and Consultancy DPS
description: At Thirteen, we’ve been working to help improve the lives of people in our neighbourhoods for years. We provide our customers with homes, support and opportunities to grow.We own and manage 35,000 properties across the North East and Yorkshire and offer a home for life, providing housing and support services. We’re here for anyone who needs a home and a helping hand too.We’re the largest housing provider in the North East of England, and amongst the biggest 25 nationally, but we remain locally responsive. We work hard to support communities in the places we have homes to help address the social, economic and environmental issues that matter to our customers and partners. Further information is available on the Group’s website www.thirteengroup.co.ukThirteen have a requirement for short/medium term delivery of the services and works detailed in the categories below and require a quicker more efficient way to engage with the market to deliver these requirements. The duties required for the contract are in the form of static and mobile patrols to deal with Anti-Social behavior or site issues such as failure of fire activation or automated door entry systems and car park facilitation.The Contract will cover all locations owned by thirteen, which are widespread, of varying sizes and usage and have various tenures. Thirteen acknowledges that the `core areas’ of business are within the Tees Valley. These include Middlesbrough, Stockton, and Hartlepool. The outlying areas e.g. Hull, Newcastle, Gateshead, Sunderland Durham, Kirklees, and York, plus a few others make up the full portfolio of possible locations that the contract will cover. title: Tuition Services - Market Engagement
description: Thurrock Council invites prospective suppliers to participate in a market engagement event in anticipation of a forthcoming tender for the provision of Tutoring services. This initiative aims to cater to the educational needs of children and young people without a school placement or with Special Educational Needs or disabilities (SEND). The Council seeks to establish a diverse pool of providers capable of delivering high-quality, cost-effective, and efficient Tuition Services beyond the confines of the enrolled school. This includes providing education when a child is not formally registered with a school. The service is designed for children unable to attend school, or where external one-to-one tuition or group-based alternative provision is deemed more suitable for their learning needs.To facilitate engagement and dialogue, a market engagement event will be hosted, providing an opportunity for interested providers to familiarise themselves with the borough, understand the service requirements, and engage in meaningful discussions with commissioners regarding service development.Please download the document available on In-Tend for further information, including the event details and how to register your attendance. The service will provide opportunities for clients to develop social networks, participate in the local community and to take up universal services in Thurrock. title: Brighter Futures Healthy Families Service
description: Thurrock Council wishes to undertake a soft market testing to explore what changes can be made to the model and delivery of its Healthy Child Programme, known locally as the Healthy Families Service (HFS). HFS provides universal, targeted and specialist public health service offer to children and young people 0-19 years (up to 25 in case of SEND). Health visitors lead the 0-5 element of the healthy child programme starting in the antenatal period when they meet people in their own homes, ending when the child enters school. The service is delivered from several settings including local community and primary care settings. The service is delivered in line with the 6 overarching high impact areas during 5 mandated visits (plus one at 3-4 months). School nurses lead the 5-19 element of the healthy child programme which is delivered through schools, via digital and other virtual support. The school nurses build on early identification of children in need of support and also support for the 6 high impact areas. Although there are no mandated visits for this element, the school nursing team are expected to see children in reception year when they have their vision and hearing checks and are measured as part of the National Child Measurement Programme (NCMP). Children will again be measured as part of NCMP in year 6. The school nursing team will also have some contacts with children and young people 5-19 at points through their education e.g. at transition points or when there is a need for support.The Council will host a soft market engagement event for existing and potential providers to meet and explore what the redesigned HFS service might look like in Thurrock for 2024 and beyond. Please download the document available on In-Tend for further information, including the event details and how to register your attendance. You must register in accordance with the process outlined in the document.

title: Pre-Market Engagement Energy  - Energy Demand Observatory and Laboratory (EDOL)
description: Pre-Market Engagement  - Energy Demand Observatory and Laboratory (EDOL)Develop and implement a new data infrastructure for the Energy Demand Observatory and Laboratory (EDOL)This Expression of Interest - Pre-Market Engagement (EOI):We are seeking information relating to the development and implementation of a new data infrastructure for the Energy Demand Observatory and Laboratory (EDOL).This Expression of Interest covers Phase 1 of the data infrastructure procurement process only.Please note the following general conditions:•	This EOI will help us to refine the requirements.•	We reserve the right not to proceed with a direct or competitive award.  Nothing shall constitute a commitment to ordering unless we undertake an award that results in the award of a Contract.  •	Should a contract be awarded following an evaluation of EOI and Written Proposal, the Potential Provider agrees to supply the Services in accordance with the Terms contained within the Statement of Requirements for the development of a new data infrastructure for Energy Demand..•	Any and all costs associated with the production of such a response to an EOI must be borne by the Supplier. We will not contribute in any way to meeting production costs of any response.•	Information contained within this document is confidential and must not be revealed to any third party without prior written consent from us.•	Buyers shall use the EOI responses to produce a Supplier shortlist.•	We expect that all responses to this EOI will be provided by Potential Providers in good faith to the best of their ability in the light of information available at the time of their response.•	No information provided by a Potential Provider in response to this EOI will be carried forward, used or acknowledged in any way for the purpose of evaluating the Potential Provider, in any subsequent formal procurement process.  OUR AIMS – WHAT WE WANT TO ACHIEVEThe Buyer is looking for one or more Suppliers to deliver the following aims:●	We are looking to develop and implement a new data infrastructure for the Energy Demand Ob-servatory and Laboratory (EDOL) project (funded until December 2027). This will replace an ex-isting data infrastructure for the Smart Energy Research Lab (SERL) which collected and man-aged smart meter and other contextual data from 13,000 homes across Great Britain. title: Hong Kong BN(O) Migrants Panel Survey
description: RFP NotificationUCL-PROC-1602Dear Bidder,On 31 January 2021, the UK government introduced a new immigration route for Hong Kong BN(O) status holders and their family members to move to the UK.  By the end of March 2023, 172,500 applications have been made under the BN(O) scheme; 113,500 people have moved to the UK on this route, with an additional 27,276 BN(O) visas granted to people who are already here.  The BN(O) migrants represent one of the largest migrant inflows to the UK from a single country ever recorded, and is likely to have profound social, economic, and perhaps political implications for the country.A research team based at UCL, KCL, and Oxford has obtained ESRC funding to design and implement a three-year three-wave panel survey of the Hong Kong BN(O) migrants in the UK.  The research project runs from 1 May 2023 to 30 April 2026.   The objectives of the study are (a) to find out how well the BN(O)s are integrating, socially and economically, in the UK, and (b) to compare the experience and needs of the BN(O)s with other migrant groups and with the UK-bornPlease see attached notification in relation to this tender.Kind RegardsUCL Procurement ServicesUCL is not a "contracting authority" or a "body governed by public law" as defined by the Public Contracts Regulations 2015. This procurement process is not regulated by EU or UK public procurement law. Where UCL advertises contracts in the Official Journal of the European Union, it does so on a voluntary basis and does not undertake any obligation to comply with the procurement legislation. UCL reserves its rights in full to adapt or step outside the procedures in the procurement legislation as UCL considers necessary.

title: Higher Education Marketing Agency to Support the Implementation of Student Recruitment Campaigns
description: The University of Chester is seeking tenders for a specialist Higher Education marketing agency through the UK Open Procedure under the Public Contracts Regulations 2015 and The Public Procurement (Amendment etc.) (EU Exit) Regulations 2020 to support primarily with media planning and buying for its student recruitment campaigns. This will be a two-year contract with the option to extend for a further 24-months on a year-by-year basis. Although the University is looking for an agency to help principally with media planning and buying, the expectation is that the successful agency will work collaboratively with the University on campaign strategy, providing relevant audience, market, and competitor insights to help the University gain a competitive advantage. Further to this, from time-to-time, the University may wish to tap into any creative services available within the agency to help with the production of creative assets and development of our messaging strategy. For the purposes of this contract, please note that the estimated contract value has been provided in the tender documents for the first 12-months of the contract with the assumption that there will be the equivalent spend in year two of the contract, and also year three and four should the option to extend be exercised. title: Customer Relationship Management (“CRM”) Re-Implementation
description: The University is seeking a supplier who will build and re-implement a new version of our current CRM solution using Microsoft Dynamics that meets the requirements of the Global Recruitment & Admissions (“GR&A”) team he primary focus of this paper is on the current GR&A use of the MS Dynamics CRM system. The initiative is to simplify what is a complicated working environment which is not helped by the current configuration and associated business processes within the MS Dynamics system.  The MS Dynamics CRM system in use by GR&A is the only system available for the recording, management and reporting of a significant volume of pre-application activity with prospective students. As a Tier 1 business-critical system, it supports all facets of university student recruitment and outreach. From application onwards, enquiries are still managed in the CRM system, however the application process and student record management is achieved with a different system, that is integrated into the CRM. It is the critical data repository and communication tool that enables the management of all  pre-application activity; including handling enquiries, prospectus requests, event record management (both in person and digital), Clearing interest, and enabling proactive and continued engagement with potential students through scheduled and personalised marketing email communications, all designed to ensure Reading is seen as a desirable University destination and drive applications across all levels of study, from UK and overseas students. As a master record of all pre-application activity, the Microsoft Dynamics CRM system is also a critical tool in measuring the impact of our recruitment efforts, most notably through the integration with our system containing application data to show return on investment through the resulting recruitment pipeline. Over a 15-month cycle, team members from GR&A manage engagement with 45,000-50,000 leads (prospective students) within the CRM system, across Undergraduate, Postgraduate (Teaching and Research), International Foundation and Pre-sessional programmes. In addition, the CRM system is also critical for supporting longer term engagement with students looking for entry in future years, recording initiatives committed to as part of our Access and Participation plan and communicating with parents and other stakeholders in the University application journey, such as teachers and international agents.

Many of our international colleagues will join the University for Research purposes.Those colleagues that have relocated with us historically have been paid HMRC related expenses, however throughout these relocations, new colleagues have had typically negative onboarding experiences for a number of reasons:-	Lack of support through the logistical process of relocating from their home country to the UK – e.g. issues with shipping of belongings and storage on arrival-	Lack of support upon arrival to the UK with difficulties experienced in orientation and settling in.  Basic information around setting up bank accounts, transferring driving licenses, arranging healthcare services etc have been common areas of concern-	Significant issues around securing short and long term accommodation in the Greater Manchester are...Full details can be found within the ITT

title: Loads Balance Component for low speed Wind Tunnel No.2
description: The University of Salford is procuring a new loads balance for its low-speed Wind Tunnel No. 2. Tunnel No. 2. This is an open-return subsonic wind tunnel achieving speeds up to 40 m/s. It has a test section of approximately 1 m (width) by 0.8 m (height) by 2 m (length). The study of low-speed flows forms a major part of the Undergraduate Aeronautical and Aircraft Engineering Programmes. Each year, more than 150 students across several years of study successfully achieve learning outcomes by conducting laboratory experiments using the low-speed wind tunnels. In addition, the research portfolio around the low-speed aerodynamics and flight dynamics of fixed and rotary wing vehicles will be expanding over the next 5 year. The new balance will support accurate measurements of aerodynamic loads across a wide range of applications and projects.

title: Fire Alarm Maintenance 2023

Any electrical testing and associated works shall be undertaken to the latest British Standard BS 7671 (The IET Wiring Regulations) at the time of installation.

title: Media City MC218 Upgrade
description: The MC218 facility which is extensively used across undergraduate and postgraduate teaching is using out of date software, and missing hardware pieces which would give it parity with industry and with our own dubbing theatre (also housed in MCUK).The software required includes the industry standard convolution package, Altiverb, the Sonnox bundle (both already in the dubbing theatre but not in the labs), Oeksound Soothe 2, and upgrading our Izotope packages as they are now several years out of date.Hardware required includes portable audio and video recorders, and additional microphones as the current provision available in the MCUK stores is not enough for the students to carry out industry standard work. This will support tighter integration with the immediate industry neighbours and give confidence to students seeking work placements etc.Full details can be found within the ITT

title: Graduation Services 2023
description: The University events team deliver two sets of graduation ceremonies each year, one in the traditional summer period in the third week of July which is held at The Lowry Theatre, MediaCityUK and a winter graduation event in early December, currently held at the University on our Peel Park Campus. At our Summer Graduation event there are approximately 3800 students in attendance, and our Winter Graduation event there are approximately 1500 students. The University also has a small number of overseas partners who host in-country ceremonies.At present there are two suppliers one for the gowning and one for photography. To streamline the service and provide a simple, easy, and high-quality offer for students and their guests, the University is now inviting sufficiently experienced and qualified suppliers to tender for a package delivering both of these products/services. The appointed supplier will be required to provide gowning and a photography service for students and their guests as well as gowns for our Vice-Chancellor’s executive team, academics, and staff volunteers at both graduation periods each year.

title: UoS Environmental Analysis ICP-OES Upgrade to ICP-MS
description: The University is looking to replace an aging (>15 years old) and increasingly costly ICP-OES that has been heavily used for environmental elemental analysis as part of teaching and research activity to an ICP-MS in an environmental suite, Cockcroft building. Upgrading to an ICP-MS will make a strong contribution to the analytical facilities of the school with applications across several areas of research and teaching and generate further commercial / consultancy income.• Quadrupole ICP-MS giving 10x higher matrix tolerance.• Needs to tolerate aqueous acidified samples (mainly Nitric and HCL and sometimes high salt samples). Potential for HF acid use.• Helium gas line for more precise and wider range of environmental analysis.• Capability to acquire and analyse nanoparticles in a single particle mode.• Recirculating chiller with temperature control.• Compact autosampler for restricted bench space but high throughput.• Ability to add on components later to facilitate new research activity as they arise.• On site expert training for operation and maintenance.• 5-year maintenance contract.• Upfront software license fees.

SBS wishes to partner with an Esports and PC specialist to design & implement an EsportsLab in Maxwell Building rooms M713 and M716.  The Lab must  support traditional academic seminar and workshop teaching activities as well as gaming activities using individual PCs and game consoles. The design and layout of the room should be flexible enough to allow reconfiguration as an Esports arena , requiring space and facilities for competing teams, small audiences and broadcasting facilities. The vendor will work with the University’s Estates department who will provide enabling and operational services to the identified space in preparation for the implementation of the agreed room layout The vendor is to provide the full turnkey solution, design, and installation, highlighting power / data and any additional structural requirements.Further details can be found within the ITT

title: Confidential Waste Management
description: The University requires a contractor to provide Confidential Wastepaper Disposal Services to satisfy the University's principal need to achieve a value for money, secure chain of custody for confidential paper waste through a low maintenance contract with the ambition of zero waste to landfill. The services must conform to BS EN15713:2009 for confidential waste destruction and must evidence a comprehensive approach to implementing an information security manage.It is estimated that there would be approximately 120 consoles required to be collected at a maximum frequency of weekly giving approximately 3000 collections a year amounting to around 50 tonnes (of which 40 tonnes is from routine collection and 10 tonnes from Ad hoc collections). The appointed Contractor would be expected to work with the University prior to commencement of the contract (and throughout) to fully scope requirements and make efficiency recommendations going forwards.Further detail can be found within the ITT

To support our growing work in cardiovascular research we are also seeking the addition of photometry and contractility measurement onto the system.

description: UWE are looking to undertake early pre-market engagement for our Electronic Point of Sale (EPoS) system so we can scope a future tender appropriately. Our current EPoS solution handles £3.5 million annually across 800,000 transactions. It is used in our 12 hospitality outlets as well as Printworks, our printing and stationery outlet. title: UOW915 - Event Management Services
description: The University of Worcester will shortly be tendering for the provision of Event Management Services. The service will predominantly be for the University’s two major annual events which are Graduation and Welcome Week. This year, Graduation is taking place w/c 11 September 2023 and Welcome Week w/c 18 September 2023, and it is expected that the events will take place at the same time of year in future years. The contract may also include some smaller events if required. The contract does not currently include the management of the Graduation ceremonies held at Worcester Cathedral but the management of the post-ceremony receptions.We are currently working on pulling a tender specification together but this is likely to cover the following:Pre event:Liaison with University colleagues from Comms & Participation, Estates & Facilities, Safety, Procurement & SUIn liaison with University colleagues agree; suppliers, dates, timings, access to site, site set up plan, safety planSupplier liaisonAttendance at planning meetings as required To assist with product sourcing.Event:To act in the role of Event ManagerLiaison with University / SU colleagues as required To conduct staff event & safety briefingsTo ensure servicing of facilities in liaison with others To work to resolve any issues as they occurTo open and close the site daily and liaise with UW security for overnight cover.Post event:Site demount / take down & reinstatementManagement of contractors onsite Site safety managementPost event de-brief meeting Liaison with finance re invoicing We would like to invite potential tenderers to the University to view the Graduation event on Wednesday 13 September 2023 in preparation for the upcoming tender. The visit will be unaccompanied but you will be able to walkaround the site, view the set-up and see likely requirements going forward. A member of University staff will be available at 2pm for an hour to answer questions you may have. A meeting location for this will be provided closer to the time.You will also be welcome to visit and view the Welcome Week set-up on any day of your choice but this will be unaccompanied with no University staff available for questions.Photographs will be taken for tenderers unable to attend the event and will be provided with the tender documents along with site layouts.Both events are to be held on the University’s City Campus in the centre of Worcester. Further information on this campus can be found at https://www.worc.ac.uk/contact/campus/city-campus.aspx.Further information on Graduation can be found at https://www.worcester.ac.uk/life/alumni/graduation-2022/graduation-2022.aspx and further information on Welcome Week can be found at https://www.worcester.ac.uk/life/prepare-for-study/welcome-to-worcester/welcome-festival-2023.aspx.The University will not be liable for any costs incurred for the site visit.

title: WP3960 - Regeneration Strategic Advisor
description: The Council are seeking framework partners to provide a range of services to take schemes through the various feasibility and development stages leading up to the point of securing funding, appointment of a developer and/or detailed design and implementation. It is noted that the Council has limited land ownership and therefore the work will require collaboration with private landowners and key stakeholders. The level and spectrum of pre-development work required for projects will vary and some may only require limited input.The framework will contain a maximum of three (3) multi-disciplinary teams to provide services across a range of regeneration, planning, property, and technical areas. Each multi-disciplinary team / framework partner will be required to provide the following skills and expertise:  Project and programme management Property and commercial, including valuations, appraisals, acquisitions/ CPO, market intelligence, and economic guidance Delivery models and approaches Development options, feasibility, and pre-development  Development funding and financing Cost consultants Business case development including benefit cost ratios and cash flows Concept plans, capacity layouts and master planning Planning and planning policy guidance Inward investment, marketing, and branding Architectural Consulting engineer(s) e.g. remediation, flood risk, transport & highways, utilities, civils, drainage Environmental consultants e.g. noise, air quality, ecology, heritage conservation, arboriculture.  The expected contract value for known work is £500k per annum, however with additional projects, potential opportunities to secure external funding and possible use across other areas of the Council this could be significantly exceeded.  The Council is looking to appoint a maximum of three (3) multidisciplinary teams /framework partners for this Contract.   It is expected that each framework partner will be managed by an identified Lead Consultant. However, the use of specialist sub-consultants may be required to assist with the delivery of the commission to provide the full spectrum of skills and services (unless the services can be provided in-house by the Lead Consultant). The Lead Consultant should therefore have the ability to bring in and contract with sub-consultants required for the commission.The Council will in the main at its discretion award a direct call-off for each particular project to the supplier that it considers the most suitable for that specific assignment, however where the Council considers it appropriate it will run a mini-competition between suppliers on the Framework in order to achieve the best outcome.

title: WP3814 - Security Services
description: The Council wishes to procure the services of a suitably qualified and experienced provider to deliver Walsall Council’s operational security services to Council owned buildings and events under their control within the borough.  The Council wishes to appoint one provider for the service outlined in the technical specification in these documents (Specification, at Part 03, Section A). These services shall be required to cover  24 hours/365-day period (for the benefit of any doubt, to include bank holidays).In relation to the Key Holding section (Sub Section 2) of the specification.  The Council currently has 26 sites where key holding services are in place, however the Council is looking to increase this number.  A list of these properties can be found at Schedule 2 of the specification.These services will be required to a range of Council owned and managed buildings (the ‘Council Premises’), a list of these properties has been issued (Appendix 3 – Master Address List) as part of these ITT documents. The Council reserves the right to add or remove properties to this list as changes to the property portfolio occurs during the life of the contract.
second_text: Public security, law and order services
fourth_text: Surveillance and security systems and devices

title: WP3952 - UKSPF Business Growth Support
description: The Council wishes to commission a contract for the provision of a business programme to support Walsall start-ups and small and medium enterprises (SMEs) to overcome barriers and maximise opportunities to increase their productivity.  Set to be delivered until 31st March 2025, the provision should provide expert advice, guidance and support to businesses in the form of 1-2-1 engagement and events. The provider should work with business leaders to take a forensic look at their business and connect them with support that will best create growth.  Funded by the UK Shared Prosperity Fund, providers should set out how they will deliver against the UKSPF investment priorities of Supporting Local Business, as well as supporting delivery of the overarching Council Plan vision and themes, by identifying priority interventions and activities that can be delivered between 1 January 2024 and March 2025, with an option to extend for further 24 months should further funding be received by Government.

title: WP3971 - Evaluation of the National Lottery Heritage Fund Capacity Project
description: Walsall Council is seeking a high-quality provider to undertake an expert independent evaluation of: AOF2020 Walsall Council: National Lottery Heritage Fund Capacity Project (1st October 2020-31st January 2024) Supported by the National Lottery Heritage Fund (NLHF) as a Strategic Funding Framework (2019-2024) priority local authority area, in 2020 Walsall Council received a £249,900 solicited grant to rebuild heritage capacity within Walsall. Central to the project was the development of a new Heritage Strategy and Action Plan, to guide discussions, set direction and identify sector needs over a 5-year period and beyond. The aim of the strategy was to place heritage at the heart of Walsall’s future, protecting what exists whilst nurturing sustainability and identifying opportunities to unlock its full value. The project created 1 FTE Heritage Programme Management Officer and 1 0.25 FTE Conservation Officer to: represent heritage sector interests, instigate projects, pilot a community grants fund and establish a new Heritage Forum, to create stronger, resilient, partnerships between public, voluntary and private sectors. The project vision was to ensure that heritage is better managed and integrated into Walsall’s overall vision and transformation, meeting the needs of a diverse local population who are proud to live, work and visit Walsall.Outline Requirements are to carry out an evaluation of the project and produce a detailed report which: •	Reviews the project’s progress against National Lottery Heritage Fund outcomes identified in the funding application. •	Reviews the project’s success in relation to its contractual obligations set out by NLHF – including its overall aim and the achievement of outputs and spends.  •	Assesses added value.•	Provides clear conclusions and recommendations to help enable stakeholders to identify and apply any lessons learned. The key audience for the report include Walsall Council and the National Lottery Heritage Fund. Further information on The National Lottery Heritage Fund can be found by visiting Welcome | The National Lottery Heritage Fund.

title: WP3970 - Walsall Leather Museum to Future Walsall Museum - Feasibility Study
description: Walsall Council is seeking a high-quality provider to deliver a feasibility study for Walsall’s future place-based museum offer, currently delivered through the Walsall Leather Museum model.  Walsall Council has received confirmation of funding via the UK Shared Prosperity Fund to undertake this. This will consider if Walsall Leather Museum is fit for the future, and if not: what future Museum would support the wider regeneration of the Borough? where would the future Museum be best located?  Capturing the momentum, both local through the Walsall Heritage Strategy (2021-2026) and regionally following the cultural successful Birmingham Commonwealth Games 2022, this is an exciting opportunity to re-imagine Walsall’s Museum offer, interrogating the existing model and proposing a fresh vision, ethos, and overall approach for a unique and innovative space in Walsall.   Walsall seeks to unlock a progressive, inclusive museum project, leveraging its industrial heritage and progressing through to its diverse creativity today.

title: PME3946  - Healthy Child Programme 0 -19
description: Walsall Borough Council are looking for an organisation who can deliver the Healthy Child programme 0-19 including public health support in pregnancy, health visiting, school nursing and teenage pregnancy prevention work for a population of 56,000 children and families. The service will work to the Schedule of Interventions Healthy child programme schedule of interventions - GOV.UK (www.gov.uk) and prioritise prevention of particular health inequalities in Walsall.The Council is carrying out this pre-market engagement to determine the strength of the market for this opportunity

title: PME3947 Integrated Sexual and Reproductive Health Services
description: Sexual and reproductive health is an important area of public health. Most of the adult population of England are sexually active and access to quality sexual and reproductive health services improves the health and wellbeing of both individuals and populations. Walsall Borough Council are looking for a specialist integrated sexual health service (ISHS) to provide service users with open access to confidential, non-judgemental services: •	including sexually transmitted infections (STIs) and blood borne viruses (BBV) testing (including HIV), treatment and management•	HIV prevention including pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) and post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP)•	the full range of contraceptive provision•	health promotion and prevention including relevant vaccinations.The Council is carrying out this pre-market engagement to determine the strength of the market for this opportunity

title: WP3926 - Housing Support Service - to support adults with mild learning difficulties and mental health issues
description: The Council wishes to procure a single organisation to deliver services for individuals aged between 18 and 65 years who have a mild learning difficulty and / or mental health issues whose housing tenancy is at risk. The purpose of the housing support service is to prevent the loss of tenancy and provide advice and support to prevent the need for funded health and social care. The service will support to prevent the loss of tenancy, uphold the rights of people who are threatened with homelessness, support people to understand the broad range of housing related issues including responsibilities under their tenancy agreement and to manage these independently.
first_text: Property management services of real estate on a fee or contract basis

title: WP3804 - New Art Gallery Walsall - Planned Preventative Maintenance Services
description: WP3804 - New Art Gallery Walsall - Planned Preventative Maintenance ServicesThe Council are looking to engage with an experienced contractor to provide a planned preventative maintenance service, and reactive remedial maintenance support, to the building systems of The NAGW.   Principally this would be to maintain the main building systems of the site – building management systems, water systems, electrical systems, pressure systems, doors and windows, lighting, and environmental controls - and in turn to support the general operation of the site, in accordance with the needs of the venue, best practice, recommended insurance advice, and statutory requirements. This contractor should also provide advice for additional reactive works as appropriate upon request from The NAGW (if works fall out of the remit described within any agreement). In this regard The NAGW measures successful delivery of the contract by an ability to maintain full operational functionality of the building systems, and the upkeep and identification of on-going maintenance needs to reduce longer-term issues.

title: WDC - Consultancy for A Green Belt Review of the South Warwickshire Local Plan
description: Tenders are invited for the provision of Consultancy for a Green Belt Review of the South Warwickshire Local Plan. Warwick District and Stratford-on-Avon District Councils (the Councils) are working together to prepare a joint South Warwickshire Local Plan (SWLP). It is intended that the new local plan will set out the planning policies that both Councils will use to assess planning applications. It will also identify and allocate sites to accommodate South Warwickshire’s future needs for homes, jobs and infrastructure.The Councils wish to appoint consultants to undertake a Green Belt review of those parts of the West Midlands Green Belt which fall within the South Warwickshire area. This study will assess which areas of land contribute most strongly to the five purposes of Green Belt as set out in the National Planning Policy Framework (NPPF). The purpose of the study is to gain an understanding of which areas of land should retain their Green Belt designation, and which areas may have the potential for release without compromising the performance of the West Midlands Green Belt as a whole. This will form an important part of the evidence base, to be considered alongside other pieces of evidence when selecting the most suitable locations for growth.The contract will be for a period of 36 months commencing February 2024. The Green Belt review within the first 12 months, the second 24 months to include representation of the councils at examination.The Contract Value is approximately £70,000 - £100,000

title: WDC - Memorial safety inspections, maintenance and repair
description: Tenders are invited for the provision of the memorial safety inspection, maintenance and repair at Warwick District Council owned burial sites and maintained closed churchyards. Warwick District Council has a duty of care to ensure the safety of visitors to the crematorium, cemeteries and closed churchyards falling under their jurisdiction this includes managing risks posed by unsafe or unstable memorials even though, in many cases the memorials themselves are not owned by the council. This contract is for the provision and installation of various cremation memorials and a rolling programme of work for the safety inspection, making safe, maintenance and repair of memorials in the following cemeteries, closed churchyards and crematorium being managed by Warwick District Council.The contract will be for a period of 5 years commencing October 2023The Contract Value is approximately £40,000 [per 12-month period]

title: WCC - Traffic/Transport Modelling Framework
description: The Authority has been using Paramics modelling software (both S-Paramics and Paramics Discovery – hereinafter collectively referred to as ‘Paramics’) since 2001 to assess highway schemes, identify the likely impacts of development and to inform strategic transport assessments of Local Plan proposals for each of Warwickshire’s five Districts and Boroughs: •	Warwick District; •	Nuneaton and Bedworth Borough; •	Rugby Borough; •	North Warwickshire Borough; and •	Stratford District. WCC has a diverse suite of models covering each District and Borough in the County, ranging from simple corridor models to more complex wide-area models which are used to test the impacts of Local Plan allocations proposed by the District and Borough Councils.  Increasing demands on the Authority’s modelling team, due to the pressures of maximising the potential of all funding opportunities through business case development for the Strategic Economic Plan/Local Growth Deal and other funding sources and the demands for support through the Local Plan process means less officer time can be spent on this task, a task which is essential to ensure the viability of the Model Revenue Fund (MRF) business model.  Specialist external modelling support is therefore required to continue the development and maintenance of WCC models and to provide robust scheme and development assessments over the next 1-4 year period.

title: Market Testing - WCC Trauma and Mental Health Support for Newly Arrived Communities
description: From March 2022, over 1100 individuals; children, young people and adults have arrived in Warwickshire, fleeing the war in Ukraine.  Warwickshire’s Migration Partnership are committed to ensuring that all newly arrived communities, who have travelled from conflict, have access to health and mental health services that meet their needs. Prior to arrival in Warwickshire families have experienced a number of traumatic experiences which include war, forced departure from their homes, the loss of family members and friends, detention, torture, violence and insecure living conditions in their initial country of asylum. On arrival in the UK, refugees face additional challenges including language and cultural adjustment.We are looking for a community-based specialist wellbeing service, which will offer several suitable interventions in support of newly arrived communities?  This wellbeing service will support young people, adults and families.The provider should have experience of delivering therapeutic support to individuals who have fled war and conflict and who may have cultural barriers to accessing mental health support. The service should be accessible to people wherever they are based in Warwickshire and should therefore operate from multiple locations across the county. Language should not be a barrier for people to access the service-the service will need to work with bi-lingual counsellors and/or specialist interpreters.

title: WCC - Transforming Care Housing with Care Development (Dordon)
description: The aim of this procurement exercise is to appoint an experienced Registered Provider (RP) of Social Housing, that will lead on the development of a purpose-built core and cluster scheme consisting of 6 bungalows to accommodate people with LD/autism with complex needs. The new scheme will offer an opportunity for its residents to benefit from an individual bungalow with self-contained private garden, designed to reflect the needs of the individuals who will take on the tenancies, and built to a high standard in line with relevant national design guidelines. The Council has identified a vacant site within its own asset portfolio.  The site is of an appropriate size and location for the proposed development. The proposal includes a disposal of land (on a 125-year lease only) owned by the Council for the above development, and as such, Heads of Terms and subsequent development agreement and lease will underpin these arrangements. It is expected that the appointed RP will be engaged in the procurement activity of the care provider recognising the required close working relationship that is necessary to provide effective accommodation and care for residents.  The Council, in partnership with Coventry City Council, Coventry and Warwickshire Integrated Care Board (ICB), Coventry and Warwickshire Partnership Trust and NHS England local specialist team, are working to deliver the Transforming Care programme (TCP) within the subregion. The aim of the Programme is to prevent avoidable admissions to specialist Learning Disability (LD) or Mental Health hospitals by autistic people or people with LD and ensure that individuals are discharged back into the community with the appropriate accommodation, help and support.  The Learning Disabilities and Autism (LDA) programme has NHS Long Term Plan targets to reduce the number of people with a learning disability and/or autism who are in a specialist LD or mental health hospital setting. Partners are keen to explore innovative care and support solutions including development of bespoke accommodation-based support services for those whose complex needs cannot be met through existing standard provision, which this scheme aims to support.This project is being delivered on behalf of Warwickshire County Council (the Council) and Coventry and Warwickshire Integrated Care Board (ICB) and the Council will act as the lead Commissioner for this project.Full details are included in the tender documents.
first_text: Property management services of real estate on a fee or contract basis

title: WCC - Refresh Community Short Breaks for Children with Disabilities in South Warwickshire
description: The Authority is seeking tenders for their Community Short Breaks for Children with Disabilities in South Warwickshire The services will operate under a framework agreement. The provision of short breaks is a statutory requirement that requires local authorities to provide access to services that are designed to assist individuals who provide care for children with disabilities to continue to do so, or to do so more effectively, by giving them breaks from caring. The local authority must offer short breaks as part of a preventative model in keeping families together, preventing family breakdown and preventing Children and Young People with disabilities becoming children looked after. The service is required for Children and Young People with a disability who are eligible for social care support where the assessment of need has identified an individual and their family/carer would benefit from access to short break services.The overall aim of the framework is to facilitate the delivery of a range of short break services for eligible customers with a disability. It is anticipated that having clearly identifiable lots will lead to increased choice and meeting need at times when families need it most, this in turn will lead to timely access to short breaks opportunities for children and their families. Short breaks will focus on personal and community assets to support customer choice, control, and increased independence. Parent/Carers will benefit by receiving respite that will enable them to focus on their own health, well-being and daily living needs.
fifth_text: Holiday centre and holiday home services

title: WCC - Delivery of Autism Conferences across Coventry & Warwickshire
description: Warwickshire County Council (WCC) is going out to tender for the delivery of conferences across Coventry and Warwickshire to share information and advice relating to autism. This tender exercise is conducted on behalf of Coventry and Warwickshire Integrated Care System (ICS) partners, including Coventry City Council and NHS Coventry and Warwickshire Integrated Care Board.The conferences will be available for anyone with an interest in autism to attend.The need for these events has been informed by engagement with members of the public, customers, and professionals which was conducted from 2021-2023. This feedback has highlighted that improved information and advice to understand and navigate available support and services locally is required and previous events of a similar format have been helpful.This specification describes the service that the provider is expected to deliver and details the main responsibilities, of the provider and the Council, in ensuring that delivery of the service is effective and leads to positive outcomes for those in attendance.Please note - it is anticipated that this service specification may evolve as the commissioner and provider:•	Work together to plan the events.•	Learn lessons to inform future development.•	Identify changes required through ongoing coproduction activity.Any changes to the specification will be agreed jointly.

title: WCC - Domiciliary Care Provider Engagement Event
description: Warwickshire County Council (WCC) in collaboration with Coventry and Warwickshire Integrated Care Board (ICB) would like to inform you of their commissioning intention to tender the Care at Home contract in March 2024 (subject to approval). The current care at home contract went live in 2016 and is due to expire on 31st July 2024. Our Care  at Home service plays a vital role in ensuring that the County’s vulnerable people are able to safely remain at home with the right care and support. The service currently supports around 2,400 people at any one time at a cost of around £36 million per year. The service is delivered through a multitude of providers each allocated a specific geographical zone to operate in and it is envisioned that this zonal model will continue for the new contract.The event is aimed at:-	Interested registered domiciliary care providers who currently do not hold a contract with WCC and/or ICB. (Non-Commissioned.)WCC will be holding a provider engagement event on Tuesday 23rd January @ 10.00am via MS Team, to gauge interest from domiciliary care providers which will inform a Tendering Exercise due to be launched in March 2023.WCC will be holding a second provider engagement event on Tuesday 13th February @ 10.00am via MS Team, for any providers who could not attend previous sessions. title: WAV - Provision of consultant services to produce a HEDNA
description: Waverley Borough Council has a recently adopted Local Plan comprising two parts.  Local Plan Part 1 was adopted in 2018 and contains strategic policies including the housing need and affordable housing requirements together with a number of strategic site allocations.  Local Plan Part 2 comprises the second part of the Local Plan for the Borough and was adopted in 2023.  The document contains the development management policies and a number of housing allocations in the settlements of Haslemere and Witley in addition to gypsy and traveller site allocations.  There are also seven made neighbourhood plans within the Borough which form part of the development plan, several of which contain site allocations for housing.  Four further neighbourhood plans are under preparation.  The Council also has a number of adopted Supplementary Planning Documents and Guidance documents on a range of planning matters including affordable housing. Despite the Council recently adopting Local Plan Part 2, the Council is now beginning the process of preparing a new local plan which once adopted will replace Local Plan Parts 1 and 2. The plan period will be 2023 – 2043.  The first stage in this process is preparing the evidence base documents to support the policies within the new local plan.The Council is seeking to procure a consultant to prepare the Housing and Economic Needs Assessment (HEDNA) to inform the new Local Plan.

A suitably qualified and experienced Quantity Surveyor to; • Understand the existing design and cost proposals (RIBA stage 1 completed), and visit site (cost proposal appended as part of the tender document).• Assess the costs against the designs proposed by the Design Team at each RIBA stage and produce a bill of quantities, Cost Plan to reflect the design, taking account the site restrictions and abnormalities as known.• Work with the Design Team as surveys and understanding of the site is developed to ensure costs are accurately reflected as we progress to submission of planning permission and procurement of build contractor.• Advise the design team regarding the best cost options for different delivery methods.• Advise on best value options with regards to retention of existing structure versus new build.• Meet with the Council Project Manager (internal and external), and finance lead to go through the Cost Plan at each stage to understand the implications for the overall viability for the project.• Advise the Council in relation to build cost inflation and preparation for cost movement when making viability assessment • Make innovative suggestions as part of the wider team for Value Engineering should the requirement be necessary

title: WHC - Howard House Refurbishment
description: Howard House is a Welwyn Garden City Town Centre block built in 1937. It has 52 purpose-built flats across 4 blocks. There are commercial units on the ground floor. Of the 52 homes 35 are tenants and 17 are leaseholders. The Council does not own the freehold to the building but has four headleases (one for each of the four blocks) which require the council to undertake maintenance on the blocks. There is a complex ownership of the freehold with parts of the building (including the commercial units) being owned by several different landlords. title: WHC - Campus West CRM Ticketing System
description: Campus West is a unique entertainment and leisure facility in Welwyn Garden City, owned and managed by Welwyn Hatfield Borough Council (the Council). It offers a three-screen independent cinema which accounts for the venue’s bulk of its income – with the Event Cinema offering contributing a significant proportion. The screens also double as spaces for private hire and conferencing activities, while its largest space is a flexible cinema/theatre which every year play host to its hugely popular in-house produced panto. Campus West also houses a soft play centre as well as the only purpose-built roller-skating rink in Hertfordshire. This multi-purpose space, well known as Roller City, is used weekly for Keep Fit, Line Dancing and Zumba classes. To complete this rich mix of diverse and fun filled activities and services, the venue runs a café which caters and provides food and beverage for all ages.50 years after it opened its doors, pre-pandemic, it sold more than £2.4 million tickets to half a million visitors annually. Campus West which is Council-owned and operated, but functions as a commercial organisation, has nurtured an active Zebra discount membership scheme with over 14,000 members actively engaging in its services. Marketing mailouts promoting Campus West and its upcoming activities are sent weekly to about 37,000 customers who have agreed to receive such emails. And with a Net Promoter Score south of 90, over 80% of Campus West users continue to affirm that this unique venue is value for money. Along with Campus West, our present Ticketing CRM solution is deployed in two sister venues: The Watermill at Mill Green Museum and The Hive. Under one single database system with separate and restricted setup, the system is used for day-to-day ticketing, merchandise and food and beverage operations across the board.The Council is seeking a suitably experienced supplier to provide a ticketing CRM solution.

title: Thatcham Memorial Fields - Flood Alleviation Scheme
description: *This is the pre-qualification stage of a two stage tender process* West Berkshire Council are looking to procure the main contractor for the provision of a flood alleviation scheme at Memorial Fields, Brownsfield Road, Thatcham, Berkshire RG18 3AG. Bidders must ONLY complete the ‘Thatcham Memorial Fields – PAS91 Questionnaire’ document for this first stage. Bidders who are successful at pre-qualification stage will be invited to tender for the contract.Please note the ITT documents have been included but are FOR REFERENCE ONLY and should not be submitted during this first stage tender.Description of the requirement:The works consist of a flood storage basin and swale connected to the adjacent Thames Water trunk sewer.   The purpose of the scheme is to prevent overland surface water flooding as experienced in 2007 by intercepting these flows and releasing these flood volumes back into the existing Thames Water sewer when capacity within the sewer network is available.  To a lesser degree, the flood alleviation scheme will provide flood storage volume when the sewer has insufficient capacity to carry peak flows from extreme storm events.  The flood alleviation scheme when implemented will prevent overland surface water flooding to existing residential properties and commercial areas downstream of the scheme. The full specification can be found within the tender pack.

title: SportAccord WMGC Exhibition Stand – Design & Build Services
description: The West Midlands Growth Company (WMGC) helps to create new jobs, expand existing businesses and attract new businesses and investment to the region, aligned to the ambitions set out in the West Midlands Combined Authority (WMCA) Strategic Economic Plan. The WMGC has been established in partnership with Local Enterprise Partnerships, local authorities, Growth Hubs, universities and a wide range of businesses across the private sector. It focuses its seven local authorities: Birmingham, Coventry, Wolverhampton, Solihull, Walsall, Sandwell and Dudley. The WMGC is owned by the WMCA and its Constituent Members, with governance that heavily involves the private sector in the majority. Its core WMCA and local authority funding will be used to attract significant additional funding from the private sector and other sources, such as future Devolution Deals. WMGC is part of the Local Organising Committee for the SportAccord World Sport & Business Summit 2024, delivering alongside Birmingham City Council and other local stakeholders as part of a Host City contract. As part of the contract for being SportAccord 2024’s Host City, we can take a presence within the exhibition area of the event. To deliver this, we require an exhibition stand  supplier to provide stand design and build services on the space allocated for us.

title: UKREiiF 2024 - Stand Design & Build Services
description: The purpose of this procurement process is to appoint an organisation who can provide stand design and build services (including AV) prior to and during the West Midlands’ attendance at UKREiiF 2024. The West Midlands Growth Company (WMGC) will be coordinating the West Midlands presence at UKREiiF 2024.UKREiiF is the UK’s real estate investment and infrastructure forum. It is a four-day real estate event that was established in 2022, defying expectations, attracting thousands of domestic and international developers, investors, councils and built environment thought leaders. Its aim is to connect people, places and businesses to accelerate and unlock sustainable, inclusive and transformational investment.Supported by a high number of regional combined authorities, local councils and Government departments – as well as the largest developers and investors from across the UK and internationally – this event will gather all the key players, influencers and decision makers within the investment and real estate markets to highlight investment and development opportunities, whilst connecting and facilitating new relationships to drive economic growth through development and regeneration.UKREiiF is a fast-growing show within its industry and the projections for 2024 are: 10,000 event attendees2,500 fringe event attendees150 exhibitors250 local authorities attending1,500 investors attending1,500 developers attendingIn 2024 the event will run from 21 – 24 May and be held at the Royal Armouries Museum in Leeds. For additional information regarding UKREiiF please visit www.ukreiif.com

title: Planet Ice Project - Dudley Town Centre: Market Viability Analysis & Economic Impact Assessment
description: A new ice rink development has been proposed for Dudley town centre. The project includes a 2,000-seat ice rink, for which there is the aspiration for it to be the home stadium for a new professional ice hockey team, and a publicly accessible ice rink. The development will also include a 139-bed hotel, to support visitors to the rink that require overnight stays, and also the wider Dudley business and leisure visitor market.  This Market Viability Analysis and Economic Impact Assessment is being commissioned by the West Midlands Growth Company, developers Planet Ice and Dudley MBC.The requirement is for two separate, but interlinked, research and analysis reports, summarised below and detailed further in the following sections:a)	The Financial Case - provide market evidence for the overall projects and various schemes, i.e., the number of visitors and their spend potential. This will need to identify the market for the ice rink and the hotel, demonstrating the overall viability of project through a 10-year financial case to assess if the investment is financially viable. The financial case should include the annual revenues and costs, and cash flows. The revenue side need to be built on an agreed addressable market for the ice rink and hotel, a realistic sales forecast, and value based/competitive pricing as appropriate. The cost side of the business case needs to include capital investment, operational costs, management costs, financing costs and other relevant costs. A clear methodology be set out to agree the assumptions underpinning the financial case. The model should be in excel, unlocked, open, documented and all parties involved (DMBC, Planet Ice and WMGC) have full rights to use after the project.b)	Economic Impact Assessment – based on the details in the market assessment, to analyse the economic impact of the project at the Dudley Borough level. This will need to consider the direct, indirect and induced effects of the project, setting out the jobs created, the GVA impact and the wider benefits of the project.  Further detail on this is given later in this brief.

The existing main pitched roofs a cut timber with clay tiles, and identified on the tender drawings as Roof A and Roof B. The structure of Roof A has suffered from partial fire damage. The project is for the complete replacement of Roof A (including structure) and replacement of the roof coverings only to Roof B, and includes ancillary works to soffits, fascias, insulation and minor Building Services works to facilitate replacement, and associated temporary works.

description: Worcestershire Children First is establishing a Dynamic Purchasing System ("the DPS") for SEND Independent School Places and seeks applications from suitably experienced, qualified and appropriately accredited Suppliers who wish to pre-qualify for this Service.The DPS for SEND Independent school places has 7 categories/lots:  Lot 1 Communication and InteractionLot 2 Cognition and LearningLot 3 Social, Emotional and Mental HealthLot 4 Sensory and Physical NeedsLot 5 AutismLot 6 Complex/Profound Multiple Learning DisabilitiesLot 7 Post 16The DPS will run from 18th March 2024 to 31st March 2027, with an option to extend for up to 2 further years (1 year + a further 1 year) and in order to be able to tender for business with Worcestershire Children First, Suppliers must first be approved to join the categories within the DPS and then will be automatically notified of opportunities to quote for specific projects as they arise in each Category. title: HEA23047 Healthy Worcestershire Programme
description: The ’Healthy Worcestershire’ programme will contribute to addressing health inequalities, and show measurable improvements in levels of physical activity, fear of falling (by improving strength and balance), general wellbeing, and social connectedness. The service will also help to increase awareness of community safety issues such as doorstep crime, scams, and fraud by directly educating participants on how they can keep themselves safe. This programme will be an integrated community-based service that’s responsive to the needs of residents, which results in empowering communities to improve health and wellbeing. The core programme will offer exercise interventions designed to reduce the risk of falls and maintain independence, as well providing a broad range of health and wellbeing advice to participants either face to face, via telephone or digitally. If you wish to view the documents for this opportunity please click `Express Interest`.
